Authors: Peck L.S., Clarke A., Holmes L.J.
Title: Summer metabolism and seasonal changes in biochemical composition of the Antarctic brachiopod Liothyrella uva (Broderip, 1833)
Source title: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
Affiliations: British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Peck, L.S., British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Clarke, A., British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Holmes, L.J., British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: Oxygen consumption and ammonia excretion were measured in Liothyrella uva (Broderip, 1833) held in the laboratory under simulated summer conditions. The mean oxygen consumption of a 50 mg AFDW brachiopod was 0.205 μg-at. O · h -1 while the ammonia excreted was 0.022 μg-at. NH3-N · h -1. The exponents of the regressions relating these parameters to AFDW were not significantly different from each other and the common slope was 0.83. The rise in metabolism over previously published winter levels was 15-20%. The difference between simulated summer and winter conditions was the presence or absence of food. The rise in metabolism was seen in both oxygen consumption and ammonia excretion whilst the oxygen to nitrogen ratio remained virtually unchanged at 9.2 (9.3 in winter), showing that, as in winter conditions, protein was the main metabolic substrate. Oxygen consumption rates were around five times lower than those of temperate brachiopods, even after applying a Q10 temperature correction, and they were two to seven times lower than Antarctic bivalve and gastropod molluscs. An investigation of the biochemical components of field specimens showed strong seasonal variation in protein and carbohydrate, although carbohydrate levels were only as ≈5-10% of protein contents at any one time. There was no significant seasonal variation in lipids, although there was some evidence to suggest that they may be involved, with protein, in the gametogenic cycle. Shell tissues (the caeca) were identified as a site of nutrient storage and may be implicated in short-term storage of material for reproduction as well as the long-term storage of overwintering energy reserves. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Biochemical composition; Brachiopod; Excretion; Liothyrella; Respiration; Seasonal metabolism

Authors: Mauclaire G., Heninger M., Fenistein S., Wronka J., Marx R.
Title: Radiative relaxation of vibrationally excited ions
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Processes
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Mauclaire, G., Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Heninger, M., Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Fenistein, S., Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Wronka, J., Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Marx, R., Laboratoire de Physico Chimie des Rayonnements (Associated to the CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: A triple cell ICR spectrometer analogous to a three-stage mass spectrometer (MS/MS/MS) but capable of studying thermal energy collisions is described. The facility to store ions in a good vacuum allows the measurement of radiative lifetimes using a chemical reaction to probe the energy contents of the ions as a function of their storage time. Vibrational lifetimes have been measured for two diatomic ions in their electronic ground state: NO+ and HCl+. NO+ and NO have similar lifetimes, in very good agreement with calculated values. HCl+ (v = 1) has a lifetime ten times shorter than HCl (3 ± 1 ms compared with 29 ms), in fairly good agreement with the calculated value of 4.6 ms. This is the first experimental confirmation of the very short lifetimes predicted theoretically for diatomic hydride ions. Qualitative results have been obtained for the radiative lifetime of NH3+. The shape of the decay curves indicates the presence of long-lived (more than 300 ms) and short-lived (10-20 ms) states. © 1987.

Title: The role of vibrational excitation of molecular ions in collisions with neutrals
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Processes
Affiliations: Institüt für Ionenphysik der Universität Innsbruck, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Lindinger, W., Institüt für Ionenphysik der Universität Innsbruck, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria
Abstract: Selected ion flow drift tube techniques have recently been used to investigate the role of vibrational excitation of molecular ions in collisions with neutrals. A model by Ferguson explaining the quenching of vibrational ionic excitation via transient complex formation followed by vibrational predissociation is supported by a series of systematic data on O2+ (v) and NO+ (v) ions. The excitation and de-excitation of molecular ions in collisions with helium buffer gas atoms has been shown to be quite efficient at elevated E/N. The influence of kinetic and vibrational energy, respectively, on the reactivity of molecular ions can be spearated quantitatively for a variety of slow ion/molecule reactions. The inclusion of an octopole storage section at the exit of the ion source of a selected ion flow drift tube allows investigations of the nascent state distributions of ions produced via different ionic reactions. © 1987.

Title: Industrial applications of rare earths in fiber optics, luminescent solar concentrators and lasers
Affiliations: Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Reisfeld, R., Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Abstract: Luminescent solar concentrators which concentrate light from large plate surfaces to the plate's edges are promising devices for lowering the price of photovoltaic electricity. Plates based on neodymium and ytterbium doped glasses covered by thin glass layers incorporating organic dyes are promising materials for efficient luminescent solar concentrators. Flouride glasses incorporating rate earths are proposed as integrated systems for fiber optic communications in the visible and infrared parts of the spectrum. Such devices may be obtained from rare earths in flouride glasses in direct contact with undoped glass of the same composition without the light-emitting lanthanide. Storage of energy in the lowest quartet state of manganese(II) and transfer of energy to neodymium(III) provides another opportunity for improving the performance of lasers. New laser materials based on the combination of rare earths and organic dyes will also be discussed. © 1987.

Authors: Benga G., Pop V.I., Popescu O., Hodârnǎu A., Borza V., Presecan E.
Title: Effects of temperature on water diffusion in human erythrocytes and ghosts - nuclear magnetic resonance studies
Affiliations: Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Benga, G., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Pop, V.I., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Popescu, O., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Hodârnǎu, A., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Borza, V., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Presecan, E., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Medicine, Medical and Pharmaceutical Institute Cluj-Napoca, Cluj-Napoca, Romania
Abstract: The temperature-dependence of water diffusion across human erythrocyte membrane was studied on isolated erythrocytes and resealed ghosts by a doping nuclear magnetic resonance technique. The conclusions are the following: (1) The storage of suspended erythrocytes at 2 °C up to 24 h or at 37 °C for 30 min did not change the water exchange time significantly, even if Mn2+ was present in the medium. This indicates that no significant penetration of Mn2+ is taking place under such conditions. (2) In case of cells previously incubated at 37°C for longer than 30 min with concentrations of p-chloromercuribenzene sulfonate (PCMBS) greater than 0.5 mM, the water-exchange time gradually decreased if the cells were stored in the presence of Mn2+ for more than 10 min at 37°C. (3) When the arrhenius plot of the water-exchange time was calculated on the basis of measurements performed in such a way as to avoid a prolonged exposure of erythrocytes to Mn2+ no discontinuity occurred, regardless of the treatment with PCMBS. (4) No significant differences between erythrocytes and resealed ghosts regarding their permability and the activation energy of water diffusion (Ea,d) were noticed. The mean value of Ea,d obtained on erythrocytes from 35 donors was 24.5 kJ/mol. (5) The value of Ea,d increased after treatment with PCMBS, in parallel with the percentage inhibition of water diffusion. A mean value of 41.3 kJ/mol was obtained for Ea,d of erythrocytes incubated with 1 mM PCMBS for 60 min at 37°C and 28.3 kJ/mol for ghosts incubated with 0.1 mM PCMBS for 15 min, the value of inhibition being 46% and 21%, respectively. © 1987.
Author Keywords: (Human blood); Erythrocyte membrane; NMR; Water diffusion; Water exchange
Index Keywords: erythrocyte ghost; erythrocyte membrane; human; human cell; nuclear magnetic resonance; water diffusion; Arrhenius; 4-Chloromercuribenzenesulfonate; Cell Membrane Permeability; Diffusion; Erythrocyte Membrane; Erythrocytes; Humans; Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy; Manganese; Temperature; Water

Authors: Abachi S., Baringer P., Bylsma B.G., Debonte R., Koltick D., Low E.H., McIlwain R.L., Miller D.H., Ng C.R., Shibata E.I., Derrick M., Kooijman P., Loos J.S., Musgrave B., Price L.E., Repond J., Sugano K., Blockus D., Brabson B., Brom J.-M., Jung C., Ogren H., Paik H.W., Rust D.R., Akerlof C., Chapman J., Errede D., Ken M.T., Meyer D.I., Neal H.A., Nitz D., Thun R., Tschirhart R., Cork B.
Title: Charged K* production in e+e- annihilations at 29 GeV
Affiliations: Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States

Cork, B., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: We report a measurement of the charged K* (892) production in e+e- annihilations at 29 GeV center-of-mass energy. The 300 pb-1 data sample used for this analysis is obtained with the High Resolution Spectrometer at the SLAC storage ring PEP. The total mean multiplicity is measured to be 〈nK*±(892)〉=0.62±0.0 45±0.04 per hadronic event. Evidence is also given for the production of a charged K2* (1430) tensor meson. © 1987.

Title: Energy transduction by the photosynthetic reaction center complex from Rhodopseudomonas viridis
Affiliations: A.N. Belozersky Laboratory of Molecular Biology and Bioorganic Chemistry, Moscow State University, Moscow, 119899, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Skulachev, V.P., A.N. Belozersky Laboratory of Molecular Biology and Bioorganic Chemistry, Moscow State University, Moscow, 119899, Russian Federation
Abstract: Comparison of data of (i) the high-resolution X-ray analysis of the Rhodopseudomonas viridis reaction center complex and (ii) direct (with a voltmeter) measurement of charge displacement in the same complex is presented. It is revealed that 95% of the energy stored in the form of the membrane electric potential is due to electron and 5% to proton transfers. Five stages of the overall process were found to contribute to the light-induced membrane charging, namely electron transfers from excited bacteriochlorophyll dimer to bacteriopheophytin, from bacteriopheophytin to MQ, from heme c-559 to bacteriochlorophyll dimer, from heme c-556 to heme c-559 and H+ transfer from cytoplasmic water to the bound CoQ. The contribution of each stage to the energy storage depends upon the dielectric constant value in the respective part of the complex rather than upon the distance covered by the electron or proton. It appears to be higher, the deeper the redox groups involved are immersed into the membrane. © 1987.
Author Keywords: (Rps. viridis); Fast kinetics; Membrane potential; Reaction center complex

Authors: Sen A., McGowan J.W., Mitchell J.B.A.
Title: Production of low-vibrational-state H2+ ions for collision studies
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic and Molecular Physics
Affiliations: Dept. of Phys., Western Ontario Univ., London, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sen, A., Dept. of Phys., Western Ontario Univ., London, Ont., Canada; McGowan, J.W., Dept. of Phys., Western Ontario Univ., London, Ont., Canada; Mitchell, J.B.A., Dept. of Phys., Western Ontario Univ., London, Ont., Canada
Abstract: A storage ion source based on the principle of confinement of charged particles by inhomogeneous oscillatory electric fields has been built for the production of H2+ ion in low vibrational states. Using a gas mixture of H2 and rare gases (Ne and He) in the ion source at high pressure, higher vibrational states of H2+ ions have been effectively quenched by ion-molecule reactions and collisional deactivation. Collision-induced dissociation measurements of H2 + on He have been performed to determine the internal energy of the ions. With an H2+Ne mixture (1:5 ratio) in the source at 80 m Torr, the H2+ ions are found to be predominantly in upsilon =O and 1 states.

Title: Soft magnetic materials - 17 years after electron irradiation
Affiliations: Naval Surface Weapons Center, White Oak, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sery, R.S., Naval Surface Weapons Center, White Oak, MD, United States
Abstract: During the period 1963-1966 about 175 flat ring samples of Supermalloy, Unimag, Mumetal, 65 Ni-Fe, and pure iron were irradiated with electrons. Energies and integrated fluxes varied from 0.5 to 2.0 MeV and (0.2-1.0)×1017 e/cm2, respectively. Some samples were irradiated in the Earth's magnetic field and the rest were irradiated with applied circumferential fields of 0.22 Oe. Temperatures of irradiation varied from about 80 to 125°C for most samples. In the course of time most of the original samples were lost, discarded, damaged, or annealed. In 1983 the remaining 55 were retested to see what changes in magnetic properties may have occurred. The properties and characteristics checked included Hc,Br, and the magnetization curves and hysteresis loops. The main findings with respect to changes in properties after about 17 years of storage are the following: (1) The properties measured showed, at most, slight changes. (2) The small changes that did occur in Hc were consistent increases of up to 20% for some samples.

Authors: Kobayashi O., Sasagawa T., Obara M.
Title: KrF laser controlled diffuse discharge opening/closing switches using a photoelimination reaction
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kobayashi, O., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223, Japan; Sasagawa, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223, Japan; Obara, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223, Japan
Abstract: Optical control of a diffuse discharge can potentially be used to switch inductive energy storage systems at high repetition rates. A means of optical enhancement of the electron attachment process can hopefully be used as an optically controlled switch. Vinylchloride (C2H3Cl) photoeliminates a vibrationally rotationally excited HCl(v,J) which strongly attaches low-energy electrons. In our experiment, we observed the opening and closing of a diffuse discharge in a mixture of C2H3Cl/He (C2H3Cl:He=0.7:99.3%, total pressure 1.5 Torr) by KrF laser irradiation of 5.7 mJ/cm2 (20 ns full width at half-maximum). Under these conditions, a discharge current of 200 μA could be interrupted with a time constant of 100 μs. The discharge was again initiated by KrF laser irradiation. As a result, both discharge opening and closing by the laser irradiation were demonstrated.

Title: Implications for a short wavelength laser experiment based on a theory of quasi-channeling phenomenon for electrons
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Makowitz, H., Physics Department, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: The theory of electron and positron channeling and radiation production in crystals has been extended to macroscopic-scale systems. The new theory, named QCP theory (quasi-channeling phenomenon), examines macroscopic systems that exhibit periodicity along the axis of beam propagation, specifically, periodic electrostatic fields; the dimensions of the field periodicity (lz) are much greater than typical interatomic lattice spacing (lL), e.g., lz≫lL, but much smaller than a typical wiggler wavelength lw, e.g., lw≫lz. The feasibility of a laser based on this predicted new phenomenon is examined in this letter. Differences between the properties of the proposed quasi-channeling radiation and radiation produced by wigglers and free-electron lasers (FEL's) are discussed. System lengths a factor of 103 shorter than FEL's are expected, with favorable scaling for below 500 eV laser photon output energies. A 500-eV QCP laser system with a gain of 1 and a length of 1 m is predicted, based on extrapolations of existing storage-ring technology.

Authors: Wang F., Schwartzman A., Fahrenbruch A.L., Sinclair R., Bube R.H., Stahle C.M.
Title: Kinetics and oxide composition for thermal oxidation of cadmium telluride
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, F., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Schwartzman, A., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Fahrenbruch, A.L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Sinclair, R., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Bube, R.H., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Stahle, C.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Thermal oxidation of single-crystal p-type CdTe has been carried out in dry and wet oxygen. The thickness of the oxide varies as the square root of oxidation time, implying a diffusion controlled process. The activation energy for thermal oxidation is 1.2 eV. Examination of the oxide by Auger electron spectroscopy, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy shows that the composition of thick layers is CdTeO3; thin layers less than 100 Å thick may differ slightly in composition. An oxygen gradient is detected in as-grown thin oxides, but with storage in air at room temperature the oxygen gradient disappears. Values of chemical shift of the x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy peaks for the cadmium-tellurium-oxygen ternary system are clarified.

Title: Achromatic storage ring for free-electron lasers
Affiliations: Stanford Photon Research Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cutolo, A., Stanford Photon Research Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Madey, J.M.J., Stanford Photon Research Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: We discuss the possibility of taking advantage on achromatic magnetic mirrors (α magnets) to construct a storage ring for free-electron lasers, where the electron trajectories are energy independent in the straight sections. This property might be efficiently used to noticeably reduce the momentum compaction.

Title: Beam extraction with electron pick-up
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik A Atomic Nuclei
Affiliations: Institut für Kernphysik, Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Poth, H., Institut für Kernphysik, Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: It is shown that electron pick-up from a cooling electron beam can be used to extract an ion beam from a storage ring. The technique is described and extraction times are estimated. A few applications for medium-energy ion storage rings are given. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Relaxation in systems with exponential or Gaussian distributions of activation energies
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC 27514, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacDonald, J.R., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC 27514, United States
Abstract: New expressions are presented, simplified, and discussed for the small-signal-frequency response of systems involving distributions of activation energies with either exponential or Gaussian probability densities. The results involve the possibility of separate but related thermal activation of energy-storage and energy-loss processes, and apply to the response of both dielectric and conductive systems. Response with a Gaussian distribution of activation energies (GDAE) may be either symmetric or asymmetric in log frequency, and typical GDAE responses are compared with those associated with several exponential distributions of activation-energy (EDAE) models, using complex nonlinear least-squares fitting. The GDAE model does not lead to the frequently observed fractional-exponent power-law response in time or frequency as does the EDAE; thus, the GDAE cannot fit any EDAE response well which involves an appreciable range of such behavior, but it is found that, conversely, the general EDAE model can often fit a GDAE response very well over a wide frequency range. Recent (KBr)0.5(KCN)0.5 dielectric data covering a range from T=13.7 to 34.7 K are analyzed with the Cole-Cole, EDAE, and GDAE models, and the GDAE is found to yield the best overall fits. The results of the GDAE fits are analyzed in detail to illustrate the application of the GDAE model to real data. Contrary to the conclusions of an earlier analysis of the same data using an idealized, symmetric, and approximate GDAE model, we find that much of the data are better fit by a somewhat asymmetric, exact GDAE model which may involve a temperature-independent, finite-width Gaussian probability density. The present analysis suggests an alternative to the earlier results and suggestions that the width of the probability-density distribution increases with decreasing temperature and that the activation energies or barrier heights themselves depend linearly on temperature. The present data fit yield estimates of the lower limit of the temperature independent distribution of activation energies E0 and of the more or less central activation energy E1, but only set a lower limit for the value of the maximum activation energy of the distribution, E ∞. There is some evidence from the fitting that there may be a glasslike transition below about 4 K, but other effects outside the GDAE model may intervene before that temperature region is reached.

Title: APPLIED RESEARCH ON COMPONENTS FOR Na/S BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kinoshita, K., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; McLarnon, F.R., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: The Na/S battery is one of the energy storage systems under development by the Office of Energy Storage and Distribution, United States Department of Energy. The Technology Base Research (TBR) Project, which is managed by Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, provides applied research on Na/S battery components to support this development program. An overview of the various research efforts in the TBR Project which are relevant to the development of Na/S batteries, for applications in electric vehicles and load-leveling, is presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Research; ELECTROLYTES; ENERGY STORAGE; RESEARCH PROJECT REVIEW; SODIUM SULFUR BATTERIES; TBR PROJECT; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Birnbreier Hermann, Fischer Wilfried, Benninger Gary N.
Title: SODIUM/SULPHUR BATTERY FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLE PROPULSION.
Affiliations: Brown, Boveri & Cie AG,, Heidelberg, West Ger, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG, Heidelberg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Birnbreier, Hermann, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG,, Heidelberg, West Ger, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG, Heidelberg, West Ger; Fischer, Wilfried, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG,, Heidelberg, West Ger, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG, Heidelberg, West Ger; Benninger, Gary N., Brown, Boveri & Cie AG,, Heidelberg, West Ger, Brown, Boveri & Cie AG, Heidelberg, West Ger
Abstract: A prototype sodium/sulphur battery for electric vehicle propulsion is presented. The battery energy density for a 2 hr discharge is 100 Wh/kg and the power density at 2/3 OCV is 165 W/kg. This performance has been projected from the energy and power densities of experimental batteries. The performance data of the prototype battery are used to calculate the drive characteristics of an electric Chrysler T 115 Minivan. These characteristics are compared with those of a T 115 propelled with both lead acid and experimental sodium/sulphur batteries.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Electric Energy; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ADVANCED BATTERY SYSTEMS; SODIUM/SULPHUR BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Betz G., Fiechter S., Tributsch H.
Title: Photon energy conversion and storage with a light-driven insertion reaction
Affiliations: Hahn-Meitner-Institut, Glienickerstr. 100, 1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Betz, G., Hahn-Meitner-Institut, Glienickerstr. 100, 1000 Berlin 39, Germany; Fiechter, S., Hahn-Meitner-Institut, Glienickerstr. 100, 1000 Berlin 39, Germany; Tributsch, H., Hahn-Meitner-Institut, Glienickerstr. 100, 1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Abstract: Experiments are presented that demonstrate the possibility of photon energy conversion with a photoelectrochemical insertion reaction. The reaction is performed with the Cu+-conducting semiconductor copper thiophosphate (Cu3PS4; band-gap energy, Eg=2.3 eV) as the photocathode. The Cu3PS4 crystals were grown by chemical vapor transport with halogen as the transport agent. The thermodynamics of the photoinsertion reaction of copper into Cu3PS4 electrodes was investigated, determining a composition-voltage diagram in the dark and under illumination. In photoelectrochemical cells the kinetics of the photoinsertion reaction was studied. Energy-converting photoinsertion cells could be realized with suitable counterelectrodes. The principles of energy-storing photoinsertion cells are discussed together with efficiency limitations and electrode arrangements that may overcome these difficulties.

Title: High-forward-voltage junction capacitance including effects of excess carrier storage in electron-hole plasma
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Central Florida, P. O. Box 25000, Orlando, FL 32816, United States; Electrical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liou, J.J., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Central Florida, P. O. Box 25000, Orlando, FL 32816, United States; Lindholm, F.A., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: A previous quasistatic junction space-charge region capacitance model is improved by including the Fermi statistics and energy band-gap narrowing that occurs in electron-hole plasmas. The model is applicable for junctions under large forward voltages. A factor of 2-4 is predicted when the present capacitance model is compared with the previous capacitance model.

Authors: Hoffmann H., Hipp E., Sedlmeier U.A.
Title: Aerobic and anaerobic metabolism of the freshwater oligochaete Tubifex sp.
Affiliations: Allgemeine Zoologie (Biologie I), Universität Ulm, Ulm, D-7900, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hoffmann, H., Allgemeine Zoologie (Biologie I), Universität Ulm, Ulm, D-7900, Germany; Hipp, E., Allgemeine Zoologie (Biologie I), Universität Ulm, Ulm, D-7900, Germany; Sedlmeier, U.A., Allgemeine Zoologie (Biologie I), Universität Ulm, Ulm, D-7900, Germany
Abstract: The freshwater oligochaete Tubifex shows several mechanisms of metabolic adaptations, enabling the worms to occupy saprobial habitats of extremely variable oxygen content. Under normoxic conditions the metabolism of the worms is mainly aerobic with a respiratory ratio of 0.7. Under hypoxic conditions, metabolism of energy sources via aerobic and anaerobic pathways is observed. During complete anoxia acetate and propionate are the main products of glycogen degradation and they are excreted in constant rates into the water. A retransfer of the worms to aerobic conditions enables them to regain aerobic metabolic state within about 60 min. In two Tubifex habitats, which we have characterized, concentrations of dissolved organic material (DOM) were low in the surface water, but high in the interstitial water from sediments. The short-chain fatty acids acetate and propionate reached concentrations up to 1 mmole/liter. Employing radioisotope techniques, we demonstrated that Tubifex can achieve an integumentary uptake of acetate and propionate from artificial tap water at naturally occurring concentrations of 5 to 1000 μM. Levels of uptake (600 to 800 nmoles/g wwt.hr) and transport characteristics are very similar to those of marine invertebrates associated with detritus rich sediments. The uptake is susceptible to inhibition by structurally analogous compounds and to metabolic inhibition. Furthermore, DOM uptake in Tubifex is susceptible to inhibition by oxygen depletion, ouabain and Na+-depletion. The results may suggest that a carrier system for DOM transport exists in the integument of the worms. The uptake system is highly specific for aliphatic C2 and C3 carboxylic acids. The absorbed volatile fatty acids are rapidly metabolized. Only 15 min after absorption, a considerable amount of radioactivity is present in the glycogen storage of the animals. Depending on the substrate concentration assumed to be available for uptake, up to 40 per cent of the oxidative requirement of the worms may be attained by using dissolved organic material from the interstitial water of their habitat. Author Keywords: anaerobiosis; dissolved organic material; freshwater oligochaete; metabolism

Title: A model for laser marking of thin organic data storage layers by short intense pulses
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hill, D.A., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Soong, D.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: A mathematical model is developed to describe the pit formation process in thin (∼0.1 μm) organic layers induced by short (<100 ns), intense laser pulses. The basic premise is an ablation-driven viscous flow, in which the reactive pressure gradient due to polymer decomposition causes fluid motion. Contrary to the case of thick layers (∼1 μm) and long (∼500 ns), weak pulses, here surface tension gradients are shown to be too small to promote material flow in the short time span of laser exposure. The derived closed-form expressions for temperature profile and pit contour allow expedient calculation of threshold energies and prediction of functional relationships among imposed (e.g., pulse energy and width) and measured (e.g., pit width) system variables. Model predictions compare favorably with experimental observations of such interrelations.

Authors: Gil K.M., Askanazi J., Elwyn D.H., Gump F.E., Kinney J.M.
Title: Energy expenditure after infusion of glucose-based total parenteral nutrition
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism
Affiliations: Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gil, K.M., Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Askanazi, J., Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Elwyn, D.H., Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Gump, F.E., Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Kinney, J.M., Department of Anesthesiology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States
Abstract: Resting energy expenditure (REE), carbohydrate balance, and lipogenesis were calculated after administration of glucose-based total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to determine whether the thermic effect of glucose is equal to the energy cost of storing the glucose. Estimated cost of storage as glycogen (5.3%) and fat (19%) was compared with measured increases in REE. Patients with malnutrition received 5% dextrose in water and 6 days of TPN with a low (1.2 times REE, group 1) or high (2.0 times REE, group 2) level of glucose intake. Increases in REE by day 6 were 10% (group 1) and 28% (group 2). The theoretical cost of glucose storage as glycogen and fat accounted for ~40% of the measured increase in REE in patients in group 2. The thermic effect of TPN (derived from patients in group 1) accounted for most of the balance. The majority of the thermic effect of high levels of glucose infused with TPN can by explained on the basis of the thermic effect of TPN and glucose storage.
Index Keywords: glucose; carbohydrate metabolism; clinical article; controlled study; energy expenditure; human; intravenous drug administration; intravenous feeding; lipogenesis; preliminary communication; therapy; thermogenesis; total parenteral nutrition; Body Temperature; Carbohydrates; Energy Metabolism; Glucose; Human; Lipids; Parenteral Nutrition, Total; Respiration; Rest; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: Body composition, food intake, and brown fat thermogenesis in pregnant Djungarian hamsters
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Regulatory Integrative and Comparative Physiology
Affiliations: Division of Neuroscience and Behavior, Department of Psychology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, J.E., Division of Neuroscience and Behavior, Department of Psychology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; Wade, G.N., Division of Neuroscience and Behavior, Department of Psychology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Abstract: Strategies for balancing energy storage and expenditure during pregnancy were examined in the Djungarian hamster. In expt 1, pregnant hamsters lost nearly 50% of their body lipid stores, even though they showed significant increases in body weight and food intake during the latter half of pregnancy. The increase in body weight was accounted for by the growth of the uteri, fetuses, and placentas. The water and fat-free dry contents of the maternal carcasses did not differ from those of the unmated controls. In expt 2, brown fat cytochrome-c oxidase activity (mitochondrial content) was significantly lower in the late- but not early-pregnancy females relative to the nonpregnant controls. Specific GDP-binding levels did not differ significantly among these groups. Thus an overall decrease in total thermogenic activity in brown fat would be expected during late pregnancy. The loss of carcass lipid, despite decreased brown fat thermogenesis and increased food intake, suggests that substantial increases in energy expenditure occur in pregnant females that are not related to heat production in brown fat. The present results are not consistent with traditional models of energy balance during pregnancy. Some of the inconsistencies may be related to differences between hoarding and nonhoarding families of rodents, whereas others may be due to the fact that the traditional model is based on a possibly exceptional species, the laboratory rat.
Index Keywords: animal experiment; brown adipose tissue; controlled study; diagnosis; food intake; hamster; nonhuman; pregnancy; preliminary communication; subcutaneous tissue; thermogenesis; Adipose Tissue; Animal; Body Composition; Body Temperature Regulation; Body Water; Brown Fat; Cytochrome-c Oxidase; Eating; Female; Hamsters; Labor, Obstetric; Lipids; Pregnancy; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: THEORETICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL INVESTIGATION OF HEAT TRANSFER PERFORMANCE OF ROTARY REGENERATIVE HEAT EXCHANGER.

Authors with affiliations: Ren, Zepei, Tsinghua Univ, Beijing, China, Tsinghua Univ, Beijing, China; Wang, Siyong, Tsinghua Univ, Beijing, China, Tsinghua Univ, Beijing, China
Abstract: In this paper, a theoretical analysis and calculation of the transient and periodic steady-state temperature distribution of the rotor material and fluids in rotary regenerator are reported. The transient temperature distribution of the fluids was measured in a test regenerator, and the results obtained by the numerical method agree with those of the experimental measurement. The effect of longitudinal heat conduction of solid matrix, temperature dependence of the thermal properties of the fluids and the effect of the heat storage of fluids on regenerator performance are discussed and presented graphically. In addition, the mathematical model presented in this paper is completely general; it provides a theoretical basis for the optimum designing of this type of regenerator.

Abstract: For the simultaneous control of real and reactive power in superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES), an asymmetrically controlled six-pulse converter has been introduced instead of the conventional twelve-pulse converter. Effectiveness of the proposed method has been proved experimentally using a 25-kJ SMES.

Authors: Davies T.S., Jefferson C.M., Mayer R.M., Somerville W.M.
Title: APPLICATION OF ENERGY STORAGE IN WIND ENERGY CONVERSION.
Affiliations: Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S., Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl; Jefferson, C.M., Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl; Mayer, R.M., Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl; Somerville, W.M., Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl
Abstract: A problem which occurs in wind energy conversion is the mismatch between supply and demand, which tend to vary independently. This problem is particularly acute in stand-alone systems. In grid connected systems it places restrictions on the proportion of wind power which can be connected or predictates the point of coupling. This paper shows that the problem can be overcome by the incorporation of dynamic energy storage and a kinetic energy storage system is demonstrated.

Title: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN FOR ABOVE-KNEE PROSTHESIS MADE IN COMPOSITE.
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can, Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Terrisse, J.P., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can, Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can; Drouin, G., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can, Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can; Levesque, C., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can, Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Que, Can
Abstract: The authors describe computer-aided design techniques intended to ease the design of above-knee prostheses. The intent is to allow the prosthesist to make his own design using this computer model. The first part of the project is to replace the metallic tube by a composite material which can increase the flexibility of this kind of prosthesis. The increased flexibility allows for storage of energy within the structure. At heel-strike energy should be absorbed and realsed at an appropriate time during the gate cycle. In doing so the energy consumption of the amputee will be decreased. It is shown that the composite material is well suited for these applications.

Title: ACCELERATOR MAGNET POWER SUPPLY USING STORAGE GENERATOR.
Affiliations: EBASCO Service Inc, USA, EBASCO Service Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: Karady, G., EBASCO Service Inc, USA, EBASCO Service Inc, USA; Thiessen, H.A., EBASCO Service Inc, USA, EBASCO Service Inc, USA
Abstract: A study investigating the feasibility of a large, 60-GeV accelerator is discussed. The conceptual design of the magnet power supply (PS) and energy storage system is presented, and the resulting system is described. The main ring magnets will be supplied by six high-voltage and two low-voltage power supplies which will drive a trapezoidal-shaped current wave through the magnets. The peak current is 10 kA and the repetition frequency is 3. 3 Hz. During the acceleration period the current is increased from 1040 A to 10,000 A within 50 ms, which requires a loop voltage of 120 kV and a peak power of 1250 MW. During the reset period, the PS operates as an inverter with a peak power of -1250 MW. For the reduction of DC ripple, the power supplies will operate in a 24-pulse mode.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SUPPLIES TO APPARATUS - Design; MAIN RING MAGNETS; STORAGE GENERATOR; TRAPEZOIDAL-SHAPED CURRENT WAVE; ACCELERATORS

Title: NEW DEVELOPMENTS IN ICE STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Wortman, A.D.
Abstract: The use of ice storage in air conditioning systems is now a widely accepted and proven concept. Ice storage is becoming the basic system of design for office buildings in many areas such as Baltimore, Washington, Florida, and Chicago. This article discusses why so many air conditioning projects are now using ice storage systems. Financial incentives are reviewed.

Abstract: Sandia National Laboratories is the lead center for the United States Department of Energy sponsored development and engineering of exploratory secondary battery technologies. The Sandia project addresses sodium/sulfur battery development by means of cost-sharing contracts with industrial participants, evaluation of prototype cells and batteries, and supporting research through inhouse analysis and modeling programs.

Title: NONLINEAR BEHAVIOR OF THE LONGITUDINAL MODES OF THE COASTING BEAM IN A STORAGE RING.

Authors with affiliations: Bogacz, S.A., Fermilab, Batavia, IL, USA, Fermilab, Batavia, IL, USA; Ng, K.Y., Fermilab, Batavia, IL, USA, Fermilab, Batavia, IL, USA
Abstract: A simple nonlinear model of a coasting beam coupled to a sharp storage ring impedance is studied in the framework of the Vlasov equation. In the case of a Gaussian beam this nonperturbative formalism simplifies to a pair of equations of motion which together with the dispersion relation fully describe nonlinear saturation of the initially unstable coherent mode. This in turn, provides a stabilizing mechanism (via Landau damping) for the overall distribution function. Some predictions about the energy overshoot are made.

Title: MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF THE PROCESS OF ACCUMULATION OF THERMAL ENERGY IN RECYCLED WATER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Soviet journal of water chemistry and technology
Authors with affiliations: But, G.S.
Abstract: On the basis of the law of conservation of energy a mathematical model is developed of the process of accumulation of thermal energy in recycled water systems. Two regimes of the process of heat accumulation are considered: nonstationary and equilibrium. Variables are determined by means of which one can control the process of stabilization of the water system temperature. It is shown that the process of accumulation of thermal energy always gradually enters an equilibrium regime.

Title: MEASUREMENT OF SEU THRESHOLDS AND CROSS SECTIONS AT FIXED INCIDENCE ANGLES.
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Criswell, Thomas L., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Oberg, Dennis L., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Wert, Jerry L., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Measel, Paul R., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Wilson, W.E., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Current SEU (single-event upset) testing and analysis techniques have as basic assumptions that the charge deposited at a junction depends linearly on the linear energy transfer (LET) of the ion and the path length of the ion through an imagined parallelpiped that represents the depletion region. These assumptions were examined for two bipolar parts, AMD 27LS00 and Fairchild 93L422, by irradiating at fixed angles while varying the LET of two ion species. It was found that the 27LS00 shows a pronounced ion-species dependence, and may show a deviation of deposited charge from the usual inverse-cosine times a fixed depletion depth, while the 93L422 exhibited the expected inverse-cosine dependence and no ion-species dependence.

Abstract: The heat transfer characteristics of the chemical thermal storage system based on decomposition reactions of the inorganic hydroxides Mg(OH)//2 and Ca(OH)//2 are carried out numerically and experimentally to investigate the configuration effects on storage performance. Experimental results show that the change in the temperature distribution and interface location of a fin-equipped packed bed can be validly simulated by a numerical model. In addition, the suitable configuration for high performance storage is found to be 0. 4-0. 6 cal/cm**2 - sec of power input, 0. 03-0. 04 cm of fin thickness, 0. 05-0. 1 cm of bottom plate thickness, 20-30 cm**3/cm of packed capacity, and the ratio of fin height to interval up to 10-12.

Title: MICROCOMPUTER STATION DATA BASE ORGANIZATION FOR ACCOUNTING MEASUREMENT OF ELECTRICAL ENERGY CONSUMPTION.
Affiliations: Mihajlo Pupin Inst, Belgrade, Yugosl, Mihajlo Pupin Inst, Belgrade, Yugosl
Authors with affiliations: Pravdic, Miodrag, Mihajlo Pupin Inst, Belgrade, Yugosl, Mihajlo Pupin Inst, Belgrade, Yugosl
Abstract: A microcomputer station for acquisition and recording of pulse data acquired from the electrical energy meters, intended for metering and billing purposes, is presented. The station concept allows its efficient use in different metering system configurations, regardless of the number of measuring points. Within the metering system it can work either as an autonomous unit or as a telemetering system outstation, performing numerous functions simultaneously. A function table in the EEPROM memory provides easy and quick reconfiguration of the station, either on site or remotely from the central station. The organization of the database as well as a concept of real and derived measuring points results in high flexibility of the station regarding the selection of data to be logged, the RAM-buffer size for data logging, and the transmission of these data to other memory media and devices.

Abstract: The power-conditioning circuits used to interface a diurnal load-leveling superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) coil to a power utility network can be 6-multiple pulse-gate-controlled silicon-controlled-rectifier (SCR) or gate-turn-off (GTO) device bridges. One desirable characteristic of the power-conditioning circuits is that they should be able to provide independent real and reactive power control. A possible solution to this requirement is to use combinations of SCR and GTO bridges. A GTO bridge circuit has been proposed for this purpose. For fast online feedback control of real and reactive power flow of SMES, a rapid digital technique has been developed to measure the real and reactive power flow.

Authors with affiliations: Fukusako, S., Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Jpn, Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Jpn
Abstract: A review work concerning the fundamental aspects of analytical or numerical methods applied to freezing and melting heat-transfer problems has been performed. An attempt is first made to demonstrate the original features of the method, which have been developed by previous investigators up to the present, by a common heat-conduction problem with change of phase and to give an outline of their modifications to more complicated systems, respectively. Some of the differences between the mathematical models and the actually observed water-freezing or ice-melting phenomena are next discussed in detail. An additional attention is focused on the freezing or melting problem with respect to phase change medium which has recently attracted a great deal of interest because of its relevance to phase-change thermal energy storage systems.

Abstract: Recent two-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) calculations have indicated that the use of a more restrictive outflow structure on a SHIVA Star driven plasma flow switch would increase current delivery to an implosion load by a factor of two. This approach has been investigated experimentally for the SHIVA Star, a 1313- mu F, 120-kV capacitive storage device capable of storing a maximum of 9. 4-MJ electrical energy. The experimental setup and results are reported. The data indicate greater than 90% current delivery from the gun muzzle to just outside the initial position implosion foil and 70-80% current delivery from the gun muzzle to the partially imploded foil.

Abstract: As part of an overall effort to advance the technology of nickel-hydrogen batteries for low earth orbit (LEO) applications, advanced designs for individual pressure vessel (IPV) nickel-hydrogen cells have been conceived. The effect of these oxygen recombination methods on the cell temperature profiles is examined.

Authors: Yamanaka Toshiaki, Hashimoto Naotaka, Kawamoto Yoshifumi, Sakai Yoshio, Honjo Shigeru, Minato Osamu
Title: FOLDED RESISTOR AND CAPACITOR (FRC) STATIC MEMORY CELL WITH TRIPLE POLY-SI STRUCTURES.
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - Symposium on VLSI Technology
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Yamanaka, Toshiaki, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn; Hashimoto, Naotaka, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn; Kawamoto, Yoshifumi, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn; Sakai, Yoshio, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn; Honjo, Shigeru, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn; Minato, Osamu, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Kokubunji, Jpn
Abstract: A folded resistor and capacitor (FRC) memory cell has been developed. The features of the cell are highly resistive poly loads with folded poly structures to achieve ultralow standby power and stacked capacitors added to the storage nodes to suppress soft errors. A description is given of the FRC memory cell structures and the characteristics of folded poly loads and stacked capacitors fabricated by a submicrometer CMOS process.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; RESISTORS; FOLDED RESISTOR/CAPACITOR (FRC); FRC MEMORY CELL; TRIPLE POLY-SILICON STRUCTURES; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Authors: Bradhurst D.H., Heuer P.M., Calka A., Stewart A.M.
Title: HYDROGEN ABSORPTION BY AMORPHOUS La//8//0Au//2//0 ALLOY.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Menai, Aust, CSIRO, Menai, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Bradhurst, D.H., CSIRO, Menai, Aust, CSIRO, Menai, Aust; Heuer, P.M., CSIRO, Menai, Aust, CSIRO, Menai, Aust; Calka, A., CSIRO, Menai, Aust, CSIRO, Menai, Aust; Stewart, A.M., CSIRO, Menai, Aust, CSIRO, Menai, Aust
Abstract: A number of amorphous and crystalline alloys were prepared and their hydrogen absorption characteristics evaluated with the objective of determining their suitability as hydrogen storage alloys. The alloys were chosen on the basis of their likely hydride-forming ability, and the ease with which they could be prepared in the glassy or amorphous state. Initial results, presented here, were obtained on an alloy of lanthanum and gold (La//8//0Au//2//0) which was known to form an amorphous phase. Repeated pressure cycling between 3. 5 MPa and 0. 4 Pa, combined with gentle heating ( less than 60 degree C) over several days, resulted in the development of a reversible hydrogen capacity at room temperature of 0. 89 wt% at 22. 5 degree C corresponding to the formula LaH//1//. //5//9Au//0//. //2//5 and a hydrogen to metal atom (H/M) ratio of 1. 28. The amorphous La//8//0Au//2//0 alloy has a larger hydrogen capacity than the corresponding crystallized form.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN - Absorption; HYDROGEN FUELS; LANTHANUM AND ALLOYS - Amorphous; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN STORAGE ALLOYS; STORAGE OF GASEOUS HYDROGEN; LANTHANUM GOLD ALLOYS

Title: OLIVE - A SMALL, LOW-ASPECT RATIO TOKAMAK.
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Crowley, T.P., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA
Abstract: The design study of a low-aperture ratio tokamak is described. The device uses the existing facilities at the RPI Plasma Dynamic Laboratory as much as possible. The plasma parameters that can be achieved, the coil structure, and energy storage requirements are described. The focus is on the design of the ohmic heating coil and the toroidal magnetic field.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC COILS; LOW-ASPECT RATIO TOKAMAK; OHMIC HEATING COIL; OLIVE TOKAMAK DEVICE; TOKAMAK DEVICES

Authors: McGarity A.E., Kirkpatrick D.L., Norford L.K.
Title: DESIGN AND OPERATION OF AN ICE POND FOR COOLING A LARGE COMMERCIAL OFFICE BUILDING.
Affiliations: Princeton Univ, USA, Princeton Univ, USA
Authors with affiliations: McGarity, A.E., Princeton Univ, USA, Princeton Univ, USA; Kirkpatrick, D.L., Princeton Univ, USA, Princeton Univ, USA; Norford, L.K., Princeton Univ, USA, Princeton Univ, USA
Abstract: A large-scale seasonal ice storage cooling system using an ice pond has been designed, built, and operated at a commercial office building complex in Princeton, NJ. Ice is produced as artificial snow during winter using ski-slope snow machines and naturally cold outside air. During the cooling season, cold melt water is circulated through the cooling system of a 130,000 ft**2 (12,000 m**2) three-floor office building. The design is discussed and data from the first full year of operation are presented. The annual coefficient of performance is 10, based on total cooling energy delivered and total electricity consumed by snow machines in the winter and by circulating pumps in the summer.
Index Keywords: ICE - Manufacture; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Cooling Water; ARTIFICIAL SNOW; COMMERCIAL OFFICE BUILDING; ICE POND; SEASONAL ICE STORAGE; SKI-SLOPE SNOW MACHINES; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: RESULTS FROM OPERATION OF A LARGE MEMBRANE STRATIFIED COOL STORAGE SYSTEM WITH HEAT RECOVERY.
Affiliations: Dallas Power & Light Co, Dallas,, TX, USA, Dallas Power & Light Co, Dallas, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tackett, R.K., Dallas Power & Light Co, Dallas,, TX, USA, Dallas Power & Light Co, Dallas, TX, USA
Abstract: A large thermal storage system, with membrane separation, stores chilled water to limit daytime chiller use, and it stores heated water produced by heat recovery chillers to reduce winter energy consumption. Design information is presented that describes how the storage volume was optimized and how heat recovery was integrated. Construction costs and electrical savings are also documented. Operational experience is reviewed to emphasize pertinent design considerations that affect storage capacity. The thermal storage system has reduced the electric utility costs by more than one-quarter million dollars per year.
Index Keywords: AIR - Cooling; COOLING WATER - Storage; MEMBRANES - Applications; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; TANKS - Performance; CHILLED WATER; CHILLER; HEAT RECOVERY; THERMAL STORAGE; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: OFFICE BUILDING CHILLED WATER STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Albert C. Martin & Associates,, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Albert C. Martin & Associates, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Okajima, T., Albert C. Martin & Associates,, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Albert C. Martin & Associates, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: A chilled water storage system, using the 'Empty Tank Concept,' was used for a 386,000 square feet (35,871 square meter) office building in downtown Los Angeles to reduce the operating energy cost by not operating the major cooling plant equipment during on-peak hours which run from 11 am to 7 pm on weekdays. The paper shows the equipment and piping arrangement, as well as a typical hot day storage system operation. The cooling plant operates satisfactorily.
Index Keywords: AIR - Cooling; COOLING WATER - Storage; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; TANKS - Performance; CHILLED WATER; COOLING PLANTS; EMPTY TANK CONCEPT; OPERATING ENERGY COST; AIR CONDITIONING

Authors: Daud T., Moopenn A., Lamb J.L., Ramesham R., Thakoor A.P.
Title: NEURAL NETWORK BASED FEED-FOWARD HIGH DENSITY ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY.
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Daud, T., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Moopenn, A., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Lamb, J.L., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Ramesham, R., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Thakoor, A.P., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: A thin-film approach to neural-network-based high-density associative memory is described. The information is stored locally in a memory matrix of passive, nonvolatile, binary connection elements with the potential to achieve a storage density of 10**9 b/cm**2. Microswitches based on memory switching in thin-film hydrogenated amorphous silicon, and alternatively in manganese oxide, have been used as programmable read-only memory (PROM) elements. Low-energy switching has been ascertained in both these materials. Fabrication and testing of the memory matrix is described. High-speed associative recall approaching 10**7 b/s and high storage capacity in such a connection-matrix memory system is also described.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Fabrication; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Neural Nets; FEED-FORWARD ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY; HIGH DENSITY ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY; NEURAL NETWORK-BASED MEMORY; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Authors: Tatchyn Roman, Csonka Paul, Toor Arthur
Title: MICROPOLE UNDULATORS IN ACCELERATOR AND STORAGE RING TECHNOLOGY.
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, Roman, Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Csonka, Paul, Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Toor, Arthur, Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: A general overview of the properties of micropole undulators as insertion devices for both accelerators and synchrotron storage rings is given. Comparisons with long-period devices are drawn on the basis of a coherence length/output power parameter defined for the purpose of this study. It is shown that micropole insertion devices, particularly undulators, have the potential for transforming conventional accelerator and synchrotron radiation technology. Some novel physical experiments, made possible by the availability of such devices, are mentioned.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Magnets; OPTIMIZATION; COHERENCE LENGTH/OUTPUT POWER PARAMETER; COHERENCE/MACHINE ENERGY PLOTS; MICROPOLE UNDULATORS AS INSERTION DEVICES; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON
