Abstract: An accelerator facility designed to provide continuous intense polarized beams of 2-4-GeV electrons and gamma-quanta with low emittance and energy spread is described. The design is based on the upgrading of the 2-GeV Kharkov electron linac (ELA) and the construction of a stretcher ring (SR) at its termination. General characteristics of the ELA-SR complex are reported, along with the results of numerical computer simulation of a slow beam extraction at the third-order resonance of horizontal free oscillations.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, LINEAR - Beam Injection; ACCELERATING-STORAGE COMPLEX; CW ELECTRON ACCELERATOR; STRETCHER RING; ACCELERATORS

Title: BEAM DIAGNOSTICS AND CONTROL FOR SLC.
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ross, M.C., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: Construction of the Stanford Linear Collider (SLC) has posed some new problems in beam diagnostic device design. Typical beam sizes are small when compared with conventional storage rings, orbit tolerances are tighter, and the pulsed nature of the machine means that signal-to-noise enhancement by averaging is not always possible. Thus the diagnostic must have high resolution, high absolute accuracy, and must deliver data from a single pulse. In practice the required performance level depends on the function and dynamics of a given region in the collider. The author reviews the major beam-diagnostic systems and discusses the global data-acquisition schemes.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; ELECTRON BEAMS - Measurements; PLASMAS - Diagnostics; BEAM DIAGNOSTICS; EMITTANCE MEASUREMENT; ENERGY SPREAD MONITOR; PHASE SPACE MEASUREMENTS; STANFORD LINEAR COLLIDER (SLC); ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Title: ION SYNCHROTRONS AND STORAGE RINGS FOR NUCLEAR AND ATOMIC PHYSICS.
Affiliations: Indiana Univ, Bloomington, IN, USA, Indiana Univ, Bloomington, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pollack, Robert E., Indiana Univ, Bloomington, IN, USA, Indiana Univ, Bloomington, IN, USA
Abstract: Within the past decade, a number of laboratories have embarked on construction projects having in common the application of synchrotron and/or storage-ring technology to research in atomic and nuclear physics. The designs span a wide range of ion species and energies. Most of these projects plan to use stochastic cooling and/or electron-beam cooling techniques. The author summarizes present understanding of the likely behavior of these devices and reviews pertinent design features. Some examples of the experimental applications that appear well-suited to the properties of these rings are described.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON; IONS - Acceleration; PHYSICS - Nuclear; ELECTRON-BEAM COOLING TECHNIQUES; ION SYNCHROTRONS; LEAR PROJECT; STOCHASTIC COOLING; STORAGE-RING TECHNOLOGY; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Korol'kov V.L., Sivkov A.S., Astashkin I.N.
Title: INFLUENCE OF VISCOSITY OF ARC-EXTINGUISHING MEDIUM ON BREAK CHARACTERISTICS OF EXPLOSIVE SWITCH.
Authors with affiliations: Korol'kov, V.L.; Sivkov, A.S.; Astashkin, I.N.
Abstract: Results are reported for experimental investigations into the influence of the viscosity of an arc-extinction medium on the characteristics of current interruption by an explosive switch. It is shown that to maximize the possible values of the characteristics it is necessary to use liquid dielectrics with minimal viscosity.
Index Keywords: DIELECTRIC MATERIALS - Viscosity; ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE - Switching; ELECTRIC INSULATING MATERIALS - Liquids; INSULATING OIL - Viscosity; ARC-EXTINGUISHING MEDIUM VISCOSITY; BREAK CHARACTERISTICS; EXPLOSIVE SWITCHES; INDUCTIVE STORAGE SWITCHING; LIQUID DIELECTRICS; ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS, OIL

Title: OPEN-CAVITY MILLIMETER-WAVE RESONATOR AS A HIGH-Q MICROSTRIP CIRCUIT ELEMENT.
Source title: Conference Digest - International Conference on Infrared and Millimeter Waves
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA,, USA, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stephan, Karl D., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA,, USA, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, USA; Young, Song-Lin, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA,, USA, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, USA
Abstract: The authors summarize their area of current research activities and previously published works on a series of experiments beginning at 10 GHz and currently being extended above 30 GHz, in which they explored means of coupling very high-Q resonator modes to a microstrip circuit placed on the flat reflector of an open Fabry-Perot resonator. It is noted that the coupling bteween a microstrip conductor and an open resonator mode can be calculated using resonator field expressions already available in the literature, and reference is made to some initial experimental results with low-permittivity substrates at 10 GHz are available. Work on the usefulness of an open cavity mode as the energy-storage medium in an array of planar oscillators is also mentioned.
Index Keywords: MICROSTRIP DEVICES - Fabrication; HIGH-Q MICROSTRIP CIRCUIT; MICROSTRIP CIRCUIT ELEMENT; OPEN CAVITY RESONATOR; RESONATORS, CAVITY

Authors: Vardiashvili A.B., Muradov M.U., Kim V.D.
Title: MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF A PEBBLE THERMAL-STORAGE BED AND A METHOD OF CALCULATING ITS THERMOTECHNICAL PARAMETERS.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Vardiashvili, A.B.; Muradov, M.U.; Kim, V.D.
Abstract: Results of statistical analysis of fill elements in a pebble thermal-storage bed are presented, and formulas derived for determining the parameters of heat exchange. On the basis of energy-balance relationships for the fill and air, differential equations are formulated which describe the thermal-storage bed's heat conditions, and a method for numerical solution of them is given. A computer program has been written. The method is illustrated with an example of calculation.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SOFTWARE; HEAT TRANSFER; ROCK PRODUCTS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; STATISTICAL METHODS; PEBBLE THERMAL STORAGE BED; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION OF ADVANCED HEAT PUMP AUGMENTED SPACECRAFT HEAT REJECTION SYSTEMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Florida Inst of Technology,, Melbourne, FL, USA, Florida Inst of Technology, Melbourne, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Scaringe, R.P., Florida Inst of Technology,, Melbourne, FL, USA, Florida Inst of Technology, Melbourne, FL, USA
Abstract: Several thermally driven heat pump configurations, including hermetically sealed Rankine-powered and hermetically sealed free piston Stirling-powered heat pumps utilizing non-azeotropic refrigerant pairs were evaluated for their application to spacecraft heat rejection systems. The benefits of a non-azeotropic refrigerant are discussed and candidate non-azeotropic refrigerants applicable in the 300-400 degree K operating temperature range are presented. Thermal energy storage, incorporating the flexible expandable bladder concept is also discussed.
Index Keywords: SPACECRAFT; EXPANDABLE BLADDERS; HEAT REJECTION SYSTEMS; NON-AZEOTROPIC REFRIGERANTS; RANKINE CYCLE SYSTEMS; STIRLING SYSTEMS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: SIMULATION OF HEAVY CHARGED PARTICLE TRACKS USING FOCUSED LASER BEAMS.
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Richter, A.K., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Arimura, I., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: A laboratory system utilizing a Q-switched Nd-doped YAG laser is used to simulate the ionization track produced as energetic heavy ions traverse a semiconductor device (resulting in single-event upset effects). Details of the optical design for producing the precisely focused spot, and the requirements for fast pulses, are described. The advantages and disadvantages of the use of this laboratory simulation are discussed. Laser tests on p-i-n diodes, p-n junctions, bipolar memories, and power MOSFETs are described and compared to high-energy particle test results.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Radiation Effects; LASER PULSES - Focusing; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, BIPOLAR - Radiation Effects; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOSFET - Radiation Effects; CHARGED PARTICLE TRACKS SIMULATION; FOCUSED LASER BEAMS; HEAVY CHARGED PARTICLES; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES

Authors: Beyer H.G., Gabler H., Gerdes G.J., Heinemann D., Luther J., Schumacher-Groehn J., Steinberger-Willms R.
Title: WIND/SOLAR HYBRID ELECTRICITY GENERATION FOR STAND ALONE SYSTEMS WITH BATTERY AND HYDROGEN STORAGE.
Affiliations: Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Beyer, H.G., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Gabler, H., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Gerdes, G.J., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Heinemann, D., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Luther, J., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Schumacher-Groehn, J., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger; Steinberger-Willms, R., Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger, Univ of Oldenburg, West Ger
Abstract: Electricity supply from renewable sources shows the general pattern of mismatch between load and generation. Therefore it is necessary to incorporate storage devices. The mismatch is alleviated by combining wind and solar sources (hybrid systems). While the diurnal variations in supply and load can be met by conventional electrochemical storage (batteries), hydrogen storage is being discussed for long-term variations. We have performed simulation calculations for systems with high fractions of renewable energy production. These systems include wind/solar convertes, battery and hydrogen storage. The system model refers to a laboratory building run by the Physics Department at Oldenburg University.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER; HYBRID SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN STORAGE; RENEWABLE ENERGY; STAND ALONE SYSTEMS; WIND ENERGY CONVERTER (WEC); WIND/SOLAR HYBRID ELECTRICITY GENERATION; WIND TURBINES

Title: NONSTEADY-STATE HEAT TRANSFER IN A SYSTEM WITH A SUBSTRATE AND SUBSURFACE THERMAL STORAGE IN A GREENHOUSE.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Vardiashvili, A.B.
Abstract: The article gives design and calculation schemes for a thermal-storage system in a greenhouse with shelves of substrate, and develops a mathematical model of nonsteady-state heat transfer in layers of the system under consideration.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; HEATING - Heat Storage; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; SUBSTRATE LAYERS; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; GREENHOUSES

Title: ADVANCED SMALL RECHARGEABLE BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Lab, Padadena, CA,, USA, Jet Propulsion Lab, Padadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Halpert, Gerald, Jet Propulsion Lab, Padadena, CA,, USA, Jet Propulsion Lab, Padadena, CA, USA
Abstract: The small rechargeable battery business continues to expand both in applications and in new electrochemical systems. The advanced rechargeable electrochemical energy storage systems and their improvements/innovations described in this paper are divided into aqueous and non-aqueous systems. The aqueous systems include Lead-Acid (Lead-Lead Dioxide), Nickel-Cadmium (Cadmium-Nickel Oxide), Nickel-Hydrogen (Hydrogen-Nickel Oxide), and Nickel-Zinc (Zinc-Nickel Oxide). The non-aqueous small rechargeable systems contain lithium as the anode. These include: non-aqueous solid cathode systems; Lithium-Molybdenum Disulfide (MOLICEL), Lithium-Titanium Disulfide, Lithium-Vanadium Oxides, non-aqueous liquid cathode systems; Lithium-Sulfur Dioxide, and a new category on the horizon; Lithium-Polymer batteries.
Index Keywords: ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ADVANCED SMALL RECHARGEABLE BATTERIES; NICKEL-CADMIUM CELL; NICKEL-HYDROGEN CELL; NON-AQUEOUS LITHIUM RECHARGEABLE SYSTEMS; SEALED LEAD-ACID CELL; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ANALYSIS OF THE TRANSIENT THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF A LATENT HEAT STORAGE PACKED BED.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN,, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pitts, D.R., Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN,, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA; Hong, Ji Shi, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN,, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA
Abstract: The present work was undertaken to provide a model which accurately predicts the thermal performance of a packed bed energy storage system utilizing spherically encapsulated phase change material (PCM). Two models were developed which are referred to as the first-order and second-order models. Both models involve modelling of the phase change material as a conduction problem with both sensible and latent energy storage and include consideration of the temperature gradients in both phases. Both models include the solution of the energy equation for the fluid passing through the packed bed.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; FLUID SECOND-ORDER MODEL; HEAT STORAGE PACKED BED; PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL MODEL; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Cornelis K., Evans L., Faugier A., Hilaire A., Schmidt R.
Title: OPERATION OF THE SPP**-S SEPARATION SCHEME.
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Cornelis, K., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Evans, L., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Faugier, A., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Hilaire, A., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Schmidt, R., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: In order for the SPS proton-antiproton collider to operate effectively with six dense proton and antiproton bunches per beam it is necessary to minimize the total tune spread due to the beam-beam interaction by separating the beams at the maximum possible number of unwanted collision points during injection, energy ramping, and storage. On the 26-GeV injection platform, in particular, there is a considerable tune spread due to both the beam-beam interaction and incoherent space-charge detuning, making it difficult to keep both protons and antiprotons away from low-order nonlinear resonances. For the first time an attempt was made to minimize the contribution of the beam-beam interaction by separating the beams at all crossing points using a single electrostatic deflector. This resulted in an improved transmission and substantially brighter antiproton bunches.
Index Keywords: PROTONS; BEAM-BEAM RESONANCES; BEAMS SEPARATION SCHEME; SPS PROTON-ANTIPROTON COLLIDER; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Frank K.T., Kozub T.A., Kugel H.W.
Title: RULE-BASED COMPUTER CONTROL SYSTEM FOR PBX-M NEUTRAL BEAMS.
Affiliations: Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Frank, K.T., Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA; Kozub, T.A., Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA; Kugel, H.W., Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Univ, Princeton, NJ, USA
Abstract: The upgrade of the Princeton Beta Experiment (PBX) neutral-beam computer control system is described. The primary tasks included in the system are data acquisition, waveform reduction, automatic control, and data storage. The rule-based approach to the automatic control portion of the system will remain intact. The control algorithms are rule-based and goal-driven. The automatic control system raises ion-source electrical parameters to selected energy goals and maintains these levels until goals are requested or faults are detected. Signal processing allows control responses to be verified for relative accuracy, and error conditions to be dynamically defined. The upgrade will preserve the functionality of the neutral-beam system, while providing the environment in which expansion of the current knowledge base is possible. Removing the limitations on data archival space and computational capability allows the control algorithms to cross-reference the expert's rules with operational data learned by the computer. It is expected that this added intelligence will result in the desired beam power being injected into a larger percentage of plasma shots.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; SIGNAL PROCESSING - Digital Techniques; TOKAMAK DEVICES; PBX-M NEUTRAL BEAMS; PRINCETON BETA EXPERIMENT (PBXC); RULE-BASED COMPUTER CONTROL SYSTEM; WAVEFORM REDUCTION; PLASMAS

Authors: Skomorokhov V.B., Anikeev V.I., Kirillov V.A.
Title: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS OF OPERATING CONDITIONS OF A CATALYTIC REACTOR FOR THERMODYNAMIC TRANSFORMATION OF SOLAR ENERGY.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Skomorokhov, V.B.; Anikeev, V.I.; Kirillov, V.A.
Abstract: The article gives a numerical analysis for a mathematical model of the process of steam conversion of methane in a reactor-receiver heated with concentrated solar radiation. The reaction of steam conversion of methane was chosen for investigations due to the high density of energy storage in the products and the prospects of their use to obtain hydrogen and in chemical technology. The mathematical model of the processes is based on equations for the heat balance in the layer of catalyst and in the counterflow heat exchanger, and for the material balance for each of the components; continuity, characteristic, and pulse equations; and also on algebraic relationships of heat transfer through the wall.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT - Reactors; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METHANE; STEAM; CATALYTIC REACTORS; HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; SOLAR ENERGY; THERMODYNAMICS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: EFFECT OF STORAGE AND LEO CYCLING ON MANUFACTURING TECHNOLOGY IPV NICKEL-HYDROGEN CELLS.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smithrick, John J., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Yardney Manufacturing Technology (MANTECH) 50 A-hr space weight individual pressure vessel nickel-hydrogen cells were evaluated. This consisted of investigating the effect of storage, and charge/discharge cycling on cell performance. For the storage test the cells were precharged with hydrogen, by the manufacturer, to a pressure of 14. 5 psia. After undergoing activation and acceptance tests, the cells were discharged at C/10 rate (5 A) to 0. 1 V or less. The terminals were then shorted. The cells were shipped to NASA Lewis Research Center where they were stored at room temperature in the shorted condition for 1 yr. After storage, the acceptance tests were repeated at NASA Lewis. A comparison of test results indicate no significant degradation in electrical performance due to 1 yr storage.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; INDIVIDUAL PRESSURE VESSEL (IPV) NICKEL-HYDROGEN CELLS; LOW-EARTH ORBIT (LEO) CYCLING; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: ECONOMIC ACTIVE SOLAR HEATED HOUSE IN THE UK.
Affiliations: Univ of Surrey, Engl, Univ of Surrey, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Matley, W., Univ of Surrey, Engl, Univ of Surrey, Engl
Abstract: The pattern of energy usage in northern temperature climate domestic premises has been studied extensively over the past 15 years or so (references 1, 2 and 3) and a general consensus conclusion is that 85% of all energy consumed is used for space and water heating. This paper confines itself to examining the space and water heating requirements of domestic (and small industrial) premises, matching them to the availability of solar energy, and proposes a low cost domestic solar energy hybrid system suitable for both new construction and retrospective fitting.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; AUTOMATIC CONTROL SYSTEM; DOMESTIC SOLAR ENERGY HYBRID SYSTEM; SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE; HOUSES

Title: HELIUM-3 FUELING CONCEPTS FOR MAGNETICALLY CONFINED FUSION.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wittenberg, Layton J., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: A brief overview of fueling techniques is given. A conceptualized process flow scheme is presented for the fabrication of fuel pellets of 3- to 4-mm radius, composed of thin-wall polymeric shells filled with liquid He-3 and overcoated with D//2 ice. The carbon introduced by the polymer constitutes less than 1% of the fuel. The pellets are designed to survive cryogenic storage and delivery by the pellet injector. Advanced fabrication techniques include the use of lithium foil shells and the incorporation of polarized He-3 fuel.

Title: HIGH DENSITY ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY.
Affiliations: Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dembo, A., Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA; Zeitouni, O., Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. A novel design of neural networks operating as associative memories is presented. An axiomatic approach leads to the characterization of energy functions with no spurious local minima. Combining these energy functions in a descent-type relaxation algorithm leads to an associative memory with only the desired memories being attractors. The proposed associative memory is powerful enough to approximate any (predetermined) pattern classification rule with arbitrarily good accuracy.

Title: UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY COMMERCIAL REACTOR SPENT FUEL PROGRAMS BEING CONDUCTED AT THE IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY.
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Piscitella, R.R., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Rasmussen, T.L., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Uhi, D.L., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: In 1982, the Congress of the United States enacted the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA). This act stated that in exchange for one mil per kilowatt of electricity generated by nuclear power, the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) would take possession of the Utilities' nuclear spent fuel and provide for permanent disposal. The act also provided for establishment of the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) within the DOE to manage the NWPA programs. The Idaho National Engineering Laboratory participation in OCRWM programs includes the Spent Fuel Storage Cask Testing Program, Dry Rod Consolidation Technology Program, Prototypical Consolidation Demonstration Program, the Nuclear Fuel Services Project, and the Cask Systems Acquisition Program.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS; LEGISLATION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Storage; RESEARCH LABORATORIES; DRY CONSOLIDATION; ELECTRIC POWER RESEARCH INSTITUTE; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; STORAGE CASK; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: ECONOMICS OF THE BACK-END OF FUEL CYCLE: CONTROVERSY, UNCERTAINTIES AND THE INDUSTRIAL EVIDENCE.
Affiliations: Cogema, Bagnois-sur-Ceze, Fr, Cogema, Bagnois-sur-Ceze, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Guais, J.C., Cogema, Bagnois-sur-Ceze, Fr, Cogema, Bagnois-sur-Ceze, Fr
Abstract: This paper will underline the usefulness of the document issued on the 'economics of the nuclear fuel cycle', as a reference methodology. Regarding the technical and costs assumptions, the author feels that COGEMA as the most important reprocessor to date has accumulated a large industrial experience allowing a better knowledge of the various costs included in the back-end operations, from spent fuel transportation handling and storage, to reprocessing and waste conditioning. The author concludes that economics, as important as it is, is not the only criteria to be considered when assessing the back-end options: overall strategy, energy policy, environmental consideration and public acceptance are the other viewpoints to use to reach a sound decision in this field.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY POLICY; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; BACK-END OPERATIONS; PUBLIC ACCEPTANCE; WASTE CONDITIONING; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors with affiliations: Amouroux, M.; El Alami, N.
Abstract: An application of quadratic cost control of distributed bilinear systems theory to the control of a thermal storage system is considered. After stating the problem, we recall the principal theoretical results, and present a numerical example.

Title: EXERGY AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES OF THE ENERGY STORAGE PROCESS BASED ON SULFURIC ACID DECOMPOSITION AND SYNTHESIS PROCESSES.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que,, Can, Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Bilgen, E., Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que,, Can, Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que, Can
Abstract: Exergy and economic analyses were carried out of the chemical energy storage system which is based on sulfuric acid decomposition and synthesis processes using hot oxygen as a vector. The process is operated at 9 bar using all adiabatic equipment; In an example study storing about 2788 GJ per cycle, isothermal heat at 1098 K is supplied to the energy storage process and the heat at 1044 K is restituted from the system. It is found that the energy storage density is about 0. 68 GJ/m**3 for 365 cycles per year operation, the overall thermal energy storage efficiency is about 40% and the cost of energy storage is about 5 /GJ for typical economical assumptions of 10% interest rate, 5% inflation rate and 10% capital charge rate.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Thermodynamics; INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS - Analysis; SULFURIC ACID - Decomposition; ADIABATIC EQUIPMENT; CHEMICAL ENERGY STORAGE; EXERGY; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Chung Kie Hyung, In Sang Ryul
Title: CONDITIONS OF PLASMA FOCUS.
Affiliations: Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Chung, Kie Hyung, Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea; In, Sang Ryul, Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, South Korea
Abstract: A Mather-type plasma gun is operated at below 1 Torr with an energy storage system (4 kJ, 16. 5 kV, 35 nH) to study the conditions for the efficient operation of the plasma focus. When the D//2 gas filling pressure is 0. 18 Torr and the stored energy is 3. 8 kJ, a discharge current of 180 kA maximum is obtained, and the average axial velocity of the plasma is about 7 cm/s. This is lower than the calculated velocity for these conditions using the snowplow model. The discrepancy is due to the currents flowing over the insulator surface.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; DISCHARGE CURRENT; MATHER-TYPE PLASMA GUN; PLASMA FOCUS; PLASMA DEVICES

Title: RESERVOIR REGULATION IN THE MONSOON CLIMATE OF KOREA.
Affiliations: US Army Corps of Engineers, Ft., Shafter, HI, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Ft. Shafter, HI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dexter, James R., US Army Corps of Engineers, Ft., Shafter, HI, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Ft. Shafter, HI, USA
Abstract: An examination of reservoir regulation rules in light of uncertain estimates of river flow in the Han River Basin, Republic of Korea, shows that two strategies will improve total hydroelectric energy generation value and also meet water supply and irrigation requirements. Three dams provide 95 percent of the effective reservoir storage in the basin. There are small but statistically significant variations in unit runoff at these sites in certain months. The differences may be due to shifts in surface wind patterns brought about by the monsoon climate or to differences in regional geology. These differences can be used to formulate one strategy based on shaping energy requirements of each reservoir proportionate to resource availability.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Water; MEASUREMENT ERRORS; RUNOFF - Measurements; STREAM FLOW - Estimation; WATER SUPPLY; FLOW ESTIMATE ERRORS; MONSOON CLIMATE; RESERVOIR REGULATION; RESERVOIRS

Title: COGENERATION USING AN INTEGRATED ENERGY SOLUTION AT KAISER ZION MEDICAL CENTER.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Internal Combustion Engine Division (Publication) ICE
Authors with affiliations: Henrikson, R.A.; Gilbert, R.
Abstract: This paper presents a case study of a cogeneration facility which incorporates an 'Integrated Energy Solution'. This design approach strives to maximize the owner's return on investment by leveling his energy needs and production rather than designing for peak demands. In addition to a review of the design philosophy, the design features: selection of the prime mover, leveling energy demand by demand. Continuous system monitoring and control with an on-line computer system are detailed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEAT ENGINES; HOSPITALS; REFUSE INCINERATORS; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; CHILLED WATER THERMAL STORAGE; INTEGRATED ENERGY SOLUTION; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: DEVELOPING AN INNOVATIVE BUILDING COOLING TECHNOLOGY.
Affiliations: Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Morofsky, E.L., Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: An innovative seasonal ice storage technology development is followed from conception in 1976, through preliminary design, experiment, and pilot study to detailed design of a demonstration project. The objective was to develop and perfect an automated, efficient ice freezing, storage, and utilization technique with minimal operating and maintenance costs; to determine the height of ice that could be efficiently produced as a function of winter temperatures; and to develop a standard modular approach applicable at any site in a cost-effective manner. The application was to cool commercial and industrial buildings having a significant cooling demand. This paper traces the evolution of a commercialization strategy to transfer the technology to the private sector and the changes due to technical developments and market characteristics. All of the major technical objectives have been successfully achieved.
Index Keywords: AIR - Cooling; BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; ENERGY STORAGE - Technology Transfer; ICE - Manufacture; COMMERCIALIZATION STRATEGY; SEASONAL ICE STORAGE; SUMMER COOLING; AIR CONDITIONING

Authors: Kim J.I., Lierse Ch., Bueppelmann K., Magirius S.
Title: RADIOLYTICALLY INDUCED OXIDATION REACTIONS OF ACTINIDE IONS IN CONCENTRATED SALT SOLUTIONS.
Affiliations: TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger, TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kim, J.I., TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger, TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger; Lierse, Ch., TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger, TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger; Bueppelmann, K., TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger, TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger; Magirius, S., TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger, TU Muenchen, Garching, West Ger
Abstract: The autoradiolytic oxidation of Pu(IV) and Am(III) has been investigated in saline solutions of different NaCl concentrations, pH and specific alpha -activities. The high linear energy transfer property of alpha -radiation in solution enhances the oxidation of the Cl ion and increases the redox potential (Eh) of the NaCl solutions system to a value of more than plus 1000 mV vs. NHE. Radiolytic reaction products are comparable to those from the Cl//2 saturated NaCl solution and create a metastable system consisting of Cl//2/HCl0/Cl0/Cl. The oxidation of Pu(IV) and Am(III) in such solution is dependent on the NaCl concentration, pH and specific alpha -activity involved. The quantitative oxidation to Pu(VI) and Am(V) is observed in the concentration NaCl solution at pH greater than 7 with a moderately high specific activity ( greater than 1 Ci/L).
Index Keywords: ACTINIDES - Redox; AQUIFERS; HYDROGEN ION CONCENTRATION; RADIATION EFFECTS; SODIUM CHLORIDE; AUTORADIOLYTIC OXIDATION; NUCLEAR FUELS STORAGE; OXIDATION PRODUCTS; REDOX POTENTIAL; SPECIATION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: PREDICTION CONTROL FOR A CYCLOCONVERTER OF A POWER DISTORTION COMPENSATION SYSTEM.
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn, Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Isao, Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn, Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn; Nunokawa, Masahiko, Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn, Technological Univ of Nagaoka, Jpn
Abstract: Control methods for a flywheel mechanical energy storage system composed of a flywheel-synchronous machine and a current-controlled cycloconverter are described. Improved current control of the cycloconverter is obtained using both dead-beat control and prediction control. By predicting the current value of next sample time and applying the predicted reference to the dead-beat controller, the current following characteristics are improved, having minimum error with prediction and leaning abilities. Using two digital signal processors and an 16-bit microprocessor, a totally digital control circuit is realized. The cycle time of gate control is 8. 5 s, and the calculation time of the optimum coefficients of the digital filter is 160 ms. Through simulation and experiment the approach is shown to be very promising.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Computer Interfaces; CONTROL SYSTEMS, PREDICTIVE; CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Current; SIGNAL PROCESSING - Digital Techniques; 16-BIT MICROPROCESSOR; CYCLOCONVERTER; DEAD-BEAT CONTROLLER; POWER DISTORTION COMPENSATION SYSTEM; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Title: PROCESS CONTROL TECHNOLOGY: DEMAND FOR FLEXIBILITY.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Each production process can be regarded as a unit of events during which substance, energy, and information are transmitted, converted, and stored. Process technology covers the area of substance and part of energy (for example steam), while process control technology is responsible for the other sector of energy (for example electric energy) and for the area of information. In the article process control technology is examined under the aspects of transport, conversion and storage of information, i. e. in the sense of information processing.

Title: OPTIMISATION OF HYBRID WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS FOR REMOTE AREA POWER SUPPLY.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Aust, CSIRO, Aust
Authors with affiliations: de L Musgrove, A.R., CSIRO, Aust, CSIRO, Aust
Abstract: The stochastic dynamic programming model RAPSODY is capable of simulating the operation of systems which use various combinations of renewable energy sources, conventional generating plant and battery storage systems, taking into account the variability of the renewable energy source. The model uses capital cost and operating and maintenance cost data for the system components to calculate the average daily operating cost and the average cost of electricity produced. Furthermore, it recognises the variation of fuel efficiency and maintenance costs with the ouput level of the diesel generator, and explicitly deals with an additional cost which may be incurred whenever the diesel set is switched on. RAPSODY can also analyse the influence on optimal strategies, or system design parameters of unscheduled outages of the auxiliary generator. The present paper describes the RAPSODY model and gives an example of its use in optimising the design of a small wind/battery system including a single auxiliary diesel generator.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, DYNAMIC; HYBRID WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS; RAPSODY MODEL; REMOTE AREA POWER SUPPLY (RAPS) SYSTEMS; WIND/BATTERY SYSTEM; WIND TURBINES

Title: SOLAR THERMAL OPTION: AN OVERVIEW.
Affiliations: Univ of Birmingham, Engl, Univ of Birmingham, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Jesch, L.F., Univ of Birmingham, Engl, Univ of Birmingham, Engl
Abstract: The role of solar thermal as an energy option is examined in the context of world energy reserves and consumption. The history and development of the new technology during the last two decades in the US, Japan, Europe and in the UK is outlined. The current state of the technology is described with reference to systems and components, energy storage, hydrogen transport, stratification, phase change materials, solar ponds, transparent insulation, load management and control strategy. The future of solar thermal as an energy option is analysed in an economic perspective.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ENERGY RESERVES; SOLAR THERMAL OPTION; HEATING

Abstract: Superconducting 500-MHz cavities have been developed to demonstrate the feasibility of upgrading the e-beam energy of the HERA storage ring. A prototype module with 2 multiplied by 4 cell resonators and appropriate fundamental- and higher-mode couplers has been designed and is being built by industrial firms. Design details are given, and the results of cryogenic measurements are discussed.

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 91 papers which discuss strategic planning regarding intelligent buildings and energy efficient plants. Title: THERMAL-CYCLING TESTS FOR A COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE RECUPERATOR.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The purpose of these tests was to determine the thermomechanical fatigue life of tube-to-tubesheet joints in compressed-air energy storage (CAES) recuperators. Researchers built a prototypic model of a CAES recuperator with seven tube-to-tubesheet joints. They subjected the model to thermal cycles representative of those expected in a CAES recuperator, measured strains and temperatures, and looked for cracks in the joints. These physical tests show that finite-element analyses performed in report EM-3843 conservatively predict thermal-fatigue failures, since assumed stress concentration values exceeded experimental values.

Title: LATTICE STUDIES FOR THE TRIESTE SYNCHROTRON RADIATION MACHINE.
Affiliations: INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Biagini, M.E., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy; Biscari, C., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy; Gianfelice, E., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy; Guiducci, S., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy; Palumbo, L., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy; Preger, M., INFN, Frascati, Italy, INFN, Frascati, Italy
Abstract: A study on a low-emittance lattice for a synchrotron radiation storage ring in the energy range 1. 5 to 2. 0 GeV is described. The emittance is 4. 5 multiplied by 10** minus **9 m-rad at 1. 5 GeV. The lattice has 16 dispersion-free straight sections for insertion devices. Two different structures are presented. Both lattices are based on the Chasman-Green achromat, the former with no focusing in the bending magnets and 5 quadrupoles in the achromat, the latter with vertical focusing in the magnets and a single quadrupole in the dispersion section.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; MAGNETIC LENSES; OPTICS; CHASMAN-GREEN ACHROMAT; CHROMATICITY CORRECTION; DYNAMIC APERTURE; LOW-EMITTANCE LATTICE; TRIESTE SYNCHROTRON RADIATION MACHINE; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: METHODOLOGY AND STUDY OF THREE PROPOSED COLD THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS FOR A U. S. NAVY SHORE FACILITY.
Authors with affiliations: McCauley, J.F.
Abstract: This paper deals with an organization's experience in attempting to retrofit existing HVAC systems with accepted cold thermal storage technology equipment. The HVAC equipment ranges in size from 25 to 550 ton chillers of the reciprocating, centrifugal and screw genuses. The types of storage systems studied are water, ice and eutectic salts; with single, dual and multi-tank storage arrangements.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING; ICE - Energy Storage; WATER; CHILLERS; EUTECTIC SALT ENERGY STORAGE; HVAC EQUIPMENT; ICE STORAGE SYSTEMS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Landgrebe Albert R., Meredith Robert E.

Abstract: The Electrochemical Energy Storage program of the U. S. Department of Energy provides funding to college and university education in a number of direct and indirect ways. Each year, from this particular program, funds to the extent of approximately 3 million are assigned to schools of higher learning for various research activities. While these appropriations are employed primarily to obtain certain research goals, they indirectly support graduate students and allow such students to complete their formal education requirements. During the past decade, while we have been funding research in higher education, such schools have also aided our needs and we are equally in their debt. A partial list of these institutions include MIT, Case Western Reserve, Ohio State University, ITT, Stanford, BYU, and the Universities of California, Utah, Tennessee, Pennsylvania, Rochester and Virginia.

Abstract: The paper presents results of research development of CAES plant utilizing thermal energy storage for steam generation to be mixed with compressed air and expanded to produce additional power. The paper presents the following: a) The conceptual cycle arrangements with major equipment description; b) Plant performance and cost data; c) Comparative analysis of CAES plant concepts with TES for steam generation and further use for additional power production vs. conventional CAES plant. The paper concludes that this development utilizes proven technology, is cost effective and can be considered for practical application.

Authors with affiliations: Basov, N.G.; Dorogotovtsev, V.M.; Isakov, A.I.; Merkul'ev, Yu.A.; Nikitenko, A.I.

Title: STORAGE OF THERMAL ENERGY BY MEANS OF AN ABSORPTION CYCLE.
Affiliations: NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth, NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Ruiter, J.P., NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth, NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth
Abstract: The possibilities for storing thermal energy by means of an absorption cycle are described. In such a cycle two components of a mixture are separated by the supply of energy (heat or mechanical energy). The absorption cycle was investigated for three different storage alternatives. In the first alternative the components are separated by heat supply. In the second storage alternative the heat of desorption is supplied by a heat pump that uses the heat of condensation as a heat source. In the third alternative the heat of condensations produced at such a high temperature that this heat can be used directly for desorption. A model was verified for cycles with the first and third storage alternatives, for a mixture (NH//3/H//2O) as well as for a solution (NH//3/NaSCN). An experimental installation was built for the purpose, with a net heat output of 5 kw and a storage capacity of 40 kwh. The experimental results agree within 9% with the values that were calculated from the model.
Index Keywords: ABSORPTION - Thermal Effects; HEATING - Heat Storage; INDUSTRIAL HEATING - Waste Heat Utilization; MIXTURES; THERMODYNAMICS; ABSORPTION CYCLE AMMONIA; AMMONIA; HEAT PUMPS; PROCESS HEATING; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; WATER; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Mullett L.B., Afeef M.A., Tsilingiris P.T.
Title: SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS - A REASSESSMENT OF EFFICIENCY AND STABILITY.
Affiliations: Univ of Reading, Engl, Univ of Reading, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Mullett, L.B., Univ of Reading, Engl, Univ of Reading, Engl; Afeef, M.A., Univ of Reading, Engl, Univ of Reading, Engl; Tsilingiris, P.T., Univ of Reading, Engl, Univ of Reading, Engl
Abstract: The salt-gradient solar pond exploits three properties of water. It is an excellent medium for heat storage at the bottom of the pond and, when convection is suppressed leaving only conductive loss of heat to the surface, it is a surprisingly good insulator which is also remarkably transparent to solar radiation. Convection is suppressed in the central gradient zone by an increase in concentration of salt (sodium and/or magnesium chloride) with depth, such that hotter water below is always heavier than cooler water above. This paper discusses the subjects of absorption of solar radiation by solar ponds and solar pond efficiency and stability.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR POND EFFICIENCY; SOLAR POND STABILITY; SOLAR RADIATION ABSORPTION; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Berkey Brian D., Pratt Thomas H., Williams George M.
Title: REVIEW OF LITERATURE RELATED TO HUMAN SPARK SCENARIOS.
Source title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers, National Meeting
Affiliations: Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA
Authors with affiliations: Berkey, Brian D., Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA; Pratt, Thomas H., Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA; Williams, George M., Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Center, WV, USA
Abstract: This paper presents a summary of articles from the literature concerning human spark ignition scenarios. Two basic subject areas are covered. These are (1) articles related to charge generation, particularly those associated with clothing and textiles, and (2) articles related to energy storage and discharge. The papers have been organized according to their primary subject. However, it should be recognized that many of the papers relate to both subject areas. The key conclusions and recommendations from each of the cited articles are included, as well as a summary of conclusions drawn from the overall literature review.

Title: GEL 2KWp SPV POWER PACK FOR A SMALL COMMUNITY.
Affiliations: Central Electronics Ltd, Sahibabad, India, Central Electronics Ltd, Sahibabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Sangal, S.K., Central Electronics Ltd, Sahibabad, India, Central Electronics Ltd, Sahibabad, India
Abstract: The electrical energy needs of distant and remotely located small villages in third-world countries are limited, dispersed and often season dependent. CEL's 2 KWp SPV Power Pack is specifically designed and integrated for small community village use in third-world countries. The Power Pack has a solar photovoltaic (SPV) module and battery storage capacities to operate designed load for three consecutive non-sunshine/low sunshine days without any adverse effect. The power pack is meant to operate domestic and outdoor fluorescent tube lights, mono-block surface-centrifugal water pump sets, a 51cm community television (TV) set and a small refrigerator for vaccine/medicine storage. This paper deals with the details of the SPV System and various load alternatives of CEL's 2 KWp SPV Power Pack.

Authors: Walls W.A., Weldon W.F., Woodson H.H., Driga M., Gully J.H.
Title: PULSED HOMOPOLAR GENERATOR POWER SUPPLIES FOR THE IGNITEX EXPERIMENT.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Walls, W.A., Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA; Weldon, W.F., Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA; Woodson, H.H., Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA; Driga, M., Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA; Gully, J.H., Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, Austin, TX, USA
Abstract: A description is given of the Ignitex pulsed homopolar generator (HPG) power supplies which use a combination of iron-core machine technology and relatively new composite energy-storage flywheel developments. For the Ignitex experiment, a total of 14. 6 GJ are required for the 10-s total pulse length, 12 GJ for the toroidal-field excitation and 2. 6 GJ for the poloidal-field coils. The toroidal-field supply is composed of twelve, 1-GJ modules each rated at 12. 5-MA output current and an open circuit voltage of 30 V. Five generators have stored energies between 40 and 700 MJ each and output ratings from 8 MA at 60 V to 750 kA at 150 V. For the 1-GJ machines, the brushes operate at a 200-m/s slip speed and a current density of 1. 25 kA/cm**2. These are below state-of-the-art performance levels for pulsed HPGs. Composite flywheel technology allows the 1-GJ modules to be built compact enough to be placed close to the Ignitex coil system and provides a significant cost savings over steel flywheel energy storage. Flywheels for the generators are fiberglass/epoxy composite rims with 3. 75-m outer diameters and 1-m axial lengths.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONDUCTORS, BRUSH; ELECTROMAGNETS - Electric Power Supplies; NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION; ENERGY-STORAGE FLYWHEEL; IGNITEX EXPERIMENT; POLOIDAL FIELD POWER SUPPLY; PULSED HOMOPOLAR GENERATOR (HPG); TOROIDAL FIELD POWER SUPPLY; TOKAMAK DEVICES

Authors: Cherng John G., Dickey Leland C.
Title: EXPERIMENTAL CHARACTERIZATION OF LOW-DENSITY POLYETHYLENE OXIDE AND FREON IN A DIRECT-CONTACT HEAT TRANSFER PROCESS.
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn,, MI, USA, Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cherng, John G., Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn,, MI, USA, Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA; Dickey, Leland C., Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn,, MI, USA, Univ of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA
Abstract: The direct-contact heat transfer process is attractive in various thermal applications. However, the characteristics of this process are highly dependent on the kind of heat transfer fluid and energy storage medium being used. This study presents the experimental results of a unique direct-contact heat transfer process between low density polyethylene oxide (PEO) and freon. It was found that the solid formed during the solidification process has very low permeability, which causes difficulties in the melting process. Both the solidification and melting mechanisms are discussed in detail as well as the test facility and instrumentation used. The energy transferred during the process was measured and is then compared with theoretical calculations. An example of a heat exchanger design based on the test results is also included in the paper.
Index Keywords: FREONS - Heat Transfer; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Design; POLYETHYLENES - Heat Transfer; DIRECT-CONTACT HEAT TRANSFER; POLYETHYLENE OXIDE/FREON; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: ROLE OF CATALYST SUPPORT ON THE ACTIVITY OF NICKEL FOR REFORMING METHANE WITH CO//2.
Source title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers, National Meeting
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gadalla, Ahmed M., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA; Bower, Barbara, Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: Thermodynamic studies were conducted to determine the operating conditions needed to inhibit carbon deposition and nickel carbide formation as well as to study the possible solid state reactions within the catalysts in reforming methane with CO//2. Five nickel commercial catalysts, manufactured for steam reforming, on supports containing alumina in different forms were studied and their catalytic activity, selectivity and stability were established using different feed ratios, space velocities and temperatures. Fused alpha -Al//2O//3 was the only stable catalyst but yielded relatively lower conversion. Although gamma -alumina partly reacted forming NiAl//2O//4 solid solution and partly transformed to alpha form with a resultant exothermic effect and drastic decrease in surface area, a decrease in conversion was not detected. alpha -Al//2O//3 in presence of mullite caused rapid irreversible deactivation due to the exothermic formation of NiAl//2O//4, which shatters the support. On the other hand, the presence of alpha -Al//2O//3 in presence of MgAl//2O//4 or calcium aluminate gave high conversions which increase with time.
Index Keywords: CARBON DIOXIDE; METHANE; NICKEL COMPOUNDS; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; SYNTHETIC FUELS; CARBON DIOXIDE REFORMING; CATALYTIC STEAM REFORMING; FREE ENERGY; MAGNESIUM ALUMINATE; NEWTON-RAPHSON TECHNIQUE; THERMODYNAMICS; CATALYSTS

Title: INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT'S INSPECTION REPORTS F. E. R. C. ORDER NO. 122 - THE FIRST FIVE YEARS.
Affiliations: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, USA, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hawk, John K., Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, USA, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, USA
Abstract: On January 21, 1981, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) issued Order No. 122, revising and expanding the periodic inspection program established in 1965 by the Federal Power Commission (FPC), the predecessor of the FERC. This program was intended to provide third-party, unbiased safety evaluations of dams at the Commission's licensed projects. Inspections were to be performed at five year intervals by 'independent' consultants engaged by the licensees. The FPC program included projects having a dam exceeding 10. 7 meters (35 feet) in height or having a gross storage capacity in excess of 2. 5 million cubic meters (2,000 acre-feet). By the time Order No. 122 was issued, most of the licensed dams already had been inspected three times. With the regulations promulgated by Order No. 122 now more than five years old, the second round of inspections are underway. This paper presents a discussion of the success of the program, its importance within the context of the Commission's dam safety program, problems encountered relative to approval of consultants, the quality of reports submitted, the application of current design criteria to existing dams, and the independence of consultants.
Index Keywords: INSPECTION; LEGISLATION; DAM SAFETY PROGRAM; INDEPENDENT CONSULTANTS; INSPECTION REPORTS; DAMS

Title: PUMPED STORAGE AND COMPRESSED AIR STORAGE, A COMPARISON.
Affiliations: Stone & Webster Engineering, Corp, Denver, CO, USA, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Makarechian, A.H., Stone & Webster Engineering, Corp, Denver, CO, USA, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp, Denver, CO, USA; Grinnell, G.C.K., Stone & Webster Engineering, Corp, Denver, CO, USA, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: Pumped storage hydroelectric power plants and compressed air energy storage (CAES) plants are used for peaking and intermediate duty on electrical utility load systems. In comparing pumped storage with CAES, the development stage of the two technologies should be kept in mind. Pumped storage is a fully mature technology. CAES utilizes components of tested and mature technologies. However, CAES is a relatively new technology compared to pumped storage and only a limited number of CAES plants have been built. Both pumped storage and CAES have exacting site requirements. A conventional pumped storage project can not be located in an area without mountains and valleys.

Authors: Phinney D.L., Ryerson F.J., Oversby V.M., Lanford W.A., Aines R.D., Bates J.K.
Title: INTEGRATED TESTING OF THE SRL-165 GLASS WASTE FORM.
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Phinney, D.L., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Ryerson, F.J., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Oversby, V.M., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Lanford, W.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Aines, R.D., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA; Bates, J.K., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: Integrated testing of the important components of a glass waste form waste package has been performed in order to gain a better understanding of the processes of radionuclide release and transport in the near field environment. Based upon an interpretation of the depth of penetration of hydrogen in reacted SRL-165 glass the authors have modeled the radionuclide release from the glass as a combined process of the diffusive exchange of alkalis and boron in the glass for hydrogen species in the solution (D equals 10** minus **1**6 cm**2/s) and surface dissolution. Surface dissolution controls the release of components not exchanged by diffusion and takes place at a rate of 1. 5-3. 0 mu m/yr. Subsequent to release the radionuclides may remain in the leach solution, diffuse into the tuff, or precipitate as secondary phases. Precipitation is particularly important for plutonium and americium. Diffusive transport of radionuclides through the tuff takes place at a slow rate, D equals 10** minus **1**6 cm**2/s. As such, the mass of radionuclides incorporated in the tuff by diffusion during the tests is inconsequential relative to that in the leach solution (with the exception of plutonium) and can be ignored in mass balance calculations. Mass balance calculations based upon the release of radionuclides by surface dissolution of the glass waste form are in good agreement with observed solution chemistry when allowances are made for a pulse of dissolution early in the tests. This pulse may be due to either the rapid dissolution of high-energy surface features early in the integrated tests or an initially high surface dissolution rate that decreases with time as silica saturation is approached, or a combination of the two.
Index Keywords: GLASS - Dissolution; NUCLEAR FUELS - Waste Disposal; NUCLIDES - Radioactive; NEVADA NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE INVESTIGATIONS PROJECT; RADIONUCLIDES; TUFF; WASTE PACKAGE DESIGN; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Abstract: In this paper the conditions to define the efficiency of a process as applicable within the first and the second laws of thermodynamics are investigated. Abstract: An ac uninterruptible power supply (UPS) is introduced that has high efficiency, ac input-voltage regulation, and continuity of output power during any type of commercial ac-input power disturbance. Authors: Gupta R.P., Kekez M.M., Lau J.H.W., Lougheed G.D.
Title: SOLENOID GAS PUFF SOFT X-RAY SOURCE EXPERIMENTS.
Affiliations: Natl Research Council, Can, Natl Research Council, Can
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, R.P., Natl Research Council, Can, Natl Research Council, Can; Kekez, M.M., Natl Research Council, Can, Natl Research Council, Can; Lau, J.H.W., Natl Research Council, Can, Natl Research Council, Can; Lougheed, G.D., Natl Research Council, Can, Natl Research Council, Can
Abstract: The gas-puff system has been studied in 1986-87 with no major problems determined that would limit its application as a repetitive soft X-ray source. The gas-puff system has unique features which allow the injection of uniformly preionized low-mass liners into the interelectrode gap. A large-radius (3. 8-cm) system was selected for the initial experiments to obtain efficient energy transfer to the dynamic load. Comparison with slug model simulations indicate that 0. 1-0. 5- mu g shells are formed and imploded using krypton and xenon. Pinhole camera images indicate a less than 1-mm diameter X-ray source including shot-to-shot scatter. The initial experiments to determine the feasibility of the gas puff used low-inductance capacitor banks as drivers. A dc-charged castor oil/paper Blumlein system has since been adopted.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; PREIONIZED LOW-MASS LINERS; SOFT X-RAY SOURCE; SOLENOID GAS-PUFF SYSTEM; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION

Title: SECOND LAW ANALYSIS OF PHASE-CHANGE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi, State, MS, USA, Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi State, MS, USA
Authors with affiliations: Adebiyi, G.A., Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi, State, MS, USA, Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi State, MS, USA; Russell, L.D., Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi, State, MS, USA, Univ of Mississippi, Mississippi State, MS, USA
Abstract: Thermal Energy Storage Systems which have been proposed belong to one or other of three main groups, namely, Sensible Heat Storage, Latent Heat Storage and Chemical Storage Systems. All such systems are, essentially, periodic-flow regenerators for which first-law analysis is given in the literature. Only in relatively few instances, however, has the performance of a thermal energy storage system been evaluated on the basis of the second law of thermodynamics. In such cases the analysis has been limited to only one design, the Sensible Heat Storage System. This paper presents a comparative performance evaluation of the Sensible Heat and Latent Heat storage systems which have been proposed, this time from a second-law perspective.
Index Keywords: THERMODYNAMICS - Analysis; LATENT HEAT STORAGE SYSTEM; SECOND LAW ANALYSIS; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE SYSTEM; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors with affiliations: Anderson, C.K., Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor,, CT, USA, Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor, CT, USA; Burns, W.J., Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor,, CT, USA, Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor, CT, USA; Shimura, Y., Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor,, CT, USA, Combustion Engineering Inc, Windsor, CT, USA
Abstract: Increasing inventories of spent fuel and decreasing storage capacities at reactors are prompting development of alternative storage technologies. In the United States of America, the Department of Energy is engaged in the development of a geological repository and is committed to begin accepting fuel for permanent storage by 31 January 1998. Until this time, US utilities have assumed the responsibility for handling this material. The storage situation is also recognized in Japan and several utilities are now engaged in the development of alternative storage options. In recognition of these situations, Combustion Engineering, Inc. and Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd are engaged in a programme to develop and manufacture a cask capable of safely storing and transporting spent nuclear fuel. The Dry-Cap cask, designed to fulfil the long and short term storage needs for utilities is discussed in this article.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; BURNUP; DRY-CAP CASK; REACTIVITY MONITOR; CONTAINERS

Authors: Luna R.E., Cashwell J.W., Neuhauser K.S.
Title: ANALYTICAL METHODOLOGY FOR ESTIMATING THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF THE TRANSPORTATION OF NUCLEAR WASTE.
Source title: International Atomic Energy Agency, Proceedings Series
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA

Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy Offices of Defense Programs and Civilian Radioactive Waste Management are in the process of locating fixed facilities for the processing and/or storage of radioactive wastes. To support the Environmental Assessments (EA) for these programs, Sandia National Laboratories, with the assistance of Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratory and Oak Ridge National Laboratory has developed and utilized a system of computerized models and databases for the estimation of transportation-related costs and risks. This presentation outlines the major components of the system and the interactions between the components.

Abstract: A proposed upgrade of the Bevalac accelerator complex is described in which the present Bevatron is being replaced with a modern, strong-focusing 17-T-m synchrotron. This ring is designed to accelerate all ions throughout the periodic table with intensities 100 to 1000 times higher than the present Bevatron. It will also provide a substantially improved beam spill structure and reduce operating costs. A fast extraction capability can be used to inject a future heavy ion storage ring. Pulse-to-pulse switching of energy and ion species is an important goal. The existing injectors, shielding, experimental facilities and utilities will remain substantially intact.

Title: 'DO-IT-YOURSELF' DDC FOR THERMAL STORAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Sosoka, J.R.; Peterson, K.W.
Abstract: There were two primary goals for this project. The first was to develop a highly reliable and accurate control system that was suitable for unsupervised remote operation. The second was to develop non-proprietary user generated control software that could be modified for use at other similar sites. This paper will discuss the advantages of industrial microcomputer for some applications, but the main thrust will be related to the programming considerations. The programming not only had to provide local control, it had to allow for communication and remote trouble shooting.

Authors: McCormick Michael E., Altera Allan G.
Title: COMPARATIVE STUDY OF TWO CAPTURE CHAMBER GEOMETRIES.
Affiliations: US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA, US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCormick, Michael E., US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA, US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA; Altera, Allan G., US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA, US Naval Acad, Annapolis, MD, USA
Abstract: Results of an experimental study of two capture chambers are presented. The capture chamber geometries are those that have been either used or recommended in conjunction with pneumatic wave energy conversion. The respective waterplanes of the chambers are square and circular, and the areas of each are equal. The pressure of the entrapped air above the internal water surface is measured for a series of wave frequencies and heights. The pressure values are then used to determine the potential energy of the compressed air. For each of three inlet areas of the chambers, the square waterplane chamber is shown to be a more effective energy storer. The reason for this is that the circular chamber is a better radiator. The peak energy storage efficiency of the square chamber is approximately 60%, while that of the circular chamber is 20%. Inlet losses due to the non-streamlined inlet sides are small and, therefore, not responsible for the low efficiency values.
Index Keywords: PNEUMATICS; TURBOMACHINERY - Design; CAPTURE CHAMBER; CHAMBER ONLETS; COMPARATIVE STUDY; GEOMETRIES; PNEUMATIC WAVE ENERGY CONVERSION; WATER WAVES

Authors: Lewandowski E., Benson D., Fronczak F., Beachley N.
Title: TEST RIG DESIGN FOR HYDROSTATIC ACCUMULATOR ENERGY-STORAGE AUTOMOBILE RESEARCH.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Design Engineering Division (Publication) DE
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lewandowski, E., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Benson, D., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Fronczak, F., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Beachley, N., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The use of a hydrostatic transmission and energy storage hydropneumatic accumulator in an automobile power train allows the combination of brake energy recovery and continuously-variable transmission ratios, with the resulting potential of significantly improved fuel economy and performance. Previous analytical studies have resulted in economy predictions, tentative control policies, and preliminary hardware design. Based on this information, a versatile, well-instrumented test rig was designed and built (including a hydraulic simulation of an internal combustion engine) for experimentally evaluating the efficiency, performance, and control aspects of the concept. This paper describes the details of the hardware and instrumentation and includes a summary of the test program. The test rig can be used to conduct a wide range of tests, including component and subsystem efficiency and control tests. Tests conducted using the rig have been very encouraging, and the test program has provided a significant amount of data useful for further development of the concept.
Index Keywords: VEHICLES - Transmission; ENERGY STORAGE VEHICLE; HYDROSTATIC ACCUMULATOR; AUTOMOBILE TRANSMISSIONS

Abstract: The availability of pulsed power, high-energy kinetic energy storage devices offers an opportunity to perform a wide range of experiments. The power density/interaction time plot gives the regimes where the processing has the most potential. Processing approaches can be divided between direct and indirect techniques. HEHR processing is a potentially useful approach to powder consolidation for two reasons. The first is that the speed associated with the processing offers the opportunity to maintain the fine microstructure associated with the original powders in the consolidated material. This fine structure could be either a non-equilibrium microstructure or a fine grain or subgrain structure. The second is that the heating is concentrated at the interfaces of the conducting particles.

Authors: Neri J.M., Boller J.R., Commisso R.J., Hinshelwood D.D., Ottinger P.F., Weber B.V., Young F.C.
Title: PHYSICS OF HIGH POWER OPERATION OF THE PLASMA EROSION OPENING SWITCH.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Neri, J.M., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Boller, J.R., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Commisso, R.J., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Hinshelwood, D.D., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Ottinger, P.F., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Weber, B.V., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Young, F.C., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The operation and performance of the plasma erosion opening switch (PEOS) are described. The switch has demonstrated the ability to compress the output pulse of a capacitively-based pulsed-power generator, resulting in a pulse whose voltage and power simultaneously exceed the matched load values by factors greater than 2. Experiments on the Gamble II generator have demonstrated simultaneous voltage gain of 2. 7 (4. 6 MV) and power gain of 2. 4 (3. 5 TW) over the ideal matched load values (1. 7 MV, 1. 46 TW). This is accomplished by inductive energy storage, where a vacuum inductor shunted by the PEOS is located between the generator and the load. Energy from the initial portion of the generator pulse is stored in the vacuum inductor, with the PEOS closed. The PEOS then opens swiftly ( less than 10 ns), delivering the inductively-stored energy and the balance of the generator pulse to the load. The coupling of the PEOS to the load is also critical in obtaining voltage and power gain.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INDUCTORS; ELECTRIC SWITCHES - Performance; HIGH POWER OPERATION; OPENING SWITCH; PLASMA EROSION; PULSED-POWER GENERATOR; VACUUM INDUCTOR; PLASMA DEVICES

Authors: Brown G., Cerino J., Hofmann A., Liu R., Troxel T., Wang P., Wiedemann H., Winick H., Berndt M., Brown R., Christensen J., Donald M., Graham B., Gray R., Guerra E.
Title: OPERATION OF PEP IN A LOW EMITTANCE MODE.
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Brown, G., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Cerino, J., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Hofmann, A., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Liu, R., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Troxel, T., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Wang, P., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Wiedemann, H., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Winick, H., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Berndt, M., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Brown, R., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Christensen, J., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Donald, M., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Graham, B., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Gray, R., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA; Guerra, E., Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA
Abstract: The possibility of using the PEP storage ring in a dedicated mode for synchrotron radiation is considered. PEP has been operated at 8 GeV where the uncoupled beam emittance is 27 nm-rad. Since a lower beam energy is now required, the optics have been modified to reduce the emittance further. In a brief run at 8 GeV a beam was successfully injected and accumulated. The horizontal and vertical emittances were measured using the photon beam of the 58-m long undulator beam line and found to be 12. 1 and 1. 2 nm-rad. This is close to the expected value of 9. 9 nm-rad for the sum of the two. The beam lifetime was over 30 h at low currents. Methods for reducing this emittance even further are investigated. Increasing the horizontal damping partition from one to two is seen as most promising, does not require new hardware, and can be achieved with a small increase of the RF-frequency of about 4 kHz. Such an operation mode has been computed and tracked. The dynamic acceptance is very large and the expected uncoupled emittance is 4. 3 nm-rad at 8 GeV.
Index Keywords: PHOTONS; X-RAYS; LOW EMITTANCE MODE; PEP STORAGE RING; PHOTON BEAM PROFILE; UNDULATOR SPECTRUM; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Abstract: The Tevatron collider energy is held constant at 150 GeV for some time while proton and antiproton bunches are injected prior to acceleration and storage. Under these conditions the machine chromaticity has been observed to change by as much as 70 units over the course of several hours. The data are consistent with a decay of the sextupole component of the 774 superconducting dipoles in the ring. Measurements of individual magnets in the Magnet Test Facility show similar behavior. An operating procedure that gives a satisfactory beam lifetime has been devised to compensate for the chromaticity changes.

Title: HEAT TRANSFER IN HYDRAULIC FRACTURING.
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, (Paper) SPE
Affiliations: Meyer & Associates Inc, Meyer & Associates Inc
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, B.R., Meyer & Associates Inc, Meyer & Associates Inc
Abstract: An analytical heat transfer model is presented for the combined convection along a vertical fracture with conduction and convection in the reservoir. The model couples the energy (heat transfer) and fracture propagation equations resulting in a closed form integral dimensionless temperature solution. Major model enhancements include incorporation of the following mechanisms: 1) a finite film coefficient, 2) time dependent fracture temperature for calculating the instantaneous heat flux, 3) energy storage in the fracture and 4) coupled energy and fracture propagation equations. The introduction of a power-law Nusselt number to determine the convection film coefficient is also new and unique. The influence of fluid leak-off and a finite convection film coefficient as heat reduction mechanisms is discussed. The effect of energy storage and a time dependent fracture temperature on the heat transfer rate is also illustrated.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; CLOSED FORM TEMPERATURE SOLUTION; FINITE FILM COEFFICIENT; FRACTURE PROPAGATION; VERTICAL FRACTURE; OIL WELLS

Abstract: A reactive sputtering technique was used for the preparation of Ta//2O//5 films on Si substrates. The films were found to produce results either comparable or superior to the best results reported in the literature in breakdown field strength, dielectric constant, and/or leakage current. Thermal oxidation of the Ta//2O//5 film resulted in the growth of SiO//2 under Ta//2O//5. The electrical characteristics of the oxidized film were close to pure SiO//2 with an advantage of 20% higher storage charge density. From underlying silicon oxidation kinetics, an activation energy of 0. 9 eV was found for the oxygen diffusion in Ta//2O//5 film has shown potential for applications in advanced dynamic RAMs.

Title: SIZE EFFECT OF ION CHARGE TRACKS ON SINGLE EVENT MULTIPLE-BIT UPSET.
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Martin, R.C., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Ghoniem, N.M., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Song, Y., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Cable, J.S., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: Double-bit upset rates in satellite memory cells as high as several percent of total upsets have recently been reported. This significant fraction may be explained by cosmic ion track sizes which are larger than previously postulated. Generation and transport of high-energy secondary electrons along heavy-ion tracks have been analyzed using the Monte Carlo (MC) code TRIPOS-E. Indications are that initial track radii are significantly larger than previously thought. An evaluation of the probability of double-bit upsets as a function of track size and hypothetical device dimensions is presented.
