Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC/DIESEL HYBRID SYSTEMS: THE DESIGN PROCESS.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, Gary J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Chapman, N., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: A photovoltaic/storage system by itself may be uneconomical for stand-alone applications with large energy demands. However, by combining the PV system with a back-up energy source, such as a diesel, gasoline, or propane/thermoelectric generator, system economics can be improved. Such PV/fossil hybrid systems are being used, but their design has required detailed modeling to determine the optimal mix of photovoltaics and back-up energy. Recent data on diesel field reliability and a design technique for stand-alone systems are reported that have overcome this problem. The approach provides the means for sizing the photovoltaic system to obtain a near-optimal hybrid system, with about a 90% savings in back-up fuel costs. System economics are determined by comparing PV capital cost to the present value of the displaced diesel operation and maintenance costs.
Index Keywords: DIESEL ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; NEAR-OPTIMAL HYBRID SYSTEM; PHOTOVOLTAIC/DIESEL HYBRID SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC/STORAGE SYSTEM; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: INTERNATIONAL APPROACHES TO SPENT FUEL AND WASTE MANAGEMENT.
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institu
Authors with affiliations: Stephany, M.
Abstract: Many people consider spent fuel today as just another form of nuclear waste to be disposed of directly. That, however, seems to be the wrong conclusion: the cost of reprocessing and plutonium fabrication may well fall and the price of enriched uranium may and probably will rise substantially in the future; political scenarios may well change again. The rational route to take, therefore, is to store all the spent fuel that is not to be processed on an intermediate basis. To leave the spent fuel in an intermediate storage facility until such time as a final judgement can be made on whether it is only waste, or whether its contained fissionable fuel is worth recovering, appears to be logical and this is what will happen to the bulk of the spent fuel coming out of reactors up to the end of this century.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - International Cooperation; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Management; INTERMEDIATE STORAGE; PLUTONIUM FABRICATION; REPROCESSING; WASTE MANAGEMENT; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS WITH PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL STORAGE.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jawadi, Z., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Winn, C.B., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to develop a design method to determine the long term thermal performance of a passive solar heating system with phase change material (PCM) storage. The thermal performance of the enclosure, based on a 'linearized' model of the PCM storage, is determined using Frequency Domain methods. The nonlinearity due to the time varying phase state is incorporated by defining a Switching Function. The accuracy of the analytical model is evaluated by comparing its results with numerical simulation results.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Mathematical Models; PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEM; PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL; SOLAR SAVINGS FRACTION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: LICENSING AND OPERATION EXPERIENCES IN INCINERATION OF LOW LEVEL RADWASTE IN TAIWAN, R. O. C.
Affiliations: Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan, Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Tsai, C.M., Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan, Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan; Liu, D.S., Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan, Atomic Energy Council, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: Taiwan is a densely populated island with six nuclear power units in operation. Rising radwaste generation rates and limited storage space make the waste incineration a very attractive choice to reduce the waste volume effectively. Radwaste Administration (RWA), under Atomic Energy Council (AEC) is responsible for licensing and inspection of radioactive waste incineration installations. Regulations of Radwaste incineration installations were promulgated by Atomic Energy Council to encourage waste generators to apply to AEC for a license or construction permit. The Regulations mandate that for an incinerator installed inside a nuclear power plant's site boundary, the annual maximum individual dose at the nearest residence resulting from the operation of the incinerator and the reactor together should not exceed 50 mRem per reactor site.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS - Radiation Protection; REFUSE INCINERATORS; ATOMIC ENERGY COUNCIL; OPERATING CERTIFICATE; RADWASTE ADMINISTRATION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: BATTERY DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING AT ESA.
Affiliations: ESA, ESA
Authors with affiliations: Verniolle, Jean, ESA, ESA
Abstract: The principal activities of the Energy Storage Section of the Space Research & Technology Center (ESTEC) of the European Space Agency are presented. Nickel-hydrogen and fuel cell systems development are reported. The European Space Battery Test Center (ESBTC) facilities are briefly described along with the current test programs and results obtained.
Index Keywords: FUEL CELLS - Testing; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; NICKEL COMPOUNDS; FUEL CELL SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENT; NICKEL-HYDROGEN; TEST PROGRAMS; SPACECRAFT

Title: THERMODYNAMIC MECHANISM FOR BUNCH LENGTHENING.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meller, R.E., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: A thermodynamic mechanism for bunch lengthening in electron storage rings is described, with the synchrotron radiation playing the role of a heat bath. The steady state of the bunch is determined by the minimum of the free energy, of which the potential energy of bunch displacement is a key part. The result is that bunch oscillation becomes thermodynamically favored when the parasitic losses have displaced the bunch by approximately one rms width from its zero current equilibrium location. This phenomenon is independent of the synchrotron tune shifts and unrelated to the mechanical instabilities predicted by the linearized Vlasov equation. The threshold scaling shows that thermodynamic bunch lengthening dominates for short bunches, and a detailed calculation using the power-law impedance shows that this is the probable mechanism for the bunch lengthening in SPEAR II.
Index Keywords: PARTICLE BEAMS - Thermodynamics; ELECTRON STORAGE RINGS; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; THERMODYNAMIC BUNCH LENGTHENING; ACCELERATORS

Title: THERMAL STORAGE WITH EMS CONTROL - AN IN-HOUSE APPLICATION.
Authors with affiliations: Herro, M.J.; Roach, R.
Abstract: This paper will describe an in-house application of ice thermal storage controlled by a centralized energy management system. The combined system is installed and operating in the newly remodeled Trane Company's Technology Center in La Crosse, Wisconsin. The paper will begin by giving an overview of the building and its energy management system. A description of the thermal ice system layouts will be followed by a discussion of the basic design considerations. Various aspects of the three thermal storage operating conditions will then be presented, with an emphasis on energy management control sequences. Finally, a description of other energy management features implemented at the Technology Center will be reviewed.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING; ENERGY MANAGEMENT; HOUSES - Climate Control; AIR HANDLING; CHILLERS; ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM; ICE STORAGE SYSTEM; THERMAL STORAGE; ICE

Title: SHIELDING DESIGN FOR THE PROPOSED ADVANCED PHOTON SOURCE AT ARGONNE.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Moe, H.J., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; Veluri, V.R., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: The design of bulk shielding for two linacs, the positron converter, booster synchrotron, and the storage ring is described. The shielding design limits exposure to 20 mrem/wk for occupational and 25 mrem/yr for an individual member of the public from radiation products that include high-energy neutrons, giant resonance neutrons, and bremsstrahlung radiation. The beam-loss parameters at various components were estimated, and dose rates were computed for continuous loss during beam decay using an empirical method. Normal operational losses and certain accidental beam losses were also considered.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, LINEAR; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; NEUTRONS; PHOTONS - Sources; RADIATION PROTECTION - Design; ADVANCED PHOTON SOURCE SHIELDING; BREMSSTRAHLUNG RADIATION; BULK SHIELDING FORMULAE; GIANT RESONANCE NEUTRONS; HIGH-ENERGY NEUTRONS; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Kupschus P., Bailey W., Gadeberg M., Hedley L., Twynam P., Szabo T., Evans D.
Title: JET MULTI-PELLET INJECTOR LAUNCHER-MACHINE INTERFACE.
Affiliations: JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Kupschus, P., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Bailey, W., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Gadeberg, M., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Hedley, L., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Twynam, P., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Szabo, T., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Evans, D., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl
Abstract: The machine-launcher interface of a three-barrel repetitive pneumatic pellet launcher is discussed. The interface is designed to meet future requirements of JET (Joint European Torus). It will allow the attachment of the high-speed pellet launchers now under development as well as remote handling and tritium operation. This discussion covers: the vacuum interface; liquid helium supply and intermediate storage; the primary fuel and propellant gas supply; pellet trajectory and pellet diagnostics; and the control and data acquisition interface.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Fusion; JOINT EUROPEAN TORUS (JET); MACHINE-LAUNCHER INTERFACE; PELLET INJECTOR; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Authors: Bandopadhyay S., Chatterjee J.K., Tripathy S.C.
Title: SOME ASPECTS STABILITY IMPROVEMENT DUE TO MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE IN POWER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India): Electrical Engineering Division
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Bandopadhyay, S., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Chatterjee, J.K., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Tripathy, S.C., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: Following sudden increase of load in a power system, frequency and tie line power oscillations occur because the immediate requirement of power comes from the kinetic energy of the generator rotor till the governor comes into action and adjusts the output. Till to date the approach of power engineers towards this problem has been to find the best way of controlling the governors so that the oscillations and maximum deviation can be brought to a minimum. A parallel approach has been developed recently which points out that the crux of the problem lies in the fact that the only storage capacity a power system has is in the inertia of the generator rotors. It also suggests that the situation can be improved by employing fast acting energy storage devices which can share the sudden requirement of power. Magnetic energy storage seems to be the most suitable for this purpose.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC LINES - Stability; MAGNETISM; MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; STORAGE CAPACITY; TIE LINE POWER OSCILLATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE CMOS PLDs AND APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wong, David K., Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA; Saffari, Bobby, Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA, Signetics Corp, Sunnyvale, CA, USA
Abstract: One of the advantages of CMOS technology is that circuits can be designed to dissipate very little energy when idle, which reduces the over-all power consumption of the entire circuit. With the advancement of wafer-fab technology which is producing smaller and smaller geometry, circuit designers now can pack more functions in a chip without exceeding the power-density limits imposed by the packaging technology. At the same time the speed performance is kept at a reasonable level. The 27HC641, a high speed 8Kx8 CMOS EPROM, and the PLC473, a CMOS UV Erasable Programmable Logic Device, are CMOS devices which lead to the next generation of high density, high performance programmable logic devices. This paper discusses the performances and applications of these two devices as well as some of their features.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Fixed; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS; LOGIC CIRCUITS - Electric Power; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOS - Applications; COMPLEMENTARY MOS (CMOS); ERASABLE PROGRAMMABLE ROM (EPROM); PROGRAMMABLE LOGIC DEVICES (PLD); READ ONLY MEMORY; ULTRAVIOLET (UV) ERASABLE PLD (EPLD); LOGIC DEVICES

Authors: Buchner S.P., Wilson D., Kang K., Gill D., Mazer J.A., Raburn W.D., Campbell A.B., Knudson A.R.
Title: LASER SIMULATION OF SINGLE EVENT UPSETS.
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Buchner, S.P., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Wilson, D., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Kang, K., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Gill, D., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Mazer, J.A., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Raburn, W.D., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Campbell, A.B., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA; Knudson, A.R., Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Martin Marietta Lab, Baltimore, MD, USA
Abstract: A pulsed picosecond laser was used to produce upsets in both a commercial bipolar logic circuit and a specially designed CMOS static RAM test structure. A comparison of the laser energy necessary for producing upsets in transistors that have different upset sensitivities with the single-event upset (SEU) level predicted from circuit analysis showed that a picosecond laser could measure circuit sensitivity to SEUs. The technique makes it possible not only to test circuits rapidly for upset sensitivity but also, because the beam can be focused down to a small spot size, to identify sensitive transistors.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Radiation Effects; LASER BEAMS - Effects; LOGIC CIRCUITS - Radiation Effects; BIPOLAR LOGIC CIRCUIT; CMOS SRAM; LASER SIMULATED SEU; SINGLE EVENT UPSETS (SEU); SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, BIPOLAR

Authors: Piszczor Jr. Michael F., O'Neill Mark J.
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF AN ADVANCED PHOTOVOLTAIC CONCENTRATOR SYSTEM FOR SPACE APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Piszczor Jr., Michael F., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; O'Neill, Mark J., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The advanced Photovoltaic Concentrator Program is an effort to take advantage of recent advancements in refractive optical elements. By using a domed Fresnel lens concentrator and a prismatic cell cover, to eliminate metalization losses, dramatic reductions in the required area and mass over current space photovoltaic systems are possible. The advanced concentrator concept also has significant advantages when compared to solar dynamic Organic Rankine Cycle power systems in Low Earth Orbit applications where energy storage is required. The program is currently involved in the selection of a material for the optical element that will survive the space environment and a demonstration of the system performance of the panel design.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY - Space Applications; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; ADVANCED PHOTOVOLTAIC CONCENTRATOR; SPACE POWER; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Kashiwagi T., Itoh S., Kurosaki Y., Hirose S.
Title: EFFECTS OF THE NATURAL CONVECTION IN A PARTIALLY SUPERCOOLED WATER CELL ON THE RELEASE OF SUPERCOOLING.
Affiliations: Tokyo Univ of Agriculture &, Technology, Jpn, Tokyo Univ of Agriculture & Technology, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kashiwagi, T., Tokyo Univ of Agriculture &, Technology, Jpn, Tokyo Univ of Agriculture & Technology, Jpn; Itoh, S., Tokyo Univ of Agriculture &, Technology, Jpn, Tokyo Univ of Agriculture & Technology, Jpn; Kurosaki, Y., Tokyo Univ of Agriculture &, Technology, Jpn, Tokyo Univ of Agriculture & Technology, Jpn; Hirose, S., Tokyo Univ of Agriculture &, Technology, Jpn, Tokyo Univ of Agriculture & Technology, Jpn
Abstract: The concept of using ice for a thermal storage system recently has attracted attention from those interested in developing more compact reservoirs for thermal storage. The flow and heat transfer characteristics of pooled water with a supercooled region were studied experimentally using a real-time holographic interferometry technique. Pure water in a rectangular container was initially at room temperature (293 K) and was cooled on top or bottom until the release of supercooling. The time-dependent sequential flow patterns and heat transfer of natural convection were obtained for cases where cooling is affected both below and above, using various heights for the test container. The factors affecting the release of supercooling were also investigated, taking into full consideration the influences of cooling wall conditions, the degree of supercooling, and the heat transfer characteristics evaluated by Nusselt numbers. As a result, it is determined that the turbulence induced by the bulk convective flow is highly important, in addition to the existence of bulk flow.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Turbulent; HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; ICE - Manufacture; INTERFEROMETRY, HOLOGRAPHIC; HOLOGRAPHIC INTERFEROMETRY; NATURAL CONVECTION; SUPERCOOLED WATER CELL; THERMAL STORAGE; REFRIGERATION

Authors: Lacy Dovie E., Coles-Hamilton Carolyn, Juhasz Albert
Title: SELECTION OF HIGH TEMPERATURE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE MATERIALS FOR ADVANCED SOLAR DYNAMIC SPACE POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lacy, Dovie E., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Coles-Hamilton, Carolyn, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Juhasz, Albert, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The NASA Lewis Research Center has initiated an in-house thermal energy storage program to identify combinations of phase change thermal energy storage media for use with a Brayton and Stirling Advanced Solar Dynamic (ASD) space power system operating between 1070 and 1400 K. A study has been initiated to determine suitable combinations of thermal energy storage (TES) phase change materials (PCM) that result in the smallest and lightest weight ASD power system possible. To date the heats of fusion of several fluoride salt mixtures with melting points greater than 1025 K have been verified experimentally. The study has indicated that these salt systems produce large ASD systems because of their inherent low thermal conductivity and low density.
Index Keywords: AIR ENGINES; DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ADVANCED SOLAR DYNAMIC (ASD) SPACE POWER SYSTEM; BRAYTON CYCLE SYSTEM; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS (PCM); SOLAR DYNAMICS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES); ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Fujiwara Kenichiro, Hoft Richard G., Nomura Hiroshi
Title: SERIES-CONNECTED BRIDGE CONVERTERS.
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fujiwara, Kenichiro, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA; Hoft, Richard G., Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA; Nomura, Hiroshi, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA
Abstract: Line-commutated fully controlled thyristor converters are used in high-power applications for dc or ac motor drive systems and are being investigated for application to superconducting energy storage systems because of their high reliability and low cost. However, they have inherent disadvantages such as high reactive power demand from the ac line and high ripple factor in the dc output voltage at low output voltage. A novel circuit topology is studied for unequal ac input voltage in the series connection for each unit converter to improve input and output characteristics. Analytical and experimental results are shown to explain significant improvement in the input power factor and in the ripple factor of the output voltage at reduced output voltage.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS - Electric Drive; ELECTRIC POWER FACTOR; THYRISTORS; OUTPUT VOLTAGE RIPPLE FACTOR; SERIES-CONNECTED BRIDGE CONVERTERS; SUPERCONDUCTING ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Authors: Van Dine Leslie, Gonzalez-Sanabria Olga, Levy Alexander
Title: REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL STUDY FOR SATELLITES IN GEO ORBIT.
Affiliations: Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT,, USA, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Van Dine, Leslie, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT,, USA, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT, USA; Gonzalez-Sanabria, Olga, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT,, USA, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT, USA; Levy, Alexander, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT,, USA, Int Fuel Cells, South Windsor, CT, USA
Abstract: This paper summarizes the results of a 12-month study to identify high-performance regenerative hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell concepts for geosynchronous satellite application. Emphasis was placed on concepts with the potential for high energy density (watt-hours/lb) and passive means for water and heat management to maximize system reliability. Both polymer membrane and alkaline electrolyte fuel cells were considered, with emphasis on the alkaline cell because of its high performance, advanced state of development and proven ability to operate in a launch and space environment. Three alkaline system concepts were studied.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; FUEL CELLS - Space Applications; ALKALINE ELECTROLYTE FUEL CELLS; GEOSYNCHRONOUS SATELLITES; HYDROGEN-OXYGEN FUEL CELLS; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELLS; SATELLITES

Authors: Trewin R.R., Langdon F.M., Nelson R.M., Pate M.B.
Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF A MULTIPURPOSE COMMERCIAL BUILDING WITH THREE DIFFERENT HEATING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Trewin, R.R., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Langdon, F.M., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Nelson, R.M., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA; Pate, M.B., Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ, Ames, IA, USA
Abstract: A commercial building with three distinct zones, each having different heating equipment, was monitored for two heating seasons using a computerized data acquisition system. An analysis of the thermal performance of both the building envelope and the heating equipment was performed. The office area was heated by a heat pump with an auxiliary backup furnace; the warehouse area used off-peak thermal-electric storage units; the garage area heating load was met by a gas-fired radiant system. The microcomputer-based data acquisition system obtained and stored hourly temperatures, humidities, and energy flows. The zone loads and equipment energy consumption and performance were calculated. Variable-base degree-days were computed for each zone, and it was observed that standard-based (65 F) degree-days could be in error by a factor of two. It is shown that the use of an incorrect base temperature for the degree-day calculations could result in overestimation of degree-days by a factor of two.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Heating; THERMAL VARIABLES MEASUREMENT; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; COMPUTERIZED DATA ACQUISITION; DEGREE-DAY BASE TEMPERATURES; THERMAL PERFORMANCE; HEATING

Title: MEASUREMENT OF THE EFFECTIVE THERMAL DIFFUSIVITY OF A WATER-SOIL POROUS MEDIUM SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA, Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wong, Kau-Fui Vincent, Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA, Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA
Abstract: The objective of this work is to establish a method of determining the effective thermal diffusivity of a water-soil porous medium system. In comparing the results for the three types of soil, it is noted that the times to reach steady state is about the same for the commercial gravel and the Hallandale fine sand. The Plantation muck took the longest to reach steady state. This is physically realistic as one would expect the effective thermal diffusivity of the Plantation muck to have the least value of the three.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; POROUS MATERIALS - Heat Transfer; SOILS - Heat Transfer; EARTH THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY TRANSPORT IN SOIL; THERMAL DIFFUSIVITY; WATER-SOIL POROUS MEDIUM SYSTEM; SOILS

Title: TRANSIENT BEHAVIOR OF A SOLAR GRAIN DRYING SYSTEM WITH PEBBLE-BED ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED

Abstract: A mathematical model is developed to determine the dynamic characteristics of a solar drying system equipped with a pebble-bed energy storage unit. An application is demonstrated in the drying of cereals. The effects of air velocity and heat transfer coefficient on the temperatures are determined. The study can be utilized to determine an optimum combination of drying air temperature and air flow rate for an efficient and economic operation of the solar drying system.

Authors: Sen M., Best R., Pilatowsky I.
Title: Thermal degasification of ammonia in a porous generator
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, 46556, IN, United States; Laboratorio de Energía Solar, Instituto de Investigaciones en Materiales, U.N.A.M., Temixco, Mor., 62580, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Sen, M., Department of Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, 46556, IN, United States; Best, R., Laboratorio de Energía Solar, Instituto de Investigaciones en Materiales, U.N.A.M., Temixco, Mor., 62580, Mexico; Pilatowsky, I., Laboratorio de Energía Solar, Instituto de Investigaciones en Materiales, U.N.A.M., Temixco, Mor., 62580, Mexico
Abstract: Solid generators are often used in mechanically simple refrigeration systems and thermochemical energy storage devices. In this work we analyze the heat and mass transfer associated with the desorption of ammonia in calcium chloride ammoniate due to the application of heat. The ammoniate is in solid phase in the form of a porous matrix and the ammonia gas that is generated by the degasification filters through it due to the pressure gradient generated by the degasification. Assuming chemical equilibrium between reactants and products, as well as Darcy's law for flow through porous media, a simplified model of the process is developed. A strongly nonlinear diffusion equation is obtained under a constant specific heat and molecular mass approximation. Numerical solutions of this diffusion equation for a semi-infinite slab are examined. Qualitative information has been obtained on the kind of heating that is desirable. © 1987 Martinus Nijhoff Publishers.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Porous Materials; GASES - Heat Transfer; MASS TRANSFER; CALCIUM CHLORIDE; DARCY'S LAW; POROUS GENERATOR; SOLID GENERATORS; THERMAL DEGASIFICATION; AMMONIA

Title: CONTROL AND MEASURED PERFORMANCE OF A PASSIVE OFF-PEAK STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Picard, P., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Winn, C.Byron, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Abstract: The energy consumption in two similar townhouses was monitored over the 1985-86 heating season to gain field experience with the concept of passive off-peak storage. In one of these all-electric passive solar residences, the constant off-peak charge of a brick wall by embedded electrical wires provided a base load while the comfort requirements were by conventional convectors. The second building was used as a reference building and had an identical mass wall but without the embedded electrical wires. Two separate analyses for similar very cold weather showed for the wired house a 10 to 40% reduction in baseboard energy consumption during the on-peak period and a 30 to 80% reduction in baseboard energy consumption during the high demand hours of the day. From December to February the storage accounted for 46 to 79% of the average daily heating load of the test units.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Control Systems; ALL-ELECTRIC PASSIVE SOLAR RESIDENCES; PASSIVE OFF-PEAK STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Tung T.P., Clark R.H., Cole J.
Title: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM ON SMALL SCALE AND LOW HEAD HYDRO BY THE CANADIAN GOVERNMENT.
Affiliations: Dep of Energy, Mines &, Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Dep of Energy, Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Tung, T.P., Dep of Energy, Mines &, Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Dep of Energy, Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Clark, R.H., Dep of Energy, Mines &, Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Dep of Energy, Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Cole, J., Dep of Energy, Mines &, Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Dep of Energy, Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: In July 1985 the Canadian Department of Energy, Mines and Resources (EMR) was assigned the responsibility for the federal support program for renewable energy R&D in Canada. In 1986, 14 R&D cost sharing contracts were awarded through a Request for Proposal (RFP) process. In 1987, another 15 projects have been approved. This paper describes the technical aspects and the status of those projects recently completed or on-going, such as: syphon intake geometry and submergence laboratory tests which have been carried out; research on flowthrough rockfill dams and spillways, now underway; a 5 kW Darrieus type vertical axis hydro turbine installed on the back of a fibre-glass boat is being field tested.

Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE SOLID OXIDE REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL FOR SOLAR PHOTOVOLTAIC ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bents, David J., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: This paper describes a hydrogen-oxygen regenerative fuel cell (RFC) energy storage system based on high-temperature solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) technology. The reactants are stored as gases in lightweight insulated pressure vessels. The product water is stored as a liquid in saturated equilibrium with the fuel gas. The system functions as a secondary battery and is applicable to darkside energy storage for solar photovoltaics. The system design, its component parts and their arrangement is presented. Forward and reverse operating cycles are described.
Index Keywords: OXIDES; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; SPACECRAFT - Fuel Cells; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELLS; SOLID OXIDE FUEL CELLS; SPACE POWER; FUEL CELLS

Abstract: A procedure is suggested for calculating the heating capacity of a solar unit and the temperature of the heat-transfer medium entering the consuming equipment, on the basis of averaged climatic, operating, and other factors.

Title: SPECULATIONS ON FUTURE OPPORTUNITIES TO EVOLVE BRAYTON POWERPLANTS ABOARD THE SPACE STATION.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: English, Robert E., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Although both Rankine and Brayton cycles, two concepts for solar-dynamic power generation, now compete to power the Space Station, this paper confines its attention to the Brayton cycle using a mixture of He and Xe as its working fluid. Such a Brayton powerplant to supply the Station's increasing demands for both electric power and heat has the potential to gradually evolve higher and higher performance by exploiting already-evolved materials (ASTAR-811C and molten-Li heat storage), its peak cycle temperature rising ultimately to 1500 K. Adapting the Station to exploit long tethers (200 to 300 km long) could yield large increases in payloads to LEO, to GEO, and to distant destinations in the solar system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Space Applications; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Space Applications; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Space Applications; BRAYTON CYCLE; SOLAR-DYNAMIC POWER GENERATION; SPACE POWER GENERATION; SPACE STATION; SATELLITES

Title: INVESTIGATION OF HEMISPHERICAL RESONATOR FOR AN ENERGY STORE.

Authors with affiliations: Avgustinovich, V.A.; Avgustinovich, L.Ya.; Artemenko, S.N.; Yushkov, Yu.G.
Abstract: High-power microwave pulses can be generated by the slow storage of energy in a resonant cavity, and the subsequent discharge of this energy in a time interval much less than the storage time. The amplitude of the radio pulse obtained depends on the volume of the cavity, its Q, the stored energy density, and the nature of the operation of the switching device. The simplest method of increasing the level of stored energy in the resonant system is to increase its volume while simultaneously choosing the optimum geometry. We give some results of an investigation of a superdimensional hemispherical copper resonator for the purpose of using it as an energy store when generating microwave pulses.
Index Keywords: ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; WAVEGUIDE COMPONENTS - Junctions; HEMISPHERICAL RESONATOR; MICROWAVE PULSES; RESONATORS, CAVITY

Title: EFFECT OF COMPONENT COMPRESSION ON THE INITIAL PERFORMANCE OF AN IPV NICKEL-HYDROGEN CELL.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gahn, Randall F., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: An experimental method was developed for evaluating the effect of component compression on the charge and discharge voltage characteristics of a 3 one-half in. diameter boiler plate cell. A standard boiler plate pressure vessel was modified by the addition of a mechanical feedthrough on the bottom of the vessel which permitted different compressions to be applied to the components without disturbing the integrity of the stack. Compression loadings from 0. 94 to 27. 4 psi were applied by suspending weights from the feedthrough rod. Cell voltages were measured for 0. 96-C, 55-min charge and for 1. 37-C, 35-min and 2-C, 24-min discharges. An initial change in voltage performance on both charge and discharge as the loading increased was attributed to seating of the components.

Title: Nutrient balance: New insights into obesity
Affiliations: Section of Diabetes and Clinical Nutrition, University of Southern California, USC School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA 90033, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bray, G.A., Section of Diabetes and Clinical Nutrition, University of Southern California, USC School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA 90033, United States
Abstract: This overview of nutrient balance suggests the following general conclusions. Nutrient balance is in part regulated by the two limbs of the autonomic nervous system. Hypothalamic and genetic obesity are associated with lower levels of sympathetic activity. Conversely the reduced weight of animals with lateral hypothalamic lesions is associated with increased sympathetic activity. Thus the activity of the sympathetic nervous system appears to be inversely related to energy stores. The levels of hormones such as insulin, adrenal steroids, gonadal steroids and growth hormone play an important role in modulating nutrient intake and storage. The data seem to fit the hypothesis that nutrient stores are regulated systems with afferent feedback systems acting on a central controller which regulates intake, storage and metabolism of nutrients through modulation of the autonomic nervous system and motor control of food seeking.
Index Keywords: autonomic nervous system; heredity; human; hypothalamus; metabolism; nutrient; obesity; short survey; Human; Nutrition; Obesity; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Abstract: Thermal characterization of structural materials, such as concrete, rock, and sand, plays a primary role in problems related to energy generation, transmission, and storage, as well as power plant safety and energy conservation. The principles of the two-linear-parallel-probe method for measuring thermal diffusivity and thermal conductivity of such materials are described with details of the experimental configuration and the data acquisition system. To test this equipment tests were carried out on Pyrex, PTFE, and concrete, and the results obtained were compared with the results obtained in other laboratories to demonstrate the accuracy of the method. A systematic set of measurements on concrete samples was statistically evaluated to assess the reliability of the method and of the related devices when applied to materials which are not quite homogeneous.

Abstract: Horizontal flow packed beds have been charged whilst losing energy from the top sealed surface. The forms of the resulting fluid flows were inferred from a matrix of temperature sensors in the beds. When the beds reached the steady state, the inferred flow took the form of two helicoids along the beds situated symmetrically about the central plane. A one-dimensional model was able to predict the transient mean temperatures on planes normal to the mean forced flow. Restrictive inlets to the beds produced a complex interaction between the forced and natural convections.

Abstract: The Thermally Stimulated Current (TSC) spectra of a series of Sub-T//g annealed polyethylene terephthalate (PET) specimens have been measured. It is found that there is only one peak at 80 degree C above room temperature, which related to the thermo-relaxation of frozen-in dipoles. The activation energy of such dipole motion has been calculated. The relation between the maximum current and the storage time can be explained by the free volume theory and agrees with the results from the excess thermodynamic properties. Compared with differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) and tensile stress-strain method, TSC is a simpler and more sensitive method in studying Sub-T//g annealed polymers.

Authors with affiliations: Teji, D.S.; Balon, R.J.
Abstract: In 1985 the City of Phoenix received federal grant money to perform applied research in thermal storage. The research, as reported in this paper, completed four primary tasks: (1) A review of the state of the art in thermal storage technology; (2) A survey of municipal buildings to assess thermal storage opportunities and select a demonstration site; (3) Design and installation of a demonstration system; and (4) Monitoring and payback analysis of the demonstration system.

Authors: Goodwin James M., Rosen Bruce E., Vidal Jacques J.
Title: DESIGN FOR AN ASSOCIATIVE SPIN GLASS PROCESSOR.
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goodwin, James M., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Rosen, Bruce E., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Vidal, Jacques J., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: A physical implementation of a spin glass processor is proposed. Implicit in the design is capability for associative memory, fast associative access, and massive information storage. It is based primarily on implementation of ideas from the Boltzmann machine. An amorphous magnetic material such as a spin glass film is 'trained' with the series of pattern vectors by locally laser-heating it in the magnetic field from an imposed input pattern until the spins become mobile and then allowing the magnetic spins of the system to seek an energy minimum. Simulations show that after repeated training sessions, an energy landscape is created that effectively stores and permits retrieval of pattern vectors from a set of given inputs. The techniques needed for storage and retrieval of the patterns, which are now available from optical disk technology, are described.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; MAGNETIC MATERIALS - Amorphous; ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY; BOLTZMANN MACHINE; OPTICAL DISK; PATTERN VECTORS; SPIN GLASS PROCESSOR; OPTICAL DATA PROCESSING

Title: COMPUTER SIMULATION OF THE REFLEX SWITCH.
Affiliations: Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA, Berkeley Research Associates, Springfield, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Geary, James L., Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA, Berkeley Research Associates, Springfield, VA, USA; Ambrosiano, John J., Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA, Berkeley Research Associates, Springfield, VA, USA; Terry, Robert E., Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA, Berkeley Research Associates, Springfield, VA, USA; Pereira, N.R., Berkeley Research Associates,, Springfield, VA, USA, Berkeley Research Associates, Springfield, VA, USA
Abstract: The reflex switch is a fast-opening switch for inductive energy storage schemes with a configuration similar to the reflex triode. The basic elements are a primary cathode, a foil anode, and a secondary cathode which is electrically floating. An external magnetic field is applied in the axial direction to prevent the electron beam from modifying its radial profile. As the secondary cathode charges up, electrons reflex through the anode foil drawing a large ion current. This phase forms the high-current, low-voltage closed mode of operation. Later in time, plasma flow or some other mechanism shorts the secondary cathode to the anode. The electrons stop reflexing and travel directly to the secondary cathode beginning the opening phase. The vacuum inductance tries to maintain the current and the energy discharges into the load. When the switch fully opens, the diode is expected to exhibit bipolar flow.
Index Keywords: PLASMA DEVICES - Switching; FAST-OPENING SWITCH; INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORAGE SCHEMES; PLASMA OPENING SWITCH; REFLEX SWITCH; ELECTRIC SWITCHES

Abstract: The pulse radiolytic studies of the quadricyclane (Q)-norbornadiene (NBD) system in 3-methylpentane at temperature of 92-96 K have been reported. These studies proved the presence of two distinct radical cations Q** plus and NBD** plus . In the transient spectrum of Q determined after the pulse no absorption in the vicinity of 635 nm, characteristic for NBD** plus , has been observed. The appearance and evident growth of this absorption has been noted in millisecond time scale and has been assigned to the interconversion Q** plus yields NBD** plus .

Abstract: Now in development, the DYNASTORE computer model is the first production cost model designed to accurately represent changes in the utility daily load. By quantifying the dynamic benefits of energy storage, it highlights the significant cost savings linked with this technology.

Title: CLARIFYING ENERGY STORAGE FIELD STRUCTURE IN DYNAMIC SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Michigan State Univ, East Lansing,, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rosenberg, R.C., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing,, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, MI, USA; Beaman, J., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing,, MI, USA, Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, MI, USA
Abstract: The energy variables associated with a dynamic system can be considered as a set of candidate state variables. However, when algebraic coupling among the energy variables exists, then the associated state-space equations are implicit in form. Typically, such equations require implicit integration methods for their solution, unless the original model is modified suitably. Bond-graph models, through the use of causality techniques, allow one to indentify the existence of algebraic energy-variable coupling. The detailed nature of the coupling leads to various options for solving such problems. A modification of, and extension to, the standard sequential causality assignment procedure is given that permits the identification of the structure of energy fields.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - State Space Methods; BOND GRAPH MODELS; DYNAMIC SYSTEMS; ENERGY STORAGE FIELD STRUCTURE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: INTRODUCTION OF ELECTRONICS IN LOW-VOLTAGE METERING.
Affiliations: Electricite de France, Fr, Electricite de France, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Revelaud, G., Electricite de France, Fr, Electricite de France, Fr; Dephamp, J.C., Electricite de France, Fr, Electricite de France, Fr; Bedier, M., Electricite de France, Fr, Electricite de France, Fr
Abstract: An article published in February 1984 drew attention to the various functions which had to be perfected before electronic meters could be put into industrial production on a large scale. These functions were mainly energy metering, data storage (linked with reliability and cost of non-volatile memories), data display (linked with life length of liquid crystal). But in three years methods and know-how have developed and it seemed worthwhile to reassess the difficulties encountered by conducting industrial field experiments on an electronic meter. To this end, Electricite de France has entered into partnership with a constructor to develop the metering system described in the present paper.

Title: UNDULATOR TUNABILITY AND SYNCHROTRON RING-ENERGY.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Viccaro, P.J., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA; Shenoy, G.K., Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, IL, USA
Abstract: The photon energy of an undulator and its tunability are determined by the period of the device, the magnetic gap, and the storage-ring energy. In general, the larger the tunability range, the more useful the device. Therefore, for a given required maximum photon energy, it is desirable to find the operating conditions and device parameters that result in the largest tunability interval possible. With this in mind the authors have investigated the question of undulator tunability with emphasis on the role of the ring energy in order to find the smallest storage-ring energy consistent with the desired tunability interval and photon energy. They have included a preliminary criterion concerning the tunability requirements of the advanced photon source (APS) to be built at Argonne. The analysis is aimed at X-ray undulator sources on the APS but is applicable to any storage ring.
Index Keywords: MAGNETS; PHOTONS - Sources; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION; ADVANCED PHOTON SOURCE (APS); PHOTON ENERGY; SYNCHROTRON RING-ENERGY; UNDULATOR TUNABILITY; X-RAY UNDULATOR SOURCES; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Abstract: A description is given of the lattice design of HISTRAP (Heavy-Ion STorage Ring for Atomic Physics), a proposed 46. 8-m-circumference synchrotron-cooling-storage ring optimized to accelerate, cool, decelerate, and store beams of highly charged very-heavy ions at energies appropriate for advanced atomic physics research. Title: PHASOR NEURAL NETWORKS.
Affiliations: NIBR, Amsterdam, Neth, NIBR, Amsterdam, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Noest, Andre J., NIBR, Amsterdam, Neth, NIBR, Amsterdam, Neth
Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. The behavior of coupled networks of unit-length 2-vectors (phasors) is analyzed. The information is represented in their relative phases, and the couplings and dynamics are chosen so that learned patterns have a low energy to which the network relaxes. Results on accuracy of recall, capacity and spurious stable states in content-addressable memory applications are reported. These illustrate by a simple example the extent to which one can go beyond sigmoidal scalar signals in collective processing of information in neural networks without the need of awkward recoding of signals with rotational symmetry.

Abstract: A diagnostic neutral-beam source (DNB) has been built and installed on the Texas Experimental Tokamak (TEXT). The power supplies necessary for the 100- mu s pulsed source operation have been built and are discussed. The high-voltage power supply that uses capacitor banks for energy storage is described. Title: QUENCH PROTECTION AT HERA.
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Mess, K.H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: The Hadron-Electron-Ring Accelerator (HERA), now under construction at DESY, Hamburg, consists of a 30-GeV electron storage ring and a storage ring for protons of 820 GeV. Most of the magnets for the proton ring are superconducting. In total there are 416 horizontally and 6 vertically bending cipoles, 224 quadrupoles, and many correction magnets. The HERA quench protection system is based on cold diodes, to keep quenching magnets safe from the stored energy of all other magnets, and on a subdivision of the electrical circuit to limit the voltages. Quenches are detected by magnetic amplifiers, which sense the current in the center connection of a bridge. Almost all components can be tested even with the beam in the storage ring.
Index Keywords: AMPLIFIERS, MAGNETIC; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; HADRON-ELECTRON-RING ACCELERATOR (HERA); QUENCH DETECTION; QUENCH PROTECTION; QUENCHING MAGNETS; ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING

Authors with affiliations: Herb, S., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA; Kirchgessner, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: The Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR), a 768-m-circumference electron positron collider that operates in the 10-GeV center-of-mass energy region of the UPSILON resonances, has been modified by the insertion of strong permanent magnet quadrupoles close to the two interaction points. The additional focussing permits a reduction in the beta function at the interaction points from 3 cm to 1. 5 cm. CESR has operated with the new configuration for about one-half year. The initial operation and measurements of luminosity performance as the beta function approaches the bunch length are reported.

Title: MODELLING OF A WIND ENERGY SYSTEM WITH AN INHERENT ENERGY STORAGE MEDIUM.
Affiliations: King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Al-Shehri, Abdallah M., King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Variations in wind speed, direction, and temperature, over both time and space, make it difficult to harness any appreciable portion of a tremendous energy source, i. e. wind energy, with reasonable economic costs. Wind energy storage and transmission are the most costly aspects of wind energy systems. To circumvent this problem, it is proposed to utilize wind energy by means of wind energy systems with an inherent storage medium. One such system, used for the production of hydrogen, chlorine, and caustic soda from electrolysis of brine, is studied in this research. The proposed system is composed of a wind generator, a transformer, rectifier diodes, and electrolysis cells. An electrical equivalent model of the system that takes the variations in the system frequency and output power into account is developed. By using wind data for Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, yield of chemicals and available electrical power from the system are predicted.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SYSTEMS ANALYSIS; INHERENT ENERGY STORAGE; WIND ENERGY SYSTEM; WIND POWER; wind power system

Title: FUNDAMENTALS OF MIXING.
Affiliations: Mixing Equipment Co, Mixing Equipment Co
Authors with affiliations: DeVries, Thomas C., Mixing Equipment Co, Mixing Equipment Co
Abstract: Fluid mixing operations occur in all phases of the preparation, storage, and application of pigmented paper coatings. An understanding of mixing characteristics and the nature of mixing requirements is therefore helpful in the selection of proper equipment for each storage of coatings makeup. The process requirements are varied, but consist primarily of the blending of low- and high-viscosity fluids and the suspension of solids. The type of fluid mixing needed ranges from simple fluid flow to high-energy, intensive mixing with high shear and turbulence.

Abstract: The possibility of using high-temperature solar energy for industrial processes has prompted research in this area. In this paper, we present some recent developments in high-temperature solar thermal energy systems that have received particular attention: a liquid film, direct-absorption central receiver, high-temperature sensible heat storage, and direct-contact heating of small particles or droplets. Technical problems that warrant further research work are also identified.

Title: DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION OF THE CONVERSION/SOLIDIFICATION PROCESS FOR THE CEUSP PROJECT.
Source title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers, National Meeting
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hall, R., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Collins, E.D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Johnson, J.K., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Krichinsky, A.M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; McGinnis, C.P., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Patton, B.D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Shor, J.T., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Vedder, R.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: A uranium nitrate solution from reprocessing irradiated nuclear fuel of the Atomic Energy Commission was solidified for safe long-term storage by the Consolidated Edison Uranium Solidification Program (CEUSP). The key process steps of the program includes the following: (1) a batch evaporation to concentrate the uranium-cadmium-gadolinium nitrate solution to slightly less than the saturation concentration; (2) the use of formaldehyde in the evaporator to destroy nitric acid so that crystallization of the nitrate salts due to supersaturation would not occur; (3) the use of an in-situ thermal denitration process to convert uranium, cadmium, and gadolinium to the oxide form inside the storage cans; (4) the use of remotely operated equipment to weld lids onto the storage cans; (5) encapsulation of each can within a crimp-sealed, secondary containment canister; and (6) transfer of the finished packages to a shielded storage well.
Index Keywords: EVAPORATION; FORMALDEHYDE; INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Radioactive Materials; NUCLEAR FUELS - Reprocessing; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; CONSOLIDATED EDISON URANIUM SOLIDIFICATION PROGRAM (CEUSP); IN-SITU THERMAL DENITRATION PROCESS; INDIAN POINT-I REACTOR; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Authors: Katoh M., Honjo I., Kamiya Y.
Title: LATTICE DESIGN FOR 8 GEV SYNCHROTRON RADIATION SOURCE.

Abstract: Preliminary results are presented of a design study on a storage ring lattice intended to be the next-generation synchrotron radiation source as one of the possible future projects at KEK. The nominal beam energy is 8 GeV. The circumference of the ring is 1160 m. The lattice consists of FODO cells and 24 dispersion-free long straight sections. The emittance is 7 nm-rad. The dynamic aperture is sufficiently large for the injection and the stable storage of the beam.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; BENDING MAGNETS; CHROMATICITY CORRECTION; QUADRUPOLE MAGNETS; STORAGE RING LATTICE; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION SOURCE; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: ANALYSIS OF THERMAL STORAGE OPTIONS.
Authors with affiliations: Bechard, B.; Evans, E.A.
Abstract: A thermal storage system can be compared to a rechargeable flashlight battery. The thermal battery stores heating or cooling energy for use at a later time. The storage medium may be water, ice, eutectic salts, or other media such as rocks. The storage medium is heated or cooled (charged) during periods of low energy usage and is discharged during periods of high energy usage. The cycle is then repeated. Most thermal storage system operate on a 24-hour cycle; however, weekly or yearly cycles are not uncommon. Thermal storage systems provide a means to decouple the use of thermal energy from the thermal load being served. Thermal storage options used for chilled water storage will be analyzed in this paper.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Energy Storage; CHILLED WATER STORAGE; ENERGY SAVINGS; PEAK SHAVING; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Wubben E.A., Shapiro H.N., Nelson R.M.
Title: PRODUCTION AND STORAGE OF ICE FOR LATER USE IN RESIDENTIAL COOLING.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ Engineering Research, Inst, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ Engineering Research Inst, Ames, IA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wubben, E.A., Iowa State Univ Engineering Research, Inst, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ Engineering Research Inst, Ames, IA, USA; Shapiro, H.N., Iowa State Univ Engineering Research, Inst, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ Engineering Research Inst, Ames, IA, USA; Nelson, R.M., Iowa State Univ Engineering Research, Inst, Ames, IA, USA, Iowa State Univ Engineering Research Inst, Ames, IA, USA
Abstract: A strategy that may conserve energy and/or provide economic benefits in buildings is to use an ice production system to provide cool storage for later use when cooling is needed. A lumped parameter model of ice growth on a heat exchanger submerged in a water storage tank is described. Results of an experimental study of an ice storage system installed in a residential research facility are also presented. The results of a parametric study are also presented that show some of the effects of geometric and operating variables on system performance. Trends exhibited in the results suggest ways to optimize ice production for the particular heat exchanger geometry studied.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; ICE STORAGE SYSTEM; RESIDENTIAL COOLING; BUILDINGS

Authors: Heller D.F., Chin T.C., Morris R.C.
Title: ATHERMAL ND:BEL SLAB LASERS.
Affiliations: Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA, Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Heller, D.F., Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA, Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA; Chin, T.C., Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA, Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA; Morris, R.C., Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA, Allied Corp, Morristown, NJ, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. It is shown how a careful analysis of the stress-optic properties of Nd:La//2Be//2O//5 (Nd:BEL) permits the design and fabrication of face-pumped slab lasers that eliminate first-order thermooptical effects over an extended range of operating conditions. A major consequence of this is that very simple and inexpensive straight-through slab geometries can be used in applications that heretofore have required zigzag slab geometries. This greatly reduces slab fabrication tolerances, times, and costs, since only the slab ends need be polished to optical finishes and parallelism requirements are relaxed. Because high optical fluences no longer contact the pumped and cooled slab faces, optical damage problems are substantially alleviated; consequently, the mounting of the slab and the design of the pumping chamber are greatly simplified. In addition, optical anisotropy of Nd:BEL mitigates the effects of stress and thermally induced optical birefringence, while its strongly polarized emission and moderate emission cross section permit relatively high-energy storage and substantially reduce ASE parasitics. Recent data on the performance of athermal straight-through Nd:BEL slabs are presented. Their termal lensing, gain, and preliminary laser performance in several wavelength regions (1. 07 mu m, 1. 08 mu m, and 136 mu m) are described.
Index Keywords: LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; NEODYMIUM AND ALLOYS - Applications; OPTICAL PROPERTIES - Thermal Effects; ABSTRACT ONLY; FACE-PUMPED SLAB LASERS; OPTICAL ANISOTROPY; THERMOOPTICAL EFFECTS; TUNABLE LASERS; LASERS, SOLID STATE

Title: TRNSYS ENHANCEMENTS.
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Braun, J.E., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Beckman, W.A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: TRNSYS is a modular computer program in which models of the system components (solar collectors, pipes, storage, heat exchangers, etc. ) are written as FORTRAN subroutines. The component models can be connected to simulate a complex system in a manner analogous to the way pipes and wires connect the physical pieces of equipment. The simulation is driven by actual weather records and/or other time-dependent forcing functions such as load schedules. TRNSYS solves the set of algebraic and differential equations describing the system at each time-step. The program is designed so that the user can formulate or modify existing models and add them to the library of components. During the 12 years that the TRNSYS has been in the public domain, many equipment models have been added to the library. The program, originally developed for simulating solar energy systems, has been used to model a wide variety of systems. Its success stems from its modularity and flexibility and the quality of the documentation and support. It has been designed to operate on any computer with a FORTRAN compiler.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES - FORTRAN; MODULAR COMPUTER PROGRAM; TRNSYS PROGRAM; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: CHARACTERISTICS OF THE ROESEL MACHINE USED FOR SMALL SCALE HYDRO/WIND OR SEA WAVE ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION AND STORAGE.
Affiliations: Univ of Limerick, Limerick, Irel, Univ of Limerick, Limerick, Irel
Authors with affiliations: Levy, Dan, Univ of Limerick, Limerick, Irel, Univ of Limerick, Limerick, Irel
Abstract: An electrical machine with property of synchronous as well as asynchronous characteristics and based on ceramic magnet programming technology by continuous printing of the desired number of poles on the rotor to allow fixed output frequency independant on speed is analysed and the advantages and disadvantages of such machine for hydro/wind/sea wave generator are given. The machine has ability in particular for long inertial storage time which is useful in electric power generation from sea wave turbines with pulsating power characteristics. The rotor of the machine is normally made from ceramic magnet with no slip rings or commutators. The machine is analysed in two modes of operation, self excitation and grid excitation to feed power to the utility grid system. The machine can feed direct power to the grid without an interface, synchronization network, governor or gear ratio if the stator winding is wound properly according to the turbine requirement. The reactive power is adjustable to be 'leading' or 'lagging'.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC GENERATORS, ASYNCHRONOUS - Analysis; ELECTRIC GENERATORS, SYNCHRONOUS - Analysis; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Equipment; ENERGY STORAGE; WIND POWER; GRID EXCITATION; HYDRO/WIND/SEA WAVE GENERATOR; LONG INERTIAL STORAGE TIME; SELF EXCITATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Yunker Wayne H., Glass Robert S.
Title: LONG-TERM CORROSION BEHAVIOR OF COPPER-BASE MATERIALS IN A GAMMA-IRRADIATED ENVIRONMENT.
Affiliations: Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yunker, Wayne H., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA; Glass, Robert S., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy is evaluating the feasibility of using copper-base materials for the manufacture of nuclear waste containers. One site under consideration for geologic disposal of nuclear waste is at Yucca Mountain, Nevada. One feature of this waste repository will be the initial presence of ionizing gamma radiation at high dose rates which may alter the corrosive medium. To evaluate such effects, three copper-base materials (pure copper, 7% aluminum-copper and 30% nickel-copper) have been exposed (presently up to 14 months) to a gamma radiation field of approximately 1 multiplied by 10**5 roentgens/hr. The exposure environments have been 1) groundwater (regional to the repository site, although taken from a lower elevation) at 95 degree C; 2) the water-vapor saturated air phase above it; and 3) air/water vapor at 150 degree C. In addition to uniform corrosion, both pitting and crevice corrosion have been observed. Characterization of the corrosion layers by X-ray diffraction has shown the presence of mixed copper (I) and copper (II) oxides. Studies by Auger Electron Spectroscopy (AES) have also been conducted in order to further characterize the compositions and structures of these corrosion products.
Index Keywords: COPPER ALUMINUM ALLOYS - Corrosion; COPPER AND ALLOYS - Corrosion; COPPER NICKEL ALLOYS - Corrosion; CORROSION - Pitting; RADIATION EFFECTS; CANISTERS; CORROSION PRODUCTS; CREVICE CORROSION; NEVADA NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE INVESTIGATIONS PROJECT; SPECTROSCOPIC ANALYSIS; X-RAY DIFFRACTION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: ELECTRICITY AND DESALINATED WATER.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Swift, Andrew, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA; Reid, Robert, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA
Abstract: The El Paso Solar Pond project was initiated in July, 1983 when an existing, 3-meter deep water storage pond located at Bruce Foods Corporation in El Paso was found to be suitable for conversion to a solar pond. The 3355 m**2 El Paso Solar Pond has recently established two milestones for solar ponds in the U. S. In September, 1986, 85 degree C brine from the pond began supplying energy for the boiler of a 100 kw organic Rankine cycle (ORC) engine-generator. In June, 1987, 89 degree C brine was also supplied to a 19,000 liters/day (5000 gal/day) multi-stage desalination system.

Title: ANALYSIS AND DESIGN OF ADVANCED ENERGY SYSTEMS: APPLICATIONS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 15 papers on the analysis and design of advanced energy systems. The main topics of the conference include: process integration using pinch technology; thermodynamic analysis of power generation systems; exergetic and thermoeconomic analyses of industrial heating systems; energetic and exergetic approaches to smelting, welding, chemical, and other processes; energy storage systems; thermodynamic cycles; etc. The discussion underlines the need for steady improvement in thermal energy systems for effective energy resource utilization. To this end, thermodynamic analysis is particularly relevant, especially when aided by modern optimization and computational techniques and integrated with economic considerations encountered in engineering practice.

Abstract: The intent of this paper is to outline a forecast approach developed to enable the operation of power storage projects, and to illustrate from employing the approach that overall system performance can be improved by minimizing the spill in an expected wet year and protracting the carryover storage to maximize the firm power during an expected dry cycle.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; METEOROLOGY - Weather Forecasting; RUNOFF; STATISTICAL METHODS - Regression Analysis; CARRYOVER STORAGE; HYDROPOWER OPERATION; POWER STORAGE PROJECTS; RUNOFF FORECAST; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: CONVERTED WAVE ENERGY TRANSMISSION, STORAGE AND INTEGRATION.
Affiliations: Rykusheisha Co, Jpn, Rykusheisha Co, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Masuda, Yoshio, Rykusheisha Co, Jpn, Rykusheisha Co, Jpn; McCormick, Michael E., Rykusheisha Co, Jpn, Rykusheisha Co, Jpn
Abstract: Results of a number of full-scale studies of transmission, storage and integration of electricity resulting from wave energy conversion are discussed. These studies involved the floating system, KAIMEI, and the fixed systems at Sanze, Japan. The undersea transmission of electricity by an FRP armored cable over a period of several years was a success. After seven years exposure to salt water no alteration of the transmission capability of the cable was noted. Fluctuations in the electrical output were successfully smoothed by the flywheel effect of the turbine in conjunction with an AC-DC-AC conversion system, allowing the electricity produced by an induction generator to be transmitted to the local power grid. For smaller application of wave power, a lead-acid battery system in parallel with a Diesel-powered generator was found to be most suitable. This system of storage and integration could be used on remote islands where the power demand is relatively low. Finally, the use of dampertanks for energy smoothing was found to be ineffective.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Interconnection; ELECTRIC POWER TRANSMISSION; ENERGY STORAGE; CONVERTED WAVE ENERGY; ELECTRICAL OUTPUT SMOOTHING; INTEGRATION; JAPANESE SYSTEMS; LOCAL POWER GRID; WATER WAVES

Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)

Abstract: The article presents results of investigations on creation of an experimental unit intended for drying coarse fodder products on animal-husbandry farms. The drying unit was constructed on the animal-husbandry farm of the Khamzy kolkhoz in the Sverdlovsk district of Bukhara Oblast. The total area of the dryer is 150 m**2; length 15 m; width 10 m; height 10 m. The slope of the front pitch is phi equals 30 degree to the south. The unit is also equipped with an electric heater and a pebble thermal-storage unit.

Abstract: This conference contains 7 papers. The papers deal with conventional and alternate energy conversion systems and components, some address thermo-economics, and they span the range from new entropy microscales, and variational procedures to extremize exergy production for the computation of flow fields, through another look at the ubiquitous internal combustion engine, all the way to exergy auditing in thermal power stations.
