Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE IN DOMESTIC AND COMMERCIAL HEATING AND HOT WATER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: British Gas Corp, Engl, British Gas Corp, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Nevrala, D.J., British Gas Corp, Engl, British Gas Corp, Engl; Green, M.B., British Gas Corp, Engl, British Gas Corp, Engl
Abstract: Thermal energy storage offers a number of potential benefits when incorporated into hydronic heating systems using gas fired heat generators. The principal benefits are higher annual efficiency, low installed cost, rapid warm-up and a reduction of peak gas demand by virtue of smaller installed boiler capacity. In domestic dwellings, the provision of a good sanitary hot water service is important and with this aspect in mind, an integrated thermal storage heating and hot water system has been developed. The paper discusses the concept, performance and application of such an integrated thermal storage system. In order to explore the potential of thermal storage in commercial premises, British Gas has examined two different field applications - an office block and a large school. The results and field experience are presented.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Hot Water Systems; INTEGRATED THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Mills David R., Mao Yin Qiu
Title: NEW SOLAR COOKING STOVE WITH THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Univ of Sydney, Aust, Univ of Sydney, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Mills, David R., Univ of Sydney, Aust, Univ of Sydney, Aust; Mao Yin, Qiu, Univ of Sydney, Aust, Univ of Sydney, Aust
Abstract: This article describes a village cooking stove using pressurized water thermal storage. The collector is an evacuated tube collector with a seasonally adjusted mirror. No moving parts are used, yet the cooker will fry, bake, boil or steam food for two family meals on sunny days, and can be supplemented by conventional fuel on cloudy days. The thermal storage allows the stove to be permanently placed indoors and it will cook in the evening after sundown. The collector technology used has the potential to be used to supply water heating, space heating, refrigeration and pumping in the future and could provide the basis of a simple 'Third World Kitchen'.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; STOVES; FOCUSING DISH SOLAR COOKER; SOLAR OVEN; UNPRESSURIZED SOLAR STEAM COOKER; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: PROSPECTS OF SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS USING SEAWATER IN THE STORAGE ZONE.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA,, USA, San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lowrey III, P., San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA,, USA, San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: Analysis of the established dynamic stability criteria suggests that solar ponds using a fresh water surface over a storage zone filled with normal seawater can be viable and produce useful temperatures. This analysis further suggests that these novel solar ponds would be most competitive with conventional solar ponds in temperate latitudes, in winter, and in non-arid climates. In these locations it would be easier to maintain the fresh water surface the novel solar ponds require. Moreover the winter temperatures that should be theoretically stable in the proposed novel solar ponds almost equal the temperatures that have actually been maintained in conventional, high salinity, solar ponds in Ohio. Exploratory experiments have been started on this novel kind of solar pond. Expected advantages, disadvantages and applications are discussed.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; DYNAMIC STABILITY; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: OPERATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN COGENERATION PLANTS WITH REFRIGERATION SUPPLY TO LOW-TEMPERATURE COLD STORAGES.
Source title: ASME Int Gas Turbine Inst Publ IGTI
Affiliations: Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger, Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Holldorff, G.M., Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger, Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger; Malewski, W.F., Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger, Borsig GmbH, Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: Adsorption refrigeration systems use low-qualified thermal energy. Cogeneration with an absorption refrigeration system offers a favourable solution in cases of not sufficient direct waste heat utilization. For the first time two cogeneration plants have been installed in California generating approx. 27 MW power each in a combined cycle together with about 3. 5 MW refrigeration capacity (1,000 tons of refrigeration) each at minus 40 degree C by ammonia absorption refrigeration covering the demand of existing cold storages. Concept, design, operational experience, performance and special features are reported.
Index Keywords: COLD STORAGE; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; AMMONIA ABSORPTION REFRIGERATION; COGENERATION PLANTS

Authors: Suharta Nyoman, Budiono Chayun, Witjaksono Heru Arief
Title: SOLAR THERMAL PUMP AT PUSPIPTEK-SERPONG IN INDONESIA.
Affiliations: BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones
Authors with affiliations: Suharta, Nyoman, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones; Budiono, Chayun, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones; Witjaksono, Heru Arief, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones, BPP Teknologi, Jakarta, Indones
Abstract: The Solar Thermal Pump (STP) consists of 4 main components; solar collector, motor, condensor, and a water pump. Solar energy absorbed by the collector evaporates the working fluid. The vaporized working fluid reaches the intermediate storage tank where it is fed to the engine. Here, the vapor expands providing mechanical energy to drive the water pump before being liquified in the condenser. The liquified working fluid is pumped back to the collector evaporator by a feed pump coupled directly to the engine. The engine, water pump and feed pump all operate at the same frequency. After tests, it is concluded that the design of the condensate pump needs to be simplified; the water pump used is a prototype which should be replaced by the improved version; and, in general, the system worked satisfactorily.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FREON R11; SOLAR THERMAL PUMP; WELL PUMPS

Authors: Brefeld W., Brinkmann R., Rossbach J.
Title: LOW EMITTANCE OPTICS FOR PETRA II.
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Brefeld, W., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger; Brinkmann, R., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger; Rossbach, J., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: Due to the large bending radius, the strong quadrupoles, and the large number of sextupoles in the electron-positron storage ring PETRA at DESY, it is possible to realize electron optics with extremely small emittance. Horizontal emittances are calculated for maximum energies of 5 GeV and 15 GeV, using the PETRA II lattice configuration as it will be realized in the electron and proton booster version for HERA. Studies of the dynamic aperture for the 5-GeV and 7-GeV optics are reported, showing that chromaticity compensation by sextupoles leaves sufficient nonlinear acceptance.

Title: IMPROVING THE ENERGY RESOLUTION OF LEP EXPERIMENTS.
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Bassetti, M., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz; Jowett, J.M., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: It is suggested that the energy resolution of a LEP experiment could be considerably enhanced by means of a monochromator insertion. These schemes work by introducing opposite correlations between energy and vertical position of particles at the interaction point (IP) in each of the colliding beams. This would considerably reduce the spread in center-of-mass energies of the interactions. The authors explain why LEP appears to be the first electron-positron storage ring at which most of the obstacles to the realization of such a scheme can be overcome. Moreover, the size of the machine gives them the option of replacing the electrostatic quadrupoles considered in previous monochromator designs by RF-magnetic quadrupoles. The authors evaluate the limits to the performance of their design, giving special attention to the generation of vertical emittance by quantum excitation of coupled betatron oscillations in the monochromator insertions.

Authors: Wagner Ronald S., Bradley Jeffrey M., Bordes Nicole, Maggiore Carl J., Sinha Dipen N., Hammond Robert B.
Title: TRANSIENT MEASUREMENTS OF ULTRAFAST CHARGE COLLECTION IN SEMICONDUCTOR DIODES.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wagner, Ronald S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Bradley, Jeffrey M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Bordes, Nicole, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Maggiore, Carl J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Sinha, Dipen N., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA; Hammond, Robert B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: Funneling-current transients produced in semiconductor devices are predicted to occur on a picosecond time scale. These transients were measured by using a high bandwidth sampling system. Measurements were made on 1-, 3-, and 10- OMEGA -cm silicon low-capacitance diodes and 10**1**6 cm** minus **3 Te-doped GaAs diodes. The data are compared to the Hsieh, Murley and O'Brien, the McLean and Oldham, and the Messenger models. Risetime versus doping density, peak current, total charge, and amplitude versus bias were measured. Current transients and prompt charge versus energy are presented.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Radiation Effects; ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS - Transients; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES - Measurements; FUNNELING-CURRENT TRANSIENTS; SINGLE EVENT UPSET; ULTRAFAST CHARGE COLLECTION; SEMICONDUCTOR DIODES

Title: FLUORIDE SALTS AND CONTAINER MATERIALS FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE APPLICATIONS IN THE TEMPERATURE RANGE 973 TO 1400 K.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Misra, Ajay K., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Whittenberger, J.Daniel, NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Multicomponent fluoride salt mixtures were characterized for use as latent heat of fusion heat storage materials in advanced solar dynamic space power systems with operating temperatures in the range of 973 to 1400 K. The melting points and eutectic compositions for many systems with published phase diagrams were verified, and several new eutectic compositions were identified. Additionally the heats of fusion of several binary and ternary eutectics and congruently melting intermediate compounds were measured by differential scanning calorimetry. The extent of corrosion of various metals by fluoride melts was estimated from thermodynamic considerations, and equilibrium conditions inside a containment vessel were calculated.
Index Keywords: SALTS; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; THERMODYNAMICS; FLUORIDE SALTS; FUSION HEAT STORAGE MATERIALS; SPACE POWER; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Browning J.S., Gover J.E., Wrobel Theodore F., Hass K.J., Nasby R.D., Simpson R.L., Posey L.D., Boos R.E., Block R.C.
Title: HARD ERROR GENERATION BY NEUTRON-INDUCED FISSION FRAGMENTS.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Browning, J.S., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Gover, J.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Wrobel, Theodore F., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Hass, K.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Nasby, R.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Simpson, R.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Posey, L.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Boos, R.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Block, R.C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The authors have observed that neutron-induced fission of uranium contaminants present in alumina ceramic package lids results in the release of fission fragments that can cause hard errors in metal-nitride-oxide nonvolatile RAMs (MNOS NVRAMs). Hard-error generation requires the simultaneous presence of (1) a fission fragment with a linear energy transfer (LET) greater than 20 MeV/mg/cm**2 moving at an angle of 30 degree or less from the electric field in the high-field, gate region of the memory transistor, and (2) a WRITE or ERASE voltage on the oxide-nitride transistor gate. In reactor experiments, these hard errors were observed when a ceramic lid was used on both MNOS NVRAMs and polysilicon-nitride-oxide (SNOS) capacitors, but hard errors were not observed when a gold-plated kovar lid was used on the package containing these dies. The tracks of the fission fragments released from the ceramic lids were mapped with a mica track detector. A Monte Carlo model of fission fragment transport through the ceramic lid was used to measure the concentration of uranium present in the lids. The concentration measurements are in agreement with other measurements of uranium concentration in ceramic lids.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS - Monte Carlo Methods; NEUTRONS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES - Failure; FISSION FRAGMENTS RELEASE; HARD ERROR; NEUTRON-INDUCED FISSIONING; URANIUM CONTAMINANTS; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Authors: Sarmiento Charles J., Gruber Robert P.
Title: LOW POWER ARCJET THRUSTER PULSE IGNITION.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sarmiento, Charles J., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Gruber, Robert P., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: An investigation of the pulse ignition characteristics of a 1 kW class arcjet using an inductive energy storage pulse generator integral with a pulse width modulated power converter identified several thruster and pulse generator parameters that influence breakdown voltage including pulse generator rate of voltage rise. This work was conducted with an arcjet tested on hydrogen-nitrogen gas mixtures to simulate fully decomposed hydrazine. Over all ranges of thruster and pulser parameters investigated, the mean breakdown voltages varied from 1. 4 to 2. 7 kV. Ignition tests at elevated thruster temperatures under certain conditions revealed occasional breakdowns to thruster voltages higher than the power converter output voltage.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Space Applications; ARCJET THRUSTER PULSE IGNITION; PULSE GENERATOR; ROCKET ENGINES

Title: COUPLED-CIRCUIT TRANSIENT ELECTROMAGNETIC FORMULATION WITH EXTERNAL CONSTRAINTS.
Authors with affiliations: Perry, Michael P.
Abstract: A two-dimensional transient electromagnetic algorithm has been implemented using finite-element software. This method has been successfully tested against closed-form isothermal transient electromagnetic solutions for simple shapes. The program accommodates series and parallel combinations (one conductor comprising two materials, for example), as well as constant current and constant voltage constraints. The program has proved to be useful as a tool for evaluating specialized structures including motors, busbars, and energy storage devices.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Algorithms; 2-D ELECTROMAGNETIC ANALYSIS; DISTRIBUTED CONDUCTORS; TRANSIENT CURRENTS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS

Authors: Juhasz Albert J., Coles-Hamilton Carolyn E., Lacy Dovie E.
Title: IMPACT OF THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE PROPERTIES ON SOLAR DYNAMIC SPACE POWER CONVERSION SYSTEM MASS.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Juhasz, Albert J., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Coles-Hamilton, Carolyn E., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Lacy, Dovie E., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: A sixteen parameter solar concentrator/heat receiver mass model is used in conjunction with Stirling and Brayton Power Conversion System (PCS) performance and mass computer codes to determine the effect of thermal energy storage (TES) material property changes on overall PCS mass as a function of steady state electrical power output. Included in the PCS mass model are component masses as a function of thermal power for: concentrator, heat receiver, heat exchangers (source unless integral with heat receiver, heat sink, regenerator), heat engine units with optional parallel redundancy, power conditioning and control (PC and C), PC and C radiator, main radiator, and structure. Critical TES properties considered are: melting temperature, heat of fusion, density of the liquid phase, and the ratio of solid-to-liquid density.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; THERMOELECTRIC ENERGY CONVERSION; BRAYTON POWER CONVERSION SYSTEM; STIRLING POWER CONVERSION SYSTEM; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: UTILITY'S ROLE IN THE INDUSTRIAL APPLICATION OF APPLIED HEAT PUMPS.
Affiliations: Georgia Power Co, Atlanta, GA, USA, Georgia Power Co, Atlanta, GA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pucciano, F.J., Georgia Power Co, Atlanta, GA, USA, Georgia Power Co, Atlanta, GA, USA
Abstract: In this paper, the role of the utility in promoting mechanical heat recovery systems and their effect on industry/utility load profiles, thermal economics, and alternative fuel selection are discussed. These systems include applied heat pumps, thermal storage, and load control. The discussion compares these systems to boiler operations and cogeneration. The paper explains how mechanical heat recovery systems can be integrated into the overall thermal plant of an industry to obtain maximum thermal efficiency, low-cost energy, and production improvements and/or redundancy. The steps a utility should take to influence acceptance and installation of these systems are developed.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES; INDUSTRIAL HEATING - Costs; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Waste Heat Utilization; LOAD CONTROL; MECHANICAL HEAT RECOVERY; THERMAL ECONOMICS; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: HYDROPOWER DEVELOPMENT OF CHINA'S YANGTZE RIVER.
Affiliations: US Army Corps of Engineers,, Portland, OR, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Portland, OR, USA
Authors with affiliations: Clowes, Brian, US Army Corps of Engineers,, Portland, OR, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Portland, OR, USA
Abstract: The Yangtze has eight times the hydro potential of the Columbia River basin, currently the largest developed hydro system in the world. In order to pursue economic development through the Four Modernizations more effectively, the Chinese government is beginning the process of overhauling its entire energy system. Current and future Five-Year Plans call for the construction of several large hydro cascades, consisting of sixty projects, on the Yangtze main stem and its major tributaries. These cascades, which will be constructed over the next twenty years, will have a total capacity of at least 87,000 megawatts, yielding more than 250,000 gigawatt-hours (gWh) of electrical energy annually. Some other development plans are also discussed.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ENERGY RESOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; RIVER BASIN PROJECTS; TECHNOLOGICAL FORECASTING; HYDRO CASCADES; HYDROPOWER DEVELOPMENT; HYDROPOWER POTENTIAL; LONG-TERM ENERGY PLAN; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: O'Hare T.E., Sapienza R.S., Mahajan D., Skaperdas G.T.
Title: LIQUEFACTION OF NATURAL GAS TO METHANOL FOR SHIPPING AND STORAGE.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: O'Hare, T.E., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Sapienza, R.S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Mahajan, D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA; Skaperdas, G.T., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: A radically new methanol synthesis process has been conceived at Brookhaven National Laboratory and a research program has shown the expected operating characteristic of the expected process. To assess the economic viability of this BNL methanol synthesis, a complete process plant was designed using the research data on the process. The results show that the methanol process plant using the Brookhaven system designed for a production rate of 3,000 metric tons per stream day requires an investment that is 50% of the investment for a conventional methanol synthesis using an up-to-date, improved design, and about 70% of an LNG plant delivering the same amount of energy.
Index Keywords: NATURAL GAS; NATURAL GAS, LIQUEFIED; BNL METHANOL SYNTHESIS PROCESS; BROOKHAVEN METHANOL PROCESS; METHANOL

Authors: Voigt Bernhard, Mierke Thomas, Ruhnau Ralf, Moeller Klaus
Title: HEAT STORAGE: A MATERIALS PROBLEM.
Affiliations: Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Voigt, Bernhard, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger; Mierke, Thomas, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger; Ruhnau, Ralf, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger; Moeller, Klaus, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger, Energie-Anlagen, Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: Storage of heat is one essential aspect of effective energy usage. We examined the possibility of using hot water for such storage for a district heating system in West Berlin. We report on our studies of low-loss energy storage. The authors concentrated on: investigating maximum and minimum hydraulic charge and discharge parameters, investigating temperature distribution in the storage, and results of material investigations for pilot plant application. The pilot plant storage basin has a capacity of 170 m**3 and can store 10 MWh. The authors also studied the effect of the rate of charge and the height of the inlet port on the layers. The experiments are divided into four steps: During the first phase, two partitions are set up 0. 40 m apart within the basin. The second phase used the same experiments as the first phase, but the partitions were removed. During the third phase, the spreading of the heat layers is scrutinized. The fourth phase only examines long-term heat storage capabilities.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Heat Storage; POLYETHYLENES - High Density; SEALS - Materials; CHARGING PROCESS; STORAGE BASIN; SURFACE LOSS MINIMIZATION; WATER LAYER BOUNDARIES; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Renk T.J., Rochau G.E., McDaniel D.H., Moore W.B., Zuchowski N., Padilla R.
Title: PLASMA-FILLED DIODE EXPERIMENTS ON PBFA-II.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Renk, T.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Rochau, G.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; McDaniel, D.H., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Moore, W.B., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Zuchowski, N., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Padilla, R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The PBFA-II accelerator is designed to use a plasma opening switch (POS) for pulse shaping and voltage multiplication using inductive storage. The POS is designed to conduct up to 6 MA, and open into a 5- OMEGA diode load in 10 ns or less. Under these conditions, the voltage at the load is predicted to exceed 24 MV. Initial POS experiments using these loads have produced 1) opening times of typically 20 ns or longer, 2) poor current transfer efficiency (less than 50%) when load impedances averaged 2 OMEGA or more, and 3) differential switch opening in azimuthal segments of the power feed, thought to be caused by poor plasma uniformity across the flashboard plasma source. One possible explanation for 2) is that efficient transfer out of the POS requires that the current carried to the load be magnetically insulated, or else considerable energy will be deposited in the feed region between the POS and load. A solution to this problem is proposed.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS; ELECTRIC SWITCHES; PBFA-II ACCELERATOR; PLASMA OPENING SWITCH; PLASMA-FILLED DIODE; SWITCH OPENING; VOLTAGE MULTIPLICATION; PLASMA DEVICES

Authors: Thaller Lawrence H., Lim Hong S.
Title: PREDICTION MODEL OF THE DEPTH-OF-DISCHARGE EFFECT ON THE CYCLE LIFE OF A STORAGE CELL.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thaller, Lawrence H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Lim, Hong S., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Cycle life requirements are very high for batteries used in aerospace applications in low earth orbit. The data base required to establish confidence in a particular cell design is thus both extensive and expensive. Reliable accelerated cycle life testing and performance decay modeling represent attractive alternatives to real-time tests of cycle life. In light of certain long-term cycle life test results, this paper examines a very simple performance decay model developed earlier. Application of that model to available data demonstrates a rigid relationship between a battery's expected cycle life and the depth of discharge of cycling.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; NICKEL CADMIUM BATTERIES; SPACE POWER; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: ASHRAE TRANSACTIONS: TECHNICAL AND SYMPOSIUM PAPERS PRESENTED AT THE 1987 WINTER MEETING.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This conference proceedings consists of two parts. The first part contains 138 papers dealing with a wide variety of aspects of air conditioning, heating and ventilation systems for residential, commercial and industrial buildings. The main topics include: new developments in emission control; chilled and heated water storage; ground coupling calculation; heat pump systems; computers in university HVAC education; energy management; human factors in HVAC engineering; radiant heating and cooling; evaporative air conditioning; multizone air infiltration; fenestration; monitoring protocols; waste-to-energy facilities; district heating and cooling. Special attention is given to the energy efficient and environmentally safe HVAC systems.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Energy Conservation; ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION; HEATING; REFRIGERATION; VENTILATION; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; DISTRICT HEATING; EIREV; INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS; RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AUTOMATES STRATEGIC PETROLEUM RESERVES.
Authors with affiliations: Stiles, Robert E.
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE), is automating the process control system for the major Strategic Petroleum Reserves (SPR), located along the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana. Each of these crude oil storage facilities is being equipped with a Coggins Systems Series 8100 Distributed Control System. This system is programmed for automatic operation, while affording ease-of-user interface through color graphics process display terminals (operator's terminals). Under normal operations, a single operator is able to manage an entire facility. Complex control operations require only function selection and initiation through simple keystrokes with the aid of process display menus.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER INTERFACES; COMPUTER PERIPHERAL EQUIPMENT - Terminals; CONTROL SYSTEMS, DISTRIBUTED PARAMETER; DOE; FUNCTION SELECTION/INITIATION; PROCESS DISPLAY MENUS; SUPERVISORY CONTROL NETWORK; US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY; PETROLEUM PIPELINES

Authors: Shoga M., Adams P., Chenette D.L., Koga R., Smith E.C.
Title: VERIFICATION OF SINGLE EVENT UPSET RATE ESTIMATION METHODS WITH ON-ORBIT OBSERVATIONS.
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Shoga, M., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Adams, P., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Chenette, D.L., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Koga, R., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Smith, E.C., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: In an experiment aboard the Hughes Leasat vehicles each in geosynchronous orbit, single-event upsets (SEU) have been continuously monitored in a memory consisting of 93L422 RAMs. Using simultaneous measurements of the high-energy galactic cosmic-ray and solar-flare-particle environment from the University of Chicago experiment aboard the IMP-8 satellite, together with a Leasat mass distribution model and ground test measurements of the SEU susceptibility for the 93L422, estimates of the SEU rate are calculated based on several improvements to the standard methods. These results are discussed and compared to the Leasat flight observations.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE UNITS - Radiation Effects; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; SATELLITES - Instruments; INTEGRATED-CIRCUIT RADIATION EFFECTS; ON-ORBIT OBSERVATIONS; RANDOM-ACCESS MEMORIES; SINGLE EVENT UPSETS; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: Investigation of high current density diffuse discharges for switching applications
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: GTE Lab Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Piejak, Robert B., GTE Lab Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Abstract: Diffuse discharges offer the possibility of a fast-recovery switching medium with low electrode erosion; to be efficient they must also possess a low resistance compared to that of the load. To investigate the discharge resistance and voltage drop, an experimental system has been built, and the operating E/P (ratio of electric field to gas pressure), the discharge resistance, and the energy transfer to a resistive load have been studied in high-pressure, high-current-density, UV-preionized, self-sustained diffuse discharges. Preliminary measurements to test the system and determine the rage of parameters have been made in N2 with tri-n-propylamine (TPA) seedant and in three CO2:N2(w/TPA):He mixtures at gas pressures between 100 and 760 torr. It has been found that in the CO2:N2:He mixtures E/P decreases with increasing J/P (attachment dominated), while in N2 it increases with J/P (recombination dominated), where J is the current density. The resistance of the discharge was calculated and found to range between, 0.7 Ω and 13 Ω under various initial conditions. A simple calculation for predicting energy transfer from a capacitive storage element through a gas discharge and into a relative load is presented. Experimental data from diffuse discharge measurements show remarkable agreement with the calculated results. The agreement indicates that the ratio of Vop/Vappl (ratio of operating discharge voltage to applied voltage) is a useful parameter for determining the energy transfer efficiency of the discharge.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Gases--Ionization; Pulse Generators; Diffuse Discharges; Discharge Current Measurement; Energy Transfer; Fast-Recovery Switching; Pulse Forming Lines; Triggered Spark Gap; Electric Switches

Authors: Goforth J.H., Caird R.S., Fowler C.M., Greene A.E., Kruse H.W., Lindemuth I.R., Oona H., Reinovsky R.E.
Title: Performance of the Laguna pulsed power system
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goforth, J.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Caird, R.S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Fowler, C.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Greene, A.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Kruse, H.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Lindemuth, I.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Oona, H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Reinovsky, R.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Abstract: The goal of the Laguna experimental series is to accelerate an annular aluminum plasma z-pinch to greater than 100 kJ of implosion kinetic energy. To accomplish this, an electrical pulse >5.5 MA must be delivered to a 20-nH load in approximately 1 μs. The pulsed power system for these experiments consists of a capacitor bank for initial energy storage, a helical explosive-driven magnetic-flux-compression generator for the prime power supply, and opening and closing switches for power conditioning. While the design goal of 15 MA delivered to the inductive store of the system has not yet been achieved, all major components have functioned successfully at the 10-MA level. Significant successes and some difficulties experienced in these experiments are described.
Index Keywords: Electric Fuses; Pulse Generators; Annular Aluminum Plasma Z-Pinch; Capacitor Bank; Laguna Pulsed Power System; Magnetic-Flux-Compression Generator; Mark-IX Helical Generator; Plasma Implosions; Plasmas

Authors: Goeller Roy M., Thompson M.Clark, Hammond Robert P., Lemons Ross A., Nunnally William
Title: Investigation of cryogenic photoconductive power switches
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goeller, Roy M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Thompson, M.Clark, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Hammond, Robert P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Lemons, Ross A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Nunnally, William, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Abstract: Repetitive photoconductive power switching with an Nd:YAG laser at pulse rates up to 100 Hz was demonstrated at room and cryogenic temperatures. A silicon rod 3 cm in length and 9 mm in diameter with a resistivity of 1 kΩ-cm was optically triggered in a circuit, making it possible to pulse-charge the system or to bias the switch with constant voltage. In the pulse-charge mode, an HY8 thyratron was used as a series switch to place a maximum of 1.25 J of stored energy in a 0.1-μf capacitor. This energy was then delivered to a 0.5-Ω load by optically triggering the photoconductive switch. In the direct-current mode of operation, the triggering was performed with a constant voltage across the switch and load combination. These two arrangements made it possible to study the effect of thermal runaway in the photoconductive power switch at both room and cryogenic temperatures.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Cryogenics; Electric Waveforms; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Lasers, Solid State; Cryogenic Photoconductive Power Switches; Optical Triggering; Silicon Rod; Electric Switches, Semiconductor

Title: Focusing induction accelerator
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bernardes, J., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent,, Dahlgren, VA, USA
Abstract: The author describes a unique induction accelerator that simultaneously axially accelerates and radially compresses conic-section-shaped, sheet-copper rings. The result of this process is an axially flying, compact slug. A description of the experimental setup and of the testing of this device is presented. Special attention is given to the drive-coil design, which includes a barrel, and to the investigation of the ring-forming process using high-speed photography.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electric Coils--Design; Photography, High Speed; Barrel; Coil-Ring Geometries; Drive-Coil Assembly; Induction Accelerator; Projective Velocity; Propulsion

Title: Power conditioner for a coil-gun
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Polytechnic Univ, Weber Research, Inst, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zabar, Z., Polytechnic Univ, Weber Research, Inst, Brooklyn, NY, USA; Joshi, P.N., Polytechnic Univ, Weber Research, Inst, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Abstract: The authors describe a power-conditioning scheme for introducing currents sequentially into a linear array of coils which form the barrel of a coil gun. The projectile, a conducting cylindrical sleeve, is driven by the force exerted on it by a traveling magnetic-wave packet created by the barrel currents. Since the rate of energy transfer is proportional to the projectile velocity, it was convenient to divide the barrel into three separate sections, corresponding to the low-, medium-, and high-velocity parts of the projectile motion. Each section is excited by a different method, chosen to satisfy the need for the most efficient utilization of the energy stored in the power supply capacitors. Experiments with a breadboard model, which test the feasibility of the medium-velocity power-conditioning scheme are described. In the medium-velocity section, each stage utilizes the preceding capacitor and its left-over energy to increase the voltage and the frequency of the next stage. It was demonstrated that for a six-stage configuration the energy utilization efficiency using the power conditioner is higher than that achievable with an arrangement of six individual precharged source capacitors by a factor of two.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electric Coils; Electric Networks, Switching; Electric Waveforms; Coil Gun; Electromagnetic Accelerator; Energy Utilization Efficiency; Linear Accelerator Launcher; Power Conditioner; Propulsion

Authors: Di Capua Marco S., Molau Nicole E., Wheeler Paul C.
Title: Response of helical structures to high speed pulses or when can a helix be called an inductor?
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Di Capua, Marco S., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; Molau, Nicole E., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA; Wheeler, Paul C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab,, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: The authors describe the results of analytical approximations, circuit simulations, 3-D time-dependent electromagnetic modeling of and laboratory measurements on helices surrounded by conducting structures. On the basis of these investigations their suitability as voltage measuring devices is discussed. It is shown that the structures behave like transmission lines for short time scales and like inductors over longer time scales, subject to restrictions on the magnitude of dc/dt. By using simple approximations these structures can be adequately modeled with lumped element networks that account for the energy stored in electric and magnetic fields. Circuit simulations, 3-D simulations, and experimental measurements yield the same physical picture even though the fine structure of the waveforms may vary.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electric Inductors--Energy Storage; Electric Measurements--Impedance; Elliptic Integrals; Helical Structures; High Speed Pulses; Time-Domain Reflectometry; Pulse Generators

Authors: Laughlin R.L., Ingram M.W., Zowarka Jr. R.C.
Title: Fabrication and testing of a 6.5 μH, 1.5 MA, 100-kV inductor
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Laughlin, R.L., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA; Ingram, M.W., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA; Zowarka Jr., R.C., Univ of Texas, Cent for Electromech,, Austin, TX, USA
Abstract: Prime power for a hypervelocity (1 g at 50 km/s) electromagnetic launcher will be supplied by a 60-MJ, 9-MA Balcones homopolar generator power supply. This power supply consists of six 10-MJ homopolar generators, which can be connected in various series/parallel configurations or sequentially discharged for pulse shaping. Intermediate energy storage consists of six 6.5-μH room-temperature copper coaxial inductors, designed to operate at 1.5 MA and withstand 100 kV. Completing the system are six opening switches, six crowbar switches, a 1.0-m-diameter × 40.0-m-long vacuum chamber and high-speed diagnostics. The system was designed to be a versatile, easily maintained laboratory system. This power supply provides a substantial capability and can be used to drive a variety of experiments, such as a large-bore tactical railgun being designed to launch a 2-kg projectile at 3 km/s.
Index Keywords: Electric Inductors; Electric Switches; Pulse Generators; Crowbar Switches; Electromagnetic Launcher; Homopolar Generator; Tactical Railgun; Propulsion

Authors: McDonald K.F., Mayerchak M.A., DeHart T.E., Hedeen P.F., Hoffman A.L.
Title: Pulsed power systems for the LSX field reversed configuration experiment
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, K.F., Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA; Mayerchak, M.A., Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA; DeHart, T.E., Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA; Hedeen, P.F., Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA; Hoffman, A.L., Spectra Technol Inc, Bellevue, WA,, USA
Abstract: A very large reversed-field theta pinch experiment, called LSX (Large s Experiment), is being constructed to generate field-reversed configurations (FRCs) of relevant-size reactors. The principal parameters of the device are the dimensions of the set of single-turn theta coils, which have a 0.9-m diameter and a total length of 4.5 m. The peak forward field, applied with a 25-μs risetime, is 7.5 kG. The FRCs will be formed using slow, programmed formation techniques which rely on ohmic and axial-compression heating rather than the more standard theta pinch method of radial shock heating. LSX's basic engineering features are reverse-bias and forward-field capacitor banks, programmed-formation end coils and power supplies, multipole flux retention and stabilization fields, preionization sources, and the necessary ancillary systems. The authors provide an overview of the LSX physics, discuss the operating modes and design philosophy, describe the capacitor banks, energy storage modules, and ancillary systems, and discuss the fault prevention techniques and fault sequences.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Ion Sources; Plasmas--Confinement; Pulse Generators; Capacitor Banks; Field Reversed Configuration Experiment; LSX (Large s Experiment); Preionization Sources; Pulsed Power Systems; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion

Authors: Weeks Robert W., McKee Terrence J.
Title: Comparison of commonly used excimer laser pulsed power circuitry
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Weeks, Robert W., Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can; McKee, Terrence J., Lumonics Inc, Kanata, Ont, Can
Abstract: The authors compare the electrical characteristics of the various types of pulsed power circuits commonly used in commercial excimer lasers. Sixty-watt commercial krypton fluoride lasers are used as the test cases; however, the lasers are multigas devices operating on all the usual excimer transitions. Circuit measurements made on these lasers are presented, and energy and charge transfer through the systems are discussed and analyzed. It is shown that for power levels less than 100 W, a simple, properly designed pulse charge circuit is preferred over a magnetic switch circuit because of its higher efficiency, lower component count, and reduced complexity. For higher power levels it is inferred that more sophisticated pulse power formats with larger beam cross sections are likely to be used.
Index Keywords: Electric Networks, Switching; Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Pulse Generators; Charge Transfer Measurements; Energy Storage Measurements; LC Inversion Circuit; Pulse Charge Circuit; Pulsed Power Circuits; Lasers, Excimer

Title: Compact battery/capacitor electromagnetic launcher testbed
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: US Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, NJ,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jasper Jr., Louis J., US Army LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, NJ,, USA
Abstract: The authors describe a 0.4-MW/lb battery/capacitor system which is a viable means of powering a small-caliber electromagnetic launcher (SCEML). A SCEML testbed is in operation which uses a 55-lb, 0.9-kJ/kg electrolytic-capacitor-discharged subsystem and a demountable, compact SCEML that serves as the switch and load. A secondary silver-oxide-iron battery subsystem that weighs 45 lb. has been designed to operate at up to 1000 V and is capable of charging the capacitors at a 1.0 Hz repetition rate for a minimum of 100 cycles. The total battery/capacitor power system weight is 100 lb. Power conditioning experiments are in progress under railgun load conditions with a near-term objective of demonstrating a 100-lb power-conditioning system that is capable of powering a projectile of weight 2.0 to 4.0 g with a muzzle velocity of 2.0 km/s and with a barrel length less than 1.0 m. Experimental data are presented; higher power, energy battery/capacitor power systems are highlighted; and future program plans and some important conclusions are discussed that give support to the concept of a compact, lightweight battery/capacitor power conditioning system for an SCEML.
Index Keywords: Capacitors, Electrolytic--Energy Storage; Electric Batteries, Secondary; Battery/Capacitor Power Conditioning System; Battery/Capacitor System; Electrolytic Capacitor Bank; Electromagnetic Launcher; Railgun; Propulsion

Authors: Denison G.J., Corley J.P., Johnson D.L., Weber G.J., Hamil R.A., Crowder G.W., Alexander J.A., Petmecky D.A., Schanwald L.P., Ramirez J.J.
Title: High-voltage multistage laser-triggered gas switch
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Denison, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Corley, J.P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Johnson, D.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Weber, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Hamil, R.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Crowder, G.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Alexander, J.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Petmecky, D.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Schanwald, L.P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Ramirez, J.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: The authors describe the development and testing of an SF6-insulated, multistage laser-triggered gas switch for use in the Hermes-III accelerator at Sandia National Laboratories. Twenty of these switches are used in Hermes III to transfer energy from intermediate-energy-storage water-dielectric capacitors to the pulse-forming lines (PFLs) and to provide the overall synchronization of the accelerator. The gas switches operate in an oil environment, are charged to a peak voltage between 2.2 MV and 2.4 MV in ~1 μs, and are laser triggered with a root-mean-square (rms) jitter equal to or less than 2 ns. Both the triggered and untriggered performance of the switch have been investigated. The development test results and initial results from Hermes III are summarized. An average run time spread of 5.7 ns has been obtained in initial testing of half of the twenty Hermes-III switches. This corresponds to an rms jitter of 1.9 ns. These tests were performed with 1.8 MV across the switch.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Switching; Gases--Electric Breakdown; Hermes-III Gas Switch; Laser-Triggered Gas Switch; Multistage Switch; Sulfur Hexafluoride; Electric Switches

Authors: Mauldin G.H., Schreiner E.T., Harris J.O., Thompson M.C., Somoano R.B., Yen S.P.S.
Title: Dielectric modification of repetition rate tested polycarbonate perfluorocarbon capacitors
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mauldin, G.H., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Schreiner, E.T., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Harris, J.O., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Thompson, M.C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Somoano, R.B., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Yen, S.P.S., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: A status report on perfluorocarbon-impregnated-capacitor technology is presented. It appears that the operational life of a perfluorocarbon-impregnated capacitor is a strong function of the crystalline-amorphous character of the polycarbonate (PC) dielectric material. Results of X-ray diffraction studies and thermomechanical analysis of the material and gas studies of the impregnate solution are presented. The authors also discuss the dynamics of both equivalent series resistance and the equivalent dynamic capacitance of an in situ device as observed during testing. The results provide strong evidence to support the assumed wearing effects of repetitive service in energy storage capacitor usage.
Index Keywords: Chemical Analysis; Electric Insulating Materials--Plastics; Plastics Films; Polycarbonates; Spectroscopy, X-Ray; Equivalent Dynamic Capacitance; Equivalent Series Resistance; Polycarbonate Perfluorocarbon Capacitors; Thermomechanical Analysis; X-Ray Diffraction Studies; Capacitors

Authors: James T.E., Gray J.W., Kear M.J.
Title: Pulsed power systems research at Culham Laboratory
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Euratom/UKAEA Fusion Assoc, Culham, Lab, Abingdon, Engl
Authors with affiliations: James, T.E., Euratom/UKAEA Fusion Assoc, Culham, Lab, Abingdon, Engl; Gray, J.W., Euratom/UKAEA Fusion Assoc, Culham, Lab, Abingdon, Engl; Kear, M.J., Euratom/UKAEA Fusion Assoc, Culham, Lab, Abingdon, Engl
Abstract: The authors review the development of pulsed power systems and the experimental facilities at Culham. These include fast, high-current switching of multimegajoule energy storage systems, modulated HV (high-voltage) power systems for plasma heating applications (160 kV, 16 MV), and a lightning studies unit. Current studies include theoretical and experimental studies on compulsators and electromagnetic launchers. Experimental facilities are being considered for high-performance, repetitive switching systems and high-energy storage (~50 MJ) for electromagnetic launchers based on the use of existing HV DC (160 kV, 16 MW) and high-current DC (100 kA, 30 MW) power supplies, respectively.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Energy Storage; Lightning--Research; Pulse Generators; Compulsators; Electromagnetic Launchers; Energy Storage Systems; Pulsed Power Systems; Repetitive Switching Systems; Plasmas

Title: PBFA-II energy storage system performance and operation
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, J.Michael, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: A description is given of the energy storage for the PBFA-II (Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator II), a 36-module ion-beam accelerator constructed for inertial-confinement-fusion feasibility studies. The PBFA-II energy storage system is located in an annular oil tank at the outer periphery of the accelerator. Its main component is a set of 36 6.0-MV, 400-kJ Marx generators. In order to properly drive the machine's downline pulse-forming section and the accelerator load, the Marx generator set must erect with a first-to-last spread of less than 40 ns. The energy storage section is triggered by a chain of pulse amplifiers, beginning with a low-voltage trigger pulse from the main control system and culminating in 36 540-kV, 80-ns risetime pulses used to trigger the Marx generators. Each generator then erects to provide a 110-kA, 5.3-MV, 1.3-μs pulse to charge the pulse-forming section. The energy storage system is now operational and meeting performance specifications. The performance characteristics of the system are understood over the present operating range, and routine operation and maintenance procedures have been established.
Index Keywords: Nuclear Energy--Fusion Reactions; Pulse Generators; Energy Storage Section; Marx Charging System; Marx Firing System; Marx Generator; Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator; PBFA-II Energy Storage System; Accelerators

Authors: Akiyama H., Fujita K., Majima T., Shimomura N., Maeda S.
Title: Pulsed power generation from inductive energy storage system by two-staged opening switches
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Dep of Electrical Engineering &, Comput Sci, Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto,, Jpn

Abstract: Pulsed power generation from using the inductive energy storage system ASO-1 is reported. The design of from ASO-1 is described, and data from recent experiments are presented. In paricular, The influence of the exploding parallel wires used to decrease the inductance on the output voltage and current is investigated.

Title: Energy compression and transfer using hybrid pulsed power transformer (HPPT)
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Gen Dynamics Space Syst Div, San, Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hilal, M.A., Gen Dynamics Space Syst Div, San, Diego, CA, USA; Leung, E.M.W., Gen Dynamics Space Syst Div, San, Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: The historical approach to energy compression for Space Defense Initiative (SDI) applications has been to use a storage-inductor/homopolar-generator combination to transfer power from the primary energy source to the load. An innovative transformer concept, the hybrid pulse power transformer (HPPT), replaces the inductor and the homopolar generator. This pulse transformer significantly increases the energy transfer efficiency and eliminates the need for a high-current switch. It requires the use of a superconducting primary with a composite conductor that becomes highly resistive when driven normal. The sequence of HPPT operation is to charge the superconducting primary, then drive it normal when the energy pulse is required. The primary total resistance determines the time constant of energy transfer independently of its distribution. Since the winding resistance and inductance are distributed along the windings, internal voltage elimination is achieved locally. A 100-mJ HPPT system is described along with its performance characteristics. Experimental results for a small HPPT model which was constructed for the purpose of verifying the HPPT concept are given.
Index Keywords: Electric Windings, Transformer; Pulse Generators; Superconducting Devices; Energy Compression; Hybrid Pulsed Power Transformer; Space Defense Initiative; Superconducting Winding; Electric Transformers, Pulse

Authors: Crumley R., Salisbury K., Sallay J., Chen Y.G., Nielsen K., Sears R., Fockler J., Smith I., Boyd D.
Title: Design of a transportable current injector
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Crumley, R., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Salisbury, K., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Sallay, J., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Chen, Y.G., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Nielsen, K., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Sears, R., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Fockler, J., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Smith, I., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Boyd, D., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: A 1.2-MJ transportable current-injection pulser has been designed for direct drive of a variety of communication and power cables. The system is completely contained inside a 10 ft × 10 ft × 50 ft. trailer and consists of a two-stage, 160-kV, air-dielectric-insulated Marx generator, a two-element spiral storage inductor, a ballast resistor, and a crowbar switch, along with associated control, charging, and triggering systems. The pulse is delivered through a specially designed, low-impedance coaxial cable. The entire pulser system electrically floats, allowing one-point grounding at the load. Design goals were to inject current pulses of 2 to 150 kA into various inductive loads, with risetimes on the order of 200 μs and fall times of 12 ms. Full-voltage shots have been fired, producing peak currents of 150 kA through a 40-ft cable and 10-μH load. The risetime is 250 μs, the peak current is 67 kA, and the fall time is 12 ms. The maximum output current waveform has a peak amplitude of 150 kA.
Index Keywords: Electric Cables--Testing; Electric Insulation--Impulse Testing; Electric Waveforms; Telecommunication Cables--Testing; Current-Injection Pulser; High Energy Pulser; Marx Generator; Pulse Generators

Authors: Sasagawa Teruo, Kawahara Akihiro, Obara Minoru
Title: UV excimer laser controlled repetitive diffuse discharge opening switches
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Keio Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Yokohama, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Sasagawa, Teruo, Keio Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Yokohama, Jpn; Kawahara, Akihiro, Keio Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Yokohama, Jpn; Obara, Minoru, Keio Univ, Dep of Electr Eng,, Yokohama, Jpn
Abstract: The optical control of a diffuse discharge as a means of obtaining a high-repetition-rated opening switch for an inductive energy storage system is reported. The elementary process involved in the discharge opening is an optically enhanced electron attachment process. The vinylchloride (C2H3Cl) molecule can be UV-photoeliminated and produces highly vibrationally and rotationally excited HCl(v,J), which can strongly attach discharge electrons. Discharge opening and closing of the diffuse discharge in a mixture of He/C2H3Cl (C2H3Cl:He = 0.7:99.3% at a total pressure of 1.5 torr) under irradiation with a KrF laser (5.7 mJ/cm2, 20 ns full width at half maximum) were observed experimentally. A rapid current decrease with a time constant of 1 μs, in a diffuse discharge in a mixture of C2H3Cl/CF4/CH4 was also observed.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Lasers, Excimer; Pulse Generators; Diffuse Discharge Opening Switches; Inductive Energy Storage; Repetitive Opening Switches; UV Excimer Laser; Electric Switches
