Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Abstract: The proceedings containts 185 papers. The following topics are dealt with: switching; pulsed power for electromagnetic launchers; insulators and breakdown; rotating machinery; diagnostics and instrumentation; pulse generators; accelerators and diodes; and components and energy storage.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Power Supply; Electric Insulation--Electric Breakdown; Electric Switches; Plasmas--Diagnostics; Propulsion--Electric Energy; EIREV; Electromagnetic Launchers; Electron Beam Diodes; Energy Storage; Pulse Forming Lines; Pulsed Power Technology; Pulse Generators

Authors: Bloomquist D.D., Stinnett R.W., McDaniel D.H., Lee J.R., Sharpe A.W., Halbleib J.A., Schlitt L.G., Spence P.W., Corcoran P.
Title: Saturn, a large area X-ray simulation accelerator
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bloomquist, D.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Stinnett, R.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; McDaniel, D.H., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Lee, J.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Sharpe, A.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Halbleib, J.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Schlitt, L.G., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Spence, P.W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Corcoran, P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: Saturn is the result of a major metamorphosis of the Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator-I (PBFA-I) from an ICF (inertial confinement fusion) research facility to the large-area X-ray source of the Simulation Technology Laboratory (STL) project. Renamed Saturn for its unique multiple-ring diode design, the facility is designed to take advantage of the numerous advances in pulsed power technology made by the ICF program in recent years and much of the existing PBFA-I support system. Saturn will include significant upgrades in the energy storage and pulse-forming sections. The 36 magnetically insulated transmission lines (MITLs) that provided power flow to the ion diode of PBFA-I were replaced by a system of vertical triplate water transmission lines. These lines are connected to three horizontal triplate disks in a water convolute section. Power will flow through an insulator stack into radial MITLs that will drive the three-ring diode. Saturn is designed to operate with a maximum of 750 kJ coupled to a three-ring electron-beam diode with a peak power of 25 TW to provide an X-ray exposure capability of 5 × 1012 rads/s (Si) and 5 cal/g (Au) over 500 cm2.
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Electric Switches; Energy Storage; Pulse Generators; Large Area X-Ray Simulation Accelerator; Magnetically Insulated Transmission Lines; Marx Generators; Saturn Accelerator; Three-Ring Electron-Beam Diode; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production

Authors: Johnson W.A., Neau E.L., Schneider L.X.
Title: TEM analysis and computer simulation of DEMON and PBFA-II open transmission-line systems
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, W.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Neau, E.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Schneider, L.X., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: TEM (transverse electromagnetic) analysis and the three-dimensional, time-dependent SOS code have been used to investigate fringe-field and cross-coupling effects in the PBFA-II (Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator II) and DEMON transmission-line structures which couple the coaxial, pulse-forming lines to the central-vacuum insulator stack and inductive energy-storage section. Voltage and current measurements have been made for the DEMON prototype module. Voltage, current, and H-field measurements have been made for several one-fifth-scale sheet-metal mockups of DEMON components and in a one-fifth-scale mockup of the multimode PBFA-II transmission line and stack geometry. The energy-transport efficiencies of individual components, have been quantified, and energy-loss mechanisms have been identified and the analytic and measure of results compared. The insights gained are guiding design efforts to improve the energy-transport efficiency of PBFA II.
Index Keywords: Electric Field Measurement; Electromagnetic Fields--Computer Simulation; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Pulse Generators; DEMON Open Transmission Line; Energy-Transport Efficiency; Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator; PBFA-II Transmission Line; Pulse Forming Lines; TEM Analysis; Accelerators

Authors: Bluhm H., Bohnel K., Hoppe P., Karow H.U., Ratajczak W., Rusch D.
Title: Results from inductive store plasma opening switch experiments at the 1.5 TW generator KALIF
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Bluhm, H., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger; Bohnel, K., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger; Hoppe, P., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger; Karow, H.U., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger; Ratajczak, W., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger; Rusch, D., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Abstract: Inductive-store pulse compression experiments using plasma opening switches (POSs) were performed at the 1.5-TV KALIF (Karlsruhe Light Ion Facility) pulse power generator with the aim of investigating the possibilities of voltage and power multiplication, developing suitable methods for diode voltage and current measurements, and improving the understanding of the switch physics. Results from these experiments showed that, within the range of variation of th parameters, the switch geometry had no significant influence on the switch performance and the maximum current which could be switched by fast opening was around 500 kA only. The symmetry of the switching process was found to be in close relationship with the POS performance and the losses in the diode feed. A voltage multiplication of about two was achieved at best; the power multiplication was insignificant.
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Electric Switches; Energy Storage; Plasmas--Switching; Coaxial Switch; Inductive-Store Pulse Compression Experiments; Karlsruhe Light Ion Facility (KALIF); Plasma Opening Switches; Pulse Power Generator; Pulse Generators

Authors: Ramirez J.J., Prestwich K.R., Burgess E.L., Furaus J.P., Hamil R.A., Johnson D.L., Sanford T.W.L., Seamons L.O., Schneider L.X., Zawadzkas G.A.
Title: Hermes-III program
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ramirez, J.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Prestwich, K.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Burgess, E.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Furaus, J.P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Hamil, R.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Johnson, D.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Sanford, T.W.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Seamons, L.O., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Schneider, L.X., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Zawadzkas, G.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: The authors describe Hermes III, a gamma-ray simulator being built at Sandia National Laboratories as part of the Simulation Technology Laboratory (STL). It will deliver a 20-ns FWHM (full width at half maximum), 20-ns-risetime (10% to 90%) radiation pulse with a peak dose rate of 5 × 1012 rad(Si)/s over a cylindrical volume with a 500-cm2 front surface area and 15-cm length. The radiation pulse will be uniform within a factor of two across the front surface and within a factor of four anywhere within the volume. The minimum dose rate will be 2.5 × 1012 rad(Si)/s within this volume. The overall configuration of the Hermes-III accelerator is presented together with a discussion of the requirements for the individual components. A brief summary of the subsystems' performance to date is presented.
Index Keywords: Anodes; Energy Storage; Lasers; Pulse Generators; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production; Gamma-Ray Simulator; Hermes-III Accelerator; Hermes-III Program; Indented-Anode Diode; Pulse Forming Lines; Accelerators

Authors: Humphreys D.R., Francavilla T.L., Gubser D.U., Wolf S.A.
Title: Progress toward a superconducting opening switch
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Humphreys, D.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Francavilla, T.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Gubser, D.U., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Wolf, S.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: Niobium nitride films have been made which can carry high currents (approximately 10 MA/cm2) in their superconducting state yet have a moderately high resistivity (approximately 100 μΩ-cm) in their normal state. Laser light of moderate energy triggers the transition in nanoseconds. The high-temperature oxide superconductors show promise of having similar critical current densities but higher normal-state resistivities (approximately 1000 μΩ-cm). These properties raise the possibility of making a superconducting fast opening switch. In conjunction with superconducting inductive energy storage (approximately 100 MJ/m3), such a switch could provide the basis for very compact terawatt pulsed power generators. The authors show some of the possible configurations, physical constraints, and scaling laws for such systems.
Index Keywords: Electric Inductors; Electric Switches; Laser Beams; Pulse Generators; High-Temperature Oxide Superconductors; Niobium Nitride Films; Superconducting Inductive Energy Storage; Superconducting Opening Switch; Terawatt Pulsed Power Generators; Superconducting Devices

Authors: Lindner K., Long J., Helava H., Zucker O.
Title: Enhanced energy transfer to an EM gun
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lindner, K., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA; Long, J., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA; Helava, H., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA; Zucker, O., Energy Compression Research Corp,, Del Mar, CA, USA
Abstract: An experiment was performed to demonstrate that given a specific energy bank, inductive store, and load, the Meatgrinder circuit could accelerate a projectile to a higher velocity than would be achieved by conventional transfer (i.e., an inductor with no switching). The average projectile velocities (using data taken from ballistic pendulum measurements) showed an increase in projectile velocity and energy over the conventional transfer method of 48% and 118%, respectively, or more than double the energy. The results of the experiment show that the gun current profile was changed. Instead of drooping at the same rate as the conventional shots (approximately L/R), the current was held up at a higher level for a longer time, and therefore the projectile velocity was increased.
Index Keywords: Electric Inductors--Energy Storage; Electromagnetic Gun; Energy Bank; Inductive Energy Storage; Meatgrinder Circuit; Projectile Accelerator; Propulsion

Authors: Alme M.L., Bird G., Boyer C., Coffey S.K., Conte D., Davis J.F., Seiler S.W., Turchi P.J., Baker W.L., Degnan J.H., Hall D.J., Holmes J.L., Kriebel J.B., McCullough W.F., Price D.W., Buff J., Frese M.H., Peterkin Jr. R.E., Roderick N.F., Graham J.D., Lopez E.A.
Title: High voltage pulse generation in 10-megampere plasma flow switch experiments
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Alme, M.L., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Bird, G., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Boyer, C., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Coffey, S.K., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Conte, D., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Davis, J.F., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Seiler, S.W., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Turchi, P.J., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Baker, W.L., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Degnan, J.H., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Hall, D.J., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Holmes, J.L., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Kriebel, J.B., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; McCullough, W.F., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Price, D.W., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Buff, J., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Frese, M.H., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Peterkin Jr., R.E., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Roderick, N.F., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Graham, J.D., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA; Lopez, E.A., R&D Associates Inc, Alexandria,, VA, USA
Abstract: A description is given of the Open Fire experiments, carried out to examine the voltage capabilities of the plasma flow switch. These experiments used the Shiva Star capacitor bank, charged initially to 84 kV (4.6 MJ) to achieve currents in excess of 10 MA at the switch region. Comparisons of voltage measurements in the bank transmission line with results of numerical simulations (MACH2) computer code) indicate that the low-density, very-high-speed flow in the switch supports voltages in excess of 0.5 MV at the coaxial gun muzzle. Measurements of hard X-radiation (>10-100 keV) imply the existence of high-energy electrons and are consistent with the generation of high voltages in the plasma flow switch.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Computer Simulation; Electric Measurements--Voltage; Pulse Generators; Bank Transmission Line; Open Fire Experiments; Plasma Flow Switch; Plasma Implosions; Shiva Star Capacitor Bank; Plasma Devices

Authors: Degnan J.H., Baker W.L., Hackett K.E., Hall D.J., Holmes J.L., Kriebel J.B., Price D.W., Reinovsky R.E., Graham J.D., Lopez E.A., Alme M.L., Bird G., Boyer C.B., Coffey S.K., Conte D., Davis J.F., Seiler S., Turchi P.J.
Title: Experimental results from SHIVA star vacuum inductive store/plasma flow switch driven implosions
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Degnan, J.H., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Baker, W.L., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Hackett, K.E., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Hall, D.J., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Holmes, J.L., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Kriebel, J.B., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Price, D.W., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Reinovsky, R.E., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Graham, J.D., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Lopez, E.A., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Alme, M.L., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Bird, G., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Boyer, C.B., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Coffey, S.K., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Conte, D., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Davis, J.F., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Seiler, S., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA; Turchi, P.J., US Air Force Weapons Lab, Kirtland, AFB, NM, USA
Abstract: Using a 1313-μF, 3-nH, 120-kV, 9.4-MJ SHIVA Star capacitor bank, the authors performed vacuum-inductive-store/plasma-flow-switch (PFS) -driven implosions of low-mass (200-400 μg/cm2) cylindrical foil liners of 2-cm height and 5-cm radius. This technique uses a coaxial discharge through a plasma armature, which stores magnetic energy over 3 to 4 μs and rapidly switches it to an imploding load upon exiting the plasma armature from the coaxial gun muzzle. The current transferred to the load by the PFS has a risetime of less than 0.2 μs. With 5-MJ stored energy, fast linear implosions have been driven with a current of over 9 MA, provide an isotropic equivalent 2.7-TW, 0.5-MJ X-ray yield.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Lasers--Fusion Applications; EM Implosion; Plasma Flow Switch; Radiation Pulses; SHIVA Star Capacitor Bank; Vacuum Inductive Store; Plasmas

Authors: Curry R., Bailey V., Nett D., Putnam S., Tiefenback M., Lyons S., Weseloh W.
Title: Versatile, modular capacitor bank for a compact accelerator
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Curry, R., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Bailey, V., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Nett, D., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Putnam, S., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Tiefenback, M., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Lyons, S., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA; Weseloh, W., Pulse Sciences Inc, San Leandro, CA,, USA
Abstract: A phase I experimental and theoretical program is underway to investigate key physics issues regarding energy bandwidth, control of emittance growth, and electromagnetic instabilities for the spiral line-recirculating induction accelerator (SLIA), a compact, lightweight electron accelerator designed to produce high current (≥ 50 MeV) and moderate- to high-quality electron beams with macropulse widths up to several microseconds. General-purpose, low-voltage, modular capacitor banks consisting of 24 1.4-mF, 450-V electrolytic capacitors were chosen as the energy source for the magnet coils. With minor modifications, the capacitor banks can be connected in parallel or series to accommodate the widely varying inductances and resistances encountered in the experiments. The bank design is based on discharge current and voltage reversal characteristics determined in tests performed on electrolytic capacitors. Designed around state-of-the-art power semiconductors (SCRs and diodes), the banks are easily serviceable and inexpensive to construct. The design for the capacitor control/data acquisition system and the nine capacitor banks required for the phase I experiments are presented. Test data on the capacitor bank design to date are presented, and the applicability of computer-controlled capacitor banks to compact accelerator concepts is discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitors, Electrolytic--Energy Storage; Capacitors--Control; Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Capacitor Control/Data Acquisition System; Compact Accelerator; Computer-Controlled Capacitor Banks; Modular Capacitor Bank; Accelerators

Authors: Allano S., Delmas A., Rioux C.
Title: Study of a non dissipative transfer system and tests on related vacuum switches
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Univ de Paris VI & XI, Lab, d'Electrotech, Orsay, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Allano, S., Univ de Paris VI & XI, Lab, d'Electrotech, Orsay, Fr; Delmas, A., Univ de Paris VI & XI, Lab, d'Electrotech, Orsay, Fr; Rioux, C., Univ de Paris VI & XI, Lab, d'Electrotech, Orsay, Fr
Abstract: The authors describe a novel approach toinductive energy transfer, in which the main goal is the improvement of the efficiency of the transfer compared to other dissipative methods. The approach involves transient storage in a capacitor of the energy usually dissipated in the switches at each step of a transfer. Principles and main relations are presented, tests on a vacuum switch are described and discussed, elements of the design of an experimental device are briefly given, and results of a numerical simulation are presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Computer Simulation; Electric Networks; Electric Switches; Electrodes; Inductive Energy Transfer; Spiral Electrodes; Vacuum Switches; Electric Inductors

Title: Self-crowbarring ablation mass driver
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Inst of Plasma Phys, Nagoya Univ,, Nagoya, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ikuta, K., Inst of Plasma Phys, Nagoya Univ,, Nagoya, Jpn
Abstract: The electromagnetic acceleration of macroparticles to hypervelocities in an axisymmetric geometry was reconsidered in order to use high-energy-density capacitors (HEDC) as an energy source. This novel version of an accelerator has self-crowbarring electrodes arranged periodically in the electrode array; these electrodes can avoid a voltage reversal of HEDC since the allowable voltage reversal for HEDC is significantly low. A practical design of the mass driver is shown.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electrodes; Ablation Mass Driver; Electrode Array; High-Energy-Density Capacitors (HEDC); Macroparticles Acceleration; Projectile Velocity; Self-Crowbarring Electrodes; Propulsion

Authors: Gordon L.B., Druce R.L., Wilson M.J.
Title: Failure modes of laminate structures
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, Alabama, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, L.B., Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, Alabama, USA; Druce, R.L., Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, Alabama, USA; Wilson, M.J., Space Power Inst, Auburn Univ,, Auburn, Alabama, USA
Abstract: Laminate structures composed of alternating thin layers of conductor and dielectric material are commonly used in energy storage and transmission components. The failure of the dielectric layers in regions of high field stress, with applied 60-Hz AC, DC, and impulse voltages, was studied. Several geometries were compared, including staggered and flush edges. Electrical trees developed between the laminated dielectric layers. The visual characteristics and growth rates of the electrical trees under AC, DC, and impulse stresses were different. Partial discharge detection and analysis was used to measure the inception voltage and discharge activity at the conductor edge voids, to observe tree formation and growth, and to predict impending failure due to dielectric erosion. Electric field distributions were modeled, and partial discharge inception levels were estimated from known void geometries. The staggered-edge geometry appears to enhance the electric field stress at the recessed electrode.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric Discharges; Electric Fields; Electric Insulating Materials--Testing; Electric Field Distribution; Electrical Treeing; Kapton Laminate; Laminate Structures; Pulsed Power Systems; Electric Insulation

Title: Multicycle resonant energy recovery for inductive energy applications
Source title: 6th IEEE Pulsed Power Conference, Arlington, Virginia 1987
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ness, R.M., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Chu, E.Y., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: The authors describe an innovative concept for recovering the electrical energy remaining in an inductive energy storage system, such as that left in the barrel of a railgun after the projectile had exited the gun. Previously discussed recovery schemes generally use the a capacitor bank that is capable of storing all the energy to be recovered. The authors describe a circuit that recovers the energy in multiple parcels, each being a small fraction of the overall energy. This concept, referred to as multicycle resonant energy recovery, allows a significant reduction in the size and weight of the intermediate energy storage elements. The basic circuit and its operation are discussed as well as criteria for component selection, scaling, and tradeoffs. Results from a computer simulation of the application of the circuit to a railgun model are presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Computer Simulation; Electric Inductors; Electric Networks--Resonant Circuits; Inductive Energy Storage; Inductive Energy Storage System; Railgun Model; Resonant Energy Recovery; Propulsion

Authors: Su W-F A., Bich G.J., Merian J.S., Haderer N.G.
Title: New high temperature resistant, low viscosity, high solids polyester wire enamel
Source title: Proceedings of the Electrical/Electronics Insulation Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Su, W-F A., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Bich, G.J., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Merian, J.S., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Haderer, N.G., Westinghouse Research & Dev, Cent, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Abstract: A description is given of a high-solid-content (~40%), low-viscosity (~500 cps/25°C) polyester undercoat wire enamel developed through the synthesis of novel polymers and strict rheological control of the resulting resin formulations. This material is classified as a 200°C enamel when overcoated with modified polyamide-imides. The low viscosity of this enamel provides excellent coatability within a very wide range of wire sizes, increasing production speed and reducing scrap. Replacement of conventional 30%-solids enamels with this higher solids concentration material decreases volatile organic compound emission during the coating process, so less energy is consumed for incineration of atmospheric pollutants. Storage and transportation characteristics are also improved.
Index Keywords: Enamel; Polyesters; Polyester Wire Enamel; Undercoat Wire Enamel; Electric Conductors, Insulated Wire

Title: R&D IN ENERGY STORAGE - A FIELD OF INTEREST FOR BUILDING CONTRACTORS.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Sjokvist, Kurt
Abstract: During the construction of hydropower plants and tunnels, and construction work in urban areas with various geological conditions, Sweden has developed methods and equipment which can also be applied to the construction of subsurface energy stores. Many large-scale energy stores have thus been realized over the last eight years. The heat storage systems developed that may be mentioned in this context are: storage in rock caverns and pits; borehole stores in soil and rock; pipe systems in soil (clay) and rock; and storage in aquifers.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS - Thermal Properties; GEOLOGY - Caves; STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Underground; GENERAL ENERGY SITUATION; GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION; GEOLOGICAL CONDITIONS; NATURAL RESOURCES; SWEDEN; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Allars J., Holt S.J., York D.A.
Title: Energetic efficiency and brown adipose tissue uncoupling protein of obese Zucker rats fed high-carbohydrate and high-fat diets: The effects of adrenalectomy
Affiliations: Department of Nutrition, School of Biochemical and Physiological Sciences, Southampton University, Southampton S09 3TU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Allars, J., Department of Nutrition, School of Biochemical and Physiological Sciences, Southampton University, Southampton S09 3TU, United Kingdom; Holt, S.J., Department of Nutrition, School of Biochemical and Physiological Sciences, Southampton University, Southampton S09 3TU, United Kingdom; York, D.A., Department of Nutrition, School of Biochemical and Physiological Sciences, Southampton University, Southampton S09 3TU, United Kingdom
Abstract: The influence of diet on the response of lean and obese fa/fa rats to adrenalectomy has been studied. Adrenalectomized and sham-operated rats were fed either a semi-synthetic high-carbohydrate (HC) or high-fat (HF) diet for 13 days. Energetic efficiency, calculated for measurements of energy storage and energy intake, was increased in obese rats fed both HC and HF diets and reduced close to values of lean rats after adrenalectomy. Brown adipose tissue mitochondrial GDP binding and uncoupling protein concentration were reduced in control obese rats fed both HC and HF diets. After adrenalectomy the level of GDP binding and uncoupling protein concentration were increased to levels of lean rats. Molar ratios of GDP binding to uncoupling protein were similar in lean and obese rats, were unaffected by adrenalectomy, but were elevated in rats fed the HC diet (0.40±0.02 vs 0.28±0.03). The data suggests that diet, but not obese genotype, may influence the masking of mitochondrial uncoupling protein.
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; fat; adrenalectomy; animal experiment; brown adipose tissue; diet; energy metabolism; mitochondrion; nonhuman; obesity; productivity; uncoupling protein; Adrenalectomy; Animal; Body Composition; Body Weight; Brown Fat; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Guanosine Diphosphate; Male; Membrane Proteins; Mitochondria; Obesity; Rats; Rats, Zucker; Uncoupling Agents

Title: SEASONAL STORAGE OF HEAT FOR DISTRICT HEATING IN SWEDEN.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Sabel, Hans
Abstract: Seasonal storage of heat is still relatively little known to Swedish district heating energies. Several municipalities that operate district heating systems have investigated various heat storage projects. A generalized survey of the opportunities offered by the seasonal storage of heat for district heating is presented, together with some of the conditions that must be satisfied if heat storage projects are to materialize in Swedish municipalities operating district heating systems.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Research; HEATING - District; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; DISTRICT HEATING PLANTS; LARGE-SCALE SEASONAL HEAT STORAGE; SWEDEN; THERMAL ENERGY; MUNICIPAL ENGINEERING

Title: LONG RANGE GLOBAL ENERGY DEMAND AND SUPPLY.
Authors with affiliations: El-Abiad, A.H.
Abstract: The author gives some thought to the role of Africa in meeting future energy demand and what its current energy policies should stress. He discusses current and future demand, limitations to fossil fuel use, and global energy flow and storage. He then examines the potential of solar energy.
Index Keywords: SOLAR POWER PLANTS; LIMITATIONS TO FOSSIL FUEL USE; LONG RANGE GLOBAL ENERGY DEMAND AND SUPPLY; ENERGY POLICY

Title: BOREHOLE HEAT STORE IN ROCK AT THE LULEA UNIVERSITY OF TECHNOLOGY: CONSTRUCTIONAL AND OPERATIONAL EXPERIENCE. THE LULEVARME PROJECT 1982-1985.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Nordell, Bo
Abstract: Constructional work on the borehole heat store in Lulea was started in August 1982, and the store was started up in July 1983. The work was carried out on a turnkey basis by Svenska Energi System AB (SES), Lulea. The objective of the project is to demonstrate and investigate borehole heat storage technology in this experimental heat store. The actual heat store itself consists of a volume of rock amounting to about 100,000 m**3, beneath an overburden of mineral soil 2-6 m in depth. 120 boreholes have been drilled in the bedrock to a depth of 65 m, and serve as heat exchangers when charging and discharging the store. Much of the research program involves measurements intended to document performance of the store.
Index Keywords: BOREHOLES - Circulating Media; HEAT EXCHANGERS; ROCK - Thermal Properties; HEAT STORAGE METHODS; STORE VOLUME; TEMPERATURE SENSORS; WATER LOSS MEASUREMENTS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: ELECTRIC HEAT PUMPS FOR SPACE HEATING IN DWELLINGS.
Affiliations: Laing Group, Engl, Laing Group, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Spiers, K.J., Laing Group, Engl, Laing Group, Engl
Abstract: It was widely thought that heat pumps could provide an economic technical solution for heating domestic dwellings, particularly in those areas of the UK where natural gas was not available. Laing Research and Development Limited examined a large number of options for improving performance and reliability of the domestic heat pump and came to the conclusion that by changing three key operational factors it would be possible to produce an attractive domestic heat pump system for low heat-loss housing. Laing R plus D installed a standard Calorex heat pump together with a space heating and DHW storage system in a low-energy house at Clacton, Essex, in order to evaluate the overall performance of the concept. The CREDA Domestic Appliance Group has commissioned the design and manufacture of a prototype domestic heat pump with its associated hot water storage.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Electric; HOUSES - Space Heating; CREDA DOMESTIC APPLIANCE GROUP; ELECTRIC HEAT PUMPS; LAING RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT LIMITED; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE PROGRAMME IN SWEDEN: REVIEW OF R&D PLANNING, PROJECTS, EXPERIENCES AND FUTURE ACTIVITIES.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Lundin, Sven-Erik
Abstract: Swedish energy policy in the area of thermal energy storage made possible the application of the technology in a number of full-scale projects. Short-term heat storage in water (reservoirs) is a known and commercially available technology. Systems for seasonal storage of thermal energy have been developed concurrently with the development of solar heating technology. Direct large scale subsurface heat storage utilizing a variety of heat sources and production systems is now ready to be introduced on the market. It is estimated that by 1987, the new technologies will have become an integral part of the transition of thermal energy production towards decreased oil dependence in Sweden.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Heat Storage; RESERVOIRS - Thermal Properties; SOLAR ENERGY - Control; ENERGY TECHNOLOGY; NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAM; SWEDEN; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: GROUND HEAT STORAGE TECHNOLOGY IN SWEDEN.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Soren
Abstract: Ground heat storage in Sweden generally refers to heat storage in rock, clay or peat. Bedrock suitable for different applications of borehole heat storage is accessible in most parts of the country, whereas clay and peat in urban areas are concentrated to specific regions. A number of ground heat storage projects during the last years have been implemented in rock as well as in clay and peat. The projects are in different stages of follow up and evaluation. Other projects are planned or being designed. This paper deals with technical solutions, environmental aspects and economics of the different storage concepts.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ROCK - Energy Storage; SOILS - Thermal Properties; GROUND HEAT STORAGE TECHNOLOGY; STORAGE IN AQUIFERS; STORAGE IN WATER; SWEDEN; HEATING

Authors: Autin B., Carron G., Caspers F., Thorndahl L.
Title: Applications of microwave to antiproton control
Affiliations: CERN, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Autin, B., CERN, Switzerland; Carron, G., CERN, Switzerland; Caspers, F., CERN, Switzerland; Thorndahl, L., CERN, Switzerland
Abstract: A major achievement in particle accelerator physics has been the invention of stochastic cooling, a method which increases the density of beams of rare particles, like antiprotons, by several orders of magnitude. The beam circulates in a storage ring where it is sampled by electromagnetic devices which detect and correct the statistical fluctuations in position and energy. The efficiency is related to the sampling resolution which is itself associated with the system frequency bandwidth, a few gigahertz in practice. The coupling structures are made of electrode arrays connected by combiner or splitter networks. The dynamic range may exceed 150 dB yet fulfils stringent linear characteristics. At the detection stage, the thermal noise is reduced using cryo-electronic techniques. At the other end of the amplification chain, solid state amplifiers delivering up to 100 W CW power have been preferred to travelling wave tubes for reasons of phase linearity, lifetime and economy. The performances and technological aspects of the microwave systems are discussed by the example of the CERN antiproton project, ACOL.
Index Keywords: Protons - Control; Antiproton Control; CERN Antiproton Project; Rare Particles; Solid State Amplifiers; Statistical Fluctuations; Stochastic Cooling; Accelerators

Authors: Badziak J., Galkowski A., Kalbarczyk A., Kurzynski Z.

Affiliations: S. Kaliski Inst of Plasma Physics, & Laser Microfusion, Poland

Abstract: The analysis has been performed for two typical CO2:N2:He gaseous mixtures in the case of amplifiers with UV preionization. The results of computation have been compared with those of experimental investigation. The agreement between the electric processes and the small signal gain coefficient has been found to be relatively good. The influence of the parameters of the electric circuit on the principal laser parameters of the amplifier has been analyzed.

Authors: Galkowski A., Kalbarczyk A., Kurzynski Z.
Title: Analysis of energy storage and extraction in TEA UV-preionized CO2 laser amplifiers: Part I. Numerical determination of effective vibrational excitation rate coefficients and transport coefficients
Affiliations: S. Kaliski Inst of Plasma Physics, & Laser Microfusion, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Galkowski, A., S. Kaliski Inst of Plasma Physics, & Laser Microfusion, Poland; Kalbarczyk, A., S. Kaliski Inst of Plasma Physics, & Laser Microfusion, Poland; Kurzynski, Z., S. Kaliski Inst of Plasma Physics, & Laser Microfusion, Poland
Abstract: The development of CO2 lasers and the increasing range of their application necessitate continuous improvement of the theoretical models describing the physical processes occurring in laser media. Quatitative description of such processes gives a possibility of optimum design and considerable reduction of the costs of constructing such a device, which is particularly important for large laser systems. The present paper constitutes the first part of a work devoted to problems of energy storage and extraction of TEA UV-preionized CO2 amplifiers and is concerned with the problem of determining the transport coefficients and vibrational excitation coefficients by solving the Boltzmann equation.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Effective Vibrational Excitation Rate Coefficients; Laser Amplifiers; Transport Coefficients; Lasers, Carbon Dioxide

Title: New measuring system of transient response of advanced batteries for abrupt load changes
Source title: Journal of Physics E: Scientific Instruments
Affiliations: Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Futamata, M., Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Osaka, Japan; Takahashi, S., Gov. Ind. Res. Inst., Osaka, Japan
Abstract: A measuring system was constructed for the first time to evaluate the immediate availability of advanced batteries for an electric energy storage system. It was verified that the measuring system can be employed to determine the transient response of advanced batteries for abrupt load changes. Transient response for the charge-discharge (C/D) equipment is discussed. It was found that the transient response of the C/D equipment depends on the operating voltage and also on the internal resistance of the load (battery): the delay time of the output current was less than 100 ms at an operating voltage of between 12.5-63 V; the rise time of an output current was observed to be between 10 and 150 ms for an internal resistance between 10 and 200 m Omega . Second, the transient response of a 10 kW lead-acid battery is discussed. The rise and fall times of the load current were determined to be within 10 and 1 ms respectively with the use of this system. It was verified that the response of a large-scale secondary battery to abrupt load changes is fast enough to use the battery for an electric energy storage system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Measurements; ABRUPT LOAD CHANGES; LEAD-ACID BATTERY; TRANSIENT RESPONSE OF ADVANCED BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Beniwal R.S., Singh R., Saxena N.S., Bhandari R.C.
Title: Thermal behaviour of salt gradient solar ponds
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Dept. of Phys., Rajasthan Univ., Jaipur, India
Authors with affiliations: Beniwal, R.S., Dept. of Phys., Rajasthan Univ., Jaipur, India; Singh, R., Dept. of Phys., Rajasthan Univ., Jaipur, India; Saxena, N.S., Dept. of Phys., Rajasthan Univ., Jaipur, India; Bhandari, R.C., Dept. of Phys., Rajasthan Univ., Jaipur, India
Abstract: A numerical model has been developed to study the thermal behaviour of salt gradient solar ponds under different operating conditions. A cylindrical solar pond system with a thermal sink below and around the pond is also modelled to determine the heat losses to the earth. In these calculations, the solar pond is considered as a steady-state flat-plate collector. The effects of the thickness of three different zones and insulating materials below and around the pond on the overall thermal performance of the pond are studied. There is an optimum thickness of the non-convective zone for which the heat storage is maximum. The pond bottom and side heat losses are reduced using some low-cost insulating building materials such as dry dune sand, dry mica powder and dry marble dust below and around the pond. The results of a comparative study indicate that heat losses are considerably reduced with marble dust insulation and the solar thermal energy retaining capability of the pond is improved.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Conduction; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Numerical Analysis; THERMAL EFFECTS; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Fischer J., Kühne M., Wende B.
Title: Laser-produced plasmas as radiometric transfer-standard sources for the vacuum-ultraviolet and the soft-x-ray range
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, J., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Kühne, M., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Wende, B., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, 1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: Laser-produced tungsten plasmas were investigated with respect to their suitability as radiometric transfer standard sources in the range between 7 nm and 100 nm. For plasma generation a Nd:YAG/glass laser system with λ = 1.064 μm, a pulse length of 17 ns and pulse energies between 100 mJ and 800 mJ was used in connection with a focusing system of 85 mm focal length. The spectral concentration of radiant intensity time-integrated over one plasma radiation pulse was measured with a relative uncertainty of 8% using the electron storage ring BESSY as a primary standard. Within this uncertainty the radiant emission was reproducible during several months, if one applied specific procedures that had been developed for setting the laser parameters and the focusing conditions. The maximum of emission was found at 16.5 nm. At this wavelength a 800 mJ laser pulse generates 3.5 × 1014 photons nm-1 sr-1. The results of this study let us expect that a small transportable radiation standard is practical, which is based on a low-cost, single-stage, Nd-laser system.
Index Keywords: LASERS - Applications; PLASMAS - Production; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION - Sources; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION; LASER-PRODUCED PLASMAS; RADIOMETRIC TRANSFER-STANDARD SOURCES; SOFT-X-RAY RANGE; RADIOMETERS

Title: Modelling and characterisation of a micropole undulator with a 726μm period
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiat. Lab., Stanford Univ., CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Synchrotron Radiat. Lab., Stanford Univ., CA, United States; Csonka, P.
Abstract: Micropole undulators (i.e. undulators with submillimetre periods) have the potential for fundamentally transforming the current state of synchrotron radiation technology. For example, brightness and photon energy resolution exceeding those of conventional insertion devices will become available on storage rings of much lower energy than those in present use. The authors report on the measurement and modelling of a recently built prototype device consisting of thirty-five 726 mu m periods. This device was constructed on the basis of a novel approach that, coupled with the particular configuration of its permanent magnet and soft steel elements, constitutes a design scheme that will eventually enable much shorter periods to be reached.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; PHOTONS; MICROPOLE UNDULATOR; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; MAGNETIC DEVICES

Title: BURDEKIN FALLS DAM.
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Shannon, B.J., Queensland Water Resources, Commission, Aust, Queensland Water Resources Commission, Aust
Abstract: Burdekin Falls dam is the largest concrete gravity dam built in Australia in recent times. The dam, built on the Burdekin river, Queensland, contains 650 multiplied by 10**3 m**3 of concrete and will impound a storage of 1. 86 multiplied by 10**6 MI. A spillway section, over 500 m long, will pass floods up to 64 600 m**3/s. Monoliths for the dam are of conventional design, but no energy dissipator is provided for the spillway because of the high quality of the rock foundation and the absence of tailwater.
Index Keywords: DAMS, GRAVITY; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; IRRIGATION; SPILLWAYS; BURDEKIN FALLS DAM (AUSTRALIA); CATCHMENT HYDROLOGY; IRRIGATION PROJECT; SPILLWAY APRON; DAMS, CONCRETE

Title: AEROGENERATOR CONFIGURATIONS FOR HYBRID WIND-DIESEL SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Harrap, M.J., Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust; Baird, J.P., Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Campbell, Aust
Abstract: Autonomous wind-diesel hybrid power supply systems with limited energy storage are considered. The relationship between the aerogenerator's turbine swept area and rated power is examined using windspeed time series data from three locations. The performance of the hybrid power supply is then considered. Results from this study suggest that an aerogenerator configuration consistent with maximum annual energy production per unit swept area and unlimited storage, is not necessarily optimum when storage is limited. A case study of a small (7500 kWh/annum) hybrid power supply is made and supports the contention that aerogenerators will only prove economically useful in displacing diesel fuel if correctly configured - particularly at sites where mean windspeeds are relatively low.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; WIND POWER; AEROGENERATORS; HYBRID WIND-DIESEL POWER GENERATION; WIND TURBINES

Title: Multiconnected neural network models
Source title: Journal of Physics A: General Physics
Affiliations: Dept. of Phys., Edinburgh Univ., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gardner, E., Dept. of Phys., Edinburgh Univ., United Kingdom
Abstract: A generalisation of the Hopfield model which includes interactions between p()2) Ising spins is considered. The exact storage capacity behaves as N p-1/2(p-1)! ln N when the number of nodes, N, is large. In the limit p to infinity , the thermodynamics of the model can be solved exactly without using the replica method; at zero temperature, a solution which is completely correlated with the input pattern exists for alpha < alpha c where alpha c to infinity as p to infinity and this solution has lower energy than the spin-glass solution if alpha < alpha 1=1/4 ln 2 where the number of patterns n=(2 alpha /p!)Np-1. For finite values of p, the correlation with the input pattern is not complete; for p=3 and 4, approximate values of alpha c and alpha 1 are obtained and for p to infinity the replica symmetric approximation gives alpha c approximately p/4 ln p.

Title: Attainment of submillimeter periods and a 0.3-T peak field in a novel micropole undulator device
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Institute of Theoretical Science and Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States, Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States; Csonka, P.L., Institute of Theoretical Science and Department of Physics, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Abstract: A micropole undulator is defined here as an undulator with a very short (submillimeter) period and correspondingly shorter poles. The availability of micropole undulators is expected to profoundly affect the development of x-ray sources. For example, with such devices x-ray beams comparable to those from conventional undulators will be attainable on storage rings of much lower energy (and emittance) than those presently in use. X-ray instrumentation will also be affected, e.g., micropole undulators of sufficient length can provide extremely monochromatic outputs, obviating the need for expensive and complex ultrahigh vacuum monochromator systems. Here we describe the design and practical construction of a prototype 35 period micropole undulator whose total length is 2.54 cm. The device is of a novel hybrid/electromagnetic bias design. We also present results of field profile measurements along the central plane of the new device.

Authors: Da Silva Jr. E.F., Nishioka Y., Ma T.-P.
Title: Two distinct interface trap peaks in radiation-damaged metal/SiO 2/Si structures
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States
Authors with affiliations: Da Silva Jr., E.F., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States; Nishioka, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States; Ma, T.-P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States
Abstract: Two distinct peaks in the interface trap distribution on (100) Si, one above and the other below the Si midgap energy, have been observed in a wide selection of metal/SiO2/Si capacitors after they are exposed to ionizing radiation. The samples tested cover a wide range of gate electrode materials (Al, polycrystalline Si, Mo, and TiSi2) and oxidation environments [dry O2, steam, dry O2+TCA (trichloroethane), and dry O2+HCl at various temperatures]. Among all the samples tested, the peak above midgap (∼Ev+0.75 eV) appeared immediately after irradiation, and for most samples the peak below midgap (∼E v+0.35 eV) only appeared at long times (up to a few months) after irradiation. The evolution of the two peaks as a function of time has been found to depend strongly on the gate electrode, oxidation environment, sample storage temperature, and gate bias during storage. Detailed studies of these two peaks should lead to a better understanding of the defect formation process at the SiO2/Si interface.

Title: Electron capture by FeIII and (FeO2) centres in haemoglobin, and the absence of subsequent electron transfer from (FeO2)- centres to FeIII. An electron spin resonance study
Source title: Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 1: Physical Chemistry in Condensed Phases
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, The University, Leicester LEI 7RH
Authors with affiliations: Symons, M.C.R., Department of Chemistry, The University, Leicester LEI 7RH; Taiwo, F.A., Department of Chemistry, The University, Leicester LEI 7RH
Abstract: Haemoglobin molecules containing FeIII and FeO2 porphyrin units have been exposed to 60Co γ-rays at 77 K. Electron ejection within the protein molecules is followed by efficient electron capture at both iron centres, giving a loss in the FeIII g = 6 feature and a gain in features assigned to (FeO2)- units. Features in the g = 2 region of the spectrum are assigned to protein electron-loss centres. The results confirm that electrons in these proteins are mobile and relatively long-lived, despite their ability to react with amide groups and various side groups. Furthermore, a method is developed which gives relative yields of the FeII and (FeO2)- units with considerable accuracy and it is concluded that e- capture by FeO2 is ca. 2.5 times as probable as capture by FeIII. Also, storage at 77 K for several months resulted in no detectable intramolecular electron transfer to give FeO2 and FeII units despite the resultant gain in stability. This result is contrasted with a recent study involving electron transfer from 3ZnII to FeIII in Zn-Fe hybrids, which occurs quite rapidly at 77 K (kt ≈ 0.8 s-1). We conclude that in our case electron-transfer rates are greatly reduced because the energy difference is smaller than for the 3ZnII case. Various alternatives based on non-statistical distribution of O2 in the protein tetramers are considered, but we conclude that these cannot explain the different results. Reasons for the greater ease of electron-addition to FeO2 units relative to FeIII units are discussed. The electron-loss centres are identified as nitrogen-centred radicals, formed from the peptide backbone by proton transfer to carbonyl oxygen atoms. That these centres become rapidly immobilized is established by the fact that when pure deoxyhaemoglobin (FeII) is irradiated, there is no detectable formation of FeIII units. From an analysis of the β-proton hyperfine coupling in these N-centred radicals it is shown that the majority must be formed within the α-helical regions of this protein, the conformations requiring that A(βH) ≈ 38 G. However, a considerable number are formed in random-coil regions; these give small β-proton splittings.

Authors: Takahashi Y., Kamimoto M., Abe Y., Sakamoto R., Kanari K., Ozawa T.
Title: Investigation of latent heat-thermal energy storage materials. IV. Thermoanalytical evaluation of binary eutectic mixtures of NaOH with LiOH or KOH
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Differential scanning calorimetry is used to measure the heat capacity and heat of fusion of binary eutectic mixtures of NaOH with LiOH or KOH, which are promising materials for latent heat-thermal energy storage materials. These binary mixtures are concluded to be useful for thermal energy storage, when residual water, which has a large influence on their thermal characteristics, is exclusively eliminated. The thermophysical data obtained are also useful in R&D of the technology as well as design of the equipment. © 1987.

Title: Finite-element simulation of low-temperature, heat-pump-coupled, aquifer thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Geology, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dwyer, T.E., Department of Geology, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States; Eckstein, Y., Department of Geology, Kent State University, Kent, OH 44242, United States
Abstract: A two-dimensional, Galerkin finite-element, transport model was applied to a feasibility study of low temperature, heat pump coupled, aquifer thermal energy storage in a confined sandstone aquifer in northeastern Ohio. Simulations were run to determine the relative sensitivity of the model to transient versus steady-state radial flow, grid size, time-step lengths, and injection temperatures. In order to determine the effects of uncertainties in the values of aquifer and aquitard parameters, energy recovery factors and recovery temperatures were calculated for worst-case, best-case, and best-estimate simulations. Aquifer and aquitard parameters were either measured directly or were estimated based on previous hydrogeologic investigations. All simulations were performed assuming a 150 d injection phase with a pumping rate of 15 m3h-1, a 35 d storage phase, and a 150 d production phase, also with a pumping rate of 15 m3h-1. The worst-case simulation for an injection temperature of 23.9°C produced an energy recovery factor of 0.43 and a final production temperature of 14.6°C. The best-case simulation resulted in an energy recovery factor of 0.69 and a final production temperature of 16.2°C. The best-estimate simulation predicted an energy recovery factor of 0.50 and a final production temperature of 15.0°C. Both the energy recovery factor and the recovery temperature were most affected by the uncertainty in the storage formation longitudinal dispersivity. Using the best-estimate parameter values, an injection temperature of 18.0°C resulted in a final production temperature of 13.2°C and an energy recovery factor of 0.50. The best-estimate parameter values used with an injection temperature of 27.0°C yielded a final production temperature of 15.9°C and an energy recovery factor of 0.50. © 1987.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF WATER - Porous Materials; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER - Analysis; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method; SANDSTONE; GALERKIN FINITE-ELEMENT METHOD; SANDSTONE AQUIFER; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; AQUIFERS

Authors: Cogliandro S., Panizza M., Castelli P.
Title: Target vs. background discrimination using multispectral channel data in 1.5 - 14.5 micron
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Infrared Group I.A.M. Rinaldo Piaggio, Finale Ligure, 17024, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cogliandro, S., Infrared Group I.A.M. Rinaldo Piaggio, Finale Ligure, 17024, Italy; Panizza, M., Infrared Group I.A.M. Rinaldo Piaggio, Finale Ligure, 17024, Italy; Castelli, P., Infrared Group I.A.M. Rinaldo Piaggio, Finale Ligure, 17024, Italy
Abstract: The spectral background radiance and the spectral transmittance are experimentally investi-gated in 1.5 - 14.5 micron band and compared to LOWTRAN V model calculations. We use a BARNES spectroradiometer with CVF covering continuously 1.5 - 14.5 micron and two AGA Thermovision 782 IR scanners with three discrete filters in 3 - 5 micron band and 8 -12 micron band. Spectral and spatial IR data are available on-line by means of two personal computers: an HP9836 that drives the spectroradiometer and elaborates the data as a function of wave-length and an IBM PC-AT that drives the scanners and elaborates the spatial data in order to obtain pictures (512x512 pixels)displayed on a H.R. monitor. Our final goal is to identify the most important parameters affecting the discrimination of targets from background (spectral band choice, temperature, emissivity, and so on). To this end we measure also the IR energy emitted by a reference plate at different values of temperature and emissivity vs. various background previously investigated. In particular targets that are close to ambient temperature are considered. Emissivity gets estimated in our lab by means of a dedicated experimental set-up. This study is connected with a Piaggio R and D program in the field of IR coating and chemical reduction of IR signature for aircraft application. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Application programs; Electromagnetic wave emission; Infrared radiation; Personal computers; Radiometers; Scanning; Spectrometers; Aircraft applications; Background discrimination; Chemical reduction; Discrete filter; Experimental set up; Reference plate; Spectral transmittance; Spectro-radiometers; Digital storage

Authors: Rea P.A., Griffith C.J., Manolson M.F., Sanders D.
Title: Irreversible inhibition of H+-ATPase of higher plant tonoplast by chaotropic anions: evidence for peripheral location of nucleotide-binding subunits
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom; Department of Biology, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rea, P.A., Department of Biology, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom; Griffith, C.J., Department of Biology, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom; Manolson, M.F., Department of Biology, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Sanders, D., Department of Biology, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom
Abstract: The H+-translocating ATPase of tonoplast vesicles from storage root of Beta vulgaris L. is irreversibly inhibited by a 30 min treatment with the chaotropic anions SCN-, ClO4-, I- or NO3- in the 0.25-1.5 M concentration range. The inhibitory potencies of the anions follow the Hofmeister series (SCN- > ClO4- > I- > NO3- > CH3COO-; SO42- = 0). The H+-translocating inorganic pyrophosphatase of the same membrane is, by contrast, unaffected by chaotrope concentrations which completely abolish H+-ATPase activity. Inhibition of the ATPase is associated with the removal of two polypeptides of 67 and 57 kDa from the membrane, concomitant with their appearance in the supernatant. The chaotrope-dissociated 67 and 57 kDa polypeptides comigrate with the major subunits of the partially purified ATPase upon SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and cross-react with antibody raised to the nucleotide-binding subunits of the enzyme. Since the 16 kDa [14C]DCCD-binding proteolipid of the ATPase remains associated with the membrane after treatment with chaotrope, it is concluded that chaotropic anions inhibit the enzyme by specific detachment of the nucleotide-binding subunits. The tonoplast ATPase of Beta is therefore deduced to have structure/function partitioning analogous to the F0F1 H+-ATPase of energy-coupling membranes. © 1987.
Author Keywords: (B. vulgaris); ATPase; Chaotropic anion; H+-; Proton pump; Pyrophosphatase; Tonoplast

Title: EASY-TO-USE SOFTWARE SIZES AND ANALYZES THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Katzel, Jeanine
Abstract: Storage/PC sizes and analyzes thermal storage systems. Combining a thermal storage analysis program and load calculation program into a single unit, the package provides a fast and easy way to determine the size of the thermal equipment required for a building. The load calculation section is based on the ASHRAE load calculation method and is a computerized implementation of the ASHRAE manual load calculation procedure. Featuring a library of standard ASHRAE wall and roof constructions and people activity levels, the two-diskette program allows calculation of heat gain through glass and across partitions. The software runs easily from a diskette drive, but executes more rapidly and efficiently when installed on a hard disk.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SOFTWARE; ENERGY STORAGE - Computer Aided Analysis; HEAT TRANSFER - Computer Aided Analysis; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; BUILDINGS

Title: Transient state characteristics of changes in light conditions for the cyanobacterium Oscillatoria agardhii - II. Dynamics in cellular contents and growth rates
Affiliations: Laboratorium voor Microbiologie, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 127, Amsterdam, 1018 WS, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Post, A.F., Laboratorium voor Microbiologie, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 127, Amsterdam, 1018 WS, Netherlands
Abstract: The cyanobacterium Oscillatoria agardhii was subjected to changes in irradiance and to changes in light period. During transient states parameters as growth rate, pigment contents, photosynthetic activities and pool sizes of carbohydrate and proteins were followed. The changes in pigments and photosynthesis were similar for irradiance transitions and transitions in light period length. Carbohydrates served for the supply of carbon and energy during adaptation to low light conditions until a basal level of 125 μg · mg dry wt-1 was reached. After transfer to high light conditions excess carbon fixation led to the storage of carbohydrate reserve polymers up to 600 μg · mg dry wt-1. During adaptation to longer light periods cells showed an overcapacity for carbohydrate accumulation even in the presence of a high carbohydrate content at the start of the light period. A model for the feed back repression of photosynthesis related to carbohydrate accumulation was presented. In all cases protein synthesis was directly maximized under the given conditions. Growth rate defined as specific rate of change in carbon showed the fastest response after a shift in light conditions. It was concluded that adaptation of O. agardhii to changes in light conditions was directed to the optimization of growth. The observation that carbohydrate is used to supply carbon and/or energy during adaptation leads to the conclusion that changes on survival in low light depend on carbohydrate level, the efficiency of its conversion in cell material and the maintenance requirements. Such a survival strategy enables cyanobacteria to cope succesfully with light limiting conditions. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Carbohydrate accumulation; Cyanobacteria; Light-shade adaptation; Photosynthesis; Protein synthesis; Reserve polymers

Authors: Köhler G., Brodhun H.-P., Schäller G.
Title: Ecological energetics of Central European grasshoppers (Orthoptera: Acrididae)
Affiliations: Sektion Biologie, WB Ökologie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Neugasse 23, Jena, DDR-6900, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR)
Authors with affiliations: Köhler, G., Sektion Biologie, WB Ökologie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Neugasse 23, Jena, DDR-6900, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR); Brodhun, H.-P., Sektion Biologie, WB Ökologie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Neugasse 23, Jena, DDR-6900, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR); Schäller, G., Sektion Biologie, WB Ökologie, Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Neugasse 23, Jena, DDR-6900, Germany (Democratic Republic, DDR)
Abstract: Biomass and energy budgets and food utilization efficiencies of laboratory and wild populations of three Central European grasshopper species, Chorthippus parallelus (Zetterstedt), C. biguttulus (L.), and Gomphocerus rufus (L.), were studied between 1979 and 1984. Larval consumption is relatively low in C. biguttulus (C=4.3 kJ/ind.) compared with C. parallelus and G. rufus (4.9 kJ/ind.). In the adult phase (maturity) consumption rates of C. biguttulus and G. rufus (6.9 kJ/ind.) are similar, but higher in C. parallelus (7.3 kJ/ind.). The energy content decreases from the egg (23.2-24.3 J/mg dw) and body tissue (22.1-23.2 J/mg dw) to faeces (16.6-18.1 J/mg dw). The energy contents of faeces differ significantly between the species, indicating different rates of food conversion (on Dactylis glomerata). On average, the assimilation rates are about 30%, slightly lower in G. rufus. Approximate digestibility (A/C) ranges from 28.2 (G. rufus) to 35.7 (C. biguttulus) without great differences between larvae and adults. In contrast, the efficiency of conversion of ingested food (P/C) differs significantly between larval (10-11) and adult stages (3.4-3.6), and so to a much higher degree does the efficiency of conversion of digested food (P/A), from 30.3-33.5 in the larval to 9.5-14.9 in the adult period. Based on 5-year (C. parallelus) and 2-year studies (G. rufus) of the population dynamics and life tables, the energy budgets of wild populations were calculated and summarized into diagrams. Depending on the annually fluctuating densities, in both populations about 1%-2% of net primary production was consumed, and another 5%-9% was cut and dropped. The proportion of production of the grasshopper populations (body tissue) used for egg production differs in C. parallelus (28%) and G. rufus (44%). The energy cycling owing to energy storage in the living eggs amounts to 2%-3% of the total energy consumed by the population. The results are compared with the available data for grasshoppers in the literature. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Energy budgets; Food utilization efficiencies; Grasshoppers
Index Keywords: Chorthippus biguttulus/parallelus; Gomphocerus rufus

Authors: Akhmedov R.B., Zaichik L.I., Perederii A.D.
Title: STORAGE OF THERMAL ENERGY IN UNDERGROUND AQUIFERS.

Abstract: In the last decade great attention has been paid abroad to storing energy in underground aquifers. Thanks to a number of advantages (control of daily, weekly and seasonal load graphs, low specific capital investments, universal occurrence, important ecological advantages) aquifer storage is already used in systems of solar and decentralised heat supply. The paper sets out a method of calculation for permeation of heat carrier in aquifers. 3 Refs.

Authors: Hayashi Yujiro, Takimoto Akira, Kawahara Seiji
Title: STUDY OF COMBINED LATENT- AND SENSIBLE-HEAT THERMAL STORAGE (1ST REPORT, CHARGING AND DISCHARGING CHARACTERISTICS).

Abstract: A combined type of latent- and sensible-heat thermal energy storage is proposed to accomplish a higher performance of the thermal energy storage. Experiments were performed for water-n-octadecane and water-CaCl//26H//2O systems under various operating conditions. During the charging and discharging processes, the temperature distribution, heat transfer rate, and the phase change quantity of the PCM's were measured.

Authors: Kalnitsky A., King M.I.H., Boothroyd A.R., Ellul J.P., Hadaway R.A.
Title: MEMORY EFFECT AND ENHANCED CONDUCTIVITY IN SI-IMPLANTED THERMALLY GROWN SIO//2.
Affiliations: Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Kalnitsky, A., Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can; King, M.I.H., Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Boothroyd, A.R., Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Ellul, J.P., Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Hadaway, R.A., Northern Telecommunications, Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Northern Telecommunications Electronics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: Memory and enhanced conductivity properties of 25-nm-thick thermally grown SiO//2 implanted with 0. 5 to 20 multiplied by 10**1**5 Si ions/cm**2 at energies up to 25 keV is discussed. The implantation and subsequent anneal conditions can be chosen so that this material can be utilized as a replacement for tunnel dielectrics in floating gate EPROMs, EEPROMs, or as a charge storage medium for a 'floating trap' type single poly-Si transistor EEPROM cell. Memory effect was observed in oxides implanted with 1 to 5 multiplied by 10**1**5 at 20 and 25 keV. High conductivity with little trapping was observed in SiO//2 implanted with greater than 5 multiplied by 10**1**5 Si ions/cm**2 at 2- and 26 keV for electron injection from both substrate and gate. Postimplant annealing in diluted O//2 allows modification of the oxide conduction characteristics. An extended oxygen anneal restores the memory effect in heavily implanted oxides.
Index Keywords: OXIDES - Ion Implantation; SEMICONDUCTING SILICON; SILICA - Electric Properties; ENHANCED CONDUCTIVITY; MEMORY EFFECT; SUMMARY FORM ONLY; THERMALLY GROWN SILICA; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: ENERGY SCENE: THE COMPLETE PICTURE.
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Peter H.
Abstract: The energy scene is broad, diverse and complex with development occurring at an increasing pace. Lobbying by interest groups becomes ever more assiduous and divisive; decisions are frequently taken without a balanced awareness of their implications. There is, therefore, an urgent need for some classification of the subject of energy into recognizable and meaningful areas and for identifying, within these areas, developments which are most crucial to members of the Institute. This paper outlines such a classification framework and shows how it may be used to focus on relevant knowledge and expertise in each area.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; INFORMATION SCIENCE - Classification; POWER GENERATION; ENERGY RESOURCES

Authors: Fitt P.S., Sharma N., Attial J., Korecky B.
Title: Studies of adenosine incorporation in Langendorff rat heart and rat heart mitochondria
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada; Department of Physiology, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Fitt, P.S., Department of Biochemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada; Sharma, N., Department of Biochemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada; Attial, J., Department of Biochemistry, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada; Korecky, B., Department of Physiology, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: The acid-insoluble product isolated from well-oxygenated Langendorff rat heart after perfusion with [14C]adenosine was purified by phenol extraction and subjected to specific phosphorolysis by pure polynucleotide phosphorylase. TLC analysis of the reaction mixture showed that ADP was the only radioactive product, proving that the original substance was a polyribonucleotide. Studies of the time course of labelling and of the distribution of the acid-insoluble product between the mitochondrial and nuclear fractions showed that both are labelled even after 1 min at 25 °C, but at short times and low temperature more radioactivity is found in the mitochondria. The kinetics of adenosine incorporation resemble those expected for the labelling of hnRNA and mRNA. Isolated, respiring mitochondria incorporate adenosine and adenine nucleotides into acid insoluble form by a process dependent on oxidative phosphorylation and the adenine nucleotide translocase that is specific for adenine derivatives. The results are discussed in terms of the hypothesis that the polyribonucleotide might be a storage form of adenine nucleotides: it is concluded that the bulk of the labelled product is unlikely to play a major role in energy metabolism. © 1987 Martinus Nijhoff Publishers.
Author Keywords: adenosine incorporation; heart mitochondria; ischaemia; perfused rat heart
Index Keywords: adenine nucleotide; adenosine; animal; article; cell fractionation; heart mitochondrion; heart muscle; in vitro study; male; metabolism; rat; rat strain; temperature; Adenine Nucleotides; Adenosine; Animal; In Vitro; Male; Mitochondria, Heart; Myocardium; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Subcellular Fractions; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Temperature

Title: Luminescence of AH crystals on excitation by ultrasoft x-ray synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Estonian SSR Academy of Sciences, Tartu, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zhurakovskii, A.P., Institute of Physics, Estonian SSR Academy of Sciences, Tartu, Russian Federation
Abstract: By means of the synchrotron radiation (SR) from the storage ring VEPP-2M of the Novosibirsk Institute of Nuclear Physics the excitation spectra of the stationary recombination luminescence (SRL) of a number of alkali halide (AH) crystals have been measured in the spectral region of 50-250 eV. The nature of the spectra is shown to be determined by the migration of low-energy electronic excitations from the volume of the crystal to its surface. A near-surface component of luminescence (besides the bulk one) has been found, which is one of the results of this migration. The sum of these two - bulk and near-surface - components determines the complexity of the shape of luminescence excitation spectra in AH crystals. © 1987.
Index Keywords: LUMINESCENCE - Inorganic Solids; X-RAYS - Spectrum Analysis; EXCITATION SPECTRA; STATIONARY RECOMBINATION LUMINESCENCE; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; VEPP-2M; ALKALINE EARTH COMPOUNDS

Abstract: Race-track microtrons as injectors for SR-sources are discussed. Experience from a 100 MeV injector microtron for a 550 MeV storage ring is given. The microtron is described and the beam behaviour in the storage ring at injection energy is discussed. Suitable parameter values for an injector microtron is proposed. © 1987.

Abstract: The report deals with the results of developing the 450-MeV electron storage ring SIBERIA-1, i.e. the first phase of the specialized synchrotron radiation source of the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy. The storage ring was designed, manufactured and put into operation by the staff of the Institute of Nuclear Physics of the Siberian Department of the USSR Academy of Sciences in 1983. In 1984 a superconducting "snake" with a 4.3 T field was mounted in the storage ring. In 1984-1985, as part of the process of developing the storage ring a modification of the synchronization system of the linac FAKEL and of the injection system to the storage ring were performed. The beam diagnostics system was developed. The vacuum system of the storage ring and injection channel was up-dated. Regimes for the joint operation of the storage ring and the linac FAKEL were developed at various adjustments of the latter. A current of 180 mA was obtained at the injection energy of 55 MeV and one of 160 mA at 450 MeV. The beam lifetime has so far been limited by scattering on the residual gas in the storage ring chamber and amounts to 3.6 × 103 s at 100 mA current and to 1.4 × 104 s at 1 mA current. Presently, operations are being carried out at the experimental station of the luminescent VUV-spectroscopy of channel M and at the VUV-spectrometer for the investigation of wide-band dielectrics, including cryocrystals, at channel S. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - USSR; BEAM DIAGNOSTICS; FAREL LINAC; SIBERIA-1; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: Simultaneous control of real and reactive power by asymmetrically controlled 6 pulse converter for smes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
