Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage(SMES) is a potential energy storage having fast response and high efficiency. For the simultaneous control of real and reactive power in SMES, asymmetrically controlled 6 pulse converter has been introduced instead of conventional 12 pulse converter. Unique features of asymmetrical control including commutation process, maximum control angles, generated harmonics have been discussed. Effectiveness of the proposed method has been proved experimentally using a 25 KJ SMES. © 1987 SPIE.

Title: Scattering of electrons on thermal radiation photons in electron-positron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Telnov, V.I., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Abstract: It is shown that Compton scattering on thermal radiation photons restricts the lifetime of high energy electron beams in storage rings to a level of 30 h. At a vacuum pressure of 10-10 Torr the probability that an electron is knocked out from the beam due to scattering on thermal photons exceeds the probability of bremsstrahlung on residual gas ( ΔE E > 1%) by one order of magnitude, i.e. this effect can cause a considerable background in detectors. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; PHOTONS - Spectrum Analysis; RADIATION DETECTORS; BREMSSTRAHLUNG; COMPTON SCATTERING; THERMAL RADIATION PHOTONS; ELECTRONS

Authors: Guarino A., Possagno E., Bassanelli R.
Title: Solar energy storage: A possible use of inclusion compounds
Affiliations: Istituto di Chimica Nucleare, C.N.R., Monterotondo Stazione, Rome, I-00016, Italy

Abstract: Valence isomerization of norbornadiene to quadricyclene has been studied under different experimental conditions in order to develop a suitable system for solar energy storage. In particular, a device has been tested which exploits the sorbent properties of many inclusion compounds; norbornadiene and a suitable sensitizer are eluted through a column containing deoxycholic acid, under solar irradiation. The observed ratio of yield of quadricyclene vs. by-products is significantly favourable with respect to an analogous solar irradiation of norbornadiene and sensitizer in solution. © 1987 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF 9% Ni STEEL PLATES PRODUCED FROM CONTINUOUSLY CAST SLABS.
Affiliations: Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kinaka, Ryoji, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn; Furukimi, Osamu, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn; Kubo, Takahiro, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn; Okumura, Taketo, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn; Shingyoji, Masahiro, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn; Kudo, Junichi, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn, Kawasaki Steel Corp, Jpn
Abstract: From a low-P (0. 006% max), low-S(0. 002% max) continuously cast slab, 9% Ni steel plates for LNG storage tanks were produced by the direct quenching and tempering process (MACS-T) and reheat-quenching and tempering process (RQ-T). In the MACS-T process, slab-reheating and finish-rolling temperatures were increased in order to increase ductile fracture energy by decreasing the amount of precipitated austenite. Reliability for LNG storage tanks was examined by conducting fracture toughness tests on these steel plates and their welded joints. As a result, it was shown that these steel plates and their welded joints had good crack initiation and arrest toughness.

Title: FIRE SPREAD IN STORAGE TANK FARMS.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This article deals with the danger of fire spread by thermal radiation. It indicates how safe distances can be estimated for storage tanks for oil products. In assessing the possibility of a fire spreading through thermal radiation the following criteria have to be borne in mind: critical radiation intensity on the possible receiver; geometric position of the radiated material (receiver) to the emitter; intensity of the emitter (absolute temperature of the flame); size and position of the emitter.

Abstract: A project was undertaken in order to investigate new approaches to the design and construction of a lead-acid battery for EV applications. EPRI has sponsored electric vehicle (EV) development for the past several years. The lead-acid battery is one of the most promising candidates for implementation as a cost-effective EV energy source. This project investigated a novel lead-acid battery design that utilizes proven manufacturing technology.

Title: COAL HANDLING IN THE MOST ADVANCED COAL POWER STATION OF THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY.

Abstract: The advantages of the system include: low energy and personnel costs, high availability, a high degree of flexibility, job safety and environmental aspects, and architectonic harmony. The design of the electric equipment was, of course, subject to the standards for thermal power plants. Control is largely automatic, operating with the aid of modern electronic equipment. The rubber belts were able to be selected to ensure a high degree of operating safety and long service life. Following an appropriate start-up period, the performance of the coal handling system fulfilled the specifications made of it, and has lived up to all expectations.

Title: VIBRATIONAL STUDY OF LITHIUM BORATE GLASSES WITH HIGH Li//2O CONTENT.

Abstract: Interest in structural studies of borate glasses has been renewed in connection with the discovery of certain glass compositions that exhibit exceptionally high ionic conductivity. Such glass systems, frequently referred to as fast ionic conducting glasses, are good candidates for energy storage. The far infrared spectra of the lithium borate glasses, measured over a wide compositional region, probe the motion of lithium cations in their oxygen sites and are valuable in evaluating the nature of the interactions between the cations and the network.

Title: Time resolved calorimetry of te films during pulsed laser annealing
Source title: Applied Physics B Photophysics and Laser Chemistry

Abstract: Using a pyroelectric thin-film calorimeter the temperature of 30 nm thick Te films during pulsed laser annealing was studied in real-time. A XeCl excimer laser pumped dye laser with Raman shifter was utilized to study the wavelength and energy dependence. No significant wavelength dependence was noticed. Depending on the pulse energy, however, melting, boiling and crystallization of the Te films was observed. These findings support a strictly thermal model for laser annealing and optical recording with Te based media. In addition boiling was identified as the prevalent mechanism for the loss of material. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.

Title: New perspectives on the eruption of 1912 in the valley of ten thousand smokes, Katmai National Park, Alaska
Affiliations: US Geological Survey, Menlo Park, 94025, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hildreth, W., US Geological Survey, Menlo Park, 94025, CA, United States
Abstract: New data extend our understanding of the 1912 eruption, its backfilled vent complex at Novarupta, and magma-storage systems beneath adjacent stratovolcanoes. Initial Plinian rhyolite fallout is confined to a narrow downwind sector, and its maximum thickness may occur as far as 13 km from source. In contrast, the partly contemporaneous rhyolite-rich ash flows underwent relatively low-energy emplacement, their generation evidently being decoupled from the high column. Flow veneers 1-13 m thick on near-vent ridge crests exhibit a general rhyolite-to-andesite sequence like that of the much thicker valley-confined ignimbrite into which they merge downslope. Lithics in both the initial Plinian and the ignimbrite are predominantly fragments of the Jurassic Naknek Formation, which extends from the surface to a depth of ca. 1500 m. Absence of lithics from the underlying sedimentary section limits to < 1.5 km the fragmentation level and the structural depth of the vent, which is thought to be funnel-shaped, flaring shallowly to a surface diameter of 2 km. Overlying the ignimbrite are layers of Plinian dacite fallout, > 100 m thick near source and 10 m thick 3 km away, which dip back into an inner vent <0.5 km wide, nested inside the earlier vent funnel of the ignimbrite. The dacite fallout is poor in Naknek lithics but contains abundant fragments of vitrophyre, most of which was vent-filling, densely welded tuff reejected during later phases of the 3-day eruption. Adjacent to the inner vent, a 225-m-high asymmetrical accumulation of coarse near-vent ejecta is stratigraphically continuous with the regional dacite fallout. Distensional faulting of its crest may reflect spreading related to compaction and welding. Nearby andesite-dacite stratovolcanoes, i.e., Martin, Mageik, Trident, and Katmai, display at least 12 vents that define a linear volcanic front trending N65°E. The 1912 vent and adjacent dacite domes are disposed parallel to the front and ca. 4 km behind it. Mount Griggs, 10 km behind the front, is more potassic than other centers, taps isotopically more depleted source materials, and reflects a wholly independent magmatic plumbing system. Geochemical differences among the stratovolcanoes, characteristically small eruptive volumes ( < 0.1 to 0.4 km3), and the dominance of andesite and low-SiO2 dacite suggest complex crustal reservoirs, not large integrated magma chambers. Linear fractures just outside the 1912 vent strike nearly normal to the volcanic front and may reflect dike transport of magma previously stored beneath Trident 3-5 km away. Caldera collapse at Mount Katmai may have taken place in response to hydraulic transfer of Katmai magma toward Novarupta via reservoir components beneath Trident. The voluminous 1912 eruption (12-15 km3 DRE) was also unusual in producing high-silica rhyolite (6-9 km3 DRE), a composition rare in this arc and on volcanic fronts in general. Isotopic data indicate that rhyolite genesis involved little assimilation of sedimentary rocks, pre-Tertiary plutonic rocks, or hydrothermally altered rocks of any age. Trace-element data suggest nonetheless that the rhyolite contains a nontrivial crustal contribution, most likely partial melts of Late Cenozoic arc-intrusive rocks. Because the three compositions (77%, 66-64.5%, and 61.5-58.5% SiO2) that intermingled in 1912 vented both concurrently and repeatedly (after eruptive pauses hours in duration), the compositional gaps between them must have been intrinsic to the reservoir, not merely effects of withdrawal dynamics. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Invited paper: Fundamentals of high excitation phenomena in laser processing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Division of Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Pierce Hall, 29 Oxford Street, Cambridge, MA, 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malvezzi, A.M., Division of Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Pierce Hall, 29 Oxford Street, Cambridge, MA, 02138, United States
Abstract: The interaction of picosecond laser pulses with solid surfaces is characterized by ultra-fast energy transfer from the electronic system to the lattice. The present understanding of the elementary mechanisms responsible for carrier thermalization and cooling is briefly reviewed. In semiconductors, the electron hole plasma acts as intermediate energy storage. Recombination limits the maximum density and determines lattice heating in degenerate conditions. Experiments with femtosecond and picosecond laser sources have unraveled the salient features of the energy dissipation routes from photons to lattice. © SPIE.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; High power lasers; Laser excitation; Picosecond lasers; Electron hole plasma; Electronic systems; Intermediate energies; Lattice heating; Maximum density; Salient features; Solid surface; Thermalization; Semiconductor lasers

Title: Multispectral Imaging Simulation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Advanced Research Organization, Lockheed-Georgia Company Dept, 72-11, Zone 403, 86 South Cobb Drive, Marietta, GA, 30063, United States
Authors with affiliations: Loefer, G.R., Advanced Research Organization, Lockheed-Georgia Company Dept, 72-11, Zone 403, 86 South Cobb Drive, Marietta, GA, 30063, United States; Lao, K.Q., Advanced Research Organization, Lockheed-Georgia Company Dept, 72-11, Zone 403, 86 South Cobb Drive, Marietta, GA, 30063, United States
Abstract: Current aircraft have a requirement to operate at night and in adverse weather where optical imaging systems are inoperable. Imaging sensors operating at other wavelengths have the potential to provide vision through severe weather, but these systems need to be simulated before assuming the technological and financial risks involved in hardware development. Sensor and atmospheric models have been developed which simulate images at a variety of wavelengths. These models have been incorporated into a modified version of the IVEX Corporation Behold software which is used for the creation of three dimensional views of terrain data bases and includes fractal texturing and anti-aliasing. This new version, called Behold-ms, adds phenomenological models of material properties, such as surface roughness, emissivity, and temperature, and structured atmospheric weather models that consider path emission, backscatter, and specular/diffuse reflections of the sky. To date, images have been simulated in the visible (color), infrared (8-14µm), passive millimeter wave (35 GHz and 95 GHz), and active MMW (35 GHz and 95 GHz). These algorithms can be used for other windows over this spectral range. In order to accommodate the widely varying types of sensed energy while maintaining a practical amount of internal storage, a scheme for scaling each spectral band has been developed. Spatial resolution degradation due to diffraction, which is especially important at millimeter wavelengths, spatial sampling effects, and system noise models are also included. These sensor models and simulations have been used to examine adverse weather landing systems. Simulated images have also been used in image understanding research and spatial superresolution studies. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: ATMOSPHERIC OPTICS - Mathematical Models; ATMOSPHERIC STRUCTURE - Mathematical Models; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Algorithms; IMAGE PROCESSING; INFRARED IMAGING; ATMOSPHERIC WEATHER MODEL; BEHOLD-MS COMPUTER SOFTWARE; MULTISPECTRAL IMAGING SIMULATION; SENSOR MODEL; IMAGE SENSORS

Title: Direct and indirect calorimetry of the resting metabolism of japanese quail (coturnix coturnix japonica)
Affiliations: Institut für Biophysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Thielallee 63, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schultze-Motel, P., Institut für Biophysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Thielallee 63, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Lamprecht, I., Institut für Biophysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Thielallee 63, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: The energy metabolism of Japanese quail (Coturnix coturnix japonica) was examined with an experimental apparatus comprising a modified camping cold box as calorimeter. The resting metabolic rate, measured in the dark by indirect calorimetry, amounted to 8.1 W kg in males and 8.8 W kg in females. The rates of metabolic heat production H and of negative heat storage S summed up to 9.1 W kg (H: 89%, S: 11%), the rate of total heat loss equalled 9.6 W kg (nonevaporative heat losses: 95%, evaporative heat loss: 5%). © 1987.

Title: ASEM Analysis of Casting Defects
Authors with affiliations: Votava, W.E.
Abstract: While casting defects are a fact of life in the foundry, a method has been developed for analyzing these defects by employing analytical scanning electron microscopy (ASEM). The use of a backscattered electron detector and energy dispersive x-ray systems, available on most ASEM's, facilitates the examination of various defects. Computer storage and programming can make analysis of many particulate defects a routine procedure. Overall, the method provides a starting point from which a person with a knowledge of the process can begin to quickly diagnose the cause of defects. Examples of the usefulness of the technique are presented using case histories from a grey iron foundry. © 1987 TMS.

Title: Identification of salt-Alloy combinations for thermal energy storage applications in advanced solar dynamic power systems
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States; Department of Metallurgy and Material Science, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whittenberger, J.D., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States; Misra, A.K., Department of Metallurgy and Material Science, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio, United States, NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States
Abstract: Thermodynamic calculations based on the available data for flouride salt systems reveal that a number of congruently melting compositions and eutectics exist which have the potential to meet the lightweight, high energy storage requirements imposed for advanced solar dynamic systems operating between ∼1000 and 1400 K. Compatibility studies to determine suitable containment alloys to be used with NaF-22CaF2-13MgF2, NaF-32CaF2, and NaF-23MgF2 have been conducted at the eutectic temperature + 25 K for each system. For these three NaF-based eutectics, none of the common, commercially available high temperature alloys appear to offer adequate corrosion resistance for a long lifetime; however mild steel, pure nickel and Nb-1Zr could prove useful. These latter materials suggest the possibility that a strong, corrosion resistant, nonrefractory, elevated temperature alloy based on the Ni-Ni3Nb system could be developed. © 1987 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.

Title: Determination of the optimal conditions for the storage of energy in radical ions during an electron-transfer photoreaction
Affiliations: Volgograd Teachers Institute, Russia
Authors with affiliations: Korobov, V.E., Volgograd Teachers Institute, Russia; Markov, B.G., Volgograd Teachers Institute, Russia
Abstract: It has been established that the efficiency of the storage of energy in radical ions formed as a result of an electron-transfer photoreaction between complicated organic molecules in solution depends on the rate constants of the elementary steps of the reaction, the concentration of the electron acceptor, and the redox properties of the donor and the acceptor. Expressions for the concentration of the acceptor have been obtained theoretically, and expressions for the polarographic reduction potential of the acceptor have been found by means of numerical calculations. According to the latter, the energy stored will be maximal in two limiting cases: when the radical ions form as a result of the dissociation of either only singlet radical-ion pairs or only triplet radical-ion pairs, although they have a common dissociation channel. © 1987 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Title: The exchange coefficients for latent and sensible heat flux over lakes: Dependence upon atmospheric stability
Affiliations: College of Oceanography, Oregon State University, Corvallis, 97331, OR, United States; Division of Environmental Studies, University of California, Davis, 95616, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ted Strub, P., College of Oceanography, Oregon State University, Corvallis, 97331, OR, United States; Powell, T.M., Division of Environmental Studies, University of California, Davis, 95616, CA, United States
Abstract: Components of the energy budget of a small lake were estimated over the autumnal cooling period. Measured values of the stored thermal energy and radiative heating were used to evaluate several bulk formulae for sensible and latent heat transfer. Over 50-100 day intervals, bulk formulae for latent and sensible heat flux without stability corrections were as good as formulae that incorporated such corrections; both satisfactorily reproduced the measured heat storage data. Over shorter (daily to weekly) time-scales, predictions incorporating stability corrections were superior to those without stability corrections. Over daily periods when the atmosphere was nearly neutral or was unstable, a formulation for sensible and latent heat transfer designed for small-scale systems (cooling ponds and reservoirs) agreed closely with the usual large-scale (oceanic) bulk formulations. The corrections for stability in the small-scale formulation are based on laboratory and theoretical studies of free convection; the stability correction in the large-scale formulation uses a bulk Richardson number in a manner consistent with flux-profile theory. Both agreed with the measured data for the unstable and near-neutral cases. Under stable atmospheric conditions (in a daily average sense), both formulations underestimated the measured fluxes © 1987 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Authors: Kumar A., Prasad A., Upadhaya S.N.
Title: SPHERICAL PHASE-CHANGE ENERGY STORAGE WITH CONSTANT TEMPERATURE HEAT INJECTION.
Source title: Journal of Energy Resources Technology, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India, Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, A., Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India, Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India; Prasad, A., Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India, Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India; Upadhaya, S.N., Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India, Tata Iron & Steel Co, Jamshedpur, India
Abstract: Storage of thermal energy due to latent heat involved during outward radial melting of a phase-change material contained in a spherical shell is solved using variational, integral and quasi-steady methods. At uniform temperature heat is applied to inner surface. These methods provide closed-form solutions to the Stefan number, an independent parameter. The results for total energy storage, the phase-change depth and their rate obtained from these approximate analyses do not vary significantly.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; LATENT HEAT; OUTWARD RADIAL MELTING; PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: El'chaninov A.S., Koval B.A., Mesyats G.A., Proskurovskii D.I., Yankelevich E.B.
Title: HIGH-CURRENT PULSED SOURCE OF NONRELATIVISTIC ELECTRONS.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR
Authors with affiliations: El'chaninov, A.S., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR; Koval, B.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR; Mesyats, G.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR; Proskurovskii, D.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR; Yankelevich, E.B., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Tomsk, USSR
Abstract: The high-current electron source contains a vacuum diode with an explosive-emission cathode, a charging device based on a Tesla coil with an open ferromagnetic core connected to a shaping line, and a capacitive storage device with a series-connected inductor. The source can form at the load (vacuum diode) a two-step voltage pulse, which provides high-current electron beams with comparatively low energy and allows the power density at the anode to be varied within wide limits. The source is used to study various materials for modification of their surface properties.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS; ELECTRON TUBE COMPONENTS; ELECTRON TUBES, DIODE; EXPLOSIVE-EMISSION CATHODE; NONRELATIVISTIC ELECTRONS; PULSED ELECTRON BEAMS; TESLA COIL; ELECTRONS

Title: DESIGNING A NEW SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Procell, Charles J.
Abstract: In 1985 PLANS were made for a speculative office building-100 North-in the heart of Westchester County, New York. It was considered essential to do everything possible to keep energy costs low while providing effective comfort conditioning. The approach used in answer to the problems was a phase change ice storage system with a lower temperature duct system.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Ducts; COST ACCOUNTING; ICE - Storage; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; HIGH ELECTRIC RATES; LOWER TEMPERATURE DUCT SYSTEM; PHASE CHANGE ICE STORAGE; THERMAL STORAGE; OFFICE BUILDINGS

Authors: Maruyama X.K., Penner S., Tang C.-M., Sprangle P.
Title: Proposal for a free electron laser driven by the National Bureau of Standards' CW microtron
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maruyama, X.K., Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Penner, S., Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Tang, C.-M., Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Sprangle, P., Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States
Abstract: We propose a free electron laser (FEL) driven by the racetrack microtron (RTM) which is under development at the National Bureau of Standards (NBS). The design of the NBS RTM has many exceptional properties: (i) normalized transverse emittance of better than 10 mm mrad, comparable to a storage ring, (ii) axial emittance <30 keV deg., much superior to rf linacs, (iii) electron energy tunable from 20 to approximately 200 MeV, (iv) cw operation, (v) energy stability, (vi) compactness, and (vii) high power-conversion efficiency. We propose accelerator upgrades to increase the peak current. It seems possible to obtain peak current larger than 2 A, for an average electron beam power of 100 kW. The wavelength of the fundamental radiation from the FEL can span from 0.25 to 10 μm, and harmonics will be produced in the UV spectral region. Because of the wavelength range, tunability, high average power, continuous beam, and the ability to generate picosecond pulses, this FEL will be suitable for a wide range of applications. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, MICROTRON - Laser Applications; ELECTRONS; RESEARCH LABORATORIES - Maryland; EMITTANCE; NATURAL BUREAU OF STANDARDS; NBS RACETRACK MICROTRON; LASERS, FREE ELECTRON

Title: ASEM ANALYSIS OF CASTING DEFECTS.
Authors with affiliations: Votava, Ward E.
Abstract: While casting defects are a fact of life in the foundry, a method has been developed for analyzing these defects by employing analytical scanning electron microscopy (ASEM). The use of a backscattered electron detector and energy dispersive x-ray systems, available on most ASEM's, facilitates the examination of various defects. Computer storage and programming can make analysis of many particulate defects a routine procedure. Overall, the method provides a starting point from which a person with a knowledge of the process can begin to quickly diagnose the cause of defects. Examples of the usefulness of the technique are presented using case histories from a grey iron foundry.

Authors: Billardon M., Elleaume P., Ortega J.M., Bazin C., Bergher M., Couprie M.E., Lapierre Y., Petroff Y., Prazeres R., Velghe M.
Title: Status of the Orsay FEL experiment
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; ESPCI, Laboratoire d'Optique Physique, 10, rue Vauquelin, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; CEA, Département de Physico-Chimie, Service de Photophysique, F. 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette, France; Laboratoire de Photophysique Moléculaire, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 213, F-91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Billardon, M., ESPCI, Laboratoire d'Optique Physique, 10, rue Vauquelin, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Elleaume, P., CEA, Département de Physico-Chimie, Service de Photophysique, F. 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette, France; Ortega, J.M., ESPCI, Laboratoire d'Optique Physique, 10, rue Vauquelin, F-75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Bazin, C., LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; Bergher, M., LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; Couprie, M.E., LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; Lapierre, Y., CEA, Département de Physico-Chimie, Service de Photophysique, F. 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette, France; Petroff, Y., LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; Prazeres, R., LURE (CNRS/MEN/CEA), Université Paris-Sud, bât. 209 D, 91405 Orsay cedex, France; Velghe, M., Laboratoire de Photophysique Moléculaire, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 213, F-91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: The FEL installed on the storage ring ACO at Orsay has been operated down to a wavelength of 463 nm, at a ring energy of 200 MeV. This is probably the lowest wavelength attainable on ACO with TiO2 SiO2 dielectric mirrors because of the near-UV TiO2 broad absorption band. A careful analysis of the optical gain, taking into account the measured beam characteristics, shows a spectral dependence scaling as λ1,1, with a maximum at λ = 650 nm close to 0.4%. Therefore the ACO FEL may be tuned over almost the whole visible spectrum at the expense of time consuming mirror changes. Due to the poor transmission of these very high reflectivity mirrors the average extracted power is only a few mW throughout the visible region. However the maximum intracavity peak power (at low frequency Q-switching) reaches about 0.5 MW. The next step will be to test new Al2O3 SiO2 coated mirrors in the near-UV spectral range. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; MIRRORS; OPTICAL GAIN; OPTICAL KLYSTRON; ORSAY STORAGE RING; LASERS, FREE ELECTRON

Title: FEL optics coating test device
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnétique (CNRS-CEA-MEN), Université de Paris-Sud, F 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Velghe, M.F., Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnétique (CNRS-CEA-MEN), Université de Paris-Sud, F 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Elleaume, P., Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnétique (CNRS-CEA-MEN), Université de Paris-Sud, F 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: A crucial issue concerning FEL is the resistance of the mirrors to high flux. In the example of the ACO storage ring, the high X-ray flux of spontaneous emission sets a limit to the shortest wavelength. A detailed analysis of the resistance of multilayer dielectric TiO2 SiO2 mirrors has been carried out. Several degradation processes have been identified occurring at different energies of incident photons leading to either surface or bulk absorption. This data was very important for the operation of the FEL at wavelengths above 460 nm. For shorter wavelengths almost nothing is known about the resistance of normal incidence multilayer mirror under X-ray exposure. At Orsay we are starting a program of work to test various mirrors under such conditions. A device has been built for this purpose, allowing consecutive irradiation of more than 12 mirrors without any ultrahigh vacuum break. Precision alignment screws are provided to align the mirrors with a reference mirror in order to continuously monitor the reflectivity during X-ray exposure. A thermocouple is located on the mirror holder. The device will be inserted on the ACO storage ring in the fall of 1986. The results of this program are essential for the future UV-VUV SUPER-ACO FEL and for any other storage ring FEL. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; DIELECTRIC MATERIALS; LASERS, FREE ELECTRON; MIRRORS; PHOTONS; ACO STORAGE RING; DIELECTRIC MIRRORS; OPTICAL COATINGS

Title: MAKING THE CHOICE - BLADDER OR PISTON ACCUMULATORS?
Affiliations: Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough,, NC, USA, Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chamberlain, J., Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough,, NC, USA, Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough, NC, USA; Flippo, W., Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough,, NC, USA, Parker Hannifin Corp, Hillsborough, NC, USA
Abstract: Understanding why an accumulator fails and what factors affect accumulator efficiency can aid the designer when he must choose the best type for a particular application. Hydropneumatic accumulators are used in three general applications widely found in industry. Accumulators: store energy in the form of fluid under pressure, absorb hydraulic system shock, and dampen hydraulic system pressure and flow fluctuations. Manufacturers specify correct precharge pressure for their accumulators. In an energy storage application, a bladder accumulator typically is precharged to 80% of minimum hydraulic system pressure, a piston accumulator to 100 psi below minimum system pressure. Precharge pressure determines how much fluid remains in the accumulator at minimum system pressure.
Index Keywords: HYDRAULIC FLUIDS - Pressure Control; HYDRAULICS; BLADDER ACCUMULATORS; PRECHARGE PRESSURE; HYDRAULIC ACCUMULATORS

Authors: Abdul-Ghani Ahlam J., Bashi N.O.T., Maree S.N.
Title: SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE THROUGH CATALYZED REVERSIBLE PHOTOVALANCE ISOMERIZATION OF 9-TERT-BUTYL ANTHRACENE.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Abdul-Ghani, Ahlam J., Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq; Bashi, N.O.T., Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq; Maree, S.N., Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq
Abstract: Valance isomerization of 9-tert-butyl anthracene (9-t BA) (I) to 1-tert-butyl-dibenzo-2,5-bicyclo (2. 2. 0)-hexadiene (9-tert-butyl-9,10-Dewar anthracene) (III) was attempted by irradiation with visible light from a 250W xenon arc lamp, in ethanol and micellar solution, by using ruthenium tris-bipyridyl chloride (Ru(bip)//3)**2** plus and zinc phthalocyanine (ZnPc) as catalysts at room temperature. The mechanism of the photochemical reaction was followed by u. v. -visible spectra. It showed that an excited state photochemical reaction took place between (I) and each of the metal complexes in presence of visible light, leading to the formation of a stable complex or a decomposition process. The addition of ZnPc to the dewar form (II), in the dark, increased the rate of formation of (I).
Index Keywords: CATALYSIS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Isomerization; ETHANOL; RADIATION EFFECTS; 9-TERTIARY-BUTYLANTHRACENE; PHOTOCATALYSTS; PHOTOVALENCE ISOMERIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Lee Soo Kag, Matsuda Hitoki, Hasatani Masanobu
Title: RATE ENHANCEMENT OF THE DEHYDRATION OF Ca(OH)//2 UNDER REDUCED PRESSURES (THERMAL STORAGE).
Affiliations: Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Soo Kag, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Matsuda, Hitoki, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Hasatani, Masanobu, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Abstract: The dehydration behavior of Ca(OH)//2 was studied under reduced pressure conditions (2. 33-101. 3 KPa). It was found that the initiation temperature of the dehydration of Ca(OH)//2 was lowered by reducing the pressure in the reaction system and that the dehydration rate increased in inverse proportion to the pressure in the system. The overall reaction rate expression under static conditions was obtained by non-isothermal reaction analysis at various constant heating rates. The enhancement of the dehydration of Ca(OH)//2 by reducing the pressure in the reaction system was quantitatively estimated.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Optimization; HEAT TRANSFER - Transport Properties; REACTANTS; THERMOBALANCE; THERMOCHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMICAL OPERATIONS

Title: CONSTRUCTING AN ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY.
Affiliations: Verac, San Diego, CA, USA, Verac, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kosko, Bart, Verac, San Diego, CA, USA, Verac, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: An associative memory is a mapping from data to data, a mathematical abstraction from the familiar associative structure of human and animal learning. We associate behavioral responses with sensory stimuli, effect with cause, like character with like faces, breakfast with sizzling bacon. An associative memory is parallel distributed - as in a neural network, for example - when it memorizes data by superimposing it on the same memory medium. It is shown how to construct the simplest nonlinear neural-network associative memory - called a BAM (bidirectional associative memory) - that recalls or content-addresses stored associations (x, y) by minimizing a system 'energy' (which is defined mathematically).
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Distributed; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Construction; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Conformal Mapping; PATTERN RECOGNITION; ARTIFICIAL NEURAL SYSTEMS (ANS); ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY; BIDIRECTIONAL ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY (BAM); NEUROCOMPUTERS; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS

Title: TRANSPORT OF SOLID MATERIALS WITHIN STORAGE BASINS OF RIVER POWER PLANTS: SOFTWARE DESIGN AND PRACTICAL APPLICATION.
Authors with affiliations: Heidinger, R.; Baumhackl, G.
Abstract: Over 60 per cent of the demand for electrical energy in Austria is covered by hydroelectric power plants. Problems arise within backwater areas of river power plants, causing storage loss by sedimentation of solid particles. Higher costs in construction, loss of energy and danger of inundation cause energy companies to simulate characteristics of this phenomenon numerically. The following considerations show that particular programming techniques enable the user to predict changes in river geometry within a short time and even create an individual set of sediment transport formulae within the software.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; COMPUTER SOFTWARE - Modular Construction; Hydrology; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Numerical Methods; RESERVOIRS - Sedimentation; GALERKIN APPROACH; RIVER DRAU; RIVER GEOMETRY; STRICKLER ROUGHNESS COEFFICIENTS; Hydroelectric power plants

Title: Highlights of the Flare Build-up Study
Affiliations: Herzberg Institute of Astrophysics, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, K1A 0R6, Ontario, Canada; Laboratory for Space Research, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Gaizauskas, V., Herzberg Institute of Astrophysics, National Research Council of Canada, Ottawa, K1A 0R6, Ontario, Canada; Švestka, Z., Laboratory for Space Research, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: Years of preparation within the framework of the Flare Build-up Study culminated with intensive observations of solar flares during the Solar Maximum Year (1979-1981). Scientists operating several spacecraft and roughly 70 ground-based observatories participated in an internationally coordinated effort to observe flares with higher spatial, spectral, and temporal resolution over a wider range of wavelengths than heretofore. The FBS stimulated important advances in theories of magnetic reconnection and the growth of plasma instabilities under preflare circumstances. A series of international FBS workshops facilitated data exchanges and collaborative studies for interpreting and synthesizing the wealth of new information about flares. The FBS ended officially at the Symposium on Synopsis of the Solar Maximum Analysis held 2-5 July, 1986 at the COSPAR meeting in Toulouse, France. Here we summarize highlights of its progress towards an understanding of the storage and release of preflare energy. © 1987 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Authors: Nowak M.J., Rughooputh S.D.D.V., Hotta S., Heeger A.J.
Title: Polarons and Bipolarons on a Conducting Polymer in Solution
Affiliations: Institute for Polymers and Organic Solids, Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States; Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Moriguchi, Osaka 570, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nowak, M.J., Institute for Polymers and Organic Solids, Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States; Rughooputh, S.D.D.V., Institute for Polymers and Organic Solids, Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States; Hotta, S., Institute for Polymers and Organic Solids, Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States, Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., Moriguchi, Osaka 570, Japan; Heeger, A.J., Institute for Polymers and Organic Solids, Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States
Abstract: Electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements and spectroscopic studies have been carried out on the soluble conducting polymer poly(3-hexylthienylene) doped in solution with (NO)+(PF6)_. From the ESR and spectroscopic data, we have determined the nature of the charge-storage configurations as a function of doping level and as a function of doped polymer concentration. The results indicate that the spinless bipolaron is the lowest energy charge-storage configuration on single poly(3-hexylthienylene) macromolecules in dilute solution. Polarons are formed either as a result of an odd number of charges on a single polymer chain or as a result of interchain interactions (in the semidilute regime). © 1987, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Casalnuovo S.A., Renschler C.L., Stiefeld R.E., Draper B.L., Mahoney A.R.
Title: Effect of diffuse reflectivity on photoresist linewidth control
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Casalnuovo, S.A., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Renschler, C.L., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Stiefeld, R.E., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Draper, B.L., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Mahoney, A.R., Sandia National Laboratories, P. O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Abstract: Recent studies in our laboratory have shown that the diffuse reflectivity of sputtered A1/1% Si films plays a significant role in the lot to lot control of photoresist linewidth for 2.0 m features on our 16K SRAM device. The exposure energy required to produce 2.0 m resist lines on product wafers at this level was monitored and correlated with both the total and diffuse reflectivity as measured on control wafers included with the product wafers during Al/Si deposition. Fourteen product lots were monitored over a period of several months. The results show a strong correlation between changes in the diffuse reflectivity and the exposure energy. An increase of 64% in the diffuse reflectivity of the Al/Si film is accompanied by an increase of 80% in the exposure energy required to produce 2.0 m lines in positive resist. For these same lots, the total reflectivity varies by less than ±%, usually taken as an indication of good process control at metal deposition, with no apparent correlation to the exposure energy. Several different resist processes were investigated to control the effects of changes in the diffuse reflectivity. The most promising of these has been a new dyed photoresist developed at Sandia. The unbleachable dye has been selected for optimal performance at the exposure and alignment wavelengths used in the Ultratech stepper. The diffuse reflectivity of Al/Si films coated with dyed resist is diminished by a factor of eight over the reflectivity of films coated with our standard resist. The total reflectivity is diminished by a factor of five. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Digital - Random Access; Optical Variables Measurement; Control Wafers; Diffuse Reflectivity; Dyed Resist; Exposure Energy; Linewidth Control; SRAM Device; Photoresists

Authors: de Verdier C.-H., Niklasson F., van Waeg G., Ericson A., Högman C.H.
Title: Purine metabolism in normal and high-ITP human erythrocytes. Attempts to evaluate the ability to store the cells
Affiliations: Department of Clinical Chemistry and Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: de Verdier, C.-H., Department of Clinical Chemistry and Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden; Niklasson, F., Department of Clinical Chemistry and Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden; van Waeg, G., Department of Clinical Chemistry and Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden; Ericson, A.; Högman, C.H.
Abstract: Storage of erythrocyte units from donors with ITP pyrophosphohydrolase deficiency have been studied and compared with units from normal donors. Verifying other investigations the incidence of this genetic disorder was found to be as high as about 3%. Hemolysis in the units was higher than in other units and there was a tendency to low total adenylate concentration. It is suggested that blood centers should organize a quality assurance program where one of the aims should be to detect genetic disorders that make the erythrocytes from the donors less suitable for long term liquid storage.

Authors: Lugli P., Jacoboni C., Reggiani L., Kocevar P.
Title: Dynamical simulation of a perturbed phonon distribution induced by hot-carrier thermalisation in gaas
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica e Centro Interuniveritario di Struttura, Della Materia della Università di Modena, Via Campi 213/A, Modena, I-41100, Italy; Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Graz, Universtitatplatz 5, Graz, A-8010, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Lugli, P., Dipartimento di Fisica e Centro Interuniveritario di Struttura, Della Materia della Università di Modena, Via Campi 213/A, Modena, I-41100, Italy; Jacoboni, C., Dipartimento di Fisica e Centro Interuniveritario di Struttura, Della Materia della Università di Modena, Via Campi 213/A, Modena, I-41100, Italy; Reggiani, L., Dipartimento di Fisica e Centro Interuniveritario di Struttura, Della Materia della Università di Modena, Via Campi 213/A, Modena, I-41100, Italy; Kocevar, P., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Graz, Universtitatplatz 5, Graz, A-8010, Austria
Abstract: Time-resolved luminescence and Raman measurements have indicated in recent years the existence of nonequilibrium phonon distributions, as a result of the cooling of phototexcited electrons and holes in GaAs. While several analytic studies of hot phonons have appeared in the literature, we present here a novel Ensemble Monte Carlo calculation of nonequilibrium-phonon effects on the relaxation rate of photoexcited electrons. The build up of the phonon population on a picosecond scale is monitored, in parallel with the cooling of the electron distribution. No assumptions on the form of the phonon or the electron distributions are required. The strong phonon emission by the high-energy photoexcited electrons in the first stage of their relaxation (within a few tenths of a picosecond) is found to drive the phonon distribution strongly out of equilibrium. After the excitation, reabsorption of the emitted phonons by the carriers and nonelectronic phonon decay processes bring the distribution back to its equilibrium value. The time evolution of the calculated phonon distribution is in agreement with the available data obtained with time-resolved Raman spectroscopy. Moreover, the strongly perturbed phonon distribution can, for the moderate carrier excitation densities considered, fully account for the observed reduction of the cooling rate of the phototexcited carriers. Finally the arguments for and against a dominant role of free carrier screening are critically analysed in the light of the present and of foregoing theoretical hot-phonon theories. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Digital storage; Electrons; Gallium arsenide; Hot electrons; III-V semiconductors; Microstructure; Probes; Semiconducting gallium; Semiconductor lasers; Ultrafast lasers; Dynamical simulation; Electron distributions; Ensemble monte carlo; Free carrier screening; Nonequilibrium phonons; Photoexcited electrons; Time-resolved luminescence; Time-resolved Raman spectroscopies; Phonons

Title: Optical storage and its possible use in high-energy physics
Affiliations: University of California, Riverside, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Langeveld, W.G.J., University of California, Riverside, CA, United States
Abstract: This report discusses the current status of optical storage technology and the potential for optical data storage as an alternative to magnetic data storage for future experiments in high-energy physics. The industry is currently geared mostly towards small (5 1 4 inch) optical disk drives, both in Write Once, Read Multiple (WORM) and in erasable form. These drives present no advantage to the high-energy physics community because of their limited capacity. However, 12 inch optical disk drives are suitable, though not optimal, for large-scale data collection as is common in high-energy physics. These systems are available in single units or in the form of automated juke-boxes. An optimal and relatively cost-effective system is currently in development. It makes use of write-once optical tape. Some disadvantages common to all current optical systems are the general lack of standards and the difficulty in procuring systems and media from different sources. © 1987.

Authors: Lauer R., Slaughter A.J., Wolin E.
Title: A role for relational databases in high energy physics software systems
Affiliations: Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lauer, R., Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States; Slaughter, A.J., Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States; Wolin, E., Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the design and initial implementation of software which uses a relational database management system for storage and retrieval of real and Monte Carlo generated events from a charm and beauty spectrometer with a vertex detector. The purpose of the software is to graphically display and interactively manipulate the events, fit tracks and vertices and calculate physics quantities. The INGRES database forms the core of the system, while the DI3000 graphics package is used to plot the events. The paper introduces relational database concepts and their applicability to high energy physics data. It also evaluates the environment provided by INGRES, particularly its usefulness in code development and its Fortran interface. Specifies of the database design we have chosen are detailed as well. © 1987.

Title: Computing for HEP experiments: 1987-1997
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newman, H.B., California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States
Abstract: Computers and data communications networks are essential elements of high energy physics research. The sharp rise in computing needs for the current generation of large collider experiments is just starting at the CERN and FERMILAB pp colliders, and it is certain to continue at TRISTAN, SLC, LEP, HERA and the SSC. The diversity and sophistication of HEP's computing facilities and networks must also increase if the potential for new physics discoveries by future experiments is to be realized. This paper reviews present and future trends in the HEP physicist's computing and networking "environment". New computer architectures, personal workstations, and storage media will have a vital role to play in the offline data analysis for large experiments over the next ten years. © 1987.

Title: Nutrients That Modify the Speed of Internal Clock and Memory Storage Processes
Affiliations: Columbia University, United States; Brown University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meck, W.H., Columbia University, United States; Church, R.M., Brown University, United States
Abstract: Two experiments assessed the effects of nutrients on timing behavior by rats. The nutrients were laced with saccharin and given to rats as a snack before training on a 20-s peak-interval procedure. The primary component of the snacks for four groups of 10 rats was lecithin (phosphatidylcholine), protein (casein), carbohydrate (sucrose), or a nonnutrient (saccharin). The primary measure of behavior was the time of the rat's highest response rate during a trial (peak time), which represented the interval during which the rat maximally expected food. With a lecithin snack, peak time was gradually shifted over sessions to a shorter time, remained shifted to the left of the normal function with additional testing, and then remained at the shorter time on two sessions after the snack was discontinued; with the protein snack, peak time was abruptly shifted to a shorter time, returned to normal with additional testing, and then rebounded to a longer time when the snack was discontinued; with a carbohydrate, snack peak time was abruptly shifted to a longer time, returned to normal with additional testing, and then rebounded to a shorter time when the snack was discontinued. The behavioral patterns produced by the nutrients were interpreted in terms of precursor effects on central neurotransmitter synthesis and release, psychological stages of an information-processing model, and mathematical parameters of a scalar timing theory. © 1987 American Psychological Association.

Title: Applications of the transilient turbulence parameterization to atmospheric boundary-layer simulations
Affiliations: Boundary Layer Research Team, Department of Meteorology, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute, De Bilt, Netherlands; Institute for Meteorology and Oceanography, University of Utrecht, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Stull, R.B., Boundary Layer Research Team, Department of Meteorology, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Driedonks, A.G.M., Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute, De Bilt, Netherlands, Institute for Meteorology and Oceanography, University of Utrecht, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: An improved first-order closure approximation is developed for the non-local 'transilient turbulence' parameterization. Instead of using Richardson numbers, this improved approach uses non-local approximations to the shear, buoyancy, storage, and dissipation terms of the turbulence kinetic energy equation to parameterize the turbulent mixing potential between every combination of grid points in a 1-D model of the atmosphere. The original (n2 - n) degrees of freedom associated with the independent transilient matrix coefficients for a model of n grid points is thus reduced to four degrees of freedom associated with the four free parameters. The resulting parameterization is applied to three consecutive case-study days of boundary-layer data acquired near the Cabauw tower in The Netherlands. The first day is used for sensitivity tests to select the best values of the four free parameters. The remaining two days, used as independent tests, demonstrate that realistic entraining mixed layers and nocturnal boundary layers form in the model without explicitly parameterizing such boundary layers. Simulations are also presented for two idealized cases: 'dry' stratocumulus-induced convection and a neutral boundary layer. © 1987 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Authors: Rao D.R., Ramachandra Rao M.S., Reddy S.A.K.
Title: THERMALLY STIMULATED LUMINESCENCE OF ALKALINE EARTH SULPHIDE PHOSPHORS DOPED WITH CERIUM AND SAMARIUM IMPURITIES.
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, D.R., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Ramachandra Rao, M.S., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Reddy, S.A.K., Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India, Indian Inst of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: Alkaline earth sulfide phosphors (CaS, SrS, and BaS) doped with rare earth ion (Sm and Ce) impurities were prepared by carbon reduction of pure sulfates of Ca, Sr, and Ba in a N//2 atmosphere and using NaCl as flux. Intense flow maxima in the temperature range from 60 to 85 degree C were exhibited by most of the phosphors under three methods of excitation. Some results on thermally stimulated conductivity and photoluminescence are also reported. The trapping centers responsible for the energy storage in this system of phosphors were identified as Sm and Ce and their complexes involving native defects.

Abstract: Detailed experiments of pulsed-power generation using inductive energy storage were done by using three kinds of systems: one wire, two wires and the energy transfer between two condensers. Here, 'wire' refers to a thin copper wire that was used as an opening switch in the system.

Title: THREE OUT-OF-THE ORDINARY THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Verle A. Williams & Associates,, San Diego, CA, USA, Verle A. Williams & Associates, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Schiess, Klaus, Verle A. Williams & Associates,, San Diego, CA, USA, Verle A. Williams & Associates, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this presentation is to enlarge the awareness for the potential for Thermal Energy Storage (TES) using three case studies. TES is a technically simple process whereby cooling produced at night, during reduced energy cost periods, is stored for use during the day. The recommended projects were developed by a step-by-step approach to find the best opportunity. Every TES project is an out-of-the ordinary case due to the individuality of each opportunity and the challenges new products offer industry. Many utility companies enhance the opportunity with rate schedules that keep consultants calculating, but also help with the incentive schemes. A TES computer program was used to do the analyses. It incorporates many features and allows an accurate calculation of the potential savings.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Costs; ENERGY CONSERVATION; LOAD SHIFTING; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Abstract: Energy management has been of prime importance in Xerox since the mid-70's, when the facility in El Segundo, Calif. , implemented a comprehensive energy program. In 1983, an energy management consulting firm was hired to conduct a comprehensive energy audit and develop an energy plan for the El Segundo facility. The ice storage project resulted from a feasibility study to investigate the alternatives for replacing HVAC systems for one of the manufacturing building.

Title: OPTIMIZATION OF CHILLED WATER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Roy F. Weston Inc, West Chester, PA,, USA, Roy F. Weston Inc, West Chester, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gidwani, B.N., Roy F. Weston Inc, West Chester, PA,, USA, Roy F. Weston Inc, West Chester, PA, USA
Abstract: Chilled water systems are one of the major energy consumers in industrial, commercial, and institutional complexes. The centralization of chilled water systems has considerable advantages, namely: simplified controls, the installed capacity is reduced due to diversity, consolidated maintenance and operation. With central chilled water systems, the following areas present potential energy and cost savings: chilled water reset; condenser water reset; sequencing of the chillers; chilled water storage; and variable chilled water pumping.

Title: REDUCING EXCHANGER FOULING.
Authors with affiliations: Crittenden, B.D.; Kolaczkowski, S.T.
Abstract: Fouling from hydrocarbon streams leads to enormous financial penalties in terms of additional energy consumption and debits in thruput. A typical 100,000 bpsd oil refinery might incur total fouling related expenses of around 10 million per annum. About half of this cost can be attributed to deposit formation in the network of heat exchangers used to preheat crude oil from storage conditions to around the 350 degree C necessary for operating the crude distillation unit (CDU). An example preheat train is shown. Presented are heat transfer equipment operating, design and monitoring techniques to reduce fouling.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; PETROLEUM REFINING - Heat Exchangers; FOULING REDUCTION TECHNIQUES; FOULING RESISTANCES; HEAT EXCHANGER FOULING; PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Authors: Leyton J., Drury P.J., Crawford M.A.
Title: In vivo incorporation of labeled fatty acids in rat liver lipids after oral administration
Affiliations: Nutritional Biochemistry Unit, The Institute of Zoology, Regent's Park, London, N.W.1 4RY, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Leyton, J., Nutritional Biochemistry Unit, The Institute of Zoology, Regent's Park, London, N.W.1 4RY, United Kingdom; Drury, P.J., Nutritional Biochemistry Unit, The Institute of Zoology, Regent's Park, London, N.W.1 4RY, United Kingdom; Crawford, M.A., Nutritional Biochemistry Unit, The Institute of Zoology, Regent's Park, London, N.W.1 4RY, United Kingdom
Abstract: Striking differences were found in the compartmentalization of fatty acids into liver lipid fractions. The saturated fatty acids-lauric, myristic, palmitic and stearic-were incorporated into phosphoglycerides at faster rates with increasing chain lengths, while triglyceride incorporation was almost uniform. The degree of incorporation of the unsaturated fatty acids into phosphoglycerides (structural) compared to triglyceride (storage and energy) was the converse of their oxidation rates. The incorporation of oleic, linoleic and α-linolenic acids was mainly into triglyceride, whereas dihomo-γ-linolenic acid and arachidonic acid were preferentially incorporated into phosphoglycerides. The data suggest that distribution of each fatty acid is different depending on its destination for structural or energy function. © 1987 American Oil Chemists' Society.

Authors: Robinson T.F., Factor S.M., Capasso J.M., Wittenberg B.A., Blumenfeld O.O., Seifter S.
Title: Morphology, composition, and function of struts between cardiac myocytes of rat and hamster
Affiliations: Department of Medicine, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Department of Physiology and Biophysics, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Department of Pathology, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Department of Biochemistry, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, T.F., Department of Medicine, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States, Department of Physiology and Biophysics, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Factor, S.M., Department of Medicine, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States, Department of Pathology, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Capasso, J.M., Department of Medicine, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Wittenberg, B.A., Department of Physiology and Biophysics, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Blumenfeld, O.O., Department of Biochemistry, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States; Seifter, S., Department of Biochemistry, The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, New York, United States
Abstract: The morphology, composition, and function of struts that interconnect the lateral surfaces of cardiomyocytes were examined in the hearts of rats and hamsters. Methods included brightfield and fluorescent light microscopy, secondary and backscatter scanning electron microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy in conjunction with silver stain, cationic dye, and antibody to type-I collagen. These studies reveal a twisted, beaded appearance and a complex substructure of collagen fibrils embedded in a ground substance that has a positive reaction with cationic dye. A hierarchy of patterns of branching and attachment was seen among intercellular struts ranging in diameter from 0.1 μm to several urn. The hypothesis that struts tether not only the surfaces but the contractile lattices of laterally adjacent myocytes is supported by the following: (a) the attachments of struts to the collagen weave of the sarcolemma, often lateral to the level of Z bands, (b) the presence of collagen type I in a composite material arrangement, (c) the relative dispositions and configurational changes of struts and myocyte surfaces in various physiological states and induced, non-physiological perturbations of cardiac muscle, (d) the corrugated sarcolemmas with infoldings near Z bands, and (e) the continuity of intracellular filaments from Z bands to the inner aspect of the sarcolemma in relaxed and contracted myocytes. Implications of struts acting as tethers and sites for storage of energy in the motions of myocytes during the cardiac cycle are discussed. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Cardiac muscle cells; Collagen fibers and filaments; Extracellular matrix; Hamster; Immunohistochemistry; Rat

Title: LITHIUM/IRON SULFIDE BATTERIES DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: To develop an electric vehicle (EV) market, DOE and EPRI are cosponsoring studies on appropriate vehicle bodies such as vans, electric transmission options such as variable-frequency ac drives, and batteries, the basic sources of EV energy. Two 12-V, nine-cell modules of the Li/FeS system were constructed and tested. Operation of the modules in a thermal enclosure showed that it was possible to achieve thermal balances and to control temperature and temperature gradients. The first module constructed demonstrated an energy output of 60 Wh/kg. Changing the ratio between the quantities of negative and positive reactants improved the energy output of the second module to 91 Wh/kg, about 8% above the design goal. Estimates based on the performance of the second module suggest a range of 1. 8 mi/kWh of ac input energy for vehicular use. The heat exchanger constructed for this project successfully maintained the temperature of the second module at the operating temperature, 500 degree C. The charger equalizer designed for use with the modules met the requirements of this unique fused-salt battery system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; LITHIUM/IRON SULFIDE BATTERY; THERMAL ENCLOSURES; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: COMMERCIAL APPLICATIONS OF HEAT PUMP WATER HEATERS. (THE FEATHERS RESTAURANT TORONTO).
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Authors with affiliations: Perlman, Maier; Chiarelli, Mario
Abstract: An innovative heat pump water heater/heat recovery system was designed and installed in the kitchen area of a restaurant to recover waste heat from cooking and produce hot water. The main objective of this work was to demonstrate the capabilities of advanced heat pump technology in commercial establishments for process applications, indoor climate control and energy management. The design of the system is unique in that it takes advantage of the coincident waste heat production, hot water demand and space cooling needs. By properly balancing the hot water storage, heat pump capacity and utilization of the cool discharged air through a specially designed distribution duct, significant energy savings: 42% and demand reduction: 44% were achieved during the first year of operation. In addition, the proper distribution of the cool air provides an improved and comfortable working environment in the kitchen and adjacent areas. Excess cool air is directed to the basement of the building where the office, storage space and main refrigeration equipment are located. (Editd author abstract) 9 refs.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; KITCHENS - Air Conditioning; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; HEAT RECOVERY SYSTEM; RESTAURANT KITCHENS; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Garlick P.J., McNurlan M.A., McHardy K.C., Calder A.G., Milne E., Fearns L.M., Broom J.
Title: Rates of nutrient utilization in man measured by combined respiratory gas analysis and stable isotopic labelling: Effect of food intake
Affiliations: Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen AB2 9SB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Garlick, P.J., Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen AB2 9SB, United Kingdom; McNurlan, M.A., Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen AB2 9SB, United Kingdom; McHardy, K.C., Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen AB2 9SB, United Kingdom; Calder, A.G.; Milne, E.; Fearns, L.M.; Broom, J.
Abstract: Rates of oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production have been measured in healthy adults during 4 h of fasting followed by 4 h of hourly small meals. Both rates rose to new steady values during feeding, and the respiratory quotient (RQ) increased from 0.792 to 0.924. The RQ was consistent in repeat studies on any individual (coefficient of variation: 2.5 per cent), and differences between individuals were significant in the fasted but not the fed state. Simultaneous measurements were made of the rate of protein oxidation by primed constant infusion of (1-13C) leucine for 8 h. Rates were calculated from the enrichment of plasma α-ketoisocaproate and the production of 13CO2 in the breath, taking account of the incomplete recovery of 13CO2 and the changes in baseline enrichment resulting from natural 13C in the food. Leucine oxidation increased by 87 per cent during the feeding period. Rates of nutrient utilization were calculated from respiratory gas exchange and rates of protein oxidation. These showed that fat was predominant in the fasted state, contributing 61 per cent of total energy expenditure, compared with 27 per cent for carbohydrate and 11 per cent for protein. On feeding there was a switch to carbohydrate as the main fuel (62 per cent), with smaller contributions from fat (20 per cent) and protein (18 per cent). During feeding total utilization of each nutrient exceeded its intake from the diet, indicating storage in the body. Dietary carbohydrate was stored without conversion to fat. It is concluded that this method is useful for studying the control of nutrient utilization by food intake.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; leucine c 13; unclassified drug; article; gas exchange; human; human experiment; methodology; normal human; nutrition; oxygen consumption; priority journal; Adult; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Dietary Proteins; Eating; Energy Metabolism; Fasting; Female; Humans; Male; Nutrition Physiology; Oxygen Consumption

Levy, A., Tel Aviv University, 69978 Ramat Aviv, Israel
Abstract: Using the CELLO detector at the PETRA e+e- storage ring a search for hadronic events with low thrust and an isolated lepton has been carried out. The rate of such events and the thrust distribution of inclusive lepton events show no evidence for a threshold of new sources of inclusive lepton events at the highest PETRA energies. For s46.3 GeV we observe any electron event of this above type, compared to an expectation of 0.8±0.2 events from lower energy data. We do not observe any electron event of this class at the highest PETRA energies. The CELLO data thus do not support the observations of the MARK-J and JADE collaborations of an excess of muon events of the above type at s>46.3 GeV. © 1987.

Authors: Fox I.H., Palella T.D., Kelley W.N.
Title: Hyperuricemia: A Marker for Cell Energy Crisis
Affiliations: University of Michigan Medical Center, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fox, I.H., University of Michigan Medical Center, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Palella, T.D., University of Michigan Medical Center, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Kelley, W.N., University of Michigan Medical Center, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: The underlying cause of hyperuricemia is often obscure. Why are serum urate levels markedly elevated in some acutely ill patients in the intensive care unit?1 What lies behind reports of uric acid nephropathy after heavy exertion?2 What is the association between ethanol ingestion and hyperuricemia?3 Why is gout characteristic of glycogen storage disease?4 The development of hyperuricemia in these apparently unrelated clinical situations, as well as many others, appears to be explained by a single pathogenetic mechanism, the net degradation of ATP.5 6 7 ATP is a ubiquitous, intracellular, high-energy phosphate compound involved in intermediate metabolism. Its synthesis and consumption are dynamic… © 1987, Massachusetts Medical Society. All rights reserved.
