Title: SUPERCONDUCTING. THE NEW BILLION DOLLAR BUSINESS.
Authors with affiliations: Heppenheimer, T.A.
Abstract: Superconductivity is a physical state in which all electrical resistance vanishes. Whereas an ordinary conductor such as copper requires a battery or generator to overcome resistive losses, a superconductor can circulate electricity indefinitely without a power source. Such currents produce intense magnetic fields and require energy only to run their liquid-helium refrigerators. The chief commercial market for such magnets is presently in magnetic-resonance imaging (MRI), a medical technique for observing tissues within the human body. The intense, steady fields produced by superconducting coils shorten exposure time and produce sharper, higher-contrast pictures than those made with conventional magnets.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES - Josephson Junctions; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY - Research; MAGNETIC-RESONANCE IMAGING/MRI; SUPER COLLIDER; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Title: The daresbury synchrotron radiation source
Affiliations: SERC Daresbury Laboratory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Daresbury Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Holland, D.M.P., SERC Daresbury Laboratory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Daresbury Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Daresbury Synchrotron Radiation Source consists of an electron storage ring designed to operate at an energy of 2GeV and with a stored current of 330mA. The dipole magnets have a bending radius of 5.56m and a field of 1.2T, which results in a Λc of 3.88Å. A 5T wiggler is also in operation which shifts Λc to 0.93Å. Recently an undulator magnet has been inserted into the storage ring and will be used to provide an intense source of VUV and soft X-ray radiation. Eight beamlines are now in routine operation and provide radiation for 23 experimental stations. The experimental activities encompass a wide range of research in chemistry, physics, biology and material science, and use radiation from the infrared to the hard X-ray. In addition, time-resolved spectroscopy is undertaken with the storage ring operating in single bunch mode. Recent highlights of the VUV research in photochemistry, photophysics and surface science are described to illustrate the various experimental techniques being applied and to provide an outline of the scientific programme. A summary is given of selected X-ray work. © IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: INFRARED RADIATION; PHYSICS - Solid State; SURFACES; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION - Sources; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION; DARESBURY SRS; PHOTOCHEMISTRY/PHOTOPHYSICS EXPERIMENTS; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION SOURCE (SRS); TIME-RESOLVED SPECTROSCOPY; VUV/SOFT X-RAY RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: POWER INDUSTRY EYES NEW SUPERCONDUCTORS WITH CAUTION.
Affiliations: Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA, Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smock, Robert W., Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA, Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA
Abstract: Superconductivity has been achieved in metal oxide ceramics at temperatures much more accessible than those needed for the metal alloy superconductors now in use. This new development opens the possibility of much broader application of technology in electronics and electrical systems, but it appears that a considerable amount of work needs to be done before commercial application can become a reality. The power industry has been working with superconductivity for many years in areas such as generator design, bulk energy storage, underground transmission, and magnetic confinement systems for fusion energy. However, no practical application has emerged yet and most of these programs are at a low ebb. The new superconductivity findings will probably revive some of them, but 10 years of preliminary development work is foreseen.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC GENERATORS - Design; ELECTRIC POWER PLANT EQUIPMENT - Materials; ENERGY STORAGE; HIGH-TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS; METAL OXIDE CERAMICS; PEROVSKITES; SUPERCONDUCTING ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING GENERATORS; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Title: DETERMINATION OF PARTICLE ORIGINS IN HIGH PURITY GASES.
Affiliations: Airco Industrial Gases, Murray Hill,, NJ, USA, Airco Industrial Gases, Murray Hill, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, Jeffrey M., Airco Industrial Gases, Murray Hill,, NJ, USA, Airco Industrial Gases, Murray Hill, NJ, USA
Abstract: Dynamic particle counters can help isolate some particle generation sources of equipped with very fine time and particle size resolution capabilities. Perhaps even more useful in determining particle origins is compositional information on the particles, which is not obtained with particle counters. One convenient technique is to capture particles on flat membrane, filters and analyze these particles in a scanning electron microscope with energy dispersive x-ray analysis. Automated membrane filter analysis, computer-controlled data analysis, and storage/retrieval provide improved efficiency. Comparisons between the compositions of particles collected from a given gas stream and the materials used to produce, store, and distribute these gases may indicate a particle generating material or component. Applications of these analytical techniques to semiconductor gas lines are discussed, and areas of future work are examined.
Index Keywords: GASES; MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION - Scanning Electron Microscopy; PARTICLE SIZE ANALYSIS; PARTICLE COUNTERS; SEMICONDUCTOR GAS LIVES; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICE MANUFACTURE

Title: Influence of light absorption during recording on the characteristics of volume phase transmission gratings
Affiliations: Central Laboratory of Optical Storage and Processing of Information, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 95, Sofia, 1113, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Markovski, P., Central Laboratory of Optical Storage and Processing of Information, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 95, Sofia, 1113, Bulgaria; Koleva, N., Central Laboratory of Optical Storage and Processing of Information, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 95, Sofia, 1113, Bulgaria
Abstract: The dependence of diffraction efficiency behaviour on absorption during recording is investigated, assuming that on reconstruction the grating is purely a phase one. This behaviour is described using the multiwave coupled-wave approach. The cases of both sinusoidal and non-sinusoidal recording are investigated, taking into account the photo-induced change in the refractive index depending on the energy. © 1987 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; LIGHT - Absorption; BRAGG'S DIFFRACTION; GRATING RECORDING; REFRACTIVE INDEX MODULATION; HOLOGRAPHY

Title: IAEA SAFEGUARDS IN PERSPECTIVE.
Source title: JNMM, Journal of the Institute of Nuclear Materials Management
Affiliations: IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Eklund, S., IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: This article is a review of the development of the International Atomic Energy Agency from President Eisenhower's 1953 Atoms for Peace proposal through development of the IAEA safeguards approach in the official documents (The Statute, INFCIRC/66 and 153), and related initiators, such as the Nuclear Supplier State Agreement (INFCE/254), The International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation (1977-79), The Committee on Assurance and Supply, and the proposed International Plutonium Storage Regime. The accomplishments of IAEA safeguards are recognized as well as the continuing need for development and support.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS - Safeguard Systems; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Safeguard Systems; IAEA SAFEGUARDS; NONPROLIFERATION; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Comeau Yves, Rabionwitz Barry, Hall Kenneth J., Oldham William K.
Title: PHOSPHATE RELEASE AND UPTAKE IN ENHANCED BIOLOGICAL PHOSPHORUS REMOVAL FROM WASTEWATER.
Source title: Journal of the Water Pollution Control Federation
Authors with affiliations: Comeau, Yves; Rabionwitz, Barry; Hall, Kenneth J.; Oldham, William K.
Abstract: A biochemical model was postulated to described the metabolism of bio-P bacteria under aerated and non-aerated conditions. The purpose of this paper was to present results from a series of batch experiments that were used as the experimental basis for the model. It was desired to quantify the stored carbon as well as to test the effects of affecting the pH gradient of bacteria by the addition of various chemicals under non-aerated conditions. The effects of increasing the energy level of bacteria by the addition of various chemicals under non-aerated conditions. The effects of increasing the energy level of bacteria by the addition of nitrate under non-aerated conditions was also tested. Observations related to metallic cation release and uptake are reported. Implications of the proposed concepts, especially of the key role of carbon storage, for full-scale application are discussed.
Index Keywords: BIOCHEMISTRY; PHOSPHATES - Removal; BIOLOGICAL PHOSPHORUS REMOVAL; PHOSPHATE RELEASE AND UPTAKE; WASTEWATER

Authors: Sato S., Tanaka J., Huke K.
Title: Photon factory: Status in 1986
Affiliations: Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, S., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Tanaka, J., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Huke, K., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: The Photon Factory (PF) consists of a 2.5 GeV electron storage ring, a full energy injector linac and experimental facilities, and has been operated steadily in the third fiscal year 1985 since it was opened as a national synchroton light source in June 1983. The linac has served as the injector of the Photon Factory Ring and the 6 GeV Accumulation Ring of TRISTAN. The light source, 2.5 GeV-electron storage-ring has been running steadily after overcoming various types of instabilities and a lifetime more than 8 hr was achieved for a storage current of 200 mA and 300 mA with and without the vertical wiggler, respectively. The user's experiments started with 8 beam lines (25 experimental stations) in 1983. In addition to commissioning two beam lines in 1985, now, two new beam lines are under construction and two are under design. In collaboration with outer organizations, five beam lines are in operation or under construction. © IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, LINEAR - Storage Rings; ELECTROMAGNETS; SPECTROSCOPY, AUGER ELECTRON; SPECTROSCOPY, X-RAY; INJECTOR LINAC; PHOTON FACTORY; VERY THIN FILM X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY; WIGGLER MAGNETS; PHOTONS

Title: Synchrotron radiation laboratories at the bonn electron accelerators a status report
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 12, Bonn 1, D 5300, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hormes, J., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 12, Bonn 1, D 5300, Germany
Abstract: At the Physikalisches Institut of the University in Bonn experiments with synchrotron radiation were carried out ever since 1962. At the moment (June 1986) all work takes place in the SR-laboratory at the 2.5 GeV synchrotron. A 3.5 GeV stretcher ring (ELSA) is under construction and will come into operation at the end of 1986. This accelerator will also run as a storage ring for synchrotron radiation experiments and a laboratory to be used at this machine is also under consideration. The SR experiments which are carried out in Bonn try to take advantage of the fact that we are still using a high energy synchrotron for our work. Besides basic research also applied work is done using synchrotron radiation even as a production tool for X-ray lithography. © IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: LITHOGRAPHY; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION; ELECTRON STRETCHER ACCELERATOR (ELSA); SYNCHROTRON RADIATION EXPERIMENTS; X-RAY LITHOGRAPHY; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Inagaki Y., Shima K., Maezawa H.
Title: Response functions of a Si(Li) detector for 1.3-4.0 keV monochromatic photons
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Kyoto University, Kyoto, 606, Japan; Tandem Accelerator Center, University of Tsukuba, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki-ken, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Inagaki, Y., Department of Physics, Kyoto University, Kyoto, 606, Japan; Shima, K., Tandem Accelerator Center, University of Tsukuba, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Maezawa, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba-gun, Ibaraki-ken, 305, Japan
Abstract: The response functions of a Si(Li) detector have been measured for monochromatic photons in the energy range 1.3-4.0 keV using synchrotron radiation from a 2.5 GeV electron storage ring. The contribution of the low-energy tail, just below the Gaussian full-energy peak, changed drastically at the boundary energy of the Si-K. absorption edge. The structure of the low-energy tail and the tail-to-peak ratio can be described by introducing a new simple geometrical model. The results of a fit based on the model were excellent for all data obtained over a wide energy range. © 1987.
Index Keywords: PHOTONS - Radiation Effects; ENERGY RESOLUTION; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; RADIATION DETECTORS

Authors: Bennett Michael J., Kline Charles H.
Title: CHEMICALS: AN INDUSTRY SHEDS ITS SMOKESTACK IMAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, Michael J.; Kline, Charles H.
Abstract: Shedding its smokestack image, the chemical industry is diversifying into a variety of high-technology and service-intensive businesses. It is moving beyond traditional chemicals to products such as drugs, plant seeds, special lubricants, and advanced materials. Some chemical companies are also penetrating the market for equipment used in conjunction with the chemicals they produce. By the year 2000 no major company will be purely a manufacturer of traditional chemicals. Rather, the large firms will offer a wide variety of products based on chemistry and chemical engineering in combination with biotechnology, electronics, electrical and mechanical engineering, and materials science. The latest innovations will involve a variety of new materials such as artificial blood and superconductors. These innovations will include systems and devices for electronics, energy production an storage, health care, toxic-waste management, and military and space applications. The new chemical industry will become increasingly international in scope.
Index Keywords: BIOMATERIALS - Manufacture; CHEMICAL INDUSTRY; DRUG PRODUCTS PLANTS; LUBRICANTS; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS - Manufacture; ARTIFICIAL BLOOD; INNOVATION; SPECIALTY CHEMICALS; CHEMICALS

Title: FUEL: AN ALTERNATIVE USE FOR MIXED PAPER WASTE.
Affiliations: EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA, EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Glaub, John C., EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA, EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA; Trezek, George J., EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA, EMCON Associates, San Jose, CA, USA
Abstract: Mixed paper waste (MPW) is often easy to segregate from the waste stream, either by source separation or diversion of certain commercial loads. But, recyclers have found it historically difficult to market. MPW, the lowest quality grade of recycled paper, consists of unsorted mixed papers obtained primarily from commercial sources (office buildings, printing establishments, paper converting operations, etc. ). MPW is an attractive energy source for several reasons. It is relatively homogeneous and is mostly free from putrescibles, metals, and other noncombustibles. Minimal processing is required to convert it into the densified form of energy suitable for direct combustion or gasification. When processed into densified fuel, the heating value of the fuel is close to that of wood. The densified fuel also has excellent storage characteristics. When properly combusted, the densified fuel has a low sulfur content, and low NO//x emissions when properly combusted.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; PAPER - Waste Utilization; REFUSE DISPOSAL; FUELS

Authors: Agrawal B.L., Subrahmanyam A., Suresh M.S., Venugopalan S.
Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL ENERGY STORAGE DEVICES FOR SPACE APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Transactions of the SAEST (Society for Advancement of Electrochemical Science and Technology)
Authors with affiliations: Agrawal, B.L.; Subrahmanyam, A.; Suresh, M.S.; Venugopalan, S.
Abstract: Electrochemical energy storage device is a critical component of most space power systems. Primary batteries, secondary batteries and fuel cells are commonly used as energy storage devices. The storage device requirements of each space program are unique. Extensive test programs are planned to qualify such systems for onboard use in space missions like Geosynchronous orbiters, low earth orbiters, space stations, planetary orbiters, landers and planetary probes. The review paper discusses these aspects and gives a technical comparison of the state-of-art battery systems for space use. Electrochemical storage systems which have potential for future use are also discussed.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, PRIMARY - Applications; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE - Equipment; SATELLITES - Power Supply; DEEP SPACE PROBES; GEOSYNCHRONOUS ORBITERS; LITHIUM SULFUR DIOXIDE; POWER GENERATOR; SPACE-STATION BATTERIES; SPACECRAFT

Title: MNOS DEGRADATION MECHANISM.
Authors with affiliations: Maslovskii, V.M.
Abstract: For over 10 years, there has been much research on MNOS structure degradation in connection with developments in energy-independent MOS memory components with stable characteristics. Degradation makes itself felt in metal-silicon nitride (SN)-ultrathin oxide-semiconductor (MNOS) structures in that there are changes in charge-accumulation characteristics for electrons and holes at the trapping centers (TC) as well as in the charge flow characteristics in repeated read-write cycles, as well as on UV, irradiation (the accumulated charge is less, as is the storage time). In this paper conductivity changes have been observed in SN MNOS structures as related to the charge passing. The rates of conductivity change in the two materials are determined by the nonequilibrium-carrier concentrations in the bulk and are dependent on the manufacturing conditions.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Storage Devices; MICROELECTRONICS; OXIDES; SILICON NITRIDE; AMORPHOUS SILICON; MNOS STRUCTURES; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOS

Title: ROCKS AROUND THE CLOCK.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Electric thermal storage (ETS) for space heating is a time-tested concept that is just now becoming competitive in the U. S. energy market. This paper describes the CaliDyne crushed-rock ETS furnace which is used in residences or business establishment to shift space heating requirements to off-peak hours. At night, space heating is provided by a conventional electric heater and blower positioned adjacent to the rock chamber. But at the same time, special heating elements at the top of the rock chamber and a separate, reversible storage blower are used to heat the bed of crushed rock. During daytime hours the storage blower is reversed to move air over the charged rock bed and to supply space heating. An automatic control system, linked to temperature sensors in the furnace and outdoors, regulates the heat received by the rock bed and prevents energy from being wasted on mild days.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; CRUSHED-ROCK FURNACE; ELECTRIC THERMAL STORAGE (ETS); ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Possibilities of the Application of Heat Accumulators in Industry.
Authors with affiliations: Lambrecht, J.; Soederstroem, M.
Abstract: For many industrial processes with heavy fluctuating energy requirements, the application of heat accumulators is technically justified. Two investigations which were recently completed in the Federal Republic of Germany and Sweden include a number of examples which show that application in industry is also economically significant. The article presents the possibilities of application of heat accumulators, deals with storage materials and shows examples for the recovery of waste heat and supply of peak loads.
Index Keywords: APPLICATIONS; CASE HISTORIES; HEAT ACCUMULATORS; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION

Title: BENEFITS OF BATTERY STORAGE AS SPINNING RESERVE: QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This analysis evaluated the previously unquantified economic benefits of replacing spinning reserve with electricity stored in batteries. According to the calculations, day-to-day operations for a typical 2000-MW generating system with 100 MW of battery storage yielded annual production cost savings of 4. 35 million.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Costs; ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEM PLANNING; ELECTRIC-BATTERY-BASED POWER STORAGE; LOAD MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Oxidation as a Major Cause of Defects in Electron-Beam and Optical Resists
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Advanced Technology, Perkin-Elmer Electron Beam Technology, 26460 Corporate Avenue, Hayward, CA, 94545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dean, R., Advanced Technology, Perkin-Elmer Electron Beam Technology, 26460 Corporate Avenue, Hayward, CA, 94545, United States
Abstract: In response to a study conducted at Perkin-Elmer ALO, which showed that surface anomalies present on PBS-coated masks prior to exposure were responsible for more than 50 percent of the chrome spot defects observed on the finished masks, Perkin-Elmer EBT initiated a study focusing on the causes of the defects found in the original materials. This study found that chemical oxidation, not foreign particulate contamination, was the major cause of the discrete defects found on PBS films. Elemental analysis of the small defects on fresh PBS-coated quartz masks with a scanning electron microscope, energy-dispersive x-ray analysis, and Auger spectroscopy showed that 66 percent of the defects contained little or no elemental contamination other than excess oxygen. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and small-spot refective infrared analysis of larger oxidized defects on older plates and of defects induced by known initiators of oxidation in polymers yielded information on chemical functional groups in the defects. This information confirmed the finding that oxidation was responsible for the changes observed in discrete areas. Oxidation changes the physical and chemical properties of the reacting area and produces an embedded particle or pinhole that causes a chrome spot or pinhole defect in the finished mask. Perkin-Elmer EBT has matched chrome spot defects that are images of known oxidized areas on PBS films with chrome spot defects detected by a KLA on finished production masks at Perkin-Elmer ALO. That similar defects have been observed on PMMA, EBR-9, and several kinds of AZ optical resists allows us to predict that oxidation of resists increases defect densities in all types of microlithography. The mechanisms of oxidation that result in discrete defects are described, and ways of reducing or eliminating such defects are discussed. © 1987, SPIE.
Index Keywords: Coated materials; Electron beams; Electrons; Energy dispersive X ray analysis; Initiators (chemical); Lithography; Optical disk storage; Oxidation; Polymethyl methacrylates; Scanning electron microscopy; X ray diffraction analysis; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Auger spectroscopy; Chemical functional groups; Chemical oxidation; Embedded particles; Infrared analysis; Oxidation changes; Particulate contamination; Physical and chemical properties; Chemical analysis

Authors: Piestrup M.A., Moran M.J., Berman B.L., Pianetta P., Seligson D.
Title: Transition radiation as an x-ray source for lithography
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Adelphi Technology, Inc., 532 Emerson Street, Palo Alto, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; George Washington University, Washington, United States; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, United States; Adelphi Technology, Inc., 532 Emerson Street, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Piestrup, M.A., Adelphi Technology, Inc., 532 Emerson Street, Palo Alto, United States; Moran, M.J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, United States; Berman, B.L., George Washington University, Washington, United States; Pianetta, P., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, United States; Seligson, D., Adelphi Technology, Inc., 532 Emerson Street, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: We have demonstrated that high-intensity soft x rays (900 eV to 3 keV) from transition radiation can be generated by passing moderate-energy (17 to 109 MeV) electron beams through targets consisting of thin (1 /¿m) multiple foils of beryllium and aluminum. We measured the absolute photon flux from five foil targets using a 44-/xA, 109-MeV-elec-tron beam, and estimated the photon flux by exposing 4" silicon wafers coated with PGMA photoresist. All previous measurements of photon production used photon-counting methods. We destructively tested foils at high-average currents for the first time. We exposed photoresist using a mask to produce a soft-x-ray lithograph. This research constitutes the first use of transition radiation as a source of soft x rays for lithography.These results indicate that moderate-energy linacs with transition radiators offer an alternative method of high power production of soft x rays for lithography. The radiation produced is at least three orders of magnitude brighter on a per-electron basis than synchrotron radiation. Storage rings have higher average beam currents than linacs; however, with a 10“2 difference in average currents, our experiments show that transition radiation will have the same average flux. Small, inexpensive accelerators such as one-klystron linacs can produce the required beam energies needed and would be less expensive than larger synchrotron sources.The Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory’s (LLNL) electron-positron linac was used in a series of short experiments (two 8-hr. shifts) to show feasibility. The foils were located in the accelerator cave in a direct line with the linac primary beamline. Immediately downstream from the foils, the electron beam was deflected into a beam-monitoring system. The lithography station and photon detectors were located 6.4 m downstream of the foils. The silicon wafers were partially shielded from other ionizing radiation produced in the accelerator cave. The soft-x-ray radiation was emitted in a cone of apex angle ± 5 mrad, with a diameter at the wafer of approximately 10 cm. The average power at the silicon wafer was 0.28 mw using the 44-fiA beam. The x-ray flux produced a smooth exposure of the resist, resulting in the "doughnut" pattern that is characteristic of the transition-radiation cone. No attempt was made to determine the optimum exposure time during these runs, and the wafers were left in the photon beam for time periods between 1 to 2 hrs.Adelphi Technology currently is constructing a test station at the Stanford High Energy Physics Laboratory. The beam spot will be approximately 3 cm in diameter and will be capable of being stepped across a 4"-diameter silicon wafer. The distance from the foils to the wafer will be 1.5 m. Fluxes of 5 to 10 mw are expected to be generated with photon energies from 1 to 3 keV. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Caves; Electron beams; Electrons; Linear accelerators; Photons; Photoresists; Silicon wafers; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Average currents; Lawrence livermore national laboratories; Photon counting method; Photon production; Soft x-ray radiation; Synchrotron source; Three orders of magnitude; Transition radiation; X rays

Authors: Jacobs D.B., Berenski C.J., Spangler R.A., Jung C.Y.
Title: Radiation inactivation target size of rat adipocyte glucose transporters in the plasma membrane and intracellular pools.
Authors with affiliations: Jacobs, D.B.; Berenski, C.J.; Spangler, R.A.; Jung, C.Y.
Abstract: The in situ assembly states of the glucose transport carrier protein in the plasma membrane and in the intracellular (microsomal) storage pool of rat adipocytes were assessed by studying radiation-induced inactivation of the D-glucose-sensitive cytochalasin B binding activities. High energy radiation inactivated the glucose-sensitive cytochalasin B binding of each of these membrane preparations by reducing the total number of the binding sites without affecting the dissociation constant. The reduction in total number of binding sites was analyzed as a function of radiation dose based on target theory, from which a radiation-sensitive mass (target size) was calculated. When the plasma membranes of insulin-treated adipocytes were used, a target size of approximately 58,000 daltons was obtained. For adipocyte microsomal membranes, we obtained target sizes of approximately 112,000 and 109,000 daltons prior to and after insulin treatment, respectively. In the case of microsomal membranes, however, inactivation data showed anomalously low radiation sensitivities at low radiation doses, which may be interpreted as indicating the presence of a radiation-sensitive inhibitor. These results suggest that the adipocyte glucose transporter occurs as a monomer in the plasma membrane while existing in the intracellular reserve pool either as a homodimer or as a stoichiometric complex with a protein of an approximately equal size.
Index Keywords: cytochalasin B; glucose transporter; adipose tissue; animal; article; cell membrane; drug effect; kinetics; male; metabolism; microsome; radiation exposure; radiation response; rat; rat strain; Adipose Tissue; Animal; Cell Membrane; Cytochalasin B; Dose-Response Relationship, Radiation; Kinetics; Male; Microsomes; Monosaccharide Transport Proteins; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: Optical bidirectional associative memories
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: VERAC, Incorporated, 9605 Scranton Road, San Diego, CA  92121, United States; Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, University of California, San Diego, San Diego, CA  92093, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kosko, B., VERAC, Incorporated, 9605 Scranton Road, San Diego, CA  92121, United States; Guest, C., Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, University of California, San Diego, San Diego, CA  92093, United States
Abstract: Four optical implementations of bidirectional associative memories (BAMs) are presented. BAMs are heteroassociative content addressable memories (CAMs). A BAM stores the m binary associations (A1, B1),..., (Am, Bm), where A is a point in the Boolean n-cube and B is a point in the Boolean p-cube. A is a neural network of n bivalent or continuous neurons a.; B is a network of p bivalent or continuous neurons b.. The fixed synaptic connections between the A and B networks are represented by some n-by-p real matrix M. Bidirectionality, forward and backward information flow, in neural nets produces two-way associative search for the nearest stored pair (Ai, Bi) to an input key. Every matrix is a bidirectionally stable heteroassociative CAM for both bivalent and continuous networks. This generalizes the well-known unidirectional stability for autoassociative networks with square symmetric M. When the BAM neurons are activated, the network quickly evolves to a stable state of two-pattern reverberation, or pseudo-adaptive resonance. The stable reverberation corresponds to a system energy local minimum. Heteroassociative pairs (Ai, Bi) are encoded in a BAM M by summing bipolar correlation matrices, M = X1 Y1 +... + Xm Ym, where Xi (Yi) is the bipolar version of Ai (Bi), with -Is replacing 0s. The BAM storage capacity for reliable recall is roughly m < min(n, p)-pattern number is bounded by pattern dimensionality. BAM optical implementations are divided into two approaches: matrix vector multipliers and holographic correlators. The four optical BAMs described respectively emphasize a spatial light modulator, laser diodes and high-speed detectors, a reflection hologram, and a transmission hologram. © 1987 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Associative processing; Correlators; Holograms; Image understanding; Light modulators; Man machine systems; Neural networks; Neurons; Reverberation; Autoassociative networks; Bi-directional associative memory; Holographic correlators; Matrix-vector multipliers; Optical implementations; Spatial light modulators; Synaptic connections; Transmission hologram; Associative storage

Abstract: Mass limits are presented for various supersymmetric particles: scalar partners of electrons, muons, taus and quarks; photinos, winos and zinos. They were obtained from the analysis of an exposure of 48.6 pb-1 of the CELLO detector at the PETRA e+e- storage ring up to a center of mass energy of 46.8 GeV. Special attention has been given to the case where the photino is assumed to be the lightest supersymmetric particle, but other possibilities have also been considered. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.

Title: UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL BLENDS NEW AND OLD.
Authors with affiliations: Holness, Gordon V.R.
Abstract: The New University Hospital at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor represents a significant and impressive piece of institutional construction. Designed as a reserch and teaching hospital, the facility encompasses 1. 1 million sq. ft. of physical space with 660,000 sq. ft. dedicated to a diagnostic and treatment center and 450,000 to an inpatient tower (IPU) accommodating 586 patient beds. The building is constructed with masonry and precast concrete on a structural steel frame. The diagnostic and treatment floors are designed on an interstitial space concept to provide access to major ductwork, piping and electrical services. The air handling systems for both the diagnostic and treatment base and the IPU tower are all designed for variable volume operation. Each air handling system is fitted with inlet vane control under system static pressure regulation. Airflow monitors maintain the relationship between supply, return and exhaust airflow rates at all times.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Control; ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN - Materials; BUILDING ENVELOPE EFFICIENCY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; RADIANT COMFORT TEMPERATURES; THERMAL STORAGE BASINS; HOSPITALS

Authors: Fontaine J.C., Levoir P., Delamar M., Meyer J.J., Paumard J.L.
Title: MODIFICATION OF A VG ESCALAB MK-1 ESCA SPECTROMETER FOR DIGITAL DATA ACQUISITION AND PROCESSING.
Affiliations: CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Fontaine, J.C., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr; Levoir, P., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr; Delamar, M., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr; Meyer, J.J., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr; Paumard, J.L., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr
Abstract: To enable signal averaging on our VG ESCALAB MK-1 spectrometer, we designed a digital ramp generator with repetitive mode of operation for each selected energy analyser sweep time. For digital data acquisition purposes we constructed a dedicated microcontrolled acquisition unit performing digitization of the ESCA spectrum in 4096 channels of 12-bit words. Data flow is controlled by a 6809 microprocessor driving a parallel interface adapter. Two RS 232C serial links are provided for communication with a terminal and a mass storage unit.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; SURFACES - Chemical Analysis; RAMP GENERATOR; SIGNAL AVERAGING; SPECTROMETERS

Title: THERMAL MASS: WHAT R-VALUES NEGLECT.
Authors with affiliations: Van Geem, Martha G.
Abstract: Laboratory tests use a calibrated hot box (ASTM Designation: C 976) to determine the thermal mass effects of walls and other building components. During dynamic calibrated hot box tests, heat flow is measured through a test specimen exposed to temperature changes typical of an exterior wall. The response of a test wall to temperature changes is a function of both thermal resistance and heat storage capacity. This article describes calibrated hot box test results for four masonry walls and one frame wall. Measured heat flows are compared to predicted heat flows based on R-values.
Index Keywords: BUILDING CODES; BUILDINGS - Energy Conservation; CALIBRATED HOT BOX TESTS; THERMAL MASS; MASONRY MATERIALS

Title: DESIGN GUIDELINES FOR PRESSURE TUNNELS AND SHAFTS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: After examining some 60 years of operating history of pressure tunnels and shafts - components of hydroelectric storage and power plants - researchers determined design deficiencies that caused leakage or major failures. Utilities can take advantage of the two improved design strategies recommended in this report to avoid similar problems in future hydro projects. Case studies demonstrate their applicability.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; POWER PLANTS - Design; SHAFT SINKING; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING; COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE; PUMPED HYDROELECTRIC STORAGE; UNDERGROUND POWERHOUSES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: NOVEL ACOUSTIC COUPLING DEVICE USING PERMEABLE MEMBRANE.
Authors with affiliations: Buynak, C.F.; Crane, R.L.
Abstract: This paper describes a new type of acoustic coupling device that possesses the advantages of a fluid couplant and is simple yet inexpensive enough to be used in most field-level applications. Briefly, the device consists of a water column supported by and allowed to leak slowly through a permeable membrane. This allows a small amount of water to wet the surface between the membrane and the part, providing an ultrasonic couplant. Because the membrane has an acoustic impedance very close to that of water, there is practically no reflection of acoustic energy from it, thereby permitting detection of near-surface flaws. The small amount of fluid required for the coupling very nearly eliminates problems associated with storage, dispensation, and cleanup of liquid or gel couplants. The device is quite simple in design and inexpensive enough to be disposable.
Index Keywords: MEMBRANES - Acoustic Properties; ACOUSTIC COUPLING DEVICE; CONTACT ULTRASONIC INSPECTION; NEAR-SURFACE FLAWS; PERMEABLE MEMBRANE; NONDESTRUCTIVE EXAMINATION

Authors: Ananthanarayanan V., Sahai Y., Mobley C.E., Rapp R.A.
Title: Modeling of fixed bed heat storage units utilizing phase change materials
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ananthanarayanan, V., Department of Metallurgical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States; Sahai, Y., Department of Metallurgical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States; Mobley, C.E., Department of Metallurgical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States; Rapp, R.A., Department of Metallurgical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States
Abstract: A computer model has been developed for the calculation of the heat exchanged and temperature profiles in a packed bed containing a phase change material. The packed bed is intended as a heat storage unit in which an inert fluid flowing through the bed exchanges heat with an encapsulated spherical shot of the phase change (melting and freezing) material. Examples of predicted bed temperature profiles during heat storage and utilization cycles are given. For A1-12 wt pct Si and Al-30 wt pct Si shot, a sequence of storage and utilization cycles with cyclic cocurrent fluid flow was found to utilize the high latent heat of fusion of the shot efficiently and permit the utilization of the bed as a near isothermal (577°C) heat recuperator. © 1987 The Metallurgical Society and ASM INTERNATIONAL.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM SILICON ALLOYS; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Packed Beds; HEAT TRANSFER - Packed Beds; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; COMPUTER APPLICATIONS; HEAT STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; SHOT; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: SOLAR RESEARCH FOR THE NEXT DECADE.
Authors with affiliations: Kurkowski, Ted
Abstract: In order for designers to specify products that make solar energy work in a building, a research program for sophisticated solar building materials was born. Solar researchers concluded that what were needed were cost-effective, controllable glazing and thermal storage systems that resemble the curtain wall skins or stud wall interiors traditionally used but that admit, store, and release solar heat and daylight as needed by the building. The products described in this article are designed to do just that. They are still in the laboratory, but because they adapt research developed and proven for other technological areas, the likelihood of success seems high. These include: glazing systems, thermal storage, core daylighting, dehumidification and integrated systems.
Index Keywords: BUILDING MATERIALS; BUILDINGS - Energy Conservation; DAYLIGHTING; GLAZES; SILICA GEL; AEROGEL; DEHUMIDIFICATION; SOLAR BUILDING MATERIALS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: McGarity A.E., Kirkpatrick D.L., Norford L.K.
Title: PUTTING AN OFFICE BUILDING ON ICE: A CASE STUDY.
Authors with affiliations: McGarity, A.E.; Kirkpatrick, D.L.; Norford, L.K.
Abstract: This article reports on the design and first full year of operation of an 'ice pond,' a large seasonal ice production and storage system. The ice pond is used to cool a large commercial office building in an office complex located near Princeton, New Jersey. At the time of this writing, the first full year of operation of the ice pond has just been completed. This article presents results on the performance of the ice pond in the ice-making mode and in the ice-using (building cooling) mode. Considerations that went into the design of the pond and on the progress that were made in analyzing data on the performance of the pond are discussed. Refs.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Energy Conservation; BUILDINGS - Cooling; SNOW AND SNOWFALL - Manufacture; ICE PONDS; SNOW MACHINES; ICE

Title: REDUCING WATER PUMPING POWER COSTS.
Authors with affiliations: Clark, Tom
Abstract: In general, a water system is designed for peak consumption periods. During periods of low consumption, the system is in a sense over designed and inefficient. By using data on Kilowatt hour usage per million gallons of water pumped (kwh/MG) as a performance index, the system operator can develop a program using existing equipment to reduce power consumption. The strategy is to gradually allow storage levels to decrease (during periods of low consumption) before starting the pumps. This will not only minimize pump starts, but will increase run time per start. By using the kwh/MG as an index, this can be accomplished over a period of time until the efficiency improves to an acceptable level.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION; PUMPS - Energy Conservation; WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS

Authors: Pashkov Tu.I., Serikov S.V., Monoshkov A.N.
Title: DEVICE WITH ENERGY STORE OF ELASTIC ENERGY FOR ASSESSING THE CRACK RESISTANCE OF MATERIALS.
Affiliations: Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR, Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Pashkov, Tu.I., Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR, Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR; Serikov, S.V., Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR, Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR; Monoshkov, A.N., Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR, Urals Science Inst of Tube Industry, Chelyabinsk, USSR
Abstract: For determining the crack resistance of materials, special devices with elastic energy storage instruments are used at present. In contrast to existing testing machines these devices permit one to determine on one specimen (Menager or Charpy) crack initiation during static loading and crack propagation during high-speed dynamic loading. Such a loading scheme of specimens permits a maximum approximation of the test conditions to the conditions of fracture of most structural steels and to reduce considerably the number of specimens as well as increase and improve the reliability of their testing. The authors propose a fundamentally new scheme for the testing device involving the use of energy accumulation.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; MATERIALS TESTING - Elasticity; STEEL - Crack Propagation; STEEL TESTING - Fracture; CRACK RESISTANCE ASSESSMENT; ELASTIC ENERGY STORAGE; HIGH-SPEED DYNAMIC LOADING TESTS; STATIC LOADING TESTS; MATERIALS TESTING APPARATUS

Title: SEISMIC FRAGILITY TESTING AT THE ENERGY TECHNOLOGY ENGINEERING CENTER.
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: DeVita, Vincent, Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: The Energy Technology Engineering Center (ETEC), a Department of Energy laboratory operated by Rockwell International near Los Angeles, California, has designed a system to meet the seismic fragility testing needs of the scientific community. This article describes the recently operational test system, its unique features, and initial test program results.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, DIGITAL; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; PIPE - Testing; VIBRATIONS; ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; SEISMIC FRAGILITY TEST SYSTEM; SHAKER TABLES; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL PERFORMANCE AND TRANSPORT PROPERTIES OF A NAFION MEMBRANE IN A HYDROGEN-BROMINE CELL ENVIRONMENT.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Baldwin, Richard S., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The overall energy conversion efficiency of a hydrogen-bromine energy storage system is highly dependent upon the characteristics and performance of the ion-exchange membrane utilized as a half-cell separator. This study has investigated the electrochemical performance and transport properties of a duPont Nafion membrane in an aqueous HBr-Br//2 environment. Membrane conductivity data are presented as a function of HBr concentration and temperature for the determination of ohmic voltage losses across the membrane in an operational cell. Diffusion-controlled bromine permeation rates and permeabilities are presented as functions of solution composition and temperature. Relationships between the degree of membrane hydration and the membrane transport characteristics are discussed. The solution chemistry of an operational hydrogen-bromine cell undergoing charge from 45 percent HBr to 5 percent HBr is discussed.
Index Keywords: DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY STORAGE; MEMBRANES - Ion Exchange; SPACECRAFT - Fuel Cells; HYDROGEN-BROMINE FUEL CELLS; NAFION MEMBRANE; FUEL CELLS

Title: COMPUTERIZATION OF BUILDING STANDARDS.
Affiliations: Lab of Urban Planning & Building, Design, Lab of Urban Planning & Building Design
Authors with affiliations: Kahkonen, Kalle, Lab of Urban Planning & Building, Design, Lab of Urban Planning & Building Design
Abstract: This publication is concerned with both the theoretical foundations and the software tools for computerizing building regulations. Previous research, especially from the United States, Australia and the United Kingdom, is also briefly reviewed. A number of prototype systems developed at the Technical Research Center of Finland are described. These include an expert system for fire regulations running in a question-and-answer mode and an augmented expert system which contains descriptive pictures illustrating the implementation of regulations. Next, an example of integration of an energy calculation program with a CAD system is described. Finally, current work related to the use of optical video discs as storage and presentation media for computer-controlled regulations data is briefly presented. As a conclusion, some suggestions are made concerning research and development work in the computer-aided creation and use of building standards.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; BUILDINGS - Computer Aided Design; COMPUTER SOFTWARE - Reviews; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; DATABASE SYSTEMS - Management; BUILDING CODE COMPUTERIZATION SOFTWARE; BUILDING CODE DATA STORAGE; BUILDING CODE DATABASES; CAD; BUILDING CODES

Title: COMBUSTION OF CROP RESIDUES FOR ENERGY.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The predominant application for combustion of crop residues is grain drying, although some use the energy for space heating of schools, homes, greenhouses and farm outbuildings. Key considerations when contemplating purchase of a biomass furnace include the moisture content of the residue when combusted, the cost of residue collection, storage and combustion, the type of residue the combustor is designed to burn, and the effect of residue collection on soil erosion.
Index Keywords: BIOMASS - Combustion; ENERGY RESOURCES - Waste Utilization; FUELS - Refuse Derived Fuels; BIOMASS FURNACES; BURNER DESIGNS; CROP RESIDUES; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Domogala G., Freiesleben H., Hippert B.
Title: Preparation and thickness determination of thin metallic 6Li targets
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-4630 Bochum, Germany; Dynamitron Tandem Laboratorium, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-4630 Bochum, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Domogala, G., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-4630 Bochum, Germany; Freiesleben, H., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-4630 Bochum, Germany; Hippert, B., Dynamitron Tandem Laboratorium, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-4630 Bochum, Germany
Abstract: It is indispensible for nuclear reaction studies between 6Li and 6Li at energies above E(6Li)≈8MeV to use targets which are largely free of carbon, oxygen, and fluorine. The preparation of metallic 6Li targets on thin titanium and nickel backings and the precautions taken to avoid such contaminations during production, storage, and irradiation are described. The target thicknesses are determined by comparison with 6Li(6Li, p)11B reaction rates at suitable beam energies from a thin 6Li deposit on a carbon backing. The 6Li content of the latter is determined by Rutherford scattering of 58Ni ions at Elab=8.5 MeV. © 1987.
Index Keywords: LITHIUM AND ALLOYS - Radiation Effects; NUCLEAR REACTION STUDIES; RUTHERFORD SCATTERING; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Getz H.-P., Knauer D., Willenbrink J.
Title: Transport of sugars across the plasma membrane of beetroot protoplasts
Affiliations: Botanisches Institut, Lehrstuhl III, Universität zu Köln, Gyrhofstrasse 15, Köln 41, D-5000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Getz, H.-P., Botanisches Institut, Lehrstuhl III, Universität zu Köln, Gyrhofstrasse 15, Köln 41, D-5000, Germany; Knauer, D., Botanisches Institut, Lehrstuhl III, Universität zu Köln, Gyrhofstrasse 15, Köln 41, D-5000, Germany; Willenbrink, J., Botanisches Institut, Lehrstuhl III, Universität zu Köln, Gyrhofstrasse 15, Köln 41, D-5000, Germany
Abstract: Protoplasts isolated from beetroot tissue took up glucose preferentially whereas sucrose was transported more slowly. The 14C-label from [14C]glucose and [14C]sucrose taken up by the cells could be detected rapidly in phosphate esters and, after feeding of [14C]glucose was found also in sucrose. The temperature-dependent uptake process (activation energy EA about 50 kJ · mol-1) seems to be carrier mediated as indicated by its substrate saturation and, for glucose, by competition experiments which revealed positions C1, C5 and C6 of the D-glucose molecule as important for effective uptake. The apparent Km(20° C) for glucose (3-O-methylglucose) was about 1 mM whereas for sucrose a significantly lower apparent affinity was determined (Km about 10 mM). When higher concentrations of glucose (5 mM) or sucrose (20 mM) were administered, the uptake process followed first-order kinetics. Carrier-mediated transport was inhibited by N,N′-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide, Na-orthovanadate, p-chloromercuribenzenesulfonic acid, and by uncouplers and ionophores. The uptake system exhibited a distinct pH optimum at pH 5.0. The results indicate that generation of a proton gradient is a prerequisite for sugar uptake across the plasma membrane. Protoplasts from the bundle regions in the hypocotyl take up glucose at higher rates than those derived from bundle-free regions. The results favour the idea that apoplastic transport of assimilates en route of unloading might be restricted to distinct areas within the storage organ (i.e. the bundle region) whereas distribution in the storage parenchyma is symplastic. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Assimilate allocation; Beta (sugar uptake); Protoplast (sugar uptake); Sugar uptake

Authors: Cirkel H.-J., Bette W., Friede D., Müller R.
Title: A new type of pulse forming network of low inductance and large energy storage density
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Kraftwerk Union AG, Hammerbacherstraße 12 + 14, Erlangen, D 8520, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Cirkel, H.-J., Kraftwerk Union AG, Hammerbacherstraße 12 + 14, Erlangen, D 8520, Germany; Bette, W., Kraftwerk Union AG, Hammerbacherstraße 12 + 14, Erlangen, D 8520, Germany; Friede, D., Kraftwerk Union AG, Hammerbacherstraße 12 + 14, Erlangen, D 8520, Germany; Müller, R., Kraftwerk Union AG, Hammerbacherstraße 12 + 14, Erlangen, D 8520, Germany
Abstract: A pulse forming network for excitation of high pressure TE-lasers using a large number of paralleled waterline capacitors is described. The low inductance PFN can be arranged in different circuits and has to be treated as a lumped circuit. At 33 kV charging voltage the XeCl-laser has emitted 4.0 J optical energy. A scaling of the PFN to a storage capacity of 7 kJ electrical energy is presented. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Applications; PULSE GENERATORS; HIGH PRESSURE TE-LASERS; LARGE ENERGY STORAGE DENSITY; LOW INDUCTANCE PULSE FORMING NETWORK; PARALLELED WATERLINE CAPACITORS; PULSE TRACES; LASERS, EXCIMER

Title: Development in remote area power supply in New South Wales
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Energy Authority of New South Wales
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, L., Energy Authority of New South Wales
Abstract: A convenient, reliable domestic energy supply is an essential aspect of living in remote areas and in 1983 the energy Authority identified the provision of remote area power supply (RAPS) as being a key issue. Technical and economic analyses of both stand alone diesel systems and more advanced hybrid systems utilising storage, inverters and renewable energy sources such as wind and solar energy, have been undertaken. Performance and operational strategies for various systems ranging from small lighting units to large domestic power systems have been examined and general findings regarding their operation and maintenance are outlined. In an attempt to redress a number of identified inequities experienced by residents of remote areas, the New South Wales Government has induced the Remote Area Power Assistance Scheme which provides capital assistance to residents for either grid connection or for the purchase of a RAPS system. The Scheme started on 1 January 1987 and will run for a period of 5 years. The Scheme's primary aims are to provide a reasonable level of assistance to remote residents and to facilitate the rapid introduction of new energy efficient generating and storage technology.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - New South Wales, Australia; Energy Resources; Operational Strategies; Remote Area Power Assistance Scheme; Remote Area Power Supply; Renewable Energy Sources; Electric Power Generation

Title: Laterally and longitudinally dispersive recoil mass separators
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: II. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Giessen, 6300 Giessen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wollnik, H., II. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Giessen, 6300 Giessen, Germany
Abstract: Principles of laterally dispersive and time-of-flight mass separators are outlined. Special emphasis is given to separators for very energetic recoils for which electrostatic fields would be technologically impossible. The principle of energy isochronous time-of-flight mass separators is shown to be applicable to storage rings. © 1987.
Index Keywords: IONS - Transport Properties; PARTICLE OPTICS; SEPARATORS; BEAM FOCUSING; MASS SEPARATORS; RECOIL SEPARATORS; ION SOURCES

Authors: Bohdansky J., Croessmann C.D., Linke J., McDonald J.M., Morse D.H., Pontau A.E., Watson R.D., Whitley J.B., Goebel D.M., Hirooka Y., Leung K., Conn R.W., Roth J., Ottenberger W., Kotzlowski H.E.
Title: Behavior of graphite under heat load and in contact with a hydrogen plasma
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Max-Planck-Institut für Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association D-8046 Garching, München, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bohdansky, J., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Croessmann, C.D., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Linke, J., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; McDonald, J.M., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Morse, D.H., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Pontau, A.E., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Watson, R.D., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Whitley, J.B., Sandia National Laboratories, NM 87185, USA and Livermore, Albuquerque, CA 94550, United States; Goebel, D.M., University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Hirooka, Y., University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Leung, K., University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Conn, R.W., University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Roth, J., Max-Planck-Institut für Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association D-8046 Garching, München, Germany; Ottenberger, W., Max-Planck-Institut für Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association D-8046 Garching, München, Germany; Kotzlowski, H.E., Max-Planck-Institut für Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association D-8046 Garching, München, Germany
Abstract: Graphite is extensively used in large tokamaks today. In these machines the material is exposed to vacuum, to intense heat loads, and to the edge plasma. The use of graphite in such machines, therefore, depends on the outgassing behavior, the heat shock resistance, and thermochemical properties in a hydrogen plasma. Investigations of these properties made at different laboratories are described here. Experiments conducted at Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), Livermore, and the Max-Planck-Institut für Plasmaphysik (IPP) in Garching showed that the outgassing behavior of fine-grain reactor-grade graphite and carbon fiber composites depends on the pretreatment (manufacturing and/or storage). However, after proper outgassing the samples tested behave similarly in the case of fine-grain graphite, but the outgassing remains high for the carbon fiber composites. Heat shock tests have been made with the Electron Beam Test System (EBTS) at SNL, Albuquerque. Directly cooled graphite samples (FE 159 graphite brazed onto Mo tubes) showed no failure at a heat load of 700 W/cm2, 20 s; or 10 kW, 1 s. Thermal erosion due to sublimination and particle emission from the graphite surface was observed. This effect is related to the surface temperature and becomes significant at temperatures above 2500°K. Fourteen different types of graphite were tested; the main differences among these samples were the different surface temperatures obtained under the same heating conditions. Cracking due to heat shocks was observed in some of the samples, but none of the carbon fiber composites failed. Thermochemical properties have been tested in the PISCES plasma generator at UCLA for ion energies of around 100 eV. The formation of C-H compounds was observed spectroscopically at sample temperatures of around 600°C. However, this chemical reaction did not lead to erosion as observed in beam experiments but to a drastic change of the surface structure due to redeposition. Carbon-hydrogen lines were still observed at sample temperatures of around 100°C. Under these conditions the erosion yield is high and in agreement with those measured in beam experiments. © 1987.
Index Keywords: PLASMAS; TOKAMAK DEVICES - Materials; HEAT LOADS; LIMITER; OUTGASSING; GRAPHITE

Title: Urban heat storage derived as energy balance residuals
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B. C., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oke, T.R., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B. C., Canada; Cleugh, H.A., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B. C., Canada
Abstract: The hourly heat storage changes of a suburban area in Vancouver B.C. are evaluated by residual after determining all other terms in the surface energy balance. Despite the errors and uncertainties associated with this approach, the resulting diurnal cycle of heat storage uptake and release appears to behave in a fashion similar to that of less complex systems. When plotted against the net all-wave radiation, the heat storage values display a hysteresis loop with the peak storage preceding that of radiation. Therefore, although a linear parameterization of heat storage is shown to produce reasonable first-order estimates of storage, a form which includes the time derivative of the net radiation is probably better. © 1987 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: HOT WATER BOILERS.
Affiliations: Plant Engineering, Newton MA, USA, Plant Engineering, Newton MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Holzhauer, Ron, Plant Engineering, Newton MA, USA, Plant Engineering, Newton MA, USA
Abstract: Hot water is often ignored when an energy medium is chosen. In actuality, it offers a number of significant advantages over steam in many applications where either choice is acceptable from an operational point of view. This article discusses low and high temperature equipment for space heating and process applications. Subjects covered include rating and capacity, heat storage, and others.
Index Keywords: HEATING; INDUSTRIAL HEATING; WATER HEATERS; BOILERS

Title: MARX GENERATOR FOR HIGH VOLTAGE EXPERIMENTS.
Authors with affiliations: Richley, E.A.
Abstract: This article discusses the high voltage Marx Generator using capacitors charged in parallel but discharged in series. The mechanism by which this high voltage pulse generator works is described.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC ARCS; ELECTRIC CORONA; GLOW DISCHARGES; CORONA DISCHARGE; CORONA LEAKAGE; HIGH VOLTAGE MARX GENERATOR; MEGAVOLT PULSE GENERATOR; PULSE GENERATORS

Title: MODIFIED 501 POWERS 10 MW AND 25 MW STORAGE PEAKERS.
Authors with affiliations: de Biasi, Victor
Abstract: In the past few months, Columbia Energy Storage, Inc (CESI), in Miami, Florida has been drumming up industrial and electric utility interest in a Programmed Air Compression Energy Recovery (PACER) peaking system designed around a modified Allison 501 gas turbine - rated at 10 MW output without its compressor load - and a prefabricated tank farm for compressed air storage. The idea is to compress air during off-peak hours using low cost electric power or steam turbine, store the pressurized air at 2000 psig until needed and then draw it off as required during on-peak hours for delivery at 160 psig to the combustor of the turbo expander to generate peak electric power. CESI is marketing two different PACER system designs.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; FUEL COSTS; PROGRAMMED AIR COMPRESSION ENERGY RECOVERY; GAS TURBINES

Title: COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE: AN ANALYSIS OF FUEL FLEXIBILITY AND PLANT COMPONENTS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Compressed-air energy storage plants show promise for economically meeting intermediate and peak electricity demands by storing excess energy from baseload plants. This report documents the successful operation of the first CAES plant, presents a design for a commercial fuel-flexible combustor system, and suggests improvements for various plant components.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; GAS TURBINES - Combustors; COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE; EXHAUST STACK RECUPERATORS; GAS TURBINE COMBUSTORS; GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS

Title: A study of curve fitting to liquid scintillation counter calibration data
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Department of Physical Sciences, Trent Polytechnic, Clifton Lane, Nottingham, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Crookes, J.N., Department of Physical Sciences, Trent Polytechnic, Clifton Lane, Nottingham, England, United Kingdom; Lilley, I., Department of Physical Sciences, Trent Polytechnic, Clifton Lane, Nottingham, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: A comprehensive study is made of the various curve fitting procedures available for representing the calibration data used in the dpm assay of LSC samples and compatible with the limited memory storage available in modern instruments. The output data from the LSC are echoed to a microcomputer allowing the utilisation of user developed algorithms for data processing and analysis. The evidence shows that the normal practice of the machine selecting a curve without choice by the user may not produce the best results. In general the cubic spline interpolation with natural end conditions is found to give the best representation for standards involving errors of less than 1.5% for 3H and 14C. However, for 14C and higher energy β-emitters there is strong evidence for the use of Stineman interpolation. © 1987.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Curve Fitting; CUBIC SPLINE; LIQUID SCINTILLATION COUNTERS; SCINTILLATION COUNTERS

Authors: Lamphere Frank J., Valentino Thomas A.
Title: INNOVATIVE WAYS TO SAVE ENERGY IN NEW BUILDINGS.
Affiliations: Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ,, USA, Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lamphere, Frank J., Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ,, USA, Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ, USA; Valentino, Thomas A., Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ,, USA, Climate Control Inc, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Abstract: Changing the energy consumption patterns of customers is very difficult. However, innovative mechanical systems employing thermal storage can yield substantial owning and operating savings for consumers. Additional benefits are reduced peak demands for power companies (this ultimately benefits all their customers) and new business opportunities for heating/piping/air conditioning engineers and contractors. In the coming years, thermal storage is expected to play a growing part in managing operating costs for owners. This paper presents two case histories: one for a new office complex and the other for an existing office building.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY CONSUMPTION PATTERNS; THERMAL STORAGE; BUILDINGS

Authors: Chen Peter Y.S., Helmer Wayne A.
Title: DESIGN AND TESTS OF A SOLAR-DEHUMIDIFIER KILN WITH HEAT STORAGE AND HEAT RECOVERY SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA, USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Peter Y.S., USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA, USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA; Helmer, Wayne A., USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA, USDA, Carbondale, IL, USA
Abstract: A rockbed heat storage unit, an additional solar collector, and a heatpipe heat recovery system were added to an existing experimental solar-dehumidifier kiln and tested with 4/4 yellow-poplar. This novel system kiln-dried and conditioned yellow-poplar lumber from green (92%) to 8 percent moisture content in 7 to 11 days throughout the year. These drying times are almost equal to the conventional steam-heated kiln-drying time of 6 to 10 days. Lumber quality was excellent. The lumber was lighter in color than conventional kiln-dried lumber. No collapse, surface checking, or end checking was observed in the dried lumber. Adding heat storage and heat recovery systems and a second solar collector to the solar-dehumidifier kiln increased the kiln's energy efficiency by nearly 30 percent. A solar-dehumidifier kiln, with heat storage and heat recovery systems and an additional collector, offers an energy-efficient method of drying hardwood lumber.
Index Keywords: KILNS - Moisture Control; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; DEHUMIDIFICATION KILNS; DEHUMIDIFICATION LUMBER DRYING; SOLAR DRYING SYSTEM; LUMBER

Title: MILITARY DRAWS A BEAD ON ELECTROMAGNETIC GUNS.
Authors with affiliations: Heppenheimer, T.A.
Abstract: In the development of advanced tank technology the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) is sponsoring development of advanced tank technology to offset the West's numerical inferiority. High on the priorities list are electromagnetic tank guns that offer muzzle velocities considerably higher than those of conventional ammunition used by old-style Soviet tanks. Effective ranges of 5 and even 10 kilometers are possible with electromagnetic guns, instead of just 2 kilometers or less for present-day ordnance. Considered are several major elements: the gun barrel, the power source, the energy storage and switch, and the projectiles themselves. Possible gun barrels include railguns, coilguns, and electrothermal guns.
Index Keywords: MILITARY VEHICLES - Tanks; COILGUNS; ELECTROMAGNETIC GUNS; ELECTROTHERMAL GUNS; LONG RANGE GUNS; RAILGUNS; GUNS

Authors: Mengoli G., Musiani M.M., Pletcher D., Valcher S.
Title: Studies of Zn|ZnX2|polyaniline batteries. II. X=I
Affiliations: Corso Stati Uniti, Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa del CNR, Padova, 4-35100, Italy; Department of Chemistry, The University, Southampton, SO9 5NH, United Kingdom; Istituto Chimico G. Ciamician, Universitá di Bologna, via Selmi, Bologna, 2-40100, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mengoli, G., Corso Stati Uniti, Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa del CNR, Padova, 4-35100, Italy; Musiani, M.M., Corso Stati Uniti, Istituto di Polarografia ed Elettrochimica Preparativa del CNR, Padova, 4-35100, Italy; Pletcher, D., Department of Chemistry, The University, Southampton, SO9 5NH, United Kingdom; Valcher, S., Istituto Chimico G. Ciamician, Universitá di Bologna, via Selmi, Bologna, 2-40100, Italy
Abstract: The characteristics of a Zn|ZnI2|polyaniline battery have been examined. It is demonstrated that the polymer has a charge storage capacity of 143 A h kg-1 and an energy efficiency above 70%. The battery has an open circuit voltage of 1.2 V and polarization during charges and discharges at 30-120 mA were low. Self discharge is low compared to the chloride and bromide electrolyte batteries and charge recovery was 60% after 12 days stored on open circuit. It is shown that these promising characteristics may be interpreted in terms of a system where the polyaniline largely acts as a current collector and the I3-/I- couple is rapid within the film. The kinetics of the system are determined by a.c. impedance. © 1987 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: BROMINE COMPOUNDS - Applications; ELECTROLYTES - Materials; POLYMERS - Oxidation; CHARGE DENSITY; EMERALDINE; POLYANILINE BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: SEALED LEAD-HYDROGEN STORAGE BATTERIES.
Authors with affiliations: Tsenter, B.I.; Lyzlov, N.Yu.
Abstract: The authors have attempted, in particular, to build lead-hydrogen storage batteries on the basis of an electrochemical system. To this end the behavior of lead dioxide electrodes was studied in detail in sulfuric acid solutions under hydrogen. The lead-hydrogen storage battery (LHB) proposed by the authors has certain advantages over other known metal-hydrogen storage batteries. First, the hydrogen electrode of the LHB is more active than that of the NHB (Nickel Hydrogen Battery) or SHB, which is due to the fact that the exchange current density of the hydrogen reaction at platinum is much higher in acidic than in alkaline medium. Hence in fabricating the hydrogen electrodes of LHB one can use a much smaller amount of platinum catalyst (with electrodes operated in the kinetic mode), and hence lower the cost of the battery. Another advantage of LHB over NHB and SHB is the higher charge retention found for LHB.

Authors: Chikenji T., Elwyn D.H., Gil K.M., Danforth Jr. E., Askanazi J., Kinney J.M.
Title: Effects of increasing glucose intake on nitrogen balance and energy expenditure in malnourished adult patients receiving parenteral nutrition
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chikenji, T., Department of Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Elwyn, D.H., Department of Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Gil, K.M., Department of Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, United States; Danforth Jr., E.; Askanazi, J.; Kinney, J.M.
Abstract: 1. The effects of increasing glucose intake on nitrogen balance, energy expenditure and fuel utilization were measured in malnourished adult patients receiving parenteral nutrition with constant nitrogen intake and high or low glucose intakes for 8 day periods. 2. Energy balance, nitrogen balance, weight and temperature were determined daily. Blood samples taken at admission and at the end of days 7 and 8 of each diet were analysed for glucose, fatty acids, urea, insulin, glucagon and thyroid hormones. 3. The effect of increasing glucose intake was to increase nitrogen balance by 0.28 ± 0.08 (SEM) mg/kJ. A scheme is proposed, based on present and previous findings, of the separate effects of nitrogen and energy intake on nitrogen balance, permitting calculation of rates of repletion of fat and lean body mass from estimates of nitrogen intake and energy balance. Malnourished patients are shown to attain markedly positive nitrogen balances at zero or negative energy balances. Large errors in estimation of energy requirements have little effect on nitrogen balance. 4. Changes in nitrogen balance were entirely due to changes in urea excretion. 5. Creatinine excretion increased 12% with high glucose intake, attributed mainly to increased muscle mass (7%) and body temperature (4%). 6. A 12% increase in resting energy expenditure was only partly due to costs of glycogen storage and lipogenesis; the remainder, about one-half, is probably due to glucose and insulin mediated increases in sympathetic activity. 7. There were marked increases in 3,5,3'-tri-iodothyronine (T3) concentrations with time, but no difference between the high and low glucose diets. The T3/thyroxine ratio, an index of free T3 concentration, increased much more rapidly on the high than on the low glucose diet. Changes in T3 could not account for the effect of glucose, under these conditions, to increase resting energy expenditure.

Authors: Drummond T.J., Jones E.D., Hjalmarson H.P., Doyle B.L.
Title: Growth and characterization of gaas/alas superlattice alloys
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drummond, T.J., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87135, United States; Jones, E.D., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87135, United States; Hjalmarson, H.P., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87135, United States; Doyle, B.L., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87135, United States
Abstract: Recent studies of short period GaAs/AlAs superlattices grown by molecular beam epitaxy have shown that the superlattice bandstructure resembles that of the AlCaAs alloy system. We have studied indirect gap GaAs/AlAs superlattice alloys using x-ray diffraction and pressure dependent magneto-luminescence. Analysis of the x-ray data shows that the AlAs layers are strained to be pseudomorphic with the GaAs substrate. Because the indirect conduction band ground state derives from the AlAs X-point these superlattice alloys must be treated as strained-layer superlattices. Interpretation of luminescence data using Kronig-Penney and tight-binding analyses of the superlattice bandstructure and optical dipole matrix elements shows that this experiment provides a sensitive measure of the conduction band offset for the GaAs/AlAs system. Quantum size effects lift the three-fold degeneracy of the X-point to yield an in-plane X band quantized according to the transverse electron mass (Xt) and a separate X band along the superlattice axis quantized according to the longitudinh electron mass (X1). Strain shifts at the X-points are of the same magnitude as quantum size effect shiffs and drive the Xt band toward lower energies. The effect of strain in the conduction band can be acdurately modeled by assuming GaP deformation potentials for the AlAs layers. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Aluminum gallium arsenide; Conduction bands; Digital storage; Gallium arsenide; Gallium phosphide; Ground state; III-V semiconductors; Luminescence; Molecular beam epitaxy; Semiconducting gallium; Semiconductor alloys; Deformation potential; Effect of strain; GaAs substrates; GaAs/AlAs superlattice; Optical dipole matrix element; Pressure dependent; Quantum size effects; Strained layer superlattice; Aluminum alloys
