Abstract: Photosynthetic action spectra (F = frac(φ ('; r) α, λ)) (Carpentier, R., Larue, B. and Leblanc, R. (1984) Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 228, 534-543.), from 400 to 750 nm were studied in bundle sheath cells of maize. Photosynthetic action spectra in the presence of 10 mM ascorbate or 4 mM ribose-5-phosphate were increased and shifted through all the spectra. After the addition of 10 M DCMU photosynthetic action spectra were remarkably diminished. On the basis of these results we suggest that the role of PSII in BS chloroplasts will be to prevent the overoxidation of PSI. I1 appears that in addition to PSII some endogen electron donor may regulate the PSI activity in bundle sheath cells. © 1987 Academic Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: The nucleon emission asymmetry in →d(e, pn)e′ reaction was measured using the tensor-polarized deuterium jet target in the VEPP-2 electron storage ring. At the present experimental accuracy, the results for the proton energy interval Ep = 12-100 MrmMeV do not contradict the nonrelativistic calculations. © 1987.

Authors: Brown D.C., Benfey D.P., Gehm W.J., Holmes D.H., Lee K.K.
Title: Parasitic oscillations and amplified spontaneous emission in face-pumped total internal reflection lasers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, D.C., General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States; Benfey, D.P., General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States; Gehm, W.J., General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States; Holmes, D.H., General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States; Lee, K.K., General Electric Company, Electrical and Laser Systems, P. O. Box 5000, Binghamton, NY, 13902, United States
Abstract: Parasitic oscillations and amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) can often strongly influence the operation and efficiency of laser devices, as has been shown previously for disk and active-mirror amplifiers. Here we report the first comprehensive investigation of those phenomena in total internal reflection (TIR) face-pumped lasers. The results to be presented here were made possible by the development of two three-dimensional computer codes. The first (PARA) systematically searches for parasitic oscillations in slab lasers and determines the gain required to reach threshold. Our second code (AMSPE) is a three dimensional raytrace model which includes temporal gain and allows for non-uniform gain profiles. AMSPE calculates the gain depletion as well as changes in spatial gain profile and thus the decrease in amplifier efficiency as a function of a number of critical parameters such as slab aspect ratio, spontaneous emission spectral profile, and slab face angle. In this paper we first review the classes of parasitics in slab lasers and show how symmetry breaking can significantly increase the energy storage capability of such deyices. We then review the construction of the AMSPE code and show how it may be used to identify maximum efficiency slab laser configurations. © 1987 SPIE.

Title: Highly-charged ions at electron-volt energies and below: Production, storage, and measurements
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Church, D.A., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: Goals of thermal multicharged ions for collision and spectroscopic studies, and of subthermal antiprotons for gravitational tests and atomic and nuclear measurements, lead to requirements of capture, confinement, and cooling of these charges. Storage of recoil ions in a radio-frequency trap, synchrotron radiation production of stored multicharged ions near room temperature, and external injection of ions into a Penning trap are discussed, and used as a basis for speculations on achieving higher charge states, lower energies, and neutral antimatter. © 1987.

Authors: Johnson B.M., Meron M., Agagu A., Jones K.W.
Title: Atomic physics and synchrotron radiation: The production and accumulation of highly charged ions
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, B.M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Meron, M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Agagu, A., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Jones, K.W., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation can be used to produce highly-charged ions, and to study photoexcitation and photoionization for ions of virtually any element in the periodic table. To date, with few exceptions, atomic physics studies have been limited to rare gases and a few metal vapors, and to photoexcitation energies in the VUV region of the electromagnetic spectrum. These limitations can now be overcome using photons produced by high-brightness synchrotron storage rings, such as the X-ray ring at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) at Brookhaven. Furthermore, calculations indicate that irradiation of an ion trap with an intense energetic photon beam will result in a viable source of highly-charged ions that can be given the name PHOBIS: the photon beam ion source. Promising results, which encourage the wider systematic use of synchrotron radiation in atomic physics research, have been obtained in recent experiments on VUV photoemission and the production and storage of multiply-charged ions. An overview of the field, current plans, and future possibilities will be presented. © 1987.
Index Keywords: IONS; PHYSICS - Atomic; PHOTOEXCITATION; PHOTOIONIZATION; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Abstract: Beam cooling methods developed for high energy colliders of protons and antiprotons are now finding application as media for experimentation in Nuclear and Atomic Physics. Abstract: Nondestructive wideband rf beam diagnostics, designed for use in the IUCF Cooler storage ring, are being used in the cyclotron beam lines. Wall gap monitors monitor the beam microscopic time structure, macroscopic time structure, and phase with respect to the main synthesizer; electrostatic pickup electrodes monitor the beam position and intensity. The signal processing and rf-inter-ference-elimination techniques which allow these monitors to operate with beam intensities as low as 10 nA are described. The performance limitations for rf pickups in low energy, low intensity accelerators, and possible methods for using the powerful synchronous detection techniques with nonbunched beams are discussed. © 1987 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. Abstract: The race-track microtron can play two important roles in X-ray lithography: It can serve as a low energy injector (at 50-150 MeV) to compact synchrotron/storage rings which are either normal conducting or superconducting; or it can, in a superconducting version, serve as full energy injector (at e.g. 680 MeV) integrated with a surrounding superconducting storage ring, forming a compact synchrotron light source. © 1987 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. Title: Atomic physics at the Heidelberg Test Storage Ring (TSR)
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Physikaliches Institut der Universität, D-6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schuch, R., Physikaliches Institut der Universität, D-6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: A brief description of the Heavy-Ion Test Storage Ring (TSR) presently being built at the Max-Planck Institut in Heidelberg is given. It will be able to store ions injected from the tandem postaccelerator combination up to ∼ 30 MeV/nucleon for a charge to mass ratio of 0.5. One of the main purposes of the TSR will be the study of electron cooling. Some atomic physics experiments are discussed using the electron cooling device which provides an electron-ion collision facility with good energy resolution and ion beams of high currents and low emittances. Here the possibilities for measurements of spontaneous and laser-induced radiative recombination and dielectronic recombination in the electron cooling section are discussed. © 1987.

Abstract: HISTRAP, Heavy-Ion Storage Ring for Atomic Physics, is a proposed 46.8-m-circumference synchrotron-cooling-storage ring optimized to accelerate, decelerate, and store beams of highly charged very-heavy ions at energies appropriate for advanced atomic physics research. The ring is designed to allow studies of electron-ion, photon-ion, ion-atom, and ion-ion interactions. An electron cooling system will provide ion beams with small angular divergence and energy spread for precision spectroscopic studies and also is necessary to allow the deceleration of heavy ions to low energies. HISTRAP will have a maximum bending power of 2.0 T m and will be injected with ions from either the existing Holifield Heavy Ion Research Facility 25-MV tandem accelerator or from a dedicated ECR source and 250 keV/nucleon RFQ linac. © 1987.

Title: The heavy ion storage and cooler ring project ESR at GSI
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: GSI-Darmstadt, Postfach 110541, D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Franzke, B., GSI-Darmstadt, Postfach 110541, D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The Experimental Storage Ring ESR [1] is designed for accumulation, storage and cooling of heavy ion beams up to uranium with energies up to 500 MeV/u either directly out of the heavy ion synchrotron SIS [2] or via a stripper target, where electron-free or electron-poor ions are produced. The intense, cold beams may be used for a large variety of experiments, preferably in-ring experiments making use of the special features of the storage ring. Due to circulation frequencies of up to 2 MHz high luminosities will be attained using thin internal gas jet or electron target. Energies can be varied over a wide range from 500 MeV/u down to 3 MeV/u. The SIS/ESR-facility will also be capable of delivering beams of unstable nuclei produced by fragmentation or fission of heavy projectiles. After preselection in a large acceptance Z/A-separator the secondary beams can be prepared for internal or external experiments by stochastic precooling, intensity accumulation and final electron cooling. © 1987.
Index Keywords: IONS; EXPERIMENTAL STORAGE RING ESR; HEAVY ION SYNCHROTRON SIS; SIS/ESR-FACILITY; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Abstract: The CRYRING project comprising the electron beam ion source CRYSIS, an RFQ linear accelerator and a combined synchrotron and storage ring, was funded in 1985. Around CRYSIS low-energy atomic and surface physics experiments are being developed and within the ring itself atomic physics experiments with merged and crossed external beams are being planned. The external beams will consist of photons, electrons and low charge state ions. © 1987.

Authors: Hirai Y., Kato Y., Naemura S., Tani C.
Title: High-resolution MIM-diode LCD addressed by storage capacitor matrix
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: This paper proposes an MIM-Diode LCD using SCAD(“Storage Capacitor Addressed Diode”) structure, and confirms the realization of a large area and high-resolution SCAD-LCD panel by fabricating an LCD panel with 450 × 450 pixels and 0.2 mm pitch. A characteristic for the “SCAD” structure is that the series connection between an MIM-diode and a storage capacitor is addressed by column and row electrodes. The voltage applied to a liquid-crystal layer is controlled by the storage capacitor voltage. “SCAD-LCD” advantages are that fine lithography and fine alignment accuracy are unnecessary, even for fine-pitch panels, due to the large storage capacitor capacitance. These advantages are also confirmed by digital simulation. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; SEMICONDUCTOR DIODES - Design; SOLID STATE DEVICES, MIM - Design; LCD; MIM-DIODE LCD; SCAD-LCD DIGITAL SIMULATION; STORAGE CAPACITOR ADDRESSED DIODE; DISPLAY DEVICES

Authors: Teoh S.H., Chuan C.L., Poo A.N.
Title: Application of a modified strain transient dip test in the determination of the internal stresses of PVC under tension
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Kent Ridge, 0511, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Teoh, S.H., Department of Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Kent Ridge, 0511, Singapore; Chuan, C.L., Department of Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Kent Ridge, 0511, Singapore; Poo, A.N., Department of Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Kent Ridge, 0511, Singapore
Abstract: A modified strain transient dip test which involves the design of a load reduction apparatus to perform rapid step unloading and extrapolating to zero extension rate has been developed to measure the internal stresses (recovery and effective stress) of PVC under uniaxial tension. This simple technique appears to be consistent with other internal stress measurement techniques. It was found that the effective stress approaches a limiting value with applied strain and an extrapolated yield point could be defined. The limiting value is a function of the strain rate during the initial load application. The general increase in applied stress (at fixed applied strain) with crosshead speed was attributed to the increase in magnitude of the effective stress. The maximum peak ratio of effective over recovery stress, at each crosshead speed, could indicate that it was the energy-dissipating part of the material that played a dominant role in the early stages of the deformation while the energy-storage part dominated the latter stages. © 1987 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS TESTING; MATERIALS TESTING APPARATUS; STRAIN; EFFECTIVE STRESSES; INTERNAL STRESSES; RECOVERY STRESS; STRAIN TRANSIENT DIP TEST; POLYVINYL CHLORIDE

Title: Self-polarization of protons in storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Niinikoski, T.O., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Rossmanith, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: It has been proposed that stored proton or heavy ion beams can be polarized by spatially separating particles with opposite spin directions, using the Stern-Gerlach effect in alternating quadrupole fields. The growth rate of the vertival betatron amplitude is calculated for beam halves with opposite polarizations rotating in the horizontal plane, at intrinsic spin resonance aγ ± νy = integer. This polarization method would work best with rings having large diameter, low vertical emittance, low vertical betatron tune, and strong superconducting quadrupoles. Provided that suitable strong quadrupoles exist, the method might advantageously replace the present technique for obtaining polarized proton or heavy ion beams, where low energy polarized beams are first generated by a source and then accelerated through numerous depolarizing resonances up to the final energy. Although the proposed self-polarization in the present colliders and storage rings might be impractically slow, it is shown that in a purpose-built machine the vertical splitting rate of the beam might be reasonably fast compared with the beam blowup or decay. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; MAGNETS; POLARIZATION; QUADRUPOLE FIELDS; STERN-GERLACH EFFECT; PROTONS

Title: STATUS OF WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INTEGRATION: CONSIDERATIONS AND PROGRAMS.
Source title: JNMM, Journal of the Institute of Nuclear Materials Management
Affiliations: DOE, Washington, DC, USA, DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hale, H.Jackson, DOE, Washington, DC, USA, DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: One of the major activities within the Department of Energy (DOE) is the development of a waste management system that will provide for proper disposal of spent fuel and high-level radioactive waste. This activity is managed by the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM). The waste management system will consist of handling, packaging, storage, transportation, and disposal elements which must be properly integrated to ensure that its operations are safe, efficient, and timely. Increased confidence in meeting programmatic goals and the provisions of the Nuclear Waste Policy Act as the waste management system is designed, constructed, and operated can best be achieved through emphasis upon systems integration.
Index Keywords: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING; SYSTEM INTEGRATION; WASTE MANAGEMENT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Authors: Lin Jian-Yuan, Shyu Ruey-Jong, Fang Liang-Jyi
Title: STUDY OF THERMAL STRATIFICATION IN STORAGE TANK WITH CHARGING.
Source title: Chung-Kuo Chi Hsueh Kung Ch'eng Hsueh Pao/Journal of the Chinese Society of Mechanical Engineers
Affiliations: Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Jian-Yuan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Shyu, Ruey-Jong, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Fang, Liang-Jyi, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: Thermal energy storage is one of the most efficient methods to store surplus energy for later usage and a stratified storage is generally preferred for such purposes. The efficiency of a stratified storage tank is closely related to the dynamic behavior of thermal stratification inside the tank. In this paper, an experimental system was built to study the thermal stratification in a storage tank during charging. It was found that the system flow rate, the inlet water temperature and the inlet flow pattern are the main factors to control the initial formation and subsequent behavior of stratification. These factors could be examined in terms of dimensionless groups such as the inlet Reynolds number, the Froude number, the tank Reynolds number, the Peclet number and the Richardson number.

Authors: Moulton Sr. K.J., Koritala S., Warner K., Frankel E.N.
Title: Continuous ultrasonic hydrogenation of soybean oil. II. Operating conditions and oil quality
Source title: Journal of the American Oil Chemists' Society
Affiliations: Northern Regional Research Center, ARS/USDA, 1815 N. University St., Peoria, 61604, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moulton Sr., K.J., Northern Regional Research Center, ARS/USDA, 1815 N. University St., Peoria, 61604, IL, United States; Koritala, S., Northern Regional Research Center, ARS/USDA, 1815 N. University St., Peoria, 61604, IL, United States; Warner, K., Northern Regional Research Center, ARS/USDA, 1815 N. University St., Peoria, 61604, IL, United States; Frankel, E.N., Northern Regional Research Center, ARS/USDA, 1815 N. University St., Peoria, 61604, IL, United States
Abstract: In previous work we found that ultrasonic energy greatly enhanced the rate of hydrogenation of soybean oil. We have now investigated parameters of ultrasonic hydrogenation and the quality of the resulting products. Refined and bleached soybean oil was hydrogenated continuously with and without ultrasonic energy at different temperatures, pressures and catalyst concentrations. Flavor and oxidative stability of the oils were compared with a commercially hydrogenated soybean oil. The extent of hydrogenation (ΔIV) was not affected by temperature between 245 and 290 C, but was greater at 106 psig than at 65 psig hydrogen pressure. The ΔIV of hydrogenated oils increased linearly with catalyst concentration from 40 ppm to 150 ppm nickel. At the same catalyst concentration the IV drop was significantly increased when ultrasonic energy was used. By reducing the amount of power supplied to the ultrasonic reactor to 40% of full power, the specific power (watts/ΔIV) was lowered by 60%. Linolenate selectivities and specific isomerization (%trans/ΔIV) remained the same, but linoleate selectivities were lower than for batch hydrogenation under varied operating parameters. Flavor scores were not significantly different, initially or after storage eight days at 60 C, for oils continuously hydrogenated with and without ultrasonic energy. Hydrogenation of soybean oil with ultrasonic energy offers a method to produce good quality products at potentially lower cost than present methods. © 1987 American Oil Chemists' Society.
Index Keywords: CATALYSIS; OILS AND FATS - Stability; ULTRASONIC EFFECTS; OIL QUALITY; OPERATING CONDITIONS; SOYBEAN OIL; ULTRASONIC HYDROGENATION; VEGETABLE OILS

Title: Kerr effect in R2Fe14B and R2Co14B compounds
Source title: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials

Authors with affiliations: Van Engelen, P.P.J., Philips Research Laboratories, 5600 JA Eindhoven, Netherlands; Buschow, K.H.J., Philips Research Laboratories, 5600 JA Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: The polar Kerr effect in several compounds of the R2Fe14B and R2Co14B series (R=rare earth metal) at room temperature was measured in the energy range 0.5-5 eV. It was found that the 3d sublattice magnetization is mainly responsible for the Kerr effect. The potential use of R2Fe14B compounds for erasable magneto-optical recording is briefly discussed. © 1987.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; MAGNETOOPTICAL EFFECTS; ERASABLE MAGNETO-OPTICAL RECORDING; KERR EFFECT; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS

Title: WSHPS MODIFIED WITH RECYCLE FILTRATION SYSTEM AND THERMAL STORAGE.
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Design Build Systems, Encino, CA,, USA, Design Build Systems, Encino, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Milton, Design Build Systems, Encino, CA,, USA, Design Build Systems, Encino, CA, USA
Abstract: One of the ways to compensate for reduced air flow during periods of light space load is to increase the level of filtration. This can be accomplished by adding additional or improved filters at the inlet of a water source heat pump (WSHP), or by taking advantage of a more judicious placement of filter in the bypass duct. This is the heart of the recycle Multiple-Source Hydronic Heat Pump (MSHHP) system. An extensive independent evaluation was completed in 1985 for the MSHHPS, a proprietary heating, ventilating and air conditioning (HVAC) system. The MSHHPS tests were conducted on a unique test bed designed and constructed by National Technical Systems (NTS).

Authors: Song M.Y., Ivanov E., Darriet B., Pezat M., Hagenmuller P.
Title: Hydriding and dehydriding characteristics of mechanically alloyed mixtures Mg-xwt.%Ni (x = 5, 10, 25 and 55)
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cédex, France; Institute of Solid State Chemistry, the Academy of Science, Siberian Division, Derzhavina 18, Novosibirsk 91, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Song, M.Y., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cédex, France; Ivanov, E., Institute of Solid State Chemistry, the Academy of Science, Siberian Division, Derzhavina 18, Novosibirsk 91, Russian Federation; Darriet, B., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cédex, France; Pezat, M., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cédex, France; Hagenmuller, P., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cédex, France
Abstract: The kinetic characteristics of magnesium have been improved either by adding a catalyst or by using magnesium-based alloys. A comparative study of Mg2Ni and a mechanically alloyed mixture Mg-55wt.%Ni has been recently carried out in the laboratory. The mixture presents some interesting properties and the preparation of this material is easier and less energy consuming owing to the absence of heating. However, while the hydrogen capacity (3.2 wt.%) is close to that of Mg2Ni, it is significantly smaller than that of magnesium (7.6 wt.%). Therefore, to improve this characteristic, several compositions of mechanically alloyed mixtures Mg-xwt.%Ni with a lower nickel weight content have been studied (x = 5, 10 and 25). It was shown that the amount of nickel has an important effect on the hydriding-dehydriding kinetics. The decrease of the particle size and the augmentation of the density of defects are because of hydriding-dehydriding cycling. These effects are enhanced by an increase in the nickel content and increase the rate of the hydriding and dehydriding reactions. In contrast, the hydrogen storage capacity diminishes as the amount of nickel increases. For these reasons, Mg-10wt.%Ni and Mg-25wt.%Ni are the most favourable compositions. © 1987.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; HYDROGEN - Absorption; DEHYDRIDING KINETICS; MECHANICALLY ALLOYED MIXTURES; PLANETARY MILL; MAGNESIUM NICKEL ALLOYS

Title: A study of the hydriding kinetics of Mg2Ni
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang, SeoulKorea
Authors with affiliations: Seb Han, J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang, SeoulKorea; Lee, J.-Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang, SeoulKorea
Abstract: A kinetic study of the hydriding reaction of Mg2Ni was performed at a constant pressure. To remove the heat effect three types of reactor were examined. When Mg2Ni was mixed with nickel thermal ballast and was hydrided in the copper tube reactor, the temperature rise was reduced to less than 2 °C. From the rate data obtained using the copper tube reactor, the hydriding kinetics were studied. Although all former researchers have obtained a negative activation energy, a positive activation energy was obtained for the first time in this study. This indicates that the negative activation energy found by previous workers was because of the heat effect. By the removal of the heat effect the absorption rate is increased by about one order of magnitude. At the initial stage of the reaction the rate-controlling step is found to be forced flow, but at the later stage surface reaction is the rate-controlling step. The activation energy at the later stage is about 19.6 kJ (mol H2)-1. © 1987.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; HYDROGEN - Storage; ACTIVATION ENERGY; FORCED FLOW; HYDRIDING KINETICS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS

Authors: Dmitriev V.F., Nikolenko D.M., Popov S.G., Rachek I.A., Toporkov D.K., Tsentalovich E.P., Woitsekhowski B.B., Zelevinsky V.G.
Title: Coincidence experiment on 16O electroexcitation
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dmitriev, V.F., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Nikolenko, D.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Popov, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Rachek, I.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Toporkov, D.K., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Tsentalovich, E.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Woitsekhowski, B.B., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Zelevinsky, V.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The selected results from the total information available on the 16O(e, e′c) reaction are presented. The coincidence experiment is carried out by the superthin internal target (SIT) method in the VEPP-2 storage ring. The physical capacity of the SIT method as well as experimental set up are discussed. The presented experimental data include the yields of different charged secondary particles c, their angular and energy distribution in a broad range of the excitation energy 0 < W < 70 MeV. Different physical channels of the reaction are separated. The decay branching ratios of the excited states of the 16O nucleus are found. The multipolarities of resonances and their form factors are analysed with the use of the (e, e′α0) reaction. An unexpected attenuation of the asymmetry in the forward-backward proton emission at W < 22 MeV has been observed in (e, eṕ0) reaction in contrast to the usually assumed W-dependence of the direct proton knockout cross section. Data on (e, e'p0) reaction are compared with RPA calculations. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Nuclear reactions

Authors: Shintomi T., Otani K., Masuda M., Kwon Y., Cha G.
Title: The experimental study of protection method of large superconducting coil systems
Affiliations: National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba, Japan; College of Engineering Seoul National Laboratory, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Shintomi, T., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba, Japan; Otani, K., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba, Japan; Masuda, M., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Tsukuba, Japan; Kwon, Y., College of Engineering Seoul National Laboratory, Seoul, South Korea; Cha, G., College of Engineering Seoul National Laboratory, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The assessment of commercial use of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) for load leveling of the electric utilities has been carried out in the United States(1) and Japan(2) during past several years. The commercial size of SMES studied in these activities is 5 GWh in capacity and 1 GW in power. The diameter of superconducting coil is 400 - 1500 meters. The comprehensive conclusions derived from the works are that there are no unresolvable technological breakthrough for construction and the existence of its commercial viabilities. However the studies have ignored many technological items related to complete commercialization of such unit. The protection method of superconducting coil is one of them. Needless to say, SMES should be as safe and reliable as power plants. In any case of accidents in SMES, the whole stored energy in such huge system can not be discharged in a short time to protect the superconducting coil. If it should be, the heavy disturbance given to the utility lines by energy dumping or high voltage will be generated on the terminals of the coil. Then an idea of coil protection that the whole stored energy is absorbed by its enthalpy keeping its temperature lower than the permissible level was proposed. (3) However the quick quench of the whole superconducting coil is overwhelming in this case. The local hot spot will pose significant problems. Even if such conditions are fulfilled, internal voltage generation comes to the next difficulties. (4) The present work is to obtain a useful method to overcome such difficulties in a protection of the superconducting coil of SMES. The idea of the protection method is proposed and the technological difficulties in realization of such idea have been investigated by experiments using a 60 kJ superconducting coil. © 1987 IEEE.

Title: 1986 APPLIED SUPERCONDUCTIVITY CONFERENCE.
Authors with affiliations: NBS, Gaithersburg
Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: history of superconductivity; international cooperation in superconductivity; instrumentation and basic physics; accelerators, energy storage, and medical applications; fabrication; digital circuits, devices, and fabrication; large coils; NN and artificial barriers; high-speed analog and digital circuits; high-field magnets and stability; superconducting materials; mixers, superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDS), instruments and basic physics; flux pinning; accelerator and detector magnets; mixers and oscillators; rotating machinery; materials and phenomena; mirror fusion test facility; integrated circuit fabrication; fusion forced flow and stability in magnets; cavities and NbTi; SQUIDs and new phenomena; ultrafine filaments and chevrel. 327 papers are published in the present proceedings.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS; EIREV; FLUX PINNING; INSTRUMENTATION; MEDICAL APPLICATIONS; SQUIDS; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY

Title: CHOPPING BLOCKS TO SIZE.
Affiliations: Blackfriars Engineering Co, Blackfriars Engineering Co
Authors with affiliations: Marsh, Roger, Blackfriars Engineering Co, Blackfriars Engineering Co
Abstract: Granulation is one way of generating rubber particles for continuous compounding. Although granules can be made fairly readily when isolating rubber from either latex or solution, they tend to agglomerate to solid blocks on storage unless high levels of partitioning agents are present. Conventional size-reduction equipment usually requires two operations: guillotining followed by granulating, and is labor intensive and not very energy efficient. Conventional granulators also can create frictional heat, some of which is passed into the rubber and can degrade properties. Through design innovations the Blackfriars bale granulator solves these problems. Processing from a standard 35 kg bale down to granules is achieved in a single, energy-efficient operation. Due to rotor design, frictional heating of material is greatly reduced. Most commonly available natural and synthetic rubbers can be processed from the standard 35 kg bale, with considerable variation in bale size being accommodated. The granule produced can be as small as 5 mm although typical requirements range from 10 to 50 mm. Cutting knives are the only consumable item.
Index Keywords: MIXING; RUBBER MACHINERY; RUBBER PRODUCTS - Manufacture; RUBBER

Title: INTEGRATING DISPERSED STORAGE AND GENERATION INTO POWER SYSTEM CONTROL.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, (Report) EPRI EL
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Because they may be owned by third parties, dispersed storage and generation (DSG) technologies - cogeneration, wind turbines, small hydroelectric units, photovoltaics, fuel cells, and batteries - challenge power system operations. Four research-grade computer programs developed to analyze DSG scheduling rely on long-term forecasts of DSG output yet provide sufficient flexibility to allow for long-term forecasting errors and short-term fluctuations. An augmented unit commitment program schedules generator use, including DSG devices; a requirements evaluation program determines hourly system operating requirements; a dispersed device control program formulates DSG usage strategy, taking into account these hourly operating requirements; and an augmented economic dispatch program adjusts generator output based on available DSG.
Index Keywords: COGENERATION PLANTS; ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Computer Aided Analysis; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER; DISPERSED STORAGE AND GENERATION (DSG); POWER GENERATION OPERATING COSTS; SOLAR-THERMAL ELECTRIC SYSTEMS; WASTE HEAT RECOVERY; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Oppel Fred J., Ghajar Afshin J., Moretti Peter M.
Title: THERMAL STORAGE: KEEP HOT AND COLD FLUIDS FROM BLENDING.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oppel, Fred J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Ghajar, Afshin J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Moretti, Peter M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: A storage tank that keeps hot and cold fluids from blending is described. It uses stratification to separate hot and cold fluids - low-density hot water is floated on top of high-density cool water, creating the advantage of a multiple tank system while using a single tank. The inlet fluid must be placed within the tank with minimal disturbance of the existing fluid in the tank. Its success depends on the design of the inlet. An analytical model by Oklahoma State University researchers helps predict turbulent mixing for a single-tank system. The relationship is based on published experimental data and hydraulic model tests with saline solutions for density stratification, using dye for flow visualization.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Energy Storage; FLUIDS - Mixing; HEATING - Heat Storage; REFRIGERATION - Energy Storage; TANKS - Mathematical Models; ANALYTICAL MODELS; COMPUTER PROGRAMS; STORAGE TANKS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; TURBULENT MIXING; BUILDINGS

Title: Explosion control
Authors with affiliations: Abrahamsen, A.R.; Crowhurst, D.
Abstract: An explosion is a rapid energy release resulting from a physical or chemical reaction. In this article we consider chemical explosions, an ever present risk in the manufacture, storage and transportation of flammable gases, liquids and solids. Such explosions are usually accidental and can be avoided or their effects minimized by prevention and protection techniques. Although the effects are similar, gas/vapor and dust explosions have different characteristics and each of them is discussed separately.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Explosions; COMBUSTION - Detonation; FIRES; GASES - Explosions; DUST EXPLOSION; EXPLOSION CONTROL; EXPLOSION HAZARDS; EXPLOSIONS; chemical industry; disaster control; explosion; theoretical study

Title: FOOD AND PROCESS ENGINEERING.
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sweat, Vincent E., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: The engineering of process operations and food products in agriculture focuses on all points from the initial producer to the final consumer. An on-farm phase of activity deals with the processing and storage of grains, fruits, vegetables, and other products. In contrast, the off-farm processes involve a broad spectrum of commodity modifications that include cotton ginning, feed milling, oil milling, milk processing, baking, meat processing, canning, food manufacturing, and producing chemical stocks from agricultural materials. Opportunities for value enhancements are reflected in many of the primary technical interests that comprise food and process engineering. Some of the key areas of current emphasis are physical properties of materials, grain and feed processing and storage, food processing, special crops processing, transportation and warehousing of agricultural products, fruit and vegetable packinghouse operations, food processing waste management and utilization, farm materials handling, and biomass energy. On-line sensing techniques are presently needed to improve the efficiency of bioreactors and downstream processing equipment. Modified atmosphere packaging offers a substantial extension in the shelf-life of products such as meats, fish, fruits, and vegetables.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING - Computer Applications; BIOCHEMICAL ENGINEERING - Computer Applications; FOOD PRODUCTS - Packaging; FOOD PRODUCTS PLANTS - Control Equipment; PACKING PLANTS - Control Equipment; FRUIT PREPACKAGING; GRAIN PROCESSING; MODIFIED ATMOSPHERE PACKAGING; ON-LINE SENSING TECHNIQUES; VEGETABLES PREPACKAGING; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

Abstract: A thin reliable drift chamber has been constructed to be used near the interaction point of the PEP storage ring in the HRS detector. It is composed of individual drift tubes with aluminized mylar walls. © 1987.

Title: ROOF SNOW-MELTING SYSTEM UTILIZING NATURAL HEAT SOURCES.
Source title: Quarterly Report of RTRI (Railway Technical Research Institute) (Japan)
Affiliations: Machinery Systems Lab, Jpn, Machinery Systems Lab, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Sawase, Kazuhisa, Machinery Systems Lab, Jpn, Machinery Systems Lab, Jpn
Abstract: Field experiments were conducted to collect solar energy and to store seasonal energy in an aquifer using a new system for melting snow on roofs. A total of 158 GJ of solar energy was collected by sprinkling water on a 2500 m**2 roof during 45 days in the summer of 1984. During this period, 10,300 m**3 of water, after being heated to 30 degree C by a boiler, was charged into a well whose depth was 194m. In winter, 38% of the total amount of energy charged into the well was recovered when the water volume which had been charged for 40 days was pumped up. The coefficient of performance was 5. 64 for solar energy collection and 1. 76 for snow-melting in the solar energy collection area.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS - Applications; BUILDINGS - Roofs; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; AQUIFER SEASONAL ENERGY STORAGE; ROOF SNOW-MELTING SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY COLLECTION; SNOW MELTING SYSTEMS

Title: PORTABLE SPECTROMETER FOR CORRELATION EXPERIMENTS.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Gavrilyuk, V.I., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Mel'nikov, O.B., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Patlan, Yu.V., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Tkachuk, I.P., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Dei, Yu.A., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Ofengenden, R.G., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Sidorenko, V.A., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR; Trishin, V.V., Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian, SSR, Kiev, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the Ukrainian SSR, Kiev, USSR
Abstract: Portable apparatus is described that is based on a built-in version of the SM-1300 microcomputer and CAMAC-compatible hardware for correlation experiments in nuclear spectroscopy. The spectrometer is mounted in a single rack; it contains an SM-1300 processor, an SM-5300 magnetic-tape storage device with an SM-5002 controller, a VTA-2000 terminal, and two CAMAC crates. The software, which is prepared in an absolute format on an SM-3 or SM-4 computer, is loaded from magnetic tape by means of a TMOS-2 monitor. The spectrometer also includes an HPGe detector with an efficiency of 40% and a Ge(Li) detector with an efficiency of 17%. The energy resolution of the detectors is approximately 2. 0 kev for a gamma-quantum energy of approximately 1. 3 Mev. The time resolution of the coincidence circuit is 14 nsec for an energy of greater than 50 kev.
Index Keywords: RADIATION DETECTORS; SPECTROSCOPY, NUCLEAR RADIATION; CAMAC; CORRELATION EXPERIMENTS; ENERGY RESOLUTION; SPECTROMETERS, PARTICLE

Title: HIGH ENERGY RECOVERY WITH NEW TYPE BURNER SYSTEM.
Affiliations: North American Manufacturing Co,, Cleveland, OH, USA, North American Manufacturing Co, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reed, Richard J., North American Manufacturing Co,, Cleveland, OH, USA, North American Manufacturing Co, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: An industrial burner with an integral heat reclaiming bed that extracts waste heat from the flue gases of a process furnace, kiln, or heater is described. It is impractical for such a unit to reclaim heat and operate as a burner simultaneously, so it is installed with a twin, and the twins alternate functions every 20 seconds. New materials and configurations have more surface area and heat storage capacity; and modern fast cycling valves permit shortened cycles. The storage unit therefore becomes small enough to be built onto the burner; thus eliminating the material and heat loss problems of hot gas ducts and hot air piping. Energy savings of up to 40-50% are obtained. The evolution of the integral burner-regenerator, some revolutionary possibilities, the advantages of the burner systems and the range of applicability are discussed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; FURNACES - Recuperators; FURNACES, HEATING - Waste Heat Utilization; GLASS FURNACES - Recuperators; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Regenerators; BOILERS; CAR-BOTTOM FURNACE; ENERGY RECOVERY; FORGING FURNACES; KILNS; FUEL BURNERS

Title: Q-SWITCHING: CHOOSING THE BEST ALTERNATIVE.
Affiliations: Lasers & Applications, Torrance,, CA, USA, Lasers & Applications, Torrance, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cunningham, Richard, Lasers & Applications, Torrance,, CA, USA, Lasers & Applications, Torrance, CA, USA
Abstract: Short pulses of high peak power are useful in many applications of lasers-materials processing, range-fining, and double-pulse holography are just a few examples. Some lasers generate such pulses as a matter of course. Others do not. Some of these other lasers can be induced to generate nanosecond pulses with peak powers of hundreds of megawatts by changing (i. e. , switching) the quality factor, Q, of the laser cavity during pumping. The key to Q-switching is energy storage capacity, a combination of optical gain and decay time. The best laser candidates for energy storage are several types of solid-state lasers - Nd:YAG, Nd:glass, and ruby.
Index Keywords: NEODYMIUM AND ALLOYS - Applications; YTTRIUM AND ALLOYS - Applications; GENERIC Q-SWITCH; ROTATING ELEMENT Q-SWITCH; LASERS, SOLID STATE

Title: Polysaccharide reserve material in the acetotrophic methanogen, Methanosarcina thermophila strain TM-1: accumulation and mobilization
Affiliations: Department of Microbiology, Cornell University, Stocking Hall, Ithaca, 14853, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murray, P.A., Department of Microbiology, Cornell University, Stocking Hall, Ithaca, 14853, NY, United States; Zinder, St.H., Department of Microbiology, Cornell University, Stocking Hall, Ithaca, 14853, NY, United States
Abstract: The ability of Methanosarcina thermophila strain TM-1 to store a reserve polysaccharide was studied using both biochemical methods and thin-section electron microscopy. When grown under conditions of excess carbon and energy (either methanol or acetate) and limiting nitrogen, M. thermophila accumulated a polysaccharide which could be hydrolyzed to glucose by the enzyme amyloglucosidase. This polysaccharide reached levels of 20 mg polysaccharide per g protein in nitrogen-limited cells, while cells limited for carbon, as well as cells in the exponential phase of growth, did not accumulate significant amounts of this polysaccharide. Thin-section electron micrographs of M. thermophila showed glycogen-like inclusion granules in nitrogen-limited cells but not in carbon-limited or exponential-phase cells. These granules were stained by a polysaccharide-specific staining procedure, the PATO stain. The polysaccharide was purified from cell extracts, the iodine-polysaccharide complex gave a maximum absorption at between 500 and 510 nm. The polysaccharide was mobilized within 21 h by cells starved for a carbon/energy source. N-Limited (polysaccharide-containing) acetategrown cells could shift to methanogenesis from methanol more quickly than did C-limited acetate-grown cells lacking polysaccharide, and ATP levels remained higher in N-limited cells. The results are consistant with the hypothesis that this polysaccharide can provide carbon and energy for metabolic shifts but other storage compounds, such as polyphosphate, may also play a similar role. © 1987 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Acetotroph; ATP; Glycogen (or polysaccharide); Methanogenesis; N-Limitation
Index Keywords: polysaccharide; methanosarcina thermophila; nonhuman; priority journal

Title: PUMP CONTROLLER ENHANCES INSTALLATIONS.
Authors with affiliations: Wyatt, Cliff
Abstract: The advent of a multiple microprocessor-based control system aimed specifically at pumps changes the pumping perspective. The article reviews some advanced functions of these control systems including manual override control facilities, pump scheduling which can reduce operating costs in water supply systems. A new concept in pump control is presented known as Flobal. This is a method of controlling pumps by using storage volume within a pumping system to balance the inflow. It is applicable to sewage pumping stations and can produce savings of up to 30% in energy consumption, depending on the site characteristics, including savings due to the efficient use of low tariff electricity.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROCOMPUTER; CONTROL EQUIPMENT - Computer Applications; PUMPS, SEWAGE; WELL PUMPS; FLOBAL PUMP CONTROL; MICROPROCESSOR-BASED PUMP CONTROL; PUMP SCHEDULING; PUMPS

Title: Distribution of vitamin A in various organs of rats in relation to the quality and the quantity of dietary proteins
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Vallabhbhai Patel Chest Institute, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, H.S., Department of Biochemistry, Vallabhbhai Patel Chest Institute, University of Delhi, Delhi, India; Misra, U.K., Department of Biochemistry, Vallabhbhai Patel Chest Institute, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Abstract: The influence of the quality and the quantity of dietary proteins on the distribution of a single massive dose of vitamin A in various organs of growing Wistar strain rats has been studied by using casein and bengal gram diets at 20 % and 10 % protein levels. The distribution of [3H]-retinyl acetate in various tissues was also investigated in these dietary conditions. The results show that the hepatic storage of dietary as well as a single massive dose (20,000 I.U.) of vitamin A was profoundly decreased in the rats fed on bengal gram diets as compared to those fed on casein diets. Regardless of hepatic stores, the plasma vitamin A levels were comparable in all the groups. Feeding of low quality of protein reduced the tissue distribution of [3H]-retinyl acetate in control as well as rats given a massive dose of vitamin A. This study suggests that both the poor quality and the inadequate quantity of dietary protein are detrimental influences on the vitamin A status of the growing rats. © 1987 Dr. Dietrich Steinkopff Verlag.
Author Keywords: Dietary protein; Rat; Vitamin A
Index Keywords: radioisotope; retinol; retinol acetate h 3; unclassified drug; animal experiment; blood and hemopoietic system; drug blood level; drug distribution; drug monitoring; drug tissue level; liver; nonhuman; oral drug administration; preliminary communication; protein intake; rat; tissue distribution; Animal; Dietary Proteins; Dose-Response Relationship, Drug; Male; Nutritional Requirements; Protein-Energy Malnutrition; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Tissue Distribution; Vitamin A

Authors: McClure J., Berman D., Schweppe F.
Title: Autonomous management of the space station electric energy system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc., 555 Technology Square, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States; Dept, of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States

Abstract: This paper discusses some of the implementation issues associated with autonomous management of the Space Station electric energy system. In particular, an executive based structure is proposed to handle the scheduling and real time control of the energy system. The major pieces of this structure are a user interface, the executive itself, a scheduler for the loads and storage, and a real time controller. The least developed of the technologies necessary to realize autonomous management is the scheduler and hence is given primary focus. This paper proposes using the simulated annealing algorithm for the solution of the scheduling problem and presents some preliminary results using this algorithm. © 1987, SPIE.

Abstract: Moiré, holography, speckle and thermographie (SPATE) stress analysis are used to analyze a variety of engineering problems involving man-made (fiber-reinforced) and natural (wood, paperboard) composites, metals and rubber. The photomechanical techniques are combinedcombined with computer-vision (digital-imaging) concepts. Some attention is devoted to hybridhybrid methodsmethods for processing and differentiating recorded optical data. Applications involve involveboth small and large large(including nonlinear) strains, and hostile environments. Authors: Baker G.J., Brocklehurst B., Holton I.R.
Title: Ion-recombination luminescence of alkane solutions excited by 15-150 ev photons
Affiliations: Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baker, G.J., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Brocklehurst, B., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Holton, I.R., Daresbury Laboratory, SERC, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Squalane solutions of para-terphenyl have been excited by radiation from the synchrotron storage ring at Daresbury. Fluorescence pulse shapes have been measured using time-resolved single-photon counting. The relative intensity of the "tail" (200-300 ns) increases with increasing photon energy, while its magnetic field enhancement decreases due to cross recombination in groups of ion pairs (spurs): the field effect is positive, in striking contrast to the negative effect observed in crystalline anthracene by Martin, Klein, Voltz and Hahn. © 1987.

Abstract: We have searched for neutrinoless tau decays into three charged particles as evidence for lepton-flavour or lepton-number violation. The data were collected using the ARGUS detector at the DORIS II storage ring. Tau pairs were produced by e+e- annhilation at centre-of-mass energies near 10 GeV. No evidence for lepton-number or lepton-flavour violation was observed, but the upper limits obtained are an order of magnitude lower than those previously published. © 1987.

Title: ECONOMIC SIGNIFICANCE OF INNOVATION.

Abstract: The article reviews ten technologies which will shape the future and lead to new innovations. These are: robotics and sensor technology; computer-aided design and manufacturing; genetic engineering; large-scale biotechnology; microprocessors; telecommunications; recycling processes; energy storage technology; laminated materials and surface treatment-technology.

Authors: Ohyabu N., DeGrassie J.S., Evans T.E.
Title: Model for divertor function in H-mode onset and proposal for H-mode operation with the island divertor
Affiliations: GA Technologies Inc., PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ohyabu, N., GA Technologies Inc., PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; DeGrassie, J.S., GA Technologies Inc., PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Evans, T.E., GA Technologies Inc., PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Abstract: We propose that the main fucntion of the divertor configuration in the H-mode mechnanism is temporary storage of the effluxing particles for a time longer than the edge energy confinement time. This temporary storage enables the edge temperature to transiently increase above a threshold temperature necessary for the H-mode transition. This model qualitatively explains the superior H-mode regime in mechanically closed poloidal divertors and opens the possibility that the same result could be achieved using the resonant island divertor. © 1987.
Author Keywords: H-mode; helical divertor; particle recycling; particle transport in divertors; plasma plugging

Title: Report on the workshop: thermal characterization of non-stoichilometric oxides and similar compounds and their application in energy storage and conversion
Affiliations: Rise National Laboratory, 4000 Denmark, Roskilde, Denmark; Nuclear Research Institute, Řež, 25068, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Toft Sørensen, O., Rise National Laboratory, 4000 Denmark, Roskilde, Denmark; Jakes, D., Nuclear Research Institute, Řež, 25068, Czech Republic
Abstract: The workshop moderators (Dr. O. Toft Sørensen and Dr. D. Jakeš) were assisted by a panel scientific board consisting of Prof. V.S. Darshane (India) and Prof. P.D. Ownby (U.S.A.). After the introduction on non-stoichiometric compounds and their application in the energy field, prepared by the Chairman, a discussion of the question "How useful is a workshop on materials science dealing with a specific class of materials for a thermal analysis conference?" took place. The report of the workshop covers presentations and discussion on three main topics and concluding remarks. © 1987.

Title: KOBELCO PCI SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In accordance with a worldwide change in the energy supply environment, low cost coal is being used as a substitute for fuel oil and coke and a pulverized coal injection system (PCI) is employed in many plants. Kobe Steel has devised the KOBELCO PCI system by applying technologies for coal storage, delivery, drying, pulverization, gas transportation, and combustion as well as technology introduced from Petrocarb Inc. This paper reports on the operational performance of Kobe No. 3 blast furnace that uses the system.
Index Keywords: KOBELCO PCI SYSTEM; PULVERIZED COAL INJECTION (PCI); BLAST FURNACE PRACTICE

Authors: Thompson Murray A., Varda Ann Park, de Clute Gary, Kriesel Ken
Title: DESIGN AND USE OF A 2 TERABYTE OPTICAL ARCHIVAL STORE.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, Murray A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Varda, Ann Park, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; de Clute, Gary, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Kriesel, Ken, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: A two-terabyte optical archival store (OAS) has been built and is currently in use with a number of VAX computers. It is intended to hold very large sets of experimental data for a minimum cost, with automatic operation and rapid random access to files. The system has been designed for easy use by scientists. The OAS can be used from a VAX cluster or via an extensive Ethernet and has shown the strong reliability needed for holding valuable data for long periods of time.

Affiliations: Stanford Univ, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, CA, USA

Abstract: Current design and fabrication techniques of hybrid devices as applied to the Stanford Linear Collider Large Detector (SLD) are discussed. Methods of developing layouts ranging from hand-cut templates to advanced designs utilizing CAD tools with special hybrid design software were applied. Physical and electrical design rules for good yield and performance are discussed. Fabrication and assembly of a variety of SLD hybrids using different construction methods are described.

Title: RAM BASED CMOS HISTOGRAMMER INTEGRATED CIRCUIT.
Affiliations: Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab,, Oxon, Engl, Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Oxon, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Slorach, F., Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab,, Oxon, Engl, Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Oxon, Engl; Alsford, J.R., Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab,, Oxon, Engl, Chilton, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Oxon, Engl
Abstract: A histogramming integrated circuit has been designed with 256 24-bit cells. The pipelined RAM-based architecture has been designed to give histogram capture rates of at least 8 MHz. The chip is capable of histogramming an entire 512 multiplied by 512 image with an 8-bit gray level in real time and is fully cascadable for increased histogram resolution or capacity. The RAM is accessable for random read/write operations through the 24-bit data and 8-bit address busses. Additional features include global thresholding, sequential read/clear, and a simple self-test on the RAM. The chip was designed using an integrated design system with a ramcell compiler and is being fabricated in a 2- mu m CMOS technology.

Authors: Baumbaugh A.E., Knickerbocker K.L., Baumbaugh B., Ruchti R.
Title: OPERATIONAL EXPERIENCE WITH A HIGH SPEED VIDEO DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEM IN FERMILAB EXPERIMENT E-687.
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Baumbaugh, A.E., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Knickerbocker, K.L., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Baumbaugh, B., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA; Ruchti, R., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia,, IL, USA, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, IL, USA
Abstract: Operation of a high-speed, triggerable, video data acquisition system (VDAS) including a hardware data compactor and a 16-Mb first-in-first-out (FIFO) buffer memory is discussed. Active target imaging techniques for high-energy physics are described, and preliminary experimental data are reported. The hardware architecture for the imaging system and experiment is discussed as well as other applications for the imaging system. Data rates for the compactor are over 30 Mb/s, and the FIFO has been run at 100 Mb/s. The system can be operated at standard video rates or at any rate up to 30 million pixels/s.

Title: Probationary Period Successfully Completed: Quality-Oriented, Non-Harmful to the Environment and Economical. [BEWAEHRUNGSPROBE BESTANDEN: QUALITAETSORIENTIERT, UMWELTBEWUSST UND PREISWERT.]
Source title: Betonwerk und Fertigteil-Technik/Concrete Precasting Plant and Technology
Authors with affiliations: Kroemer, Rupert
Abstract: The massive absorber heating system passed its probationary period also thanks to the favorable cost-performance ratio. Concrete element help save energy and are beneficial to the environment. The massive absorber system consists of an energy recipient and an energy discharge system. Outdoor and terrestrial heat is absorbed as environmental energy, conducted into storage and passed on, as required, via heat pump and control system, into the respective heating system or for use in hot water preparation. Concrete is eminently suited for absorption, in no small measure because of its good thermal conduction and thermal storage capacity.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE - Heat Transfer; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS - Performance; HEAT SINKS - Concrete Construction; ENERGY COLLECTION PROCESS; ENERGY-ACCUMULATING ABSORBERS; ENERGY-CARRYING LIQUID; MASSIVE ABSORBER ELEMENTS; HEATING

Title: ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS.
Affiliations: Univ of Maine, ME, USA, Univ of Maine, ME, USA
Authors with affiliations: Criner, George K., Univ of Maine, ME, USA, Univ of Maine, ME, USA
Abstract: Biogas from anaerobic digestion of organic residue is utilized in various ways: substitute for natural gas or liquid propane which may require scrubbing and compressing; burned directly in a boiler; or to fuel an internal combustion engine which powers an electrical generator. Farms which have existing adequate manure utilization, such as storage and field application, would normally only consider an anaerobic digestion system based on its energy producing benefits relative to all costs of the system. This paper presents an economic feasibility analysis of a particular on-farm anaerobic digestion system and assesses the impact on feasibility of varying the oil and electricity prices.
Index Keywords: BIOGAS - Production; CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT; ECONOMICS - Analysis; ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS; ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Goulon J., Elleaume P., Raoux D.
Title: Special multipole wiggler design producing circularly polarized synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Chimie Theorique, Universite de Nancy I, Unité Associée au CNRS No 510, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre les Nancy, France; CEA/IRDI/DESICP/Departement de Physico-Chimie, Cen/SACLAY-91191-Tif-sur-Yvette, France; L.U.R.E. Laboratoire Propre, CNRS No 008, CEA, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Goulon, J., Laboratoire de Chimie Theorique, Universite de Nancy I, Unité Associée au CNRS No 510, B.P. 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre les Nancy, France, L.U.R.E. Laboratoire Propre, CNRS No 008, CEA, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Elleaume, P., CEA/IRDI/DESICP/Departement de Physico-Chimie, Cen/SACLAY-91191-Tif-sur-Yvette, France, L.U.R.E. Laboratoire Propre, CNRS No 008, CEA, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Raoux, D., L.U.R.E. Laboratoire Propre, CNRS No 008, CEA, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: A planar multipole wiggler device which can produce both linearly and circularly polarized synchrotron radiation is proposed. Standard wiggler designs have a quasi sinusoidal magnetic field distribution resulting in a - more or less - perfect cancellation of right/left handed circularly polarized photons emitted from successive poles. We show here that one can easily generate a periodic but asymmetric magnetic field distribution having a field integral still equal to zero in order to maintain a straight overall direction of the particle trajectory. Due to the asymmetry of the field distribution in our device, the synchrotron radiation along the wiggler axis can keep a high degree of circular polarization above or below the particle trajectory plane. As compared to standard bending magnets, the proposed device can afford a significant increase of the available flux of circularly polarized light which is typically proportional to the number of magnetic periods. As compared now to the two crossed field undulator system, our wiggler device definitively offers a much broader spectral range of emission and far more flexibility regarding energy scanned experiments which might prove to be very difficult with a two crossed field undulator device. The wiggler described here should also accomodate any future or already existing machine with common lattices while a two crossed field undulator system is only to work on very low emittance storage rings. © 1987.
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC FIELDS; POLARIZATION; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; WIGGLER; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS LET UTILITIES LEVEL LOADS.
Affiliations: EPRI, EPRI
Authors with affiliations: York, Thomas, EPRI, EPRI
Abstract: There soon will be increasing amounts of base-load-generation electricity that cannot be used up during off-peak periods. This situation already exists in the U. S. in the Midwest and the Southeast, and it can be expected to spread to other regions as additional base-load plants are activated. Researchers at the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) believe that emerging energy-storage technologies can be deployed rapidly in small sizes, from 20 to 200 MW/installation. Utilities, then, will be able to use their off-peak base-load capacity to replace the oil and gas generation now in use to fill in the peaks in the demand cycle. In this way, the utilities can operate their systems efficienty and still save nonrenewable petroleum-based fuels. Some topics discussed are the following: new energy-storage capacity; pumped hydro and compressed-air storage; battery storage technologies; and other technologies such as superconducting magnetic-energy storage and flywheels.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES; FLYWHEELS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Shpak I.E., Shilo V.I., Dmitrienko A.O., Stolyarenko L.I.
Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL BEHAVIOR OF INTERCALATION COMPOUNDS Me//xCoO//2 IN NONAQUEOUS ELECTROLYTES.
Authors with affiliations: Shpak, I.E.; Shilo, V.I.; Dmitrienko, A.O.; Stolyarenko, L.I.
Abstract: Because of its high values of specific capacity (293 Ah/kg) and open-circuit voltage when paired with a lithium electrode (about 4. 5 v), a new material, alkali-metal cobaltate is of great interest in the development of high-energy storage batteries. Since the chemical substance selected is an intercalation compound, the overpotential and rate of the reaction at the electrode probably will be determined by the size of the intercalating cation, studied where the alkali-metal atom in the compound, the alkali-metal ion in the electrolyte and the solvent type were the variables. Based on the experimental evidence, it is concluded that among the alkali-metal cobaltates, the most promising is lithium cobaltate in lithium salt solutions with solvents similar to tetrahydrofuran in their physicochemical properties.

Authors: Fuller N.J., Stirling D.M., Dunnett S., Reynolds G.P., Ashwell M.
Title: Decreased brown adipose tissue thermogenic activity following a reduction in brain serotonin by intraventricular p-chlorophenylalanine
Affiliations: MRC Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downhams Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge, CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, CB2 2EB, United Kingdom; Department of Pathology, University of Nottingham Medical School, Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham, NG7 2UH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fuller, N.J., MRC Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downhams Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge, CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Stirling, D.M., MRC Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downhams Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge, CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom; Dunnett, S., Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, CB2 2EB, United Kingdom; Reynolds, G.P., Department of Pathology, University of Nottingham Medical School, Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham, NG7 2UH, United Kingdom; Ashwell, M., MRC Dunn Nutrition Unit, Downhams Lane, Milton Road, Cambridge, CB4 1XJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The effects of reducing brain serotonin (5-HT) levels by means of intracerebral-ventricular injections of the tryptophan antagonist p-chlorophenylalanine (PCPA) were investigated in male rats. Six days after the operation, PCPA-treated rats, either fed ad libitum or pair-fed to the food intake of control rats, showed decreased thermogenic activity and capacity in their interscapular brown adipose tissue (BAT) and also increased fat storage in their white adipose tissue (WAT). These results indicate that serotonergic synapses might play a regulatory role in the sympathetic control of BAT thermogenesis and in the rate of WAT deposition (by an as yet unidentified mechanism), in addition to their well established role in controlling food intake. © 1987 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: brown adipose tissue; p-chlorophenylalanine; serotonin; thermogenesis

Title: Materials and Optics for Solar Energy Conversion and Advanced Lightning Technology
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 59 papers. The topics discussed include: error detection and correction systems for optical disk: issues of media defect distribution, defect growth, error management, and disk longevity; optical recording in multilayer Bi/Se thin films; dynamic laser marking experiments on an organic optical storage medium; measuring method of optical disk mechanical characteristics; characteristics of the mass-produced optical disks; molding compounds for optical disk substrates; measurement and modeling of optical disk noise; tracking servo for small size optical disk system; seek techniques for the Optotech 5984 optical disk drive; a new servo method with eccentricity correction circuit; and development of high performance head positioner for an optical disk storage system.

Title: Optical Recording in Multilayer Bi/Se Thin Films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Celanese Research Company, 86 Morris Avenue Summit, New Jeresy, 07901, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suh, S.Y., Celanese Research Company, 86 Morris Avenue Summit, New Jeresy, 07901, United States
Abstract: Multi-layered Bi/Se/Bi/Se… films were prepared by thermal evaporation. Optical writing experiments on these films showed an exceptionally high sensitivity for the following reason: the absorbed light heats the film until it begins to melt, at which point an exothermic reaction between the Bi and the Se releases more energy. The bits written on the multi-layered Bi/Se films are very clean and comparable to those of the best known optical recording media. Intrin-sic S/N, corrected for the substrate defects on these films, is the same or slightly better than that of 300A pure Te thin film on glass substrate. It should also be noted that an earlier study by AT&T Bell Laboratories showed an exceptionally good environmental stability of the Bi/Se bilayers. In fact, some Bi/Se bilayer films made more than 10 years ago still show little signs of degradation. For write° pulse energies below that required to form a hole, the write beam caused the reflectivity of the film to increase. The reflectivity increase effect could be used to write format information, while hole formation could then be used to record user data. Salient features of the optical recording characteristics of these media, as well as the material preparation technique, will be presented. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Film preparation; Multilayer films; Optical multilayers; Optical recording; Reflection; Substrates; Thermal evaporation; Thin films; Bell Laboratories; Environmental stability; Glass substrates; Material preparation; Optical recording media; Recording characteristics; Salient features; Substrate defects; Optical data storage

Authors: Ishigaki M., Tokushuku N., Ohishi T., Kodera Y., Ohta Y., Fukui Y.
Title: New erasable optical media using sb-se-bi alloy film
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishigaki, M., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan; Tokushuku, N., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan; Ohishi, T., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan; Kodera, Y., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan; Ohta, Y., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan; Fukui, Y., Consumer Products Research Center, Hitachi Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, Yokohama, 244, Japan
Abstract: Antimony-Selenium alloy film with Bismuth has good characteristics for erasable optical disk media. The mechanism of the reversible change is phase transition between amorphous and crystalline states. It is confirmed by small-angle X-ray diffraction analysis that Se-Bi component plays an important role in this reversible change. The minimum erase time is 1 JJS. The film has high transition temperature and activation energy of crystallization. It has a long life span of written spots in amorphous state. Recording film of Sb-Se-Bi alloy is formed on 20 cm 0 PMMA substrate and is covered with protective films. The disk samples are written and erased at a speed of 1 800 rpm, using an optical head with two diode laser beams. Carrier-to-Noise ratio is more than 55 dB at 5 MHz, 30 KHz bandwidth. The newly developed disk realized high performance and durability for the use of an erasable video file system. © 1987 SPIE.
