Authors: Terao M., Nishida T., Miyauchi Y., Horigome S., Kaku T., Ohta N.
Title: In-se based phase change reversible optical recording film
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Terao, M., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan; Nishida, T., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan; Miyauchi, Y., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan; Horigome, S., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan; Kaku, T., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan; Ohta, N., Central Research Laboratory Hitachi Ltd., 1 Chome 280 Higashi Koigakubo, Kokubunji, Tokyo, 185, Japan
Abstract: In-Se based amorphous-crystalline phase change recording films are analysed in terms of structure, optical properties, crystallization speed, and crystallization activation energy. Crystallization by a laser beam is possible by a 0.2µs pulse. Crystallization temperature(heating rate 5°/C min.) measured by using a differential scanning calorimeter is 135°C and crystallization activation energy is calculated to be 2.6eV. The life of the amorphous state is estimated6 to be longer than 10 years at 60°C. The phase change cycles can continue even after 10 cycles in stationary state experiments for test samples. In addition, possibility of single beam overwrite (rewriting without prior erasing) is verified by using a 1.6 µm-diameter round laser beam spot on a 5-inch-diameter disk rotating at 2400rpm. The laser beam power is modulated at 1.77MHz and 0.88MHz between an amorphizing power level and a crystallizing power level. The amorphizing power level is 14mW and the crystallizing power level is 7mW. The experimental results show that the overwrite the same as magnetic disk is possible by using the In-Se based recording film. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Differential scanning calorimetry; Digital storage; Indium compounds; Laser beams; Optical data storage; Optical properties; Selenium compounds; Amorphous state; Crystalline phase; Crystallization activation energy; Crystallization temperature; Differential scanning calorimeters; Laser beam power; Magnetic disk; Stationary state; Optical films

Title: Large scale interconnections using dynamic gratings
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institut d'Optique, Centre Universitaire d'Orsay, B.P. 43, ORSAY Cedex, 91406, France
Authors with affiliations: Pauliat, G., Institut d'Optique, Centre Universitaire d'Orsay, B.P. 43, ORSAY Cedex, 91406, France; Roosen, G., Institut d'Optique, Centre Universitaire d'Orsay, B.P. 43, ORSAY Cedex, 91406, France
Abstract: Optics is attractive for interconnects because the possibility of crossing without any interaction multiple light beams. A crossbar network can be achieved using holographic elements which permit to connect independently all inputs and all outputs. The incorporation of dynamic holographic materials is enticing as this will render the interconnection changeable. However, it is necessary to find first a passive method permitting to achieve beam deflection and secondly a photosensitive material of high optical quality requiring low power levels to optically induce the refractive index changes. We first describe an optical method allowing to produce very large deflections of light beams thus enabling to randomly address any spot on a plane. Such a technique appears applicable to both interconnections of VLSI chips and random access of optical memories. Our scheme for realizing dynamic optical interconnects is based on Bragg diffraction of the beam to steer by a dynamic phase grating which spacing and orientation are changeable in real time. This is achieved in a passive way by acting on the optical frequency of the control beams used to record the dynamic grating. Deflection angles of 15° have been experimentally demonstrated for a 27 nm shift in the control wavelength. For a larger wavelength scanning (50 nm), 28° deflections are anticipated while maintaining the Bragg condition satisfied. We then discuss some issues related to photosensitive materials able to dynamically record the optically induced refractive index change. The specific example of Bi12 Si 020 or Bi12 Ge 020 photorefractive crystals is presented. Indeed these materials are very attractive as they require low driving energy and exhibit a memory effect. This latter property permits to achieve numerous iterations between computing cells before reconfiguration of the interconnect network. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Deflection (structures); Diffraction gratings; Holography; Light; Light sensitive materials; Optical data processing; Photorefractive crystals; Photosensitivity; Random access storage; Refractive index; Semiconductor quantum wells; Holographic elements; Interconnect networks; Large-scale interconnections; Multiple light beams; Photosensitive materials; Refractive index changes; Very large deflection; Wavelength scanning; Integrated circuit interconnects

Authors: Pracht P., Minotti P., Dahan M.
Title: Synthesis and balancing of cam-modulated linkages
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Design Engineering Technical Conference
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Mecanique Appliquee-Mecanismes et Robotique, Faculte des Sciences et des Techniques, Besancon, France
Authors with affiliations: Pracht, P., Laboratoire de Mecanique Appliquee-Mecanismes et Robotique, Faculte des Sciences et des Techniques, Besancon, France; Minotti, P., Laboratoire de Mecanique Appliquee-Mecanismes et Robotique, Faculte des Sciences et des Techniques, Besancon, France; Dahan, M., Laboratoire de Mecanique Appliquee-Mecanismes et Robotique, Faculte des Sciences et des Techniques, Besancon, France
Abstract: Linkages are inherently light, inexpensive, strong, adaptable to high speeds and have little friction. Moreover the class of functions suitable for linkage representation is large. For all these reasons numerous recent works deal with the problem of design mechanisms for robotic applications, but very often in terms of components such as gripper, transmission, balancing. We investigate a new application for linkages, using them to design industrial manipulator. The selected mechanism for this application is a four bar linkage with an adjustable lengh for exact path generation. This adjustment is performed by a track or cam which is substituted to a bar. By this mean, we define a cam-modulated linkage which possess superior accuracy potential and is capable of accomodating of industrial design restrictions. Such a kinematic chain is free from structural error for path generation and the presence of the track introduces the flexibility and versality in the usefull four bar chain. The synthesis technique of cam modulated linkage utilizes loop closure equations, envelop theory to find the centerline and the profile of the track. These techniques provide a systematic approach to the design of mechanism for path generation when extreme accuracy is required. In order to complete an contribution, we take in consideration the static balancing of the synthesized manipulator. To achieve static mass balancing we use the potential energy storage capabilities of linear springs, and integrated it with the non-linear motion of mechanism to provide an exact value of the desired counter loading functions. Examples are worked to demonstrate applications of these procedures and to illustrate the industrial potential of spring balancing and cam-modulated linkage. © 1987 American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Balancing; Computer aided design; Energy storage; Industrial manipulators; Kinematics; Manipulators; Potential energy; Product design; Robotics; Springs (components); Design mechanisms; Design restriction; Four-bar linkage; Industrial potentials; Non-linear motions; Robotic applications; Structural errors; Synthesis techniques; Cams

Title: Mechanical refrigeration.
Authors with affiliations: Rydzewski, A.J.; Rice, W.W.
Abstract: The mechanics of refrigeration are given together with properties and applications of refrigerants. Energy cycles are derived. Components and design of compression systems and absorption systems are described. Methods of applying refrigeration, refrigerant piping, cold storage, and the use of refrigeration in the chemical industries are discussed.

Title: New opportunities for pumped storage projects.
Authors with affiliations: Nichols, R.O.; Young, R.F.
Abstract: A variety of design, economic, power supply and environmental factors are combining which will bring a resurgence to the interest in developing pumped storage projects in the early 1990's in certain regions of the country. This paper describes the likely suitability of pumped storage facilities in the 50 MW to 300 MW range to meet the capacity requirements of utilities seeking capacity additions in this range. Smaller pumped storage projects are expected to become more common due to: the expected availability beyond the year 2000 of low cost, off peak pumping energy from the nuclear and coal fired capacity developed in the 1980's; reduced concern about net energy requirements of pumped storage projects due to perceived lower world oil prices and lower dam costs for sites suitable for roller compacted concrete design. A case study of a 120 MW pumped storage project in California scheduled for completion in the mid 1990's is presented.

Title: Volvo's secret; a variety of abilities.
Abstract: The Volvo group is active in a number of industrial sectors apart from motor manufacturing. Its subsidiaries include Volvo Hydraulics which manufacturers at Trollhattan, Sweden and in Berlin. It has patented the spherical piston in all the major industrial countries. Volvo Hydraulics production activities are in two main areas - high performance hydraulic systems such as pumps and the production of complete ready to use installations. The current range of pumps includes the F1, F11, V11, V1 and V30. Volvo Hydraulics has also developed the Cumulo system of transmission and energy storage which cuts fuel consumption by around 30%. (A.P.)

Authors: Bammert K., Johanning J., Lange H.
Title: TRANSIENT BEHAVIOR OF SOLAR HEATED RADIATION RECEIVERS FOR SMALL GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS.
Affiliations: Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger, Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Bammert, K., Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger, Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger; Johanning, J., Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger, Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger; Lange, H., Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger, Univ of Hannover, Hanover, West Ger
Abstract: Solar heating of gas turbine plants is moving back to the focus of current research. The mainly unsteady operation of solar turbine power plants can only be predicted with sufficient accuracy if the transient behavior of the solar radiation receiver is known. Therefore the transient behavior of cavity receivers of different designs is investigated. The mathematical model used to simulate heat transfer and energy storage is illustrated. Computed results for two receivers with different inner lining are compared and evaluated concerning their use in practice.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Mathematical Models; Heat transfer; Solar power plants; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR RECEIVERS; Gas turbine power plants

Title: SPACE STATION ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS AND DESIGN.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Teren, Fred, NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: This paper gives an overview of the conceptual definition and design of the Space Station electric power system (EPS). Responsibilities for design and development of the EPS are defined. The EPS requirements are listed and discussed, including average and peak power requirements, contingency requirements, and fault tolerance. The most significant Phase B trade study results are summarized, and the design selections and rationale are given. Finally, the power management and distribution system architecture is presented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Space Applications; Energy storage; PROPULSION - Space Applications; SPACE POWER; SPACE STATION; Satellites

Title: Vapor canister heater for evaporative emissions systems
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Inc., Attleboro, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bishop, R.P., Texas Instruments Inc., Attleboro, MA, United States; Berg, P.G., Texas Instruments Inc., Attleboro, MA, United States
Abstract: Automotive evaporative emissions systems use a charcoal canister to store evaporative hydrocarbon emissions. These stored vapors are later purged and burned during engine operation. Under certain conditions the engine cannot completely purge the canister of the stored fuel vapors, which results in a decreased vapor storage capacity in the canister. A self-regulating PTC (Positive Temperature Coefficient) heater has been developed to warm the purge air as it enters the canister, in order to provide thermal energy for increased release of the vapors from charcoal sites. This paper describes the construction and operation of the vapor canister heater as it relates to improved evaporative emission system performance. © Copyright 1987 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Charcoal; Engines; Fuel storage; Charcoal canister; Engine operations; Evaporative emission; Fuel vapor; Hydrocarbon emission; Purge airs; Storage capacity; Positive temperature coefficient

Authors: Nakazawa N., Kono Y., Takao E., Takeda N.
Title: Development of a braking energy regeneration system for city buses
Affiliations: Truck and Bus Engineering Center, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakazawa, N., Truck and Bus Engineering Center, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Japan; Kono, Y., Truck and Bus Engineering Center, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Japan; Takao, E., Truck and Bus Engineering Center, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Japan; Takeda, N., Truck and Bus Engineering Center, Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Japan
Abstract: In order to improve the fuel economy of city buses, which start and stop frequently, a system has been developed that stores braking energy in a hydraulic accumulator and uses the energy when the vehicle is in its start and acceleration modes. Through microcomputer control of the entire power train and energy storage system, the following goals are achieved: 1.By applying currently available transmission technologies to the conventional power train system, all component functions are controlled so as to minimize the losses over the driving cycle. 2.By applying a regenerative braking system, as much vehicle kinetic energy as possible is recovered and stored, and, 3.The energy stored is used so as to achieve maximum overall efficiency. A test vehicle functioning in city conditions achieved a 30% fuel economy gain. Other advantages of this system are that brake wear is greatly reduced and clutch life is significantly extended since the vehicle can start in motion using only hydraulic energy. Copyright © 1987 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Buses; Hydraulic accumulators; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Regenerative braking; Trucks; Braking energy; Conventional power; Energy storage systems; Hydraulic energy; Microcomputer control; Overall efficiency; Regenerative braking systems; Transmission technologies; Fuel economy

Title: Static Feed Electrolyzer technology advancement for Space application
Affiliations: Life Systems Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Fortunato, F.A., Life Systems Inc.; Burke, K.A., Life Systems Inc.
Abstract: The Static Feed Electrolyzer (SFE) is being developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) through Life Systems, Inc. (Life Systems) as part of NASA's effort to mature water electrolysis technology for application in the Space Station Environmental Control/Life Support System (ECLSS), Propulsion and Reboost System, Extravehicular Activity (EVA) and Electric Power System (EPS). The water electrolysis process generates metabolic oxygen (O2) for the crew cabin, EVA backpacks and air lock, and provides reactants for carbon dioxide (CO2) removal, CO2 reduction, propulsion/reboost systems and fuel cell electric power generation. The use within all of these applications will make water electrolysis a fundamental utilitylike technology for the Space Station. The most recent developments of the SFE technology and their applicability to Space Station systems along with the influences of Space Station design on the development of water electrolysis technology are discussed. The NASA has selected to use water electrolysis aboard the Space Station to provide the O2 and hydrogen, (H2) for use in the ECLSS and the Propulsion System. Other applications of electrolysis technology in space are energy storage using a Regenerative Fuel Cell System (RFCS) and O2 bottle recharging for EVA application. This paper discusses the design issues of electrolyzers for these applications and their relevance to the overall optimization of the electrolyzer. Also presented in this paper are results of recent developments of Life Systems' alkaline SFE. © 1987 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Bottles; Carbon dioxide; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Electrolysis; Electrolytic cells; Environmental management; Environmental technology; Fuel storage; Manned space flight; NASA; Propulsion; Regenerative fuel cells; Space stations; Electric power systems (EPS); Environmental control; Extravehicular activity; Propulsion system; Space station design; Space station systems; Technology advancement; Water electrolysis; Electric power system control

Title: WATER FOR THE HUMAN ENVIRONMENT, VOLUME 1: CONGRESS PAPERS, VOLUME 2: COUNTRY REPORTS, VOLUME 3: TECHNICAL SESSIONS, VOLUME 4: SPECIAL SESSIONS.
Abstract: One-hundred-sixty-nine papers by various authors are presented. The topics discussed are: Global environment, water resources, energy, dams, warming, Arctic oil, coal mining and water, Ganges River Basin, water law, hydraulic grids, irrigation, pollution, international coordination, hydrogeology, interbasin transfer, integrated water resources development, ground water, floods, aquifers, measurements, sewage, storage, water resources in developing nations, desalination, hydrological programs, information systems, wastewater reclamation, thermal pollution, cooling, systems analysis, hydrographs, watersheds, limnology, oxygen transfer, and water quality. Selected papers are indexed separately.
Index Keywords: Ecology; Water resources

Title: An air independent stirling energy system for autonomous ROVs
Source title: Proceedings of the 1987 5th International Symposium on Unmanned Untethered Submersible Technology, UUST 1987
Affiliations: United Stirling, AB Box 856, Malmo, 20180, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Nilsson, H., United Stirling, AB Box 856, Malmo, 20180, Sweden; Bratt, C., United Stirling, AB Box 856, Malmo, 20180, Sweden
Abstract: Stirling engines in underwater applications allow for considerably increased endurance in submerged position, also combined with vibrationless and silent operation of the vehicle. These qualities are most important from military point of view. Recently the Royal Swedish Navy has awarded United Stirling AB a cost sharing contract, also sponsored by SIND (The Swedish National Industrial Board), on development of an air independent propulsion system for an untethered autonomous remotely operated vehicle (AROV). SUTEC, a Swedish company specialized on development and manufacture of ROVs is, under a similar contract with the Royal Swedish Navy, responsible for development of the AROV, using the Stirling machinery. The Stirling energy system will be based on a well proven, reliable Stirling engine concept, adapted for underwater application, using high pressure oxygen combustion with a petroleum derivative, e.g. white Spirit, as a fuel. Initially a design study of the Stirling powered module, including fuel and oxygen storages, will be made for final choice of basic engine concept and type of oxygen supply system (LOX or GOX). © 1987 Marine Systems Engineering Lab.
Index Keywords: Automobile manufacture; Cost effectiveness; Propulsion; Remotely operated vehicles; Stirling engines; Submersibles; Vibrations (mechanical); Air-independent propulsion systems; Cost sharing contracts; Design studies; High pressure; Oxygen combustion; Oxygen storage; Stirling energy systems; Underwater application; Oxygen supply

Authors: Lin R.C., Strickland W.T., Kuo C.H.
Title: Reservoir simulation helps understand the combustion process in a heavy oil reservoir
Authors with affiliations: Lin, R.C.; Strickland, W.T.; Kuo, C.H.
Abstract: A mathematical model has been developed to simulate the flow of oil water and gas and heal: transport in a heavy oil reservoir during a combustion process. The model accounts for conduction and convection in the reservoir and instantaneous heat generation by combustion at a moving front, as well as, heat losses to cap and base rocks by conduction. In the model, the energy equation is first solved by the implicit technique to obtain temperature distribution following the burning of a block at a given injection rate. For pressure and saturation calculations. small time steps are used to obtain stable solutions of the non-linear, partial differential equations for the flow of gas, water and oil using the IMPES method. The model has been applied to study the injection and production performance of a combustion pilot in operation for about ten years in a heavy oil reservoir in the Lloydminster area. Predicated well pressures and oil production rates agree with the reported field data. The model shows that gas drive is one of the main oil recovery mechanisms associated with the fire flood process in a relatively thin heavy oil reservoir. Based on the oil recovery mechanism identified, the model was employed to investigate the effects of oxygen content, air and water rates, and fuel concentration on oil production in a given reservoir. The model also was used to study the effects of formation thickness and fluids saturations on the expected fire flood performance. From these sensitivity analyses, the optimal air injection rate and oxygen content can be determined for a given reservoir. © 1987 CURRAN-CONFERENCE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Crude oil; Digital storage; Floods; Oil well flooding; Oxygen; Petroleum reservoir engineering; Petroleum reservoirs; Petroleum transportation; Reservoirs (water); Sensitivity analysis; Combustion pro-cess; Conduction and convections; Heavy oil reservoirs; Oil recovery mechanisms; Oil-production rates; Production performance; Reservoir simulation; Thin heavy oil reservoirs; Heavy oil production

Title: Modeling acoustic waves with paraxial extrapolators
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Graves, R.W., California Institute of Technology, United States; Clayton, R.W., California Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Modelling by paraxial extrapolators is applicable to wave propagation problems in which most of the energy is travelling within a restricted angular cone about a principle axis of the problem. Frequency domain finite-difference solutions are readily generated by using this technique. The direct forward scattered waves are modelled with a single pass of the extrapolator operator in the paraxial direction for each frequency. For heterogeneous models, transmission and reflection coefficients are determined at structural boundaries within the media. The first-order back scattered energy can then be modelled by extrapolation (in the opposite direction) of the reflected field determined on the first pass. Higher order multiple scattering can be included by sweeping through the model with more passes. The chief advantages of the paraxial approach are 1) active storage is reduced by one dimension as compared to solutions that solve upgoing and downgoing waves simultaneously, 2) the decomposition in frequency allows the technique to be implemented on highly-parallel machines such the hypercube, 3) attenuation can be modelled as an arbitrary function of frequency, and 4) only a small number of frequencies are needed to produce movie-like time slices. By using this method a wide range of seismological problems can be addressed, including strong motion analysis of waves in three-dimensional basins, the modelling of VSP reflection data, and the analysis of whole earth problems such as scattering at the coremantle boundary or the effect of tectonic boundaries on long-period wave propagation. © 1996-2018 Society of Exploration Geophysicists. All Rights Reserved.
Index Keywords: Data flow analysis; Digital storage; Frequency domain analysis; Wave propagation; Arbitrary functions; Core-mantle boundary; Finite-difference solution; Heterogeneous models; Paraxial directions; Tectonic boundaries; Transmission and reflection coefficient; Wave propagation problems; Forward scattering

Authors: Freese J.M., Butler P.C., Cowan R.A.
Title: Results of a wind turbine/sealed lead-acid battery experiment.
Authors with affiliations: Freese, J.M.; Butler, P.C.; Cowan, R.A.
Abstract: A coupled, stand alone wind turbine generator/battery storage system has been evaluated by Sandia National Laboratories, U.S.A. The goal was to evaluate advanced batteries in solar applications. This paper describes the system components, instrumentation, operation and some of the results obtained during this evaluation. This system evaluation demonstrates that advanced lead acid batteries can be successfully used with wind turbines to reliably satisfy an actual energy demand.

Title: Traditional system of complex use of natural energy in vernacular houses.
Authors with affiliations: Kimura, K.; Tanabe, S.
Abstract: Discusses how traditional types of architecture, as exemplified a volcanic stone house by Niijima Island; a straw roofed house (Yamanashi Prefecture) and a heavy storage house (Kawagoe), exploit characteristics of indigenous building materials and design methods to achieve comfort conditions comparable to modern houses with air conditioning. Presents results of measurements of temperatures, (inside/outside), humidity and air velocity. Describes evaluation of the interior environment using thermal sensation indices, noting that the preferred air movement increases as temperature increases. Discusses the results of applying store to a modern house, the effect of evaporative cooling, and the use of earth sheltering.
Index Keywords: natural ventilation

Title: Jocassee Pumped Storage Station Project Design.
Authors with affiliations: McKay, H.G.
Abstract: The Jocassee Pumped Storage Project is the first pumped storage hydroelectric project designed and built by Duke Power Company. The project itself is part of the overall Duke Power Keowee Toxaway Project and is operated as part of that multipurpose energy project. The project involves a large rockfill dam (more specifically described and discussed in another paper in this publication), two large reinforced concrete intake structure located over 91 meters (300 ft) above the powerhouse, connecting concrete lined tunnels, and a four unit powerhouse with a total generating capacity of 610 MW. This paper give a general description of the project including project general arrangement drawings.

Title: Remote area power system development - RAPSYD.
Authors with affiliations: Bhattacharyya, S.
Abstract: For India's 800 million, electric power exceeding 100 GW has to be added by 2000 AD. Even then tens of thousands of small rural communities (SRCs) will remain outside grids because of remoteness and small demands. This paper discusses standalone systems for these villages for lighting, water pumping, and evening activities. Small wind energy converters (WECs) operable at low cut in speeds may provide the power. Energy storage and delivery systems are required. This aspect is discussed using devices such as flywheel, battery, photovoltaic, diesel, fuel cell, etc. The analysis indicates that wind/flywheel or wind/flywheel/battery has certain advantages and should provide answers to the problems of these small 100 to 1000 family SRCs with a very small daily demand of 2 kWh/family.

Title: Magnetic bearings. January 1970-December 1987 (Citations from the NTIS database).
Abstract: This bibliography contains citations concerning the application, design, and properties of magnetic bearings. Dynamic behaviour, including stiffness and cross axis stabilities, is presented. Applications in energy storage systems, wheels, reactors, and space systems are discussed.

Title: Parametric modelling of the effectiveness of energy storage applied to regional wind park energy production.
Authors with affiliations: Quinlan, P.J.; Scheffler, R.L.
Abstract: Hourly time series wind energy data from the Tehachapi Region, San Gorgonio, and combined wind regions were utilized by a computer model, SCESTOR, to simulate dedicated battery storage. SCESTOR calculates the increase in energy sales based on storage configurations as defined by: Relative Power Capacity, the relative power capacity of the storage system compared with the rated power capacity of the wind parks in the region; Converter Efficiency, the percent round trip throughput efficiency of the battery plus energy converter; Relative Converter Capacity, the relative size of the energy converter to the size of the storage system; and present avoided cost prices.

Authors: Celik I., Rodi W., Stamou A.I.
Title: Prediction of hydrodynamic characteristics of rectangular settling tanks.
Issue: (eds.), Washington, U.S.A., Hemisphere Publishing Corp., 1987, p.641-651. (ISBN 3-540-17284-X)
Authors with affiliations: Celik, I.; Rodi, W.; Stamou, A.I.
Abstract: A mathematical model for predicting the velocity field and the transient dye concentration distribution in rectangular settling tanks is presented and verified by comparing the predictions with measurements. In this model, an ADI (alternating direction implicit) type finite volume method is used to solve the partial differential equations governing the steady 2D turbulent flow in the vertical plane of rectangular settling tanks. The turbulent stresses are calculated with the aid of the eddy viscosity concept, the distribution of eddy viscosity, being determined via the k-EPSILON turbulence model which relates to the turbulent kinetic energy k and the rate of its dissipation, EPSILON, and determines these quantities from modelled transport equations. An additional differential equation governing the unsteady transport of dye in a steady flow field is solved to calculate the dye concentration distribution and to produce flow through curves which are used in evaluating the hydraulic efficiency of settling tanks.
Index Keywords: storage vessels

Title: The effects of turbulence spectra and load profiles on the operation of a modelled 60 kW wind/Diesel system.
Authors with affiliations: Bullock, A.M.; Musgrove, P.J.
Abstract: The majority of high frequency (1 or 2 second period) wind data available in the British Isles has been measured on Orkney and Shetland, and the turbulence spectra show a greater low frequency content than the widely used Kaimal Spectrum. This has important consequences for grid independent wind/Diesel systems, and the turbulence spectrum, as well as the turbulence intensity, has a significant effect on the fuel saving and the number of Diesel stops and starts, and hence on the optimization of the energy buffer (e.g. hydraulic accumulator), used in conjunction with the wind/Diesel system in order to minimize Diesel starts and maximize fuel savings. Yet another significant factor that affects the system optimization is the magnitude and spectrum of the load profile. A detailed model of a 60 kW wind/Diesel system has been developed which incorporates second by second wind speed and load fluctuations as well as diurnal variations in these parameters. The second by second wind data is synthesized for a range of turbulence intensities and spectra, and is consistent with a typical Weibull distribution of hourly averaged wind speeds.
Index Keywords: hybrid energy storage

Title: Built-in accumulator boosts hydraulic hammer productivity.
Abstract: The Hy-Ram impact hammer is an attachment for mobile equipment. The hammer has a unique combination of internal valving and a bladder type hydropneumatic accumulator which are both integral parts of the hammer body. The high impact energy delivered by the hammer comes from the 165 psi nitrogen gas charge and from the high pressure fluid supplied by the hydraulic pump and stored in the accumulator. Details are given of this arrangement. Instantaneous flow requirements and fluid storage are achieved through the bladder type accumulator which is easy to repair and maintain.

Title: Proceedings: geotechnology workshop on compressed-air energy storage in porous media sites.
Authors with affiliations: Mehta, B.R.
Abstract: A workshop on the use of underground storage reservoirs as the sites of compressed air energy storage plants is reported. These plants use low cost off-peak energy from base load power stations to compress air into underground storage reservoirs. At peak demand periods, power is generated by burning fuel with air from the reservoir to drive a turbogenerator. A plant of this type in Huntorf, Federal Republic of Germany, has been generating 290 MW using two salt caverns for storage for nine years. The workshop was intended to provide an understanding of the characteristics of aquifers and depleted gas reservoirs and to explore their potential for this application. (A)

Title: Field measurements of dissolved air at Ulset hydro electric plant in Norway.
Authors with affiliations: Berg, A.; Kjorholt, H.
Abstract: The interaction between water, air and rock in an underground water balanced compressed air energy storage power plant may have consequences for the stability of the plant. To measure this interaction an unlined air cushion surge chamber at a Norwegian power plant was used. Such a surge chamber is anticipated to closely resemble the behaviour compressed air energy storage plants mined in hard rock. The measurements taken inside the chamber consisted of the following: analysis of the water under the air cushion for dissolved gases, chemical composition and density differences due to differences in gas (air) saturation; analysis of the chemical composition of the surge chamber air and recording of temperature both in air and water phase. In addition, water level in the surge chamber and reservoir, plant operation and air leakage from the chamber were recorded. This report describes the surge chamber, the instrumentation, the measuring methods used and the results.

Authors: Davies T.S., Jefferson C.M., Mayer R.M., Somerville W.M.
Title: The application of energy storage in wind energy conversion.
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S.; Jefferson, C.M.; Mayer, R.M.; Somerville, W.M.
Abstract: The incorporation of dynamic energy storage into a wind energy system enhances wind energy conversion at marginal wind speeds, and in wind/Diesel system it improves frequency stability and load stability on the Diesel set. In grid connected schemes it provides a means of reducing the export power fluctuation. Synchronous connected kinetic energy storage systems are explained; these are adequate for stand alone wind turbine generators of up to 60 kW. Asynchronous connection would be required for 60-200 kW range for frequency stabilization in weak grid systems and for power stabilization in grid connected schemes. (A.J.)

Title: Small-scale hydropower as an energy supply option.
Authors with affiliations: Goldsmith, K.
Abstract: Small scale hydroelectric power is considered from the following points of view: planning; capacity determination; economic and social issues; environmental impact. The planning effort involves a preliminary survey and data gathering campaign; a pre-feasibility study; a feasibility study. It is suggested that there can be pressure to minimize initial investment expenditure, thus reducing the benefits that can be derived from them. Capacity determination involves the foward projection of past hydrological experience, the matching of flow duration and load duration as far as this is feasible. Plant sizes are discussed. Parameters used for economic appraisal are discussed. Construction work, water storage impact, water abstraction on river flow are discussed with reference to the environmental compact.

Title: Thermal-cycling tests for a compressed-air energy storage recuperator.
Abstract: A prototype model of a compressed air energy storage recuperator was built with seven tube to bulb sheet joints. The model was subjected to thermal cycles, representative of those expected in a CAES recuperator. Experimental stress concentration values were determined. Observations of failures indicated that stress concentration values ranging from 1.4 to 2.6 are applicable depending on their location on the model. Thermal fatigue was likely to occur earlier on outer tube welds than on inner tube welds. An acceptable thermal fatigue life of 7500 cycles for tube to tube sheet, welds on the recuperator was concluded from the studies. (A.J.)

Title: Compressed-air energy storage: an analysis of fuel flexibility and plant components.
Abstract: Documented here is the successful operation of the first compressed air energy storage (CAES) plant. A design for a commercial fuel flexible combustor system is presented. Suggestions are made for improvements to various plant components. (R.I.H.)

Title: Residential Heating, Ventilating, and Air Conditioning Research Workshop.
Authors with affiliations: Joyner, P.
Abstract: Summarizes a conference report of the Residential, Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning Workshop held on July 22-23, 1986 in Palo Alto, California. Research topics identified include improved efficiency, lower costs, integrated systems/energy storage, smart controls, load management and air quality. The workshop studied all technologies, in particular, heat pumps. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: conference reports

Authors: Ferrero G.L., Grassi G., Williams H.E.
Title: Biomass energy: from harvesting to storage. Proceedings of a workshop, Marino (Rome), November 1986
Source title: Biomass energy: from harvesting to storage. Proceedings of a workshop, Marino (Rome), November 1986
Affiliations: CEC, Direction Generale "Energie', Rue de la Loi 200, B-1049 Bruxelles, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Ferrero, G.L., CEC, Direction Generale "Energie', Rue de la Loi 200, B-1049 Bruxelles, Belgium; Grassi, G., CEC, Direction Generale "Energie', Rue de la Loi 200, B-1049 Bruxelles, Belgium; Williams, H.E., CEC, Direction Generale "Energie', Rue de la Loi 200, B-1049 Bruxelles, Belgium
Abstract: The workshop was held for those active in the sector under EEC and national programmes to assess the state of the art of technology and methodology of harvesting, to evaluate results, and discuss problems. Collection is one of the basic technical and economic components of the processes of converting biomass into energy. Much progress has been made in R & D and industrial applications for the collection of all types of biomass resources which ranges from orchard prunings to tree-felling waste, from straw to seaweed, from specific energy crops to arable-farming residues. The many remaining problems and their solution will influence the final use of these sources. Problems include bringing out timber waste from isolated forests, making the collection of algae and aquatic plants financially worthwhile, the lack of special machines, economic and social costs for proper forest management policy. The 36 papers are arranged in session themes: forestry; energy crops; crop by-products, straw, and pruning; economic evaluations, public incentives. -after Editors
Index Keywords: biomass energy; energy resources; harvesting methodology; storage technology

Authors: Beyer H.G., Gabler H., Gerdes G.J., Heinemann D., Luther J., Schumacher-Grohn J., Steinberger-Willms R.
Title: Wind/solar hybrid electricity generation for stand alone systems with battery and hydrogen storage.
Authors with affiliations: Beyer, H.G.; Gabler, H.; Gerdes, G.J.; Heinemann, D.; Luther, J.; Schumacher-Grohn, J.; Steinberger-Willms, R.
Abstract: Simulation calculations were performed for systems with renewable energy production. These systems included wind/solar converters, battery and hydrogen storage. The system model is characterized by the following features: they are stand alone electric systems; three primary energy sources are combined (wind, solar and a conventional fuelled motor); renewable energy source covers a high proportion of consumption (70-100%); two different storage systems (lead acid accumulator, hydrogen system). Technical data of modelled subsystems are tabulated. Storage capacities of 1 day already show high renewable fractions. (A.J.)

Title: On the groundwater pumping by using energy from the wind.
Authors with affiliations: Veltri, P.
Abstract: A brief review of problems involving wind energy conversion systems is presented. The prospects of pumping groundwater for irrigation purposes near Reggio Calabria, Italy using wind energy is discussed. The wind speed data from the local meteorological station for twenty eight years was analyzed and duration curves were examined. The rated wind speed of the wind energy conversion system was selected using the criterion of economic optimization. The problems of energy storage for a constant irrigation water supply is discussed. (from author's abstract)

Authors: Ariman T., Hamada M., Singhal A.C., Haroun M.A., Cakmak A.S.
Title: Recent advances in lifeline earthquake engineering
Source title: Recent advances in lifeline earthquake engineering
Affiliations: College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ariman, T., College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA; Hamada, M., College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA; Singhal, A.C., College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA; Haroun, M.A., College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA; Cakmak, A.S., College of Eng & Applied Sci, Univ of Tulsa, Tulsa, OK, USA
Abstract: Lifeline earthquake engineering is the application of all relevant knowledge to provide economically feasible engineering safeguards for critical infrastructure systems such as energy, transportation, water, power, communications, etc. The book contains 16 papers, comprising most of those presented at the 3rd international conference on soil dynamics and earthquake engineering, June 1987, at Princeton University. Recent developments in analytical/experimental investigations and field observations for buried pipelines, underground structures and storage tanks were presented by specialists from the USA, Japan and China. Specific topics addressed were: 1) pipeline response to large ground deformations; 2) experiments, field observations and analysis of earthquake behaviour of buried pipelines; 3) earthquake behaviour and safety of buried structures and liquid storage tanks. Some papers are abstracted separately. -after Editors
Index Keywords: earthquake engineering; ground deformations; liquid storage tanks; pipelines; soil dynamics

Title: Integrating dispersed storage and generation into power system control.
Abstract: Dispersed storage and generation technologies DSG can provide electricity from unconventional sources such as wind power, solar energy, small hydroelectric units, fuel cells etc. Current and future requirements for integrating these DSG technologies into system operations were surveyed using computer programs. Four reserach programs were developed to analyze DSG scheduling. Results showed that long term changes in DSG output are practicable to a certain extent but short term changes are totally unpredictable. (A.J.)

Title: Integrating dispersed storage and generation into power system control.
Abstract: Dispersed storage and generation technologies DSG can provide electricity from unconventional sources such as wind power, solar energy, small hydroelectric units, fuel cells etc. Current and future requirements for integrating these DSG technologies into system operations were surveyed using computer programs. Four reserach programs were developed to analyze DSG scheduling. Results showed that long term changes in DSG output are practicable to a certain extent but short term changes are totally unpredictable. (A.J.)

Title: Thermal flow in porous media.
Affiliations: Dept. Mathematics, National Inst. Scientific & Techncal Creation, Bucharest, Romania.
Authors with affiliations: Ene, H.I., Dept. Mathematics, National Inst. Scientific & Techncal Creation, Bucharest, Romania.; Polisevski, D., Dept. Mathematics, National Inst. Scientific & Techncal Creation, Bucharest, Romania.
Abstract: Thermal flow in porous media is important in a wide range of areas, including oil recovery, geothermal development, the chemical and nuclear industries, civil engineering energy storage and energy conversion. This monograph uses a systematic, rigorous and unified treatment to provide a general understanding of the phenomena involved. There are two major fields of application: natural convection and underground combustion. Both are discussed in detail. Various examples with exact or numerical solutions in the case of bounded or unbounded domains are presented, accompanied by extensive comment.-from Authors
Index Keywords: chemical; civil engineering; energy storage; geothermal development; nuclear industries; oil recovery; porous media; thermal flow

Title: THE ROLE OF VACUOLES
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, University of Dundee, Dundee, DD1 4HN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: RAVEN, J.A., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Dundee, Dundee, DD1 4HN, United Kingdom
Abstract: Many plant cells are characterized by the presence of a vacuole (hypertrophied lysosome) occupying a large fraction of the protoplast. The possible benefits of the presence of the vacuole can be divided into those which are related merely to the increased volume of the protoplast, independent of the nature of the vacuolar contents, and those which depend on the nature of the solutes in the vacuole. Increasing the volume of the protoplast per unit volume of cytoplasm increases the total surface area of the cell per unit of cytoplasmic volume. This area amplification has potential benefits in terms of resource acquisition under resource‐limiting conditions. At a given chromophore concentration in the cytoplasm, dispersal of a given volume of cytoplasm at the periphery of a vacuole increases the efficiency of photon absorption of an ‘average’ chromophore molecule relative to a comparable non‐vacuolate cell, unless the chromophore concentration is low arid/or the cell is very small (no package effect) or the total chromophore per unit projected area is such that almost all light is absorbed, regardless of vacuolation. The area amplification also increases the plasmalemma area per unit cytoplasmic volume through which‘lipid solution’, or mediated transport of chemical resources can occur on a cytoplasmic volume basis and decreases the impediment to resource transfer from a bulk aqueous phase to the cell surface, again on a cytoplasmic volume basis. The increased capacity for uptake of chemical resources from low external concentrations due to vacuolation can increase overall solute acquisition, except in cells of picoplankton size, although other remedies for restricted capacity for chemical nutrient uptake per unit cytoplasmic volume are possible (e.g. evaginations of the cell surface). In addition to these potential benefits of vacuolation which are essentially independent of the contents of the vacuole, and which relate almost entirely to the rate at which resources can be acquired, there are potentially beneficial effects of vacuolation (dependent on specific vacuolar contents) on the acquisition of resources, and on the storage, manipulation and protection of resources which have already been acquired. Effects of vacuolation which involve essentially irreversible deposition (within the life of the cell) of specific solutes in the vacuole embrace the acquisition, manipulation and protection of resources, but not, of course, true (‘reversible’) storage. Deposition‐related increases in resource (at least phosphate and iron) acquisition capacity can, in attached rhizophytic macrophytes, result from rhizosphere acidification involving accumulation of cation salts of organic acid anions in the vacuole. Related to resource acquisition (CO2, H2O) in terrestrial halophytes is the disposal of ‘excess’ salt entering the roots by deposition in hypertrophied vacuoles. Resource manipulation involving deposition of salts of organic acid anions occurs as a means of OH− disposal in the reduction of NO3− in the shoot, a process which can increase the photon and water use efficiency of N assimilation. Resource protection in plants often involves the deposition of antibiophage solutes in the vacuoles. The possible osmotic problems engendered by cation organate deposition can be ameliorated by production of insoluble calcium oxalate. Reversible accumulation of solutes in vacuoles is involved in CAM, which can increase the water (and nitrogen?) use efficiency of carbon assimilation, and may be involved in the storage of fermentation products during temporary anoxia. The storage of soluble compounds in vacuoles during CAM cannot, apparently, be replaced by that of insoluble materia; there is some scope for storage of insoluble waxes during fermentation. Storage of energy and carbon (as reduced carbon), phosphorus and nitrogen often involves soluble low‐molecular weight materials in large vacuoles, but can also, in all three cases, involve polymers in smaller vacuoles or in other parts of the cytoplasm. Other potentially beneficial effects of vacuolation include a (mechanistically unexplained) stimulation of the velocity of cytoplasmic streaming in large vacuolate cells and a role in buffering cytoplasmic volume from rapid, large changes in cells (e.g. stomata) undergoing large changes in protoplast volume. Against these putative benefits must be set, in terms of natural selection, the costs of vacuolation. These costs include the costs (energy, solutes) of producing, and those (energy) of maintaining the vacuoles, and the costs (energy, carbon) of synthesizing the extra wall material. The additional costs (all on a unit cytoplasm basis) can be substantial relative to benefits in terms of additional energy and carbon acquisition resulting from vacuolation. Additional costs may be incurred in relation to the energetics of large cells maintaining a constant turgor pressure in environments (e.g. estuaries) with frequent and large changes in external osmolarity, and as colonization opportunities lost if vacuolation reduces desiccation tolerance. The analysis conducted in the paper suggests that the specific growth rate of a cell of a given cytoplasmic volume under optimal growth conditions is decreased if it is vacuolated. Furthermore, the resource acquisition rate of the cell under conditions of low resource availability may be enhanced by vacuolation, even when the resource costs of vacuolation are taken into consideration, although this is not invariably so. Nevertheless, although the cost‐benefit analysis of resource acquisition may not always favour vacuolation, the presence of vacuoles may still lead to an increase in inclusive fitness when benefits in relation to the storage, manipulation and protection of resources are also considered. At all events, most phototrophs are vacuolate, the major exception being many planktophytes (where the lack of vacuoles may be rationalized, at least for smaller cells) and essentially all microalga‐invertebrate synthesis. Title: Conceptualization and development of an efficient tropical mushroom house
Affiliations: College of Agricultural Sciences, University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez Campus, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, United States; U.S.D.A. Tropical Agriculture Research Station, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, 00708, United States

Tropical Agriculture Research Station, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, 00708, United States
Abstract: Mignucci, J. S., Torres-López, R. and Hepperly, P. R., 1986. Conceptualization and development of an efficient tropical mushroom house. Specifications based on our research results were developed for a demonstration and research facilities for the production of tropical mushrooms. The architect and engineers of the University of Puerto Rico developed building plans based on our specifications. Structures were developed using a modular concept that will permit storage utilization of agricultural waste products, low energy input, and efficient production schemes. Assembly line production was one of the principal thrust in the design. This was attained by developing a building composed of five units, in which every one represents a production stage. These are l) Receiving, 2) Fermentation, 3) Pasteurization and Inoculation, 4) Vegetative Growth, and 5) Fructification. The structure was built on cement blocks with tin roof and utilizes roof height and ventilation system (fans and windows) to regular ambient temperature and light requirements. A steam generator is the only equipment in the system and pipes in rooms 3, 4 and 5 permit steaming of rooms, substrates and materials. At this time, production schemes previously developed at the laboratory and greenhouse, are being tested and fine tuned in this newly constructed mushroom house at the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez Campus. © 1987, Elsevier B.V.

Title: Cytology of High Alpine Plants II. Microbody activity in leaves of Ranunculus glacialis L.
Affiliations: Botanisches Institut der Universitat zu Köln, Köln 41, W., Gyrhofstr. 15 5000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Laitz, C., Botanisches Institut der Universitat zu Köln, Köln 41, W., Gyrhofstr. 15 5000, Germany
Abstract: Electron microscopy has shown that microbodies are ubiquitous organelles in leaf tissues of higher plants (Gerhardt 1978, Tolbert and Essner 1981). These organelles are sometimes found close to mitochondria and chloroplasts. Such associations could frequently be observed in sections of leaves from the high alpine plant Ranunculus glacialis (Lutz and Moser 1977). This species shows interesting photosynthetic properties: net photosynthesis (CO2-fixation) needs more than 80 klux for saturation; CO2-uptake is possible between — 7°C and +38°C (Moser et al. 1977). In general, close associations of microbodies to mitochondria and chloroplasts indicate the presence of an active photorespiratory metabolism. Microbodies in the leaves of C3-plants are numerous and show high catalase activity as demonstrated with the DAB-test. This property shows high levels of photorespiration (Frederick and Newcomb 1969). The oxygen uptake in light might be useful for formation of amino acids like serine and glycine; however, metabolic consequences of this “respiration” are mostly discussed as a waste of energy (Heber and Krause 1980, Ogren 1984). Plants, growing under unfavorable environmental conditions, instead should have developed pathways to use energy as efficiently as possible. An avoidance of photorespiratory activity similar to C4-plants was never found in high alpine species, which have to grow at relatively low temperatures. Furthermore, the C4-metabolism is not established in Ranunculales (Monson et al. 1984). Other activities of leaf peroxisomes have been described in the last years: in contrast to earlier results, they should be intensively involved in the β-oxidation of fatty acids (Gerhardt 1983). Recently, Stabenau et al. (1984) described the β-oxidation of fatty acids in algal microbodies, too. Lipid degradation as organelle function would make sense in view of the short growing season of plants from high altitudes, if they contain lipids as an energy storage form for use during their fast development in the alpine summer. Cytochemical characterization of the microbodies in leaves of Ranunculus glacialis should give information about their eventual photorespiratory activity. The occurrence of lipid bodies is also traced in favour of possible lipid oxidation activities. These studies should be the basis for subsequent physiological investigations: studies of photorespiration, and the biochemistry of lipid mobilization and cytochemical analyses have been never performed in high alpine plants. However, understanding of plant life in extreme environments requires more information from cytology and biochemistry. © 1987, Japan Mendel Society, International Society of Cytology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Ambrose J.H., Chow L.C., Beam J.E.
Title: Transient heat pipe response and rewetting behavior
Source title: Journal of Thermophysics and Heat Transfer
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, University ofKentucky, Lexington, KY, United States; Power Technology Branch, Air Force Aero Propulsion Laboratory, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH, United States

Abstract: This paper describes the results of an investigation of pulsed heat pipe startup. Two types of pulsed startup of a copper/water heat pipe are examined. In the first, the mean temperature of the transport section is nearly constant with time. In the second, the entire heat pipe is increasing in temperature, so thermal energy storage in the heat pipe is significant. Dryout of the wick at the evaporator is found to occur only for heat transport rates greater than the capillary limit. A transient heat pipe model is used to explain the dryout and rewetting of the wick in the second type of pulsed startup. © 1987 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc.. All rights reserved.

Title: Analysis, experiments and post test evaluation of LiF-MgF2-KF/inconel 617 as a phase chance energy storage system
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ  85287, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moraga, N.O., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ  85287, United States; Jacobson, D.L., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ  85287, United States
Abstract: Heat transfer and thermochemical compatibility characteristics of a L i F-MgF2-KF/I nconel 617 thermal energy storage (TES) system were investigated. The inward cylindrical problem with an exponential-in-time heat flux boundary condition was solved using perturbation methods. Experiments were performed under vacuum (pressure - 3-3 × 10-3 Pa) to determine melting temperature, (Ts = 705°C), solidification temperature (Ts = 667oC), the time for liquid-solid phase transformation and the enthalpy of solidification (h = 790 J/g). Metallographic and chemical analyses were performed at different cross sections of the container and the salt after extensive cyclic testing. The analytical results obtained for the unsteady temperature at the external surface and for the solidification time were found to be in good agreement with the experimental data obtained. Only minor signs of Intragranular corrosion along the internal surface of the Inconel 617 container were found after the LiF-MgF2-KF salt underwent 7706 cycles completing a total testing time of 16,312 hours. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. Inc., 1987.

Title: M/PCM composite thermal storage materials
Affiliations: Energy Science Laboratories Inc, P O Box 85608, San Diego, CA  92138-5608, United States
Authors with affiliations: Knowles, T.R., Energy Science Laboratories Inc, P O Box 85608, San Diego, CA  92138-5608, United States; Webb, G.W., Energy Science Laboratories Inc, P O Box 85608, San Diego, CA  92138-5608, United States
Abstract: Composite materials for use in thermal energy storage devices are described and shown to possess power capabilities far surpassing those of their component materials oyer a restricted temperature range. A material with high thermal conductivity (k) is dispersed in a material with a high volumetric heat capacity (c) such that the mixture behaves thermally like a homogeneous material with both high k and highc. Thermal performance is proportional to the material’s kc product, which is high for these composites. The high-k component is typically a metal such as aluminum, and the high-c component is typically an organic phase-change material whose latent heat provides a large effective heat capacity near the melting point. Dispersion requirements to assure homogeneous behavior are specified. A thermal model is developed based on the volume-average effective thermal parameters. Composite proportions corresponding to maximum power and maximum specific power are identified. Experimental data on the thermal performance of a set of composite test cells are presented, and comparison with numerical simulations show good agreement. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. 1987.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Dispersions; Heat storage; Phase change materials; Specific heat; Component materials; High thermal conductivity; Homogeneous materials; Power capability; Temperature range; Thermal parameters; Thermal Performance; Volumetric heat capacity; Thermal conductivity

Title: A transient analysis of phase change energy storage system for solar dynamic power
Affiliations: Space Division General Electric Company, P.O. Box 8555, Philadelphia, PA  19101, United States
Authors with affiliations: Darooka, D.K., Space Division General Electric Company, P.O. Box 8555, Philadelphia, PA  19101, United States
Abstract: The Phase Change Energy Storage System constitutes a key element of the Solar Dynamic Power System now being considered for the Space Station. The stored energy is provided to the Energy Conversion System during the non-illuminated portion of the orbit. This cyclic nature of the application requires understanding of the transient behavior of the Energy Storage System. A one dimensional thermal model was developed that uses a fixed-grid, implicit finite-difference formulation to handle the transient interface condition between the liquid and solid phases. This model was applied to a conceptual design of solar thermal receiver based on radiative coupling between the thermal energy storage container and the heat exchanger for the working fluid. Transient results indicate that the proposed design concept can meet the Space Station requirements. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1987.

Authors: O’Dell M.P., Sheffield J.W., Wen C., Dillingham E.
Title: An analytical and experimental examination of a latent thermal management system
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of MIssouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO  65401-0249, United States; Air Force Wright Aeronautical Laboratories, Wright-Patterson AFBOH  45433, United States
Authors with affiliations: O’Dell, M.P., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of MIssouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO  65401-0249, United States; Sheffield, J.W., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of MIssouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO  65401-0249, United States; Wen, C., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of MIssouri-Rolla, Rolla, MO  65401-0249, United States; Dillingham, E., Air Force Wright Aeronautical Laboratories, Wright-Patterson AFBOH  45433, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an analytical and experimental examination of a latent thermal energy storage system as part of an ongoing investigation of the thermal aspects of future spacecraft thermal management systems. Experiments have been performed in a shell-and-tuhe heat exchanger in which eight horizontal tubes were filled with P116 (a Sun wax). An improved mathematical model, based on a one-dimensional analysis, for the freezing process was used to aid in the design of the experimental apparatus. The improved technique employs a two time level, multi-step implicit method with backward time differencing and one-sided space differencing. Comparisons of previous experimental data with predictions of the time dependent, axial distribution of the temperature of the heat transfer fluid were used to verify the technique. The solid-liquid phase front motion behavior was photographically explored by using a video cassette recording system. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc 1987.

Authors: Deininger W.D., Vondra R.J., Schafer W.J.
Title: Spacecraft and mission design for the space nuclear power source reference mission
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States; Arlington, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deininger, W.D., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, United States; Vondra, R.J., Arlington, VA, United States; Schafer, W.J., Arlington, VA, United States
Abstract: The design and performance of a spacecraft employing arcjet nuclear electric propulsion, suitable for use in the Space Nuclear Power System Reference Mission, are outlined. The vehicle design is based on a 92 kW ammonia arcjet system operating at an Ispof 1050 s and an efficiency of 45%. The arcjet/gimbal system, power processing unit and propellant feed-system are described. A 100 k We space nuclear power system is assumed and the spacecraft mass is baselined at 5250 kg excluding the propellant, propellant feed system and integrated chemical boost engine. A radiation/arcjet efflux diagnostics package is included in the performance analysis. Three mission scenarios are described and are capable of demonstrating the full capability of the space nuclear power source. The missions considered include power system deployment to possible SDI platform orbits and a spacecraft storage mission to an orbit of three times geosynchronus (GEO) with return to GEO corresponding to ΔV’s between 7400 m/s, and 7900 m/s. This spacecraft meets the Reference Mission constraint of low developmental risk and is scaleable to power levels projected for future space platforms. © 1987, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Mesergle J.S., Jones O.S., Brennan S.M., Fortini A.
Title: Mixing-induced ullage condensation and fluid destratification
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mesergle, J.S., Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States; Jones, O.S., Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States; Brennan, S.M., Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States; Fortini, A., Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: Forced mixing may be required for on-orbit storage and transfer of cryogens. To provide applicable data on jet-induced mixing, an experiment was conducted in which an axial jet mixer promoted condensation of the ullage and lowered the pressure in a subscale cylindrical tank partially filled with Freon 11. The test objectives were to (1) determine the transient condensation and heat transfer rates at the 1iquid-vapor interface as a function of jet parameters, (2) quantify the important factors affecting mixing efficiency, and (3) compare mixing times to previous mixing data based on acid-base neutralization and dye dispersion. The variation of interface heat transfer coefficient with changes in jet Reynolds number was consistent with existing correlations based on measurements of steady-state rates of mixing-induced condensation of steam. Mixing times based on tank pressure decay were correlated with jet momentum flux, although buoyancy effects made it difficult to extrapolate all the results to low gravity. Mixers with large diameter nozzles and low flow rates required the most time and least amount of energy to destratify the fluid, Dimensionless mixing times agreed with comparable acid-base neutralization data, but not with dye dispersion data. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1987. All rights reserved.

Title: Low power arcjet thruster pulse ignition
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarmlento, C.J., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; Gruber, R.P., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Abstract: An Investigation of the pulse Ignition characteristics of a 1 kW class arcjet using an inductive energy storage pulse generator Integral with a pulse width modulated power converter Identified several thruster and pulse generator parameters that influence breakdown voltage including pulse generator rate of voltage rise. This work was conducted with an arcjet tested on hydrogen- nitrogen gas mixtures to simulate fully decomposed hydrazine. Over all ranges of thruster and pulser parameters investigated, the mean breakdown voltages varied from 1.4 to 2.7 kV. Ignition tests at elevated thruster temperatures under certain conditions revealed occasional breakdowns to thruster voltages higher than the power converter output voltage. These postbreakdown discharges sometimes failed to transition to the lower voltage arc discharge mode and the thruster would not ignite. Under the same conditions, a transition to the arc mode would occur for a subsequent pulse and the thruster would Ignite. An automated 11 600 cycle starting and transition to steady state test demon­strated Ignition on the first pulse and required application of a second pulse only two times to Initiate breakdown. Furthermore, no thruster damage or ero­sion was observed following the 11 600 starts and transitions to steady state operation. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astionautfcv Inc., 1987. All rights reserved.

Title: The effect of ignition energy on main discharge process
Affiliations: Space Science and Technology Center, Academia Sinica, P.O. Box 2703, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: An, S.-M., Space Science and Technology Center, Academia Sinica, P.O. Box 2703, Beijing, China
Abstract: Based on the statistic analysis of numerous experiments, especially for the PPT discharge, it is clear that the ignition process of the main discharge including the waveform and its peak value is able to change over a wide range. When the thruster is in operation the main discharge current is the key to efficient conversion of electrical energy into the directed mechanical force. Its variation has the probabilistic features and its amplitude has a certain distribution. The article tries to determine the factors affecting the waveform amplitude distribution in order to raise the thruster’s dynamic performance and to improve the waveform itself. Ultimately it should be possible to design a thruster with high performances. The amplitude characteristic of main discharge current is determined by such parameters of the circuit, as initial voltage, connection between the main gap and the element for energy storage, condition of propellant’s working surface etc., The electrical feature describing the physics of the main discharge process has even a great effect. In the transient from open circuit through ignition to the main discharge occurrence, the ignition has an obvious influence upon the process. A successful ignition can result formation of a very distinct discharge and a rapid rise time to produce a normal waveform with a high peak. It is logical to assume that for foundation of the main discharge the ignition ability plays an important role. It is more reasonable and convenient to change ignition energy level than needs. To investigate the effect of the ignition process one must keep such factors as the thruster configuration and ignition circuit, the concerned electrical parameters and the operation condition as the constant. In order to obtain sufficient data of the order of 105 discharges, the CES (Computerized Experiment system) has been used to collect data in real time and to complete respective on-line analysis. A relationship between the minimum ignition energy Eig(min) required for an effective discharge and the effective main discharge current Idis(aff) is shown to be: K.q.Exp(Eig(min))≥Idia (eff) On the basis of the equation the ignition energy can control the development of the main discharge and current amplitude which gives an evident effect on the discharge efficiency. © 1987 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Electric propulsion; Energy efficiency; Ignition; Probability distributions; Propulsion; Reconfigurable hardware; Amplitude characteristics; Discharge efficiency; Dynamic performance; Effective discharge; Electrical parameter; Minimum ignition energy; Operation conditions; Waveform amplitudes; Electric discharges

Title: Aggregation Processes in NaCl:Eu2+ System. Eu2+ Concentration Dependence of the Characteristics of the Aggregates Formed at Room Temperature
Affiliations: Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Wrocław, Poland; Dipartimento di Física, Università di Parma, Italy; G.N.S.M. (C.N.R.), C.I.S.M. (M.P.I.)
Authors with affiliations: Opyrchal, H., Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Wrocław, Poland; Manfredi, M., Dipartimento di Física, Università di Parma, Italy, G.N.S.M. (C.N.R.), C.I.S.M. (M.P.I.)
Abstract: The Eu2+ aggregates formed, after a long storage at room temperature, in two NaCl:Eu2+ samples (doped with a Eu2+ concentration of 100 and 500 ppm, respectively) are examined by luminescence and time decay spectra. In both the samples, aggregates emitting at 431, 444, and 469 nm are formed. These aggregates show the same characteristics in both the samples, seeming to be independent of the overall Eu2+ concentration; their decay scheme show a behaviour similar to that of isolated Eu2+ ions. In the more concentrated samples a further aggregate can be detected, the emission band of which is peaking at 414 nm; its decay scheme is different from that measured for the above mentioned aggregates. Finally for low doped samples an energy transfer process between the dipoles and/or clusters emitting in the region 410 to 430 nm and aggregates emitting in the region 440 to 470 nm is evidenced.
