Title: An efficient newton‐like method for molecular mechanics energy minimization of large molecules
Affiliations: Department of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06511, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ponder, J.W., Department of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06511, United States; Richards, F.M., Department of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06511, United States
Abstract: Techniques from numerical analysis and crystallographic refinement have been combined to produce a variant of the Truncated Newton nonlinear optimization procedure. The new algorithm shows particular promise for potential energy minimization of large molecular systems. Usual implementations of Newton's method require storage space proportional to the number of atoms squared (i.e., O(N2)) and computer time of O(N3). Our suggested implementation of the Truncated Newton technique requires storage of less than O(N1.5) and CPU time of less than O(N2) for structures containing several hundred to a few thousand atoms. The algorithm exhibits quadratic convergence near the minimum and is also very tolerant of poor initial structures. A comparison with existing optimization procedures is detailed for cyclohexane, arachidonic acid, and the small protein crambin. In particular, a structure for crambin (662 atoms) has been refined to an RMS gradient of 3.6 × 10−6 kcal/mol/Å per atom on the MM2 potential energy surface. Several suggestions are made which may lead to further improvement of the new method. Copyright © 1987 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Title: A powerful truncated Newton method for potential energy minimization
Affiliations: Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University, 251 Mercer Street, New York, New York, 10012, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schlick, T., Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University, 251 Mercer Street, New York, New York, 10012, United States; Overton, M., Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University, 251 Mercer Street, New York, New York, 10012, United States
Abstract: With advances in computer architecture and software, Newton methods are becoming not only feasible for large‐scale nonlinear optimization problems, but also reliable, fast and efficient. Truncated Newton methods, in particular, are emerging as a versatile subclass. In this article we present a truncated Newton algorithm specifically developed for potential energy minimization. The method is globally convergent with local quadratic convergence. Its key ingredients are: (1) approximation of the Newton direction far away from local minima, (2) solution of the Newton equation iteratively by the linear Conjugate Gradient method, and (3) preconditioning of the Newton equation by the analytic second‐derivative components of the “local” chemical interactions: bond length, bond angle and torsional potentials. Relaxation of the required accuracy of the Newton search direction diverts the minimization search away from regions where the function is nonconvex and towards physically interesting regions. The preconditioning strategy significantly accelerates the iterative solution for the Newton search direction, and therefore reduces the computation time for each iteration. With algorithmic variations, the truncated Newton method can be formulated so that storage and computational requirements are comparable to those of the nonlinear Conjugate Gradient method. As the convergence rate of nonlinear Conjugate Gradient methods is linear and performance less predictable, the application of the truncated Newton code to potential energy functions is promising. Copyright © 1987 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Authors: VALLEJO‐CORDOBA B., NAKAI S., POWRIE W.D., BEVERIDGE T.
Title: Extended Shelf Life of Frankfurters and Fish Frankfurter‐Analogs with Added Soy Protein Hydrolysates
Affiliations: Dept of Food Science, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, V6T 2A2, Canada; Summerland Research Station, Summerland Research Station, Summerland, British Columbia, VOH 1Z0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: VALLEJO‐CORDOBA, B., Dept of Food Science, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, V6T 2A2, Canada, Summerland Research Station, Summerland Research Station, Summerland, British Columbia, VOH 1Z0, Canada; NAKAI, S., Dept of Food Science, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, V6T 2A2, Canada, Summerland Research Station, Summerland Research Station, Summerland, British Columbia, VOH 1Z0, Canada; POWRIE, W.D., Dept of Food Science, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, V6T 2A2, Canada, Summerland Research Station, Summerland Research Station, Summerland, British Columbia, VOH 1Z0, Canada; BEVERIDGE, T., Dept of Food Science, Univ of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, V6T 2A2, Canada, Summerland Research Station, Summerland Research Station, Summerland, British Columbia, VOH 1Z0, Canada
Abstract: Incorporation of a low salt protein hydrolysate into a sausage batter significantly extended the shelf life of the product stored at 25°C. This temperature was chosen for saving the energy costs for refrigeration. The supplemented frankfurters (aw= 0.92) had CFU/g l/5000 and 1/ 1000 of that for the unsupplemented controls (aw= 0.97) after a 10day aerobic and anaerobic storage at 25°C, respectively. However, bacterial counts of fish frankfurter‐analogs treated similarly were reduced only slightly. Differences in flavor and texture between the supplemented and unsupplemented frankfurters were nonsignificant. Supplemented fish frankfurter‐analogs were found to be significantly softer than the unsupplemented controls. Copyright © 1987, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: N‐Nitrosodimethylamine content of aqueous dimet hylamine and phenoxy herbicide/dimethylamine formulations during storage
Affiliations: Agriculture Canada, Food Production and Inspection Branch, Laboratory Services Division, Ottawa, Ontario, KIA OC6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wigfield, Y.Y., Agriculture Canada, Food Production and Inspection Branch, Laboratory Services Division, Ottawa, Ontario, KIA OC6, Canada; McLenaghan, C.C., Agriculture Canada, Food Production and Inspection Branch, Laboratory Services Division, Ottawa, Ontario, KIA OC6, Canada
Abstract: N‐Nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) levels in samples of 600 g litre−1 aqueous dimethylamine (DMA) solution stored at 4, 25 and 40°C, in formulations of the DMA salt of 2, 4‐dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2, 4‐D) and of the DMA salt of 4‐chloro‐2‐methylphenoxyacetic acid (MCPA) at 40°C were monitored using a gas‐liquid chromatograph coupled with a thermal energy analyser (g.l.c./t.e.a.). The NDMA content of aqueous DMA at 4°C increased from 0.32μgg−1 to 8.6μgg−1 in 156 days. At 25°C it increased from 0.20μgg−1 to 10.5 μgg−1 in 156 days and at 40°C from 0.76μgg−1 to 7.12μgg−1 in 54 h. At 40°C, the NDMA in the 2, 4‐D/DMAsalt increased from 0–53μgg−1 to 2.79μgg−1 in 96 days and in the MCPA/DMA salt from 0.48μgg−1 to 5.51 μgg−1 in 21 days. Copyright © 1987 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd

Title: INTERACTIONS AMONG IRRADIANCE, OXYGEN EVOLUTION AND NITRITE UPTAKE BY CHLAMYDOMONAS (CHLOROPHYCEAE)
Affiliations: Department of Ecology and Behavioral Biology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Curtis, P.J., Department of Ecology and Behavioral Biology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 55455, United States; Megard, R.O., Department of Ecology and Behavioral Biology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 55455, United States
Abstract: Nitrite uptake and oxygenic photosynthesis by cultures of Chlamydomonas sp. isolated from Lake Superior were measured at different irradiances in order to compare predictive models of nitrite uptake and to assess the proportion of photoreductant (measured as oxygen evolution, mol × 4 eq. mol−1) that is allocated to nitrite assimilation (measured as nitrite uptake, mol × 6 eq. mol−1). These measurements are analogous to measurements of carbon fixation (CO2 uptake) at different irradiances and photosynthetic activities. Nitrite uptake as a function of irradiance did not follow Michaelis‐Menten kinetics as proposed for nitrate by MacIsaac and Dugdale (1972) because of inhibition at high irradiances. The Haldane equation described nitrite uptake better. Nitrite uptake as a function of oxygenic photosynthesis followed Michaelis‐Menten kinetics. Irradiance‐dependent (Haldane) and photosynthesis‐dependent models described nitrite uptake equally well. We suggest that nitrite is taken up and assimilated in response to intracellular concentrations of photoreductant that are directly proportional to photosynthetic activity and are related indirectly to irradiance. This contention is supported by photosynthesis‐dependent nitrite uptake (Michaelis‐Menten) at both light‐limited and photoinhibited photosynthetic activities. This is consistent conceptually with deactivation of light traps at high irradiance levels. The proportion of photoreductant allocated to nitrite uptake and assimilation increased markedly at low irradiance levels. This indicates that cells synthesize important N‐containing biomolecules across a broader range of irradiance levels than fixation of carbon for synthesis of energy storage and structural products. Copyright © 1987, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: algae; irradiance; nitrite uptake; nutrient; photosynthesis

Title: Radiation initiated grafting on fluoro polymers III. Grafting of N‐vinylpyrrolidone in aqueous solution on poly(vinylidene fluoride) films by accelerated electrons
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie, Universität zu Köln, Luxemburger Str. 116, Köln, D-5000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Niemöller, A., Institut für Physikalische Chemie, Universität zu Köln, Luxemburger Str. 116, Köln, D-5000, Germany; Ellinghorst, G., Institut für Physikalische Chemie, Universität zu Köln, Luxemburger Str. 116, Köln, D-5000, Germany
Abstract: The radiation induced grafting of N‐vinylpyrrolidone in aqueous solution onto poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVF2) films by preirradiation technique using 160 keV electrons has been investigated. Among the grafting parameters, the most important are storage time after irradiation, grafting time, grafting temperature, and absorbed dose. Trapped radicals in PVF2 are very stable; peroxy radicals generated by storage of irradiated samples in air can initiate grafting, too. The grafting of PVF2 proceeds slowly from the film surface to the inner part, ceasing when the middle of the film is reached from both sides. The penetration of the grafting front has been observed by “Differential‐Interference‐Contrast” (DIC)‐microscopy. At constant other parameters, the penetration depth depends on the grafting time and can be correlated with the time conversion curves. For the discussion of the grafting reaction a simple kinetic model has been developed. A very high activation energy of diffusion of ∼ 80 kJ mol−1 has been estimated both by sorption measurements and by application of the kinetic model with regard to the activation energies of grafting rate and saturation grafting yield (SGY). From the SGY‐dose relationship the ratio of the rate constants kpkt−1 has been calculated. As for other grafting systems this ratio has about the 105‐fold value in relation to homopolymerization of the same monomer. This indicates the restrained mobility of propagating macroradicals in the highly viscous grafting medium leading particularly to a lower kt in comparison with homopolymerization. © 1987 Hüthig & Wepf Verlag, Basel

Authors: McGEE E., BOOTH R.H., JARVIS M.C., DUNCAN H.J.
Title: The inhibition of potato sprout growth by light. I. Effects of light on dormancy and subsequent sprout growth
Affiliations: Agricultural Chemistry Department, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; Postharvest Technology, The International Potato Centre, P. 0, Box 5969, Lima, Peru
Authors with affiliations: McGEE, E., Agricultural Chemistry Department, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; BOOTH, R.H., Agricultural Chemistry Department, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom, Postharvest Technology, The International Potato Centre, P. 0, Box 5969, Lima, Peru; JARVIS, M.C., Agricultural Chemistry Department, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; DUNCAN, H.J., Agricultural Chemistry Department, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: When potato seed tubers (Solanum tuberosum cv. Pentland Javelin) were stored in darkness or diffuse daylight at 9°C and transferred at intervals to conditions suitable for sprouting, their capacity for sprout growth was unaffected by the presence or absence of light during previous storage. When similar tubers were stored at 10°C, 18°C or 25°C, sprout growth commenced earliest at 25°C, but the date was unaffected by fluorescent light. It was concluded that light did not affect the length of the dormant period, but only the rate of sprout elongation after that period had ceased. When tubers with growing sprouts at 10°C or 18°C were transferred from darkness into fluorescent light, sprout growth virtually ceased. Transfer from light into darkness resulted in immediate sprout growth, at a rate comparable with tubers stored continuously in the dark. Tubers of three Peruvian cultivars, stored in farm‐scale diffuse‐daylight stores, grew progressively shorter sprouts with increasing daily exposure to light from 30 min to 12 h. Storage of cv. Wilja under 21 Wm‐2 (total) of white fluorescent light for 10 h per day maintained the sprouts at the same length as ten times this light intensity for 1 h per day. In a subsequent experiment with cv. Bintje the 10 h, low‐intensity light regime gave slightly shorter sprouts. It appeared that the total light energy falling on the tubers was the dominant factor controlling sprout growth. Copyright © 1987, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Rao D.R., Ramachandra Rao M.S., Reddy S.A.K.
Title: Thermally stimulated luminescence of alkaline earth sulphide phosphors doped with cerium and samarium impurities
Affiliations: Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, D.R., Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Ramachandra Rao, M.S., Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Reddy, S.A.K., Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: Alkaline earth sulphide phosphors (CaS, SrS, and BaS) doped with rare earth ion (Sm and Ce) impurities were prepared by carbon reduction of pure sulphates of Ca, Sr, and Ba in a N2 atmosphere and using NaCl as flux. The thermally stimulated luminescence of these phosphors was studied by excitation with ultraviolet-, γ-, and X-rays. Intense glow maxima in the temperature range from 60 to 85°C were exhibited by most of the phosphors under the three methods of excitation. Some results on thermally stimulated conductivity and photoluminescence relevant in this context are also reported. Considering all these results, the trapping centres responsible for the energy storage in this system of phosphors were identified as Sm and Ce and their complexes involving native defects. © 1987 The Institute of Metals.

Title: A model of seasonal changes in energy balance
Affiliations: Human Nutrition Research Group, Department of Child Health, University of Queensland, St. Lucia, Q.4067, Australia; Department of Human Nutrition, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dugdale, A.E., Human Nutrition Research Group, Department of Child Health, University of Queensland, St. Lucia, Q.4067, Australia; Payne, P.R., Department of Human Nutrition, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: In developing countries, many peasant farmers experience regular seasonal changes of body weight, so that the adequacy of food energy supply cannnot be assessed simply in terms of energy balance and a desirable body weight. A computer simulation model has been devised, which predicts the pattern of changes in body weight which result from the annual cycle of agricultural work load, and the way in which food consumption is regulated over the year. The model also includes the effect of post-harvest storage losses. The actual observed patterns of food use of farmers in The Gambia, and in Burma, are first of all used to simulate the seasonal changes in body weight and these agree well with observations. The effects of alternative strategies of food use are then tried, ranging from a constant intake throughout the year, to an exaggerated feasting and fasting cycle. The simulations show that the actual food allocation patterns adopted by these two peasant populations constitute an optimum strategy in which the need to achieve maximum body weight at the time when peak work output is required, is balanced against the need to minimise the losses due to long term food storage. © 1987, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Burma; energy use; food; Gambia; harvest; seasonal change; simulation model; storage; Weight

Authors: Hwang I.H., Cha B.H., Nam S.M.
Title: Externally heated copper vapor laser using a carbon heater
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Kyungpook National University, Daegu, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Hwang, I.H., Department of Physics, Kyungpook National University, Daegu, South Korea; Cha, B.H., Department of Physics, Kyungpook National University, Daegu, South Korea; Nam, S.M., Department of Physics, Kyungpook National University, Daegu, South Korea
Abstract: An externally heated copper vapor laser using a carbon tubular heater is described. A recrystallized alumina tube of 20-mm inner diameter is used as the laser tube, which is located inside the tubular heater. When the heating power of the carbon heater is 3 kW, the temperature of the laser tube is 1600 °C. The average laser output power is measured to be 1.2 W at a laser tube temperature of 1500 °C when the charging voltage to the energy storage capacitor is 5 kV, the pulse repetition rate is 5 kHz, and the Ne gas fill pressure is 10 Torr. © 1987, American Institute of Physics. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: COPPER IONS; DESIGN; FURNACES; HEATERS; HEATING; LASER RADIATION; METAL VAPOR LASERS; OPERATION; PULSES; RELIABILITY; STIMULATED EMISSION; THERMAL INSULATION

Authors: Fontaine J.C., Levoir P., Delamar M., Meyer J.J., Paumard J.L.
Title: Modification of a VG ESCALAB MK-1 ESCA spectrometer for digital data acquisition and processing
Affiliations: ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Fontaine, J.C., ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France; Levoir, P., ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France; Delamar, M., ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France; Meyer, J.J., ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France; Paumard, J.L., ITODYS, Université Paris VII, Associé au CNRS, UA34, Paris, France
Abstract: To enable signal averaging on our VG ESCALAB MK-1 spectrometer we designed a digital ramp generator with repetitive mode of operation for each selected energy analyser sweep time. For digital data acquisition purposes we constructed a dedicated microcontrolled acquisition unit performing digitization of the ESCA spectrum in 4096 channels of 12-bit words. Data flow is controlled by a 6809 microprocessor driving a parallel interface adapter. Two RS232C serial links are provided for communication with a terminal and a mass storage unit. © 1987, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Thermal Oxidative Aging of Pentaerythritol Used as Latent-Heat-Type Thermal Storage Material
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute, Nagoya, Nagoya 462, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Taoda, H., Government Industrial Research Institute, Nagoya, Nagoya 462, Japan; Hayakawa, K., Government Industrial Research Institute, Nagoya, Nagoya 462, Japan
Abstract: To estimate the extent of thermal oxidative aging of pentaerythritol used as a latent-heat-type thermal storage material, the deterioration of pentaerythritol was investigated by applyig over two months the following heating-cooling cycle, which simulated the daily insolation : that is, 8-hour holding at 200°C as the highest temperature in a day followed by 5-hour holding at 30°C as the lowest. Several changes in pentaerythritol by the heating-cooling cycles,. e.g., weight decrease, decrease in oxygen content, production of carbonyl compound, and lowering of the heat of transition and of the transition temperature, are thought to be caused by sublimation, thermal oxidative decomposition and crosslinking between radicals produced. Radical scavengers effectively suppressed the thermal degradation of pentaerythritol. To use pentaerythritol as thermal storage material, the suppression of sublimation, of oxidation and of radical production are required. © 1987, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Crystalline Transition; Energy; Latent Heat; Pentaerythritol; Solid State PCM; Solid State Transition; Thermal Deterioration; Thermal Oxidative Aging; Thermal Storage Material
Index Keywords: Carbonyl compounds; Deterioration; Heat storage; Latent heat; Sublimation; Crystalline transition; Energy; Pentaerythritol; Solid-state transitions; Thermal oxidative aging; Storage (materials)

Authors: Loyd R.J., Schoenung S.M., Hassenzahl W.V., Rogers J.D., Purcell J.R.
Title: Coil protection for a utility scale superconducting magnetic energy storage plant
Affiliations: Bechtel National Inc., San Francisco, California, United States; Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California, United States; Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States; G.A. Technologies, Inc., San Diego, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Loyd, R.J., Bechtel National Inc., San Francisco, California, United States; Schoenung, S.M., Bechtel National Inc., San Francisco, California, United States; Hassenzahl, W.V., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California, United States; Rogers, J.D., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States; Purcell, J.R., G.A. Technologies, Inc., San Diego, California, United States
Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) is proposed for electric utility load leveling. Attractive costs, high diurnal energy efficiency (>92%), and rapid response are advantages relative to other energy storage technologies. Recent industry-led efforts have produced a conceptual design for a 5000 MWh/1000 MW energy storage plant which is technically feasible at commercially attractive estimated costs. The SMES plant design includes a protection system which prevents damage to the magnetic coil if events require a rapid discharge of stored energy. This paper describes the design and operation of the coil protection system, which is primarily passive and uses the thermal capacity of the coil itself to absorb the stored electromagnetic energy. Copyright © 1987 by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
