Title: ULTRASHORT LASER PULSES IN THE MIDINFRARED.
Affiliations: Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Rolland, C., Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Corkum, P.B., Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Natl Research Council, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: Methods of generating and amplifying ultrashort pulses in the 10- mu m wavelength region are reviewed, and emerging diagnostic techniques which will allow picosecond and femtosecond spectroscopy to be performed in the mid-infrared are discussed. The shortest mid-infrared pulses are produced by semiconductor switching. Using 70-fs 0. 6- mu m pulses to activate infrared switches, bandwidth-limited mid-infrared pulses as short as 130 fs have been produced with a peak power of approx 10**4 W. Such pulses contain only four optical cycles, and even shorter pulses should be feasible. The amplification of such pulses requires a large gain bandwidth. Pulses shorter than approx 40 ps exceed the bandwidth of a single rotational-vibration transition in even 10-atm CO//2 amplifiers. However, for pressures above approx 10 atm the individual rotational lines strongly overlap, producing a weakly modulated gain bandwidth of more than 0. 5 THz. This bandwidth is sufficient for the amplification of pulses as short as 2. 5 ps through very large gains. Furthermore, since CO//2 lasers are energy storage devices it is possible to amplify pulses to very high power in compact systems.
Index Keywords: INFRARED RADIATION; LASERS, CARBON DIOXIDE; SPECTROSCOPY, INFRARED; DIGEST OF PAPER; FEMTOSECOND PULSES; PICOSECOND MIDINFRARED PULSES; SEMICONDUCTOR SWITCHING; ULTRASHORT LASER PULSES; LASER PULSES

Authors: Hooker C.J., Shaw M.J., Kannari F.
Title: MULTIPLE-PULSE AMPLIFICATION IN A KRF LASER.
Affiliations: SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl, SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Hooker, C.J., SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl, SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl; Shaw, M.J., SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl, SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl; Kannari, F., SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl, SERC, Rutherford Appleton Lab, Engl
Abstract: The KrF laser has a very short storage time, which means that to realize the potential high efficiency, energy must be extracted from the laser continuously. Thus, previous schemes for large KrF laser systems have regarded the laser as a CW device. Recently, it was shown that very short (picosecond) pulses can be amplified to high powers in the KrF laser medium. Preliminary results are presented of experiments carried out to extend these results to high energy, with high system efficiency. This has been done by amplifying a sequence of pulses in a single module. The pulses may be separated in angle (angularly multiplexed) so that they may be recombined simultaneously on target.

Title: Individual variations in energy utilized for biomechanical processes and molecular mobility account for diverse susceptibility to obesity
Affiliations: Health Sciences Centre, The University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 4N1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Roncari, D.A.K., Health Sciences Centre, The University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 4N1, Canada
Abstract: To explain why subjects vary in body fat content despite similar nutrient intake and physical activity, a hypothesis is proposed invoking individual variability in the potentially vast quantities of energy utilizable for such biomechanical functions as cellular motility processes, and for protein mobility. The collective term "biomechanical-mobile" activity is introduced. The hypothesis explains variation without differences in external energy losses. After utilization for indispensable metabolic needs and the variable "biomechanical-mobile" activity, excess energy is mainly transduced to anabolic processes, and eventually stored as chemical energy, mostly as adipocyte triglycerides. At one extreme, are subjects with the least degrees of "biomechanical-mobile" activity, the consequently largest surfeits of energy for chemical storage, and thus the greatest susceptiblity to massive obesity. The converse applies to inordinate leanness. Between the extremes, the almost infinite individual variability is due to a "continuous" distribution of "biomechanical-mobile" activity inversely related to the quantity remaining for chemical storage. While the extremes may result from mutations, the intervening continuum is ascribed to genetic polymorphism and to novel endocrine-neural mechanisms. In addition, such environmental influences as diet and drugs might modulate "biomechanical-mobile" activity. This hypothesis is extrapolated to all living systems. © 1987.
Index Keywords: obesity; susceptibility; theoretical study; Adipose Tissue; Biomechanics; Cell Movement; Energy Metabolism; Human; Models, Biological; Obesity; Polymorphism (Genetics); Thinness

Title: A new linear model for stability prediction
Affiliations: College of pharmacy and Allied Health Professions, St. John's University, Jamaica, NY, 11439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nash, R.A., College of pharmacy and Allied Health Professions, St. John's University, Jamaica, NY, 11439, United States
Abstract: Based upon Okusa's observation (Chem. Pharm. Bull. 1975) that the slopes of a linear plot of logo log fraction of active substance degraded vs log time for first order decay kinetics and a linear plot of log of drug remaining vs log time for a zero order decay kinetics are both unity, an algorithm has been developed to resolve both the energy of activation (E) and the rate constant (Ko or Lo) at the desired shelf-life temperature (To) by analysis of the y-intercepts of parallel slopes at more than one elevated temperature (T). Preliminary estimates of both E and either Ko or Lo are then substituted into a series of mathematical expressions based upon well known Arrhenius relationship: k = A ·exp -E/1.987) (1/T-l/To) where A = Ko or Lo Using converging and interative techniques to treat elevated temperature data, the resulting mean loss rate (eithri Ko or Lo at the designated shelf-life temperature plus a residual error term thus obtained, is used to distinguish statistically between zero and first order treatments. A program called POTENCYLOSS, based upon the algorithm, has been written in business BASIC language for use with an IBM-PC micro-computer. The program is ideally suited for use in preformulation studies or in assigning provisional expiration dating and overage requirements during the early stages of formulation development when there is limited potency stability test data available at accelerated, elevated temperature storage conditions. © 1987 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Authors: Birge R.R., Schick G.A., Cooper T.M., Holloway R.A., Murray L.P.
Title: Energy Storage in the Primary Photochemical Events of Rhodopsin and Isorhodopsin
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Birge, R.R., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States; Schick, G.A., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States; Cooper, T.M., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States; Holloway, R.A., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States; Murray, L.P., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15213, United States
Abstract: The energetics associated with the photoequilibrium are measured at 77 K by using pulsed-laser photocalorimetry and a range of excitation wavelengths and relative starting concentrations. Enthalpies for the photochemical transformations R B and I B are measured to be ΔHRB= 32.2 ± 0.9 kcal mol-1and = 27.1 ± 3.2 kcal mol-1, respectively. Although the value of AHRB is slightly lower than that reported previously by Cooper of 34.7 ± 2.2 kcal mol-1 [Cooper, A. (1979) Nature (London) 282, 531–533], the two values are in agreement within experimental error. The energy difference = 5.1 ± 3.3 kcal mol-1is identical within experimental error with the difference in enthalpies of isorhodopsin and rhodopsin [5.2 ± 2.3; Cooper, A. (1979) FEBS Lett. 100, 382–384]. We suggest that this result is consistent with the theory that bathorhodopsin is a single, common photochemical intermediate connecting rhodopsin and isorhodopsin. © 1987, American Chemical Society. Authors: Hubbard R.W., Matthew C.B., Durkot M.J., Francesconi R.P.
Title: Novel approaches to the pathophysiology of heatstroke: The energy depletion model
Affiliations: US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hubbard, R.W., US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States; Matthew, C.B., US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States; Durkot, M.J., US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States; Francesconi, R.P., US Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States
Abstract: De-emphasis of the role of anhydrosis as the primary cause of heatstroke has resulted in increased usage and acceptance of animal models for heatstroke research. When the total amount of work achieved by the running rat prior to exhaustion was plotted against the rate of heat storage, a heretofore unrecognized relationship emerged. These new data suggest that physical exhaustion and heat exhaustion represent opposite ends of a continuum related to the rate of heat storage. Changes in thermoregulatory and/or physical performance can be estimated by a two-dimensional shift in the work-output/thermal storage ratio. Potassium depletion reduces thermoregulatory/physical performance; a combination of atropine plus diazepam appears to improve it. The role of the cholinergic nervous system in eliciting alterations in thermoregulatory and physical ability is reviewed; endurance training, shivering, acclimatization, set-point theory, the anticholinergic syndrome, lithium intoxication, and choline deficiency are discussed. © 1987 American College of Emergency Physicians.

Authors: Palings I., Van den Berg E., Mathies R.A., Pardoen J.A., Winkel C., Lugtenburg J.
Title: Assignment of Fingerprint Vibrations in the Resonance Raman Spectra of Rhodopsin, Isorhodopsin, and Bathorhodopsin: Implications for Chromophore Structure and Environment
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720, United States; Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Palings, I., Chemistry Department, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720, United States; Van den Berg, E., Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Mathies, R.A., Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Pardoen, J.A., Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Winkel, C., Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Lugtenburg, J., Chemistry Department, Gorlaeus Laboratories, Leiden University, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands
Abstract: 13C- and 2H-labeled retinal derivatives have been used to assign normal modes in the 1100-1300-cm-1fingerprint region of the resonance Raman spectra of rhodopsin, isorhodopsin, and bathorhodopsin. On the basis of the 13C shifts, C8-C9stretching character is assigned at 1217 cm-1in rhodopsin, at 1206 cm-1in isorhodopsin, and at 1214 cm-1in bathorhodopsin. C10-C11stretching character is localized at 1098 cm-1in rhodopsin, at 1154 cm-1in isorhodopsin, and at 1166 cm-1 in bathorhodopsin. C14-C15stretching character is found at 1190 cm-1in rhodopsin, at 1206 cm-1 in isorhodopsin, and at 1210 cm-1in bathorhodopsin. C12-C13stretching character is much more delocalized, but the characteristic coupling with the C14H rock allows us to assign the “C12-Ci3 stretch” at ~ 1240 cm-1in rhodopsin, isorhodopsin, and bathorhodopsin. The insensitivity of the C14-C15stretching mode to N-deuteriation in all three pigments demonstrates that each contains a trans (anti) protonated Schiff base bond. The relatively high frequency of the C10-C11mode of bathorhodopsin demonstrates that bathorhodopsin is s-trans about the C10-C11single bond. This provides strong evidence against the model of bathorhodopsin proposed by Liu and Asato [Liu, R., & Asato, A. (1985) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 82, 259], which suggests a C10-C11s-cis structure. Comparison of the fingerprint modes of rhodopsin (1098, 1190, 1217, and 1239 cm-1) with those of the 11-cis-retinal protonated Schiff base in methanol (1093, 1190, 1217, and 1237 cm-1) shows that the frequencies of the C-C stretching modes are largely unperturbed by protein binding. In particular, the invariance of the C14-C15stretching mode at 1190 cm-1does not support the presence of a negative protein charge near C13 in rhodopsin. In contrast, the frequencies of the C8-C9and C14-C15stretches of bathorhodopsin and the C10-C11and C14-C15stretches of isorhodopsin are significantly altered by protein binding. The implications of these observations for the mechanism of wavelength regulation in visual pigments and energy storage in bathorhodopsin are discussed. © 1987, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Compatibility of organic latent heat storage materials and plastic container materials
Affiliations: Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Werner, R., Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), Universität Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, 7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Abstract: Plastic container materials are evaluated for use in macroencapsulation of latent heat storage materials, with special emphasis on fatty acids. Different platics have been tested. Title: 'UPPER-BOUND' PLASTIC COLLAPSE ANALYSIS OF FRAMEWORKS.
Source title: Cambridge University, Engineering Department (Technical Report) CUED/C-MATS
Affiliations: Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, Engl, Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Pellegrino, S., Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, Engl, Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, Engl
Abstract: The paper develops an efficient and general, yet physically understandable, scheme to obtain the collapse load factor of an arbitrary framed structure using an upper-bound approach. The most general mechanism of collapse is expressed by a linear combination of the elementary mechanisms and the corresponding load multiplier lambda is obtained by equating the work done by the applied loads to the plastic energy dissipated. The minimum of lambda is the required collapse load. Having examined the properties of lambda , a new matrix method to find its minimum is devised; a simple example illustrates the calculations. The new method of minimization does not require non-negative variables as in previous schemes based on the Simplex method, and thus results in an algorithm which reduces computer storage and time requirements.

Title: Buckling of cylindrical shells under the action of nonuniform external pressure
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND 58202, United States; Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jerath, S., Department of Civil Engineering, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND 58202, United States; Ghosh, A.K., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States
Abstract: Over the last few decades, storage tanks have become bigger and thinner. Because of this, the buckling capacity of these cylindrical shells may well be the determining factor of shell thickness. In this paper, the critical buckling load of isotropic and orthotropic cylinders subjected to different types of wind load distributions is investigated. The prebuckling displacements are obtained by using the membrane theory of shell analysis. The principle of minimum potential energy in conjunction with Ritz's approach is used to obtain the stability matrix. The size of the stability matrix in this analysis is (81 × 81). By solving the stability matrix as an eigenvalue problem, the critical pressures are obtained as eigenvalues and the deflection shapes as eigenvectors. In the present study cylindrical shells of various dimensions, which are fixed at the base and free at the top, are investigated. The buckling load curves for isotropic and orthotropic cylinders of various dimensions are given for practical use. © 1987.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions; PRESSURE EFFECTS; STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS; CYLINDRICAL SHELLS; NONUNIFORM EXTERNAL PRESSURE; DOMES AND SHELLS

Title: RELIABILITY CONSIDERATIONS FOR OLS HOLDOVER CIRCUITS.
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Morristown, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Morristown, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kunzinger, F.F., AT&T Bell Lab, Morristown, NJ,, USA, AT&T Bell Lab, Morristown, NJ, USA
Abstract: Many applications require holdover of a power supply's output for 10 to 1000 ms to bridge short input power line outages or dips. Capacitive energy storage is a common means of providing this holdover. The author examines the reliability of a capacitive energy storage system under both operating and storage conditions. To provide meaningful results for the study, the specified storage temperature of 85 degree C had to be abandoned in favor of a more realistic temperature of 45 degree C. At this temperature, a diode-coupled 9500- mu F aluminum electrolytic capacitor network was a reasonable choice to provide a 50-ms holdover. This network offered the best compromise among reliability, size, weight, cost and maintenance. Tantalum capacitor networks, while acceptable in many areas, were approximately one hundred times more expensive than aluminum networks.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY; RELIABILITY; HOLDOVER CIRCUITS; OFFLINE SWITCHER (OLS); ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, SWITCHING

Title: HIMURO TYPE STORAGE SHED USING THE ICE STORED IN WINTER SEASON.
Affiliations: Muroran Inst of Technology, Muroran, Jpn, Muroran Inst of Technology, Muroran, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kobiyama, M., Muroran Inst of Technology, Muroran, Jpn, Muroran Inst of Technology, Muroran, Jpn
Abstract: The author and his co-workers have been developing the technique of collecting, conserving and utilizing systems of the cold heat energy in the winter season. This paper presents an example of methods for storage of agricultural products by the use of natural ice in the winter season, that is, a HIMURO-type storage shed. The author has proposed a method for the thermal designing the cold storage room, taking monthly change in environmental conditions and heat generation from agricultural products. The experiment was performed over a period of one year to verify the propriety of the thermal design and to observe the storing condition of the product by using a HIMURO-type storage shed on a practical scale. The close agreements between observed and designed characteristic values were obtained. It is clear that the characteristics of the HIMURO-type storage shed are very suitable for storing many kinds of agricultural products during long time period.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS - Applications; COLD HEAT ENERGY; HIMURO STORAGE SHEDS; ICE

Title: SPRAY INSULATION CUTS HEAT LOSSES FROM FUEL OIL STORAGE TANKS BY 80%.
Affiliations: GPU Nuclear Corp, GPU Nuclear Corp
Authors with affiliations: Miller, Stephen, GPU Nuclear Corp, GPU Nuclear Corp
Abstract: Energy losses from steam heated heavy fuel oil storage tanks can be substantially reduced by spraying on a silicone/urethane insulation system. Calculations predict a fuel savings benefit to capital cost ratio of 3 or 4 to 1. This type of project is recommended by state public service commissions in rate case reviews and performance audits, since it results in a direct pass-along savings to electric customers in the form of reduced fuel adjustment charges. This insulation application is also finding wide acceptance for condensate tanks and fire protection tanks to prevent freeze-ups because of its low initial installed cost.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEAT INSULATING MATERIALS - Foamed Products; TANKS - Heat Losses; HEAT-LOSS REDUCTION; SPRAYED URETHANE FOAM INSULATION; STEAM-HEATED OIL STORAGE TANKS; OIL FUEL

Title: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF LEAD ACID STORAGE BATTERIES.
Source title: Transactions of the SAEST (Society for Advancement of Electrochemical Science and Technology)

Abstract: Evaluation of different types of batteries for automotive and stationary cells have been carried out as per Indian Standards specification and RDSO specification, by the authors for the past 10 years. In all 100 cells of different makes and types from small scale and organized sectors have been subjected to various tests such as capacity test, high rate discharge, charge retention, resistance to overcharge, life cycle test, storage test etc. and the salient features of the performance are discussed.

Title: PROGRESS IN SODIUM-SULPHUR CELL DESIGN.
Affiliations: Chloride Silent Power Ltd, Engl, Chloride Silent Power Ltd, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Bindin, P.J., Chloride Silent Power Ltd, Engl, Chloride Silent Power Ltd, Engl
Abstract: A small sodium-sulfur cell design has been developed which enhances the cell energy density to over 20 Wh kg** minus **1 and, most importantly, has a dramatic effect on vehicle battery reliability. This cell design, combined with advances in cell technology and battery design, makes it possible to plan for a vehicle battery which need not require cell replacement for up to five years. Battery studies show that high performance vehicle batteries can be designed to fit the space available in vehicles. Results from the new cell design, and earlier generations of cell designs are presented, showing that long term, stable resistance and capacity could be maintained for up to 3,000 discharge/charge cycles.

Authors: Dutt D.K., Rai S.N., Tiwari G.N., Yadav Y.P.
Title: Comparative studies of thermal performance of a roof as an inexpensive collector/storage system
Affiliations: Department of Physics, M.M.H. College, Ghaziabad, 201 009, India; Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Dutt, D.K., Department of Physics, M.M.H. College, Ghaziabad, 201 009, India; Rai, S.N., Department of Physics, M.M.H. College, Ghaziabad, 201 009, India; Tiwari, G.N., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Yadav, Y.P., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: For economic utilization of solar energy, building materials, possessing relatively large thermal capacities and good insulating potentials, are used as an inexpensive storage of heat. The proposed roof configuration in this paper consists of a network of pipes buried in the roof with a blackened and glazed upper surface to absorb the solar energy incident on it and to reduce the convective heat loss to the ambient air from it. To reduce this heat loss further, either a movable insulation cover during off sun-shine hours over glazing or a thermal trap sheet over the blackened surface is used. This paper compares the thermal performance of a roof under different conditions, viz., bare, glazed, glazed with movable insulation and glazed with a thermal trap sheet on the roof. The use of the thermal trap material results in almost the same performance as movable insulation, while it eliminates the manually operated components, unlike movable insulation. © 1987.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Roofs; ROOFS - Insulation; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; MOVABLE INSULATION; THERMAL PERFORMANCE; THERMAL TRAP; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: VENTILATION PLANNING FOR A PROSPECTIVE NUCLEAR WASTE REPOSITORY.
Source title: Preprint - Society of Mining Engineers of AIME
Affiliations: Mine Ventilation Services Inc,, Lafayette, CA, USA, Mine Ventilation Services Inc, Lafayette, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wallace Jr., Keith G., Mine Ventilation Services Inc,, Lafayette, CA, USA, Mine Ventilation Services Inc, Lafayette, CA, USA
Abstract: In 1982 the U. S. Congress passed the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) to provide for the development of an underground repository for spent nuclear fuel. This development will be managed by the United States Department of Energy. In 1986, the President selected three areas for site characterization to determine their suitability for the development of an underground repository; those sites were: 1) a site in volcanic tuff located at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, 2) a site in bedded salt located in Deaf Smith County in Texas, and 3) a site in basalt located in Hanford, Washington. At present conceptual repository designs are being developed for each site. This paper describes the preliminary ventilation system designed for the repository in tuff. The concept provides separate ventilation systems for the construction and waste emplacement activities. The paper further describes the means by which acceptable environmental conditions will be re-established to allow re-entry into previously closed rooms for the purpose of inspection, maintenance or retrieval.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Storage; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; VENTILATION - Planning; NUCLEAR WASTE REPOSITORY; POTENTIAL WASTE RETRIEVAL; SUPPORT CONSTRUCTION; UNDERGROUND REPOSITORY; WASTE EMPLACEMENT; INDUSTRIAL WASTES

Authors: Ting K.C., Giannakakos P.N., Gilbert S.G.
Title: Durability of latent heat storage tube-sheets
Affiliations: Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ting, K.C., Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Giannakakos, P.N., Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Gilbert, S.G., Cook College, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States
Abstract: Compatibility and durability of phase change materials (PCM) and packaging laminate films were tested in this study. The objective was to identify viable component materials for heat storage tube-sheets. The tube-sheets are the essential part of a patented latent heat storage device. The unique feature of the device is its offset arrangement of mass-producible units. The results of cycling tests on two PCMs and one laminate are presented in this paper. After more than 1000 accelerated cycles of charging and discharging tests, the tubes maintained operable stability and showed no sign of deterioration. The PCMs displayed the same temperature-time pattern during the entire cycling test. The packaging laminate was compatible with the PCM's and capable of maintaining satisfactory strength. © 1987 Pergamon Journals Ltd.
Index Keywords: THERMAL INSULATION - Materials; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; PACKAGING LAMINATE FILMS; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS (PCM); THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; TUBE-SHEETS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Solar energy availability at Tehran: Performance of different types of solar collectors
Affiliations: Renewable Energy Research and Development Center, Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, P.O. Box 41-1198, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Ali, H.M., Renewable Energy Research and Development Center, Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, P.O. Box 41-1198, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: In this report, the optimum tilt of the solar collectors in Tehran is computed through a computer program. The annual optimum tilt of the collector is found to be 30°. The summer and winter optimum tilts are found to be 0° and 50°, respectively. Based on these optimum tilts, the annual performance of different types of solar collectors which have experimental efficiency curves is predicted. The variation of the performance of the collectors with the optimum tilts is found to be small. The difference between the outlet temperatures of these collectors is also found to be small. The effect of changing the incident angle from zero degrees is found to increase the efficiency of the flat-plate collectors and to reduce the efficiency of the evacuated collectors. In the coldest month of the year, the flat-plate collector can collect heat up to 70°C, while the tubular one can collect heat with temperature more than 90°C. In the other months, all the collectors collect heat with temperatures more than 90°C. The performance of a well-mixed storage tank used with one of the flat-plate collectors is annually predicted. For the initial storage tank temperature assumed at 20°C, the minimum and maximum temperatures are found approximately to equal 42°C and 93°C, respectively. The results show the high potential of the solar collectors in Tehran. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Solar collectors; Solar energy; Tehran
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; COLLECTOR OPTIMAL TILT; FLAT-PLATE COLLECTORS; SOLAR ENERGY AVAILABILITY; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: MULTISOURCE HYDRONIC HEAT PUMP SYSTEM CUTS ENERGY COSTS.
Affiliations: Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Milton, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA
Abstract: An independent engineering study and test comparing a multisource hydronic heat pump (MSHHP) system to various conventional heat pump systems shows the MSHHPS to be more cost effective on a life-cycle basis. MSHHP systems differ from conventional water source heat pump systems in that they use a chilled-water 'diversity' cooling loop, connecting air and water coils with a central chilled-water storage tank. Because of the loop, the MSHHP system uses less energy than other HVAC systems while lowering peak demand. This is done by shifting the required electrical energy consumption to lower rate periods, such as off-peak and mid-peak times. Lower installed heat pump capacity, such as refrigeration, is another benefit of the MSHHP system. This is achieved by precooling return air from a zone space - a process that allows the unitary heat pump to operate at a higher coefficient of performance - further reducing energy costs.
Index Keywords: COOLING WATER; ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION - Costs; ENERGY STORAGE; CHILLED WATER COOLING; CONVENTIONAL WATER SOURCE HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; ENERGY COSTS; MULTISOURCE HYDRONIC HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; OFF-PEAK POWER UTILIZATION; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Davies T.S., Jefferson C.M., Somerville W.M.
Title: AUTONOMOUS WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEM INCORPORATING ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Bristol Polytechnic, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Engl

Abstract: A problem that occurs in wind-energy conversion is the mismatch between supply and demand, which tend to vary independently. This problem is particularly acute in stand-alone systems, where lulls in the wind strength can cause temporary loss of supply to the system distribution network. It is shown that the problem can largely be overcome by the incorporation of dynamic energy storage. A kinetic energy system is demonstrated.

Title: On eliminating peak load auxiliary energy consumption in passive solar residences during winter
Affiliations: Energy Center, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sebald, A.V., Energy Center, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States; Munoz, D., Energy Center, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States
Abstract: This paper uses simulation analysis with Albuquerque, NM and Madison, WI weather data to address the following four questions:o1.Assuming a properly designed and controlled passive house, how does total electrical auxiliary energy consumption depend on the choice of peak load blackout periods?2.What comfort penalties arise from properly coping with a variety of peak load blackout periods?3.Where should off-peak energy be introduced into the thermal masses of the house?4.What are the effects of imprecise information on short term future weather? Using a combination of linear programming and gradient techniques, the following conclusions are obtained:. During the worst days of the heating season, passive solar houses built above ground use a substantial amount of peak backup energy even if they are well designed. Even relatively crude off-peak controls provide reasonable comfort provided the energy is introduced in thermal masses well coupled to the room [e.g. 0.05 m (2 inches) beneath the inside face of the Trombe wall or 0.05 m (2 inches) below the top of the slab floor]. Introducing off-peak energy in thermal masses poorly coupled to the room (e.g. deep in the floor slab) makes proper control very difficult without very accurate weather prediction. Reducing backup use to zero from 7 am to 10 pm requires a doubling of daily backup use in Albuquerque and Madison. Excluding backup for shorter periods (e.g. 5 pm to 9 pm) requires an increase of about 25% in daily backup consumption. Even if off-peak energy is stored at points reasonably well coupled to the room, significant backup and comfort penalties are incurred with erroneous weather forecasts. Even in two adjacent days in Madison, reversing the weather patterns while maintaining the same off peak control strategies resulted in either wasting half the backup energy or severely under heating the house. The effects of faulty weather forecasts are more severe when poorly coupled storage sites are used. © 1987 Pergamon Journals Ltd.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; OFF-PEAK ENERGY; PEAK LOAD; PEAK LOAD BLACKOUT; BUILDINGS

Title: ELECTRODES FOR ENERGY STORAGE THROUGH PHOTO-ELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS.

Abstract: Based on a three-electrode system, conversion and storage in situ of solar energy through photoelectrochemical cells are described. Thin films of n-CdS and n-CdSe were used as the photoanode. The possibility of the use of Sb/SbO** minus //2 and Co/Co(OH)//2 as storage electrodes is presented. Principle of storage and factors controlling storage efficiency are discussed.
Index Keywords: CADMIUM COMPOUNDS - Thin Films; ENERGY STORAGE - Components; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; PHOTOANODE; PHOTOELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; STORAGE EFFICIENCY PHOTOANODE; ELECTRODES

Authors: Matsushita T., Suzuki A., Nakau T., Okuda M., Rhee J.C., Naito H.
Title: Effect of Ge addition on Ga-Se-Te system reversible optical recording media
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan; College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Mozu, Osaka, Sakai, 591, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsushita, T., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan; Suzuki, A., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan; Nakau, T., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan; Okuda, M., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Mozu, Osaka, Sakai, 591, Japan; Rhee, J.C., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan; Naito, H., College of Engineering, Osaka Industrial Unversity, Nakagaito, Osaka, Daito, 574, Japan, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Mozu, Osaka, Sakai, 591, Japan
Abstract: A reversible optical storage medium capable of more than 104 write/erase cycles has been realized using a Te0.8(Ga0.05Se0.95)0.2+ 5 wt% Ge film (∼1000 Å). For this composition, a peak temperature of an exothermic curve of 156°C and an activation energy from Kissinger's plot of 2.24 eV were obtained using a differential scanning calorimeter. In this film, a peak of GeTe crystal was identified by X-ray diffraction. To investigate changes of the film surface induced through an annealing (200°C + 100 mW/cm2Xe, ∼1 min), a high resolution SEM observation was carried out; while cracks preventing the high reversibility of write/erase cycles were generated for the GeTe film, the cracks were not recognized for the Te0.8(Ga0.05Se0.95)0.2+ 5 wt%Ge film. © 1987 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: APPLICATION OF HYDROGEN STORAGE ALLOYS TO HYDROGEN FUELED BATTERY SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Japan Metals & Chemicals Co, Tokyo, Jpn, Japan Metals & Chemicals Co, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Baba, Hideo, Japan Metals & Chemicals Co, Tokyo, Jpn, Japan Metals & Chemicals Co, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Metal oxide-hydrogen rechargeable batteries have elicited a great deal of interest recently due to their excellent performance as a rechargeable system. The energy density of some representative conventional rechargeable systems and that of the metal oxide-hydrogen couple are shown. In the case of a hydrogen fueled battery system, hydrogen gas storage space is required in the cell volume. By use of a metal hydride alloy, gas storage space as well as vessel weight can be reduced tremendously with resultant higher energy and volume efficiencies than with other cell couples. In addition to these merits, this system has an excellent charge-discharge cycle life compared with the Ni-Cd couple.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES - Materials; HYDROGEN - Storage; METALS AND ALLOYS - Gases; HYDROGEN FUELED BATTERY; HYDROGEN STORAGE ALLOYS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Close D.J., Peck M.K., Salt H.
Title: Transient response of a packed bed energy store employing a convecting gas vapour mixture
Affiliations: Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Close, D.J., Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia; Peck, M.K., Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia; Salt, H., Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia
Abstract: Low temperature transient operation of a packed bed thermal energy store, employing a convecting gas/vapour mixture to enhance the effective conductivity of the store, is described. Comparisons are made between the transient response of the store and predictions from a computer model which treats heat transfer through the store as a transient, one-dimensional conduction problem. Effective conductivities for the conduction model are obtained from previously measured steady state Nusselt number versus Rayleigh number data for the system. The comparisons show that (a) the simple one-dimensional transient conduction model, useful for system simulation, gives an adequate representation of store behaviour, and (b) the conductivities measured at steady state can be used in the transient model, implying that the high values achieved with gas/vapour mixtures at steady state, apply during transient operation. Further work to develop the storage system, and to improve understanding of the complex processes within it, is described. © 1987 Pergamon Journals Ltd.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; GAS VAPOR MIXTURE; PACKED BED; THERMAL ENERGY STORE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Development of the gel pond technology
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilkins, E.S., Dept. of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States; Lee, T.K., Dept. of Chemical and Nuclear Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, United States
Abstract: A review of the development of the gel pond technology is presented. First, the emergence and growth of solar pond technology since the 1950's is described. The inherent problems encountered with the conventional salt gradient ponds are discussed, leading to the concept of the solar gel pond in which the salt gradient layer in the former is replaced by a transparent polymer gel. The major work in the first phase dealt with the experimental development of a polymer gel which met certain selection criteria. The criteria considered included transmissivity, stability of physical and chemical properties, high viscosity and other physical and optical properties. The gradual development of the polymer gel through an alternating process of testing and elimination and evaluation of relevant properties of the gel has been described. Modeling and optimization studies of the solar gel pond have been presented. Bansal and Kaushik's model for a salt gradient pond has been modified for a solar gel pond, and the results of the simulation are presented in a graphical form to serve as a quick reference for estimation of pond surface area, depth and flow rate for heat extraction depending on the extreme temperature required in the storage zone and the required heat load. Then, a cost-benefit economic analysis compares the economics of a solar gel pond with a conventional salt gradient pond. The construction of an experimental gel pond (18 m2) at The University of New Mexico is described, and the results of the study are summarized. Information on commercial scale ponds at Chamberino, New Mexico (110 m2), and in Albuquerque, New Mexico (400 m2), is provided. The review of the technology demonstrates the immense potential of the gel pond as a source of alternate energy for the years ahead. © 1987 Pergamon Journals Ltd.
Index Keywords: GELS - Applications; GEL POND; GEL SCREENING; SALT-GRADIENT POND; SWELLING RATIO; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Heat pump house heating system with phase change heat storage in the place of auxiliary heating
Affiliations: Institut für Technische Thermodynamik, DFVLR, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Krause, S., Institut für Technische Thermodynamik, DFVLR, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: A house heating system consisting of an "energy roof" (unglazed collector), a heat pump, and medium-term phase change heat storage in the place of auxiliary heating was studied using a simple computer model. The least required storage volume is calculated and discussed as a function of the significant parameters. The choice of water for the storage medium is justified by showing the closeness of its phase change temperature to the economic optimum. The system appears technically feasible and permits minimum fossil fuel consumption together with the associated environmental benefits. Its economic position will depend on future price developments. © 1987 Pergamon Journals Ltd.
Index Keywords: HOUSES - Heating; ELECTRIC HEAT PUMP (EHP); ENERGY ROOF; HOUSE HEATING SYSTEM; MONOVALENT HEATING SYSTEM (MHS); PHASE CHANGE HEAT STORAGE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Sakai Tetsuo, Ishikawa Hiroshi, Oguro Keisuke, Iwakura Chiaki
Title: NICKEL-HYDROGEN BATTERY USING HYDROGEN STORAGE ALLOYS MICROENCAPSULATED WITH COPPER.
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, Tetsuo, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn; Ishikawa, Hiroshi, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn; Oguro, Keisuke, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn; Iwakura, Chiaki, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Ikeda, Jpn
Abstract: The nickel-metal hydride secondary cell is a promising battery for widespread commercial use because it has a higher theoretical energy density than the nickel-cadmium cell and does not contain poisonous materials. Howeer, the capacity decays of hydrogen storage alloy electrodes during the charge-discharge cycling has hindered the further development of this battery. To solve this problem, the authors have developed a microencapsulated hydrogen storage alloy where the surface of the fine particles of the alloys is coated with copper (10-20 wt. %) by a chemical plating method. An electrode using the microencapsulated alloy exhibited several advantages over that using a bare alloy. As a hydrogen storage alloy, LaNi//4//. // 7Al//0//. //3 powder (average particle dimension: 15 microns) was used.

Title: PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING IN A SCANDINAVIAN CLIMATE - THREE HOUSING PROJECTS WITH LOW ENERGY CONSUMPTION.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Eek, Hans
Abstract: By far the greatest proportion of the energy consumed in Sweden is used to provide an acceptable indoor climate. Sweden has an outdoor climate with counterparts only in the other Nordic countries, parts of North America and parts of the USSR. The marked variations between the seasons are characteristic. In order to utilize solar energy for heating, one would preferably wish to store the summer's heat for winter use. In fact, experiments are in progress in Sweden, whereby solar heating is utilized on a large scale and stored in large tanks or rock caverns and in ground clay.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING RESEARCH; RESIDENTIAL BUILDING HEAT SOURCES; HOUSES

Title: SYSTEMS STUDY OF A 100 KW ELECTRODYNAMIC TETHER.
Authors with affiliations: Martinez-Sanchez, M.; Hastings, D.E.
Abstract: This work is a review of the scientific and engineering challenges that need to be overcome in the design of useful electrodynamic power and propulsive tether systems for powers up to 100 KW, and an examination of the comparative performance and cost of the most important applications of such systems. Drag compensation and orbit altitude changes are the main propulsive missions identified; power generation in a stand-alone mode, with rocket force make-up, is shown to offer large fuel savings when compared to fuel cells, but the system mass and complexity are increased due to large magnetic field and electron density fluctuations over one orbit. Energy storage for solar array systems is also a possibility, but is not by itself mass-competitive with conventional battery systems. Ionospheric impedance, contactor performance, insulator fault behavior and tether dynamics are the outstanding technical uncertainties.
Index Keywords: POWER GENERATION - Electrogasdynamic; PROPULSION - Ion Energy; ELECTRODYNAMIC TETHERS; IONOSPHERIC CHARGED PARTICLES; PLASMA CONTACTORS; PROPULSIVE TETHER SYSTEMS; SATELLITES

Authors: Tock R.Wm., Parker H.W., Shafi M., Ethington D.
Title: MASS AND ENERGY BALANCES AROUND ELECTRICAL DISCHARGES AT OIL-WATER INTERFACES.
Affiliations: Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tock, R.Wm., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Parker, H.W., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Shafi, M., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA; Ethington, D., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Abstract: Mass and energy balances were performed around an electrothermal gas generator. The gas was produced by high-voltage, low-amperage ac discharges at a water-oil interface. While most of the dissociation and reforming which occurs is due to thermal fluxes and fast pyrolysis, the electrical current skews the gas composition to components having better electrical conductivity. Mass balances indicated that the oxygen in the water helps prevent amorphous carbon buildup. The liquids surrounding the discharge remain relatively cool and quench the reaction zone. This prevents gross boiling and latent energy losses. Energy balances indicated that it is possible to store electrical energy as chemical energy in an efficient manner. Storage of electrical energy occurs by reformation of saturated carbon-carbon bonds into unsaturated bonds of higher energy levels.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL ANALYSIS - Balances; ENERGY STORAGE; LUBRICATING OILS - Testing; MASS TRANSFER; ENERGY BALANCE; MASS BALANCE; OIL-WATER INTERFACES; ELECTRIC DISCHARGES

Title: STUDIES OF RADIATIVE COOLING SYSTEMS FOR STORING THERMAL ENERGY.
Affiliations: Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn, Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ito, S., Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn, Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn; Miura, N., Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn, Ikutoku Technical Univ, Atsugi, Jpn
Abstract: The thermal performance of an uncovered radiator and a radiative cooling system was investigated experimentally and theoretically. The net radiative power of a black-painted surface at ambient air temperature epsilon q//0 was measured by heat flux plates at night in order to use the results for predicting temperatures of the radiator surface and the fluid in the cooling system on the same night. epsilon q//0 obtained by the measurements was 40-60 W/m**2 on clear nights in the summer and 60-80 W/m**2 in the fall and winter. When the sky was clear, the measured epsilon q//0 agreed well with the estimates obtained from the equation given by Berdahl and Fromberg (1982). The average temperature of the energy storage tank on clear nights became 2-5 degree C below the ambient temperature. The experimental and analytical results agreed well with each other.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER - Performance; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; ENERGY STORAGE TANK; NET RADIATIVE POWER; RADIATIVE COOLING SYSTEMS; THERMAL PERFORMANCE; RADIATORS

Authors: Roucos Salim, Wilgus Alexander, Russell William
Title: SEGMENT VOCODER ALGORITHM FOR REAL-TIME IMPLEMENTATION.

Abstract: Methods are described for reducing computational and storage requirements of the segment vocoder and presents an algorithm that is implementable in real-time on hardware containing several DSP chips such as the TMS320 or DSP32. The segment vocoder algorithm: segment quantization for coding the spectral envelope and the quantization algorithms for pitch and energy contours is described. A tree-structured codebook that decreases computations in segment quantization is presented. The authors describe the method for coding speech at a fixed rate and discuss the trade-off delay, computational rate, and output speech quality. The coder delay, when implemented in hardware using several digital signal-processor chips, is expected to be approx. 0. 5 s.

Authors: Faith D.S., Kirby M.L., Sickles D.W.
Title: Carbohydrate, lipid and oxidative metabolism in the sympathetically aneural chick heart
Source title: Journal of Molecular and Cellular Cardiology
Affiliations: Department of Anatomy, Medical College of Georgia, Augusta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Faith, D.S., Department of Anatomy, Medical College of Georgia, Augusta, GA, United States; Kirby, M.L., Department of Anatomy, Medical College of Georgia, Augusta, GA, United States; Sickles, D.W., Department of Anatomy, Medical College of Georgia, Augusta, GA, United States
Abstract: Ablation of premigratory trunk neural crest over somites 10 through 20 gives rise to chick hearts which lack sympathetic innervation. Norepinephrine, the neurotransmitter of the postganglionic sympathetic nerves, increases the rate of formation of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in cells. Cyclic AMP the modulator of certain key enzymes of metabolism, was decreased in sympathetically-aneural hearts. Six histochemical assays were used to investigate the metabolic profile of sympathetically aneural hearts as compared to control hearts. NADH-tetrazolium reductase activity (indicator of oxidative metabolism), glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase activity (indicator of glycolytic rate), β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase (indicator of β-oxidation of fatty acids), and oil red 0 assay (neutral lipid content) each demonstrated no difference between aneural and control hearts. Periodic acid-Schiff method for glycogen content, indicated greater stores of glycogen in aneural hearts compared to controls. α-Glucan phosphorylase, an enzyme responsible for glycogen hydrolysis, showed less activity in aneural hearts than in controls. The results indicate that the sympathetically aneural heart's metabolism is altered by decreased capability in the maximal rate of glycogen breakdown (decreased phosphorylase Vmax) and subsequent increased storage of the glycogen substrate. Enzymes of other energy transformation pathways were unaltered in the absence of sympathetic nerves. © 1987 Academic Press Inc. (London) Limited.
Author Keywords: Chick embryo; Developing heart; Metabolism; Sympathetic innervation

Authors: Haberal M., Oner Z., Bayraktar U., Bilgin N.
Title: The use of silver nitrate-incorporated amniotic membrane as a temporary dressing
Affiliations: Burn Center, Hacettepe University Hospital and the Turkish Transplantation, Burn Foundation, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Haberal, M., Burn Center, Hacettepe University Hospital and the Turkish Transplantation, Burn Foundation, Ankara, Turkey; Oner, Z., Burn Center, Hacettepe University Hospital and the Turkish Transplantation, Burn Foundation, Ankara, Turkey; Bayraktar, U., Burn Center, Hacettepe University Hospital and the Turkish Transplantation, Burn Foundation, Ankara, Turkey; Bilgin, N., Burn Center, Hacettepe University Hospital and the Turkish Transplantation, Burn Foundation, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Human ammotic membrane is one of the most effective biological dressings used in burn treatment. Since 1978, we have been using human amniotic membrane incorporating 0·5 per cent silver nitrate. Studies in 96 patients using this method showed that the silver-incorporated membranes gave a better therapeutic effect than plain amniotic membranes. It was noted that 0·5 per cent silver nitrate incorporated into the membranes increased their manageability, provided easier application to the burned area and created a bactericidal effect, therefore reducing the risk of contamination and infection. One of the main advantages of wound coverage with amniotic membrane is that it does not appear to discourage re-epithelization, reduces fluid, protein, heat and energy loss, increases mobility and most important this may be the ideal wound cover next to the patient's own skin. Therefore, we highly recommend the use of 0·5 per cent silver nitrate-incorporated amniotic membrane, since it is readily available and freely obtainable has low preparation and storage costs that make it an ideal dressing to use especially in countries where economic factors prevent the purchase of other types of dressings. © 1987.

Title: Cord transferrin and ferritin values in newborn infants at risk for prenatal uteroplacental insufficiency and chronic hypoxia
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology, University of Minnesota School of Medicine, Minneapolis, MN, United States; Division of Gastroenterology, University of Minnesota School of Medicine, Minneapolis, MN, United States; Division of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, Children's Hospital of St. Paul, MN, United States

Abstract: We measured cord transferrin and ferritin levels in 50 newborn infants with fetal conditions associated with either uteroplacental vascular insufficiency or chronic hypoxia. Sixteen small for gestational age infants, 21 infants of mothers with preeclampsia, and 13 symptomatic infants of diabetic mothers had significantly higher transferrin levels and lower ferritin levels and calculated iron stores than did asymptomatic gestational age-matched control infants without these conditions. Cord ferritin levels and calculated iron stores were significantly lower in the infants of diabetic mothers than in any other group of infants. Cord transferrin levels were inversely correlated with ferritin levels (r=-0.59, P<0.001) and were unrelated to transthyretin levels and birth weight in the high-risk infants, but were positively correlated with ferritin levels (r=0.50, P<0.001), transthyretin levels (r=0.65, P<0.001), and birth weight (r=0.75, P<0.001) in the control infants. We conclude that cord transferrin levels do not reflect protein-energy status in newborn infants with prenatal histories suggesting uteroplacental insufficiency or chronic hypoxia, and that when associated with decreased cord ferritin levels, indicate possible impaired iron stores in these infants. © 1987 The C. V. Mosby Company.

Title: Structure and neural control of the pectoralis in pigeons: Implications for flight mechanics
Affiliations: Department of Biologigcal Sciences, Northern Arizona University, Flagstaff, Arizona, 86011, United States; Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Museum of Comparative Zoology, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 02138, United States; Muscum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 02138, United States

Abstract: The pectoralis muscle in pigeons (Columba livia) is composed of two heads (sternobrachialis, thoracobrachialis) that are separately innervated and have different fiber orientations. High‐speed film and electromyographic studies of free‐flying pigeons reveal that the pectoralis is activated prior to wing depression (the power stroke) and that its two heads are differentially recruited during takeoff, level flight, and landing. The elecrical activity patterns of both heads support an interpretation that intramuscular elasticity provides energy storage. The pectoralis is not only the prime wing depressor but is also capable of adjusting the excursion of the wing during different phases of flight. Copyright © 1987 Wiley‐Liss, Inc.

Authors: Schömig A., Fischer S., Kurz T., Richardt G., Schömig E.
Title: Nonexocytotic release of endogenous noradrenaline in the ischemic and anoxic rat heart: Mechanism and metabolic requirements
Affiliations: Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schömig, A., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany; Fischer, S., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany; Kurz, T., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany; Richardt, G.; Schömig, E.
Abstract: The release of endogenous noradrenaline and its deaminated metabolite dihydroxyphenylglycol in the myocardium have been studied in the isolated perfused heart of the rat subjected to three models of energy depletion: ischemia, anoxia, and cyanide intoxication. Anoxia and cyanide intoxication were combined with substrate deficiency at constant perfusion flow. All three energy-depleting procedures caused a similar overflow of noradrenaline which, following a constant delay of 10 minutes without increased release, amounted to more than 25% of total heart content within 40 minutes. This noradrenaline overflow was not diminished in the absence of extracellular calcium and was inhibited by the uptake1 blocker desipramine in all three experimental models, indicating a common and nonexocytotic release mechanism. In the presence of glucose, neither anoxia nor cyanide intoxication resulted in a measurable noradrenaline overflow. Conversely, blockade of glycolysis or glucose depletion prior to ischemia or cyanide poisoning accelerated the noradrenaline overflow, demonstrating a key role of the sympathetic nerve cells' energy status in causing nonexocytotic catecholamine release. Blockade of energy metabolism in the presence of oxygen (cyanide model) resulted in the overflow of high amounts of dihydroxyphenylglycol that was not inhibited by uptake1 blockade. The release of the lipophilic dihydroxyphenylglycol by diffusion reflects deamination of axoplasmic noradrenaline by monoamine oxidase. Since saturation of the enzyme could be excluded in this model dihydroxyphenylglycol release can be taken as a mirror of cytoplasmic noradrenaline concentration. The results obtained by these studies indicate that nonexocytotic catecholamine release is a two-step process induced by energy deficiency in the sympathetic varicosity. In a first step, noradrenaline is lost from storage vesicles, resulting in increasing axoplasmic concentrations. The second step is the rate-limiting transport of intracellular noradrenaline across the cell membrane by the uptake1 carrier that has reversed its normal net transport direction.
Index Keywords: 3,4 dihydroxyphenylethylene glycol; cyanide; noradrenalin; animal experiment; etiology; heart; heart muscle ischemia; ischemia; nonhuman; priority journal; rat

Title: Expenditure and storage of energy in man
Affiliations: Metabolic Unit, Department of Medicine, University of Vermont, Burlington, VT 05405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sims, E.A.H., Metabolic Unit, Department of Medicine, University of Vermont, Burlington, VT 05405, United States; Danforth Jr., E., Metabolic Unit, Department of Medicine, University of Vermont, Burlington, VT 05405, United States
Abstract: We have described two counterbalancing mechanisms that affect energy balance in man. The one tends to limit storage of energy as fat by promoting the dissipation of nonessential dietary calories and tends to preserve mobility. It appears to be largely under control of the sympathetic nervous system. The other promotes storage of dietary fat in the form of fat, and tends to protect in time of famine. These two mechanisms operate in varying proportions in the heterogeneous animal that is man. The predominance of the second mechanism of fat storage and the insulin resistance that often accompanies it is associated with modern lifestyles and is closely related to the byproducts of obesity, hypertension, non-insulin-dependent diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Continued research into the factors controlling these two main mechanisms is therefore of prime importance.
Index Keywords: adrenergic system; autonomic nervous system; cardiovascular system; diabetes mellitus; endocrine system; energy balance; fat intake; human; hyperlipidemia; hypertension; obesity; priority journal; review

Abstract: Conventional portal films taken with high energy x rays are severely impaired by poor image quality, and many attempts have been made to overcome this problem. A new technology, computed radiographic imaging, has been investigated as a means of producing images taken with 6 and 10 MV x rays. The computed radiographic imaging (CRI) system is based on the principle of laser stimulated luminescence induced in an image receptor plate exposed to ionizing radiation, and direct conversion of the light into digital form. Image processing using contrast enhancement and unsharp masking yields images at least as good as the best portal films obtainable with conventional commercial radiotherapy cassettes. Additionally, CRI offers advantages of reduced image size and digital storage. The system is capable of producing normal film densities over an extremely wide range of exposure. © 1985, American Institute of Physics for the National Institute of Standards and Technology. Abstract: Exercise and work potential of a patient with coexistent myophosphoryhse and myoadenylate deaminase (AMPDA) deficiency was compared with that of three patients with myophosphorylase deficiency alone. The patient with the combined defect failed to produce an abnormal rise in serum ammonia or hypoxanthine as seen in the other patients after forearm exercise. Maximum oxygen consumption and work rates during cycle egometer testing were similar in all patients, but well below controls. The occurrence of two defects involving short-term energy metabolism in muscle presents an opportunity to define further the metabolic role of AMPDA. © 1987 American Academy of Neurology.

Abstract: An electron-beam transport system is described that consists of a sectional focusing solenoid and a pulse power system based on a capacitive storage device. The solenoid has main sections 0. 25 m in diam and 0. 3 m long and correcting sections 0. 44 m in diam and 0. 1 m long. The induction-pulse amplitude is 6 T, for which the relative deformation of a section is less than equivalent to 6 multiplied by (times) 10** minus **6. The capacitive storage device, which has an energy capacity of 9. 7 MJ, is made up of units each of which consists of 12 IS-5-200 capacitors, a charging circuit, and a thyristor commutator.

Title: A vapour re-compression heat pump using liquidised CaCl2/H2O/NH3 and CaCl2/NaSCN/NH3 systems for thermochemical energy storage

Abstract: This work was concenned with building and testing a prototype heat pump which incorporated thermochemical energy storage. The heat pump was designed to utilise the cheap 'Economy 7' electric tariff. Ammonia was used as the refrigerant and ambient air as a heat source. This heat pump featured two-stage compression and incorporated a liquidised CaCl2 absorbent. The use of a liquidised absorbent system improved the heat and mass transfer and simplified the construction of the generator/absorber of the heat pump. Both heat pumping and regeneration phases were demonstrated. Experimental tests on liquidised absorbent systems are described together with an analysis of the results. © 1987.

Title: Gliding motility of Mycoplasma sp. nov. strain 163K
Affiliations: Institut fur Mikrobiologie und Tierseuchen, Tierarztliche Hochschule Hannover, D-3000 Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rosengarten, R., Institut fur Mikrobiologie und Tierseuchen, Tierarztliche Hochschule Hannover, D-3000 Hannover, Germany; Kirchhoff, H., Institut fur Mikrobiologie und Tierseuchen, Tierarztliche Hochschule Hannover, D-3000 Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The gliding movements of Mycoplasma sp. nov. strain 163K cells were characterized by photomicrographic and microcinematographic studies. The capability of gliding proved to be a very stable property of strain 163K. Cells were continuously moving, without interruption by resting periods, on glass as well as on plastic surfaces covered with liquid medium. Gliding cells always moved in the direction of their headlike structure; their course did not indicate any preference for a certain direction. Under appropriate growth conditions, cells showed linear and circular movements. Under inadequate conditions, cells glided in narrow circles or entered into zigzag trembling and tumbling movements. Organisms glided as single cells, in pairs, and in multicellular configurations. Movement patterns and gliding velocity were significantly affected by the cultivation and preparation time, the medium viscosity, and the storage and observation temperature. The number of passages on artificial media and the composition of the media used did not have a striking influence on gliding motility, but movements were effectively inhibited by homologous antiserum. The data obtained suggest that at least some of the structures associated with gliding are heat sensitive and located on the cell surface, that the gliding mechanism requires an intact energy metabolism, and, finally, that gliding motility is an extremely stable genetic property of Mycoplasma sp. nov. strain 163K.
Index Keywords: Mycoplasma; nonhuman; priority journal; Mycoplasma; Mycoplasma sp.

Title: MELTING WITHIN A HORIZONTAL CYLINDER: EFFECTS OF SUBCOOLING AND NATURAL CONVECTION.

Abstract: This paper numerically models the heat transfer process involved in the melting of a subcooled phase change material in a horizontal cylinder, subjected to a constant wall temperature. The scheme considers the time-varying shapes of the solid and melt domains and natural convection in the liquid zone. It solves for the temperature profiles in both domains, the time-dependent interface positions and natural convection velocity distribution. This model was used to study the effect of variation of subcooling within the range of application in solar energy storage devices.

Abstract: Thermal stratification in a horizontal water tank simulating the thermal storage for a solar thermosyphon water heating system was investigated experimentally in two load flow plumbing configurations and for six periodically varying load flow rates (53 to 450 ml/s left bracket 0. 84 to 7. 0 gpm right bracket ). Twenty percent of the tank volume was withdrawn in each one-half hour period. Results are compared to results from an earlier study in which continuous withdrawal flow rates were used. Performance improvements are noted for the higher flow rates due to the restoring effect of the thermosyphon heating when the load flow is interrupted.

Authors with affiliations: Klaassens, J.Ben, Delft Univ of Technology, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Neth; Moize de Chateleux, W.L.F.H.A., Delft Univ of Technology, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Neth; van Wesenbeeck, M.P.N., Delft Univ of Technology, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Neth
Abstract: A method for decreasing the ripple on the output voltage of high-power ac-dc or dc-dc series resonant converters without increasing the internal converter frequency or the capacity of the energy storage elements is discussed. This improvement is accomplished by subdividing the converter into two or more series-resonant power modules. The power modules are operated with a constant relative phase shift (phase-staggering control). The elimination of the harmonic components in the input and output currents of the conversion system without increasing the internal pulse frequency is justified by Fourier analysis of the current waveforms. The frequency spectra of the source and output waveforms for the continuous and discontinuous resonant current mode are shifted to higher frequency ranges for both a single module and paralleled modules. Inadequacies in the phase-staggering control method applied to series-resonant converters are indicated. The control method decreases the rms current through the input and output capacitors of the converter and the losses in the indicated components, which is advantageous for low-voltage, high-current applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE - Control; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS - Resonance; PARALLELED POWER MODULES; PHASE STAGGERING CONTROL; SERIES-RESONANT DC-DC CONVERTER; CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES

Authors: Cheng T.S., Parekh J.P., Tuan H.S.
Title: ENERGY STORAGE EFFECT IN MSSW METAL-FINGER REFLECTIONS.
Source title: IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium Digest
Affiliations: Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, T.S., Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA; Parekh, J.P., Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA; Tuan, H.S., Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA
Abstract: Experimental results are presented on the magnetostatic-surface-wave (MSSW) scattering properties of a grating of metal fingers placed at a variable height above the YIG (yttrium iron garnet) film and are compared with theory. The agreement is excellent if energy storage at the metal-finger edges is taken into account and if the width of the metal fingers is larger than the YIG-film thickness. It is concluded that for smaller finger widths the interaction between the edges of a metal finger must be incorporated in the theory. The present results are significantly different from those for the scattering of magnetostatic forward volume waves (MSFVWs) by a grating of metal fingers.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; GARNETS; FINGER WIDTHS; MAGNETOSTATIC FORWARD VOLUME WAVES; MAGNETOSTATIC-SURFACE-WAVE; METAL FINGERS; YIG; MAGNETOSTATICS

Title: SIMPLE MODEL FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE OF PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS. AN APPLICATION IN SOLAR REFRIGERATION SYSTEM.

Authors with affiliations: Onyejekwe, D.C., Univ Paris XII, Evry, Fr, Univ Paris XII, Evry, Fr; Grignon, M., Univ Paris XII, Evry, Fr, Univ Paris XII, Evry, Fr
Abstract: We present a simple, rapid and sufficiently precise model based on the global energy balance technique for solving heat transfer problems for low temperature applications of a mixture of salt/water eutectic materials undergoing liquid-solid phase changes. The result of the model is compared to that of the finite element method and then verified against the experimental results of the NaCl/H//2O eutectic at a temperature of application ( minus 18 degree C). The effect of natural convection in a rectangular cavity during sensible cooling and fusion is considered.

Abstract: A solid-gas reaction of ammonium thiocyanate (NH4SCN) and ammonia produces liquid ammoniate (NH4SCN·nNH3). The region of the liquid phase and the equilibrium properties of the ammoniate have been determined. Crystalization of the ammoniate was not observed, though the liquid was cooled to - 10°C. The enthalpy changes in the liquid phase were also estimated. Accordingly, this system has a wide range of liquid phase and offers a medium for thermal energy storage or a chemical heat pump system. © 1987.

Authors: Carpio J., Lopez M., Valcarcel M.
Title: MODEL TO SOLVE THE WEEKLY PLANNING PROBLEM IN A HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEM WITH PUMP STORAGE AND SAFETY CONSTRAINTS.
Affiliations: Lab Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, Madrid, Spain, Lab Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, Madrid, Spain

Abstract: A model is presented for hour-by-hour generation planning for periods of a week or longer (up to one year). The operation cost associated with the failure of thermal units can be taken into account. Overloading in tie lines between zones is avoided both in the case of normal operation and in case of failure of a thermal unit. Weekly scheduling is carried out using hydro and pump-storage energy with the constraints required to reduce the number of thermal units needed.

Title: THEORETICAL EVALUATION OF CONSOLIDATED ROD TEMPERATURE IN SPENT FUEL STORAGE CANISTER.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Kaiser Engineers Inc, Oakland, CA,, USA, Kaiser Engineers Inc, Oakland, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Y.J., Kaiser Engineers Inc, Oakland, CA,, USA, Kaiser Engineers Inc, Oakland, CA, USA
Abstract: An analytical method has been developed to calculate the cladding temperature of disassembled spent fuel rods in a dry storage canister. This method solves the two-dimensional, steady-state heat transfer of coupled conduction and radiation phenomena among closely compacted rods with an equilateral triangular pitch arrangement in a rectangular canister. A two-dimensional Laplace equation is solved by the collocation method to evaluate the conductive heat transfer relationship between rods and the radiant heat transfer relationship between rods is simplified by assuming that the reflected energy returns to the originated surface. The equations governing the conservation of energy among rods and canister surface can be solved by Newton-Raphson iteration method. A sample calculation has been presented utilizing the computer code developed based on this analytical method.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS; HEAT TRANSFER - Conduction; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; CONSOLIDATED ROD TEMPERATURE; NEWTON-RAPHSON ITERATIVE METHOD; SPENT FUEL STORAGE CANISTER; NUCLEAR REACTORS
