Abstract: Optimum parameters of the SCR turnoff model are extracted from a set of recovered charge curves and another set of reverse energy-loss curves given so that the curves may be fitted over a wide range of di/dt zero current and peak forward SCR current I//f just before its current reversal. In the parameter extraction the storage time and the ratio of fall time to storage time were assumed to be functions of di/dt and I//f. For various SCRs, the extracted parameters fit both sets of the above-mentioned curves within an error of 8% over a 1:100 ratio of di/dt at zero current and over 1:4 ratio of I//f.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Current; OPTIMUM PARAMETER DETERMINATION; RECOVERED CHARGE CURVES SET; REVERSE ENERGY-LOSS CURVES; SILICON-CONTROLLED RECTIFIER (SCR); TURNOFF MODEL; ELECTRIC RECTIFIERS

Title: FACTORS AFFECTING THE PERFORMANCE OF ROCKSTORAGES AS SOLAR ENERGY COLLECTION/STORAGE SYSTEMS FOR GREENHOUSES.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh,, NC, USA, North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Willits, D.H., North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh,, NC, USA, North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, NC, USA; Peet, M.M., North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh,, NC, USA, North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, NC, USA
Abstract: Data from 6 years operation were analyzed in order to identify important factors affecting the performance of rockstorages as devices for saving energy and enhancing CO//2 enrichment in greenhouses. The data were taken from two similar rockstorages of slightly different design attached to two different size greenhouses. The data included seasons conducted with four different crops (lettuce, peas, tomatoes, and cucumbers), two different covers (single fiberglass and double polyethylene), with and without CO//2 enrichment, systems of two sizes with similar wind exposures, and systems of the same size with different wind exposures. Fuel savings using the rockstorages ranged from a low of 54. 8 MJ/m**2 in the winter of 1981 to a high of 143. 3 MJ/m**2 in the spring of 1979. Percentage enrichment time ranged from 64. 3% for the spring of 1984 to 100% in the winter of 1981, up to 45% more enrichment time than conventionally enriched treatments. Electrical energy debit, the additional electricity required to operate the rockstorages, ranged from 9. 5 MJ/m**2 to 34. 6 MJ/m**2 whereas collection efficiency varied from 8. 0% to 19. 3%. Equations for fuel savings, percentage enrichment time, electrical consumption increase, and collection efficiency were determined from the data and evaluated to provide a basis for comparing the effects of important seasonal differences.
Index Keywords: CARBON DIOXIDE - Agricultural Applications; FUEL ECONOMY; GREENHOUSES - Heating; HEATING - Heat Storage; CARBON DIOXIDE ENRICHMENT; DUMPING OPERATION; ROCKBED HEAT STORAGE; ROCKSTORAGE PERFORMANCE; SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: CONTRIBUTION TO THE POWER PROCESSING OF PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr, Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Braunstein, A., Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr, Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr; Singer, S., Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr, Tel-Aviv Univ, Isr
Abstract: The power flow between a photovoltaic (PV) array, the load, and an energy storage system is studied. The PV system operation is analyzed in a matched and nonmatched model. A general model of a matching system composed of a power-processing unit and a signal-processing circuit is presented. The matching system ensures PV system operation at its maximum power point, with optimum energy utilization and efficiency. As an illustration, the operation of a motor powered by a PV array is discussed. Higher starting torques and better efficiencies are obtained by using matching systems.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS, DC; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS; PV ARRAY-LOAD MATCHING; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors with affiliations: Thaller, L.H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, USA
Abstract: The higher power and higher voltage levels anticipated for future space missions have required a careful review of the techniques currently in use to preclude battery problems that are related to the dispersion characteristics of the individual cells. The Lewis Research Center is involved with several non-traditional electrochemical storage concepts including bipolar nickel-hydrogen, regenerative hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells, and hydrogen-bromine systems and, based on this involvement and familiarity with methods used to monitor and control nickel-cadmium, nickel-hydrogen, and some preliminary methods of making usable sodium sulfur batteries, a number of general principles have evolved which help the system designer of possible energy storage systems.

Abstract: The thermodynamic performance of some representative CAES (Compressed Air Energy Storage) plant configurations is computed both at steady-state nominal point and during time-variable conditions, by making use of a simulation technique capable of accounting for thermal inertia of recuperators and TES (Thermal Energy Storage), for part-load characteristics of turbomachinery and for power regulation modes. The results of the analysis are presented in terms of the energy losses caused by the irreversibilities occurring in the various plant components, with reference to the second law of thermodynamics.

Authors with affiliations: Sabayo, M.R., Department of Metallurgical Engineering, Mehran University of Engineering and Technology, Jamshoro, Sind, Pakistan
Abstract: An attempt has been made to discuss various design aspects of the coal gasification plant for the developing country on effective utilization of coal as a fuel there, where coal is used at the moment as the energy raw material for local cement, lime and brick manufacturers. This includes economic exploitation, economic justification and the IGCC technology proving to be an effective method of coal utilization and environmentally safe and clean design. The present work suggests the material with higher resistance to minimise crack failure for the transportation, storage and utilization of hydrogen fuels desired there. For this the soft soldered composite laminates made from 4340 steel were tested under plane strain conditions in the environments of hydrogen especially at 700 torr. This all is supported by the fracture behaviour of the soft soldered composite laminates which remains same with and without hydrogen during final stage of fracture there. © 1987.

Abstract: The concept of a forced stratified thermal energy storage tank which has multiple compartments divided by insulating and permeable horizontal plates is proposed for energy conservation. Performance of this tank is evaluated by a relatively simple evaluation method and compared with the ideal perfect stratified thermal energy storage tank and perfect mixed thermal energy storage tank. It is suggested that the performance of the forced stratified thermal energy storage tank is high and nearly comparable with the perfect stratified thermal energy storage tank.

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 10 papers presenting results of current research being performed on heat transfer through building envelope materials, within structures and between a structure and its environment. Topics range from heat transfer through building insulation materials to thermal simulations of complete structures. Improved methods of experimental measurement, analytical modeling of heat transport within materials and thermal system simulation are reported.

Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de, Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia, Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia
Authors with affiliations: Hamdi, S., Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de, Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia, Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia; Eckhoff, S.R., Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de, Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia, Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia; Spillman, C.K., Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de, Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia, Ecole Superieure des Ingenieurs de Genie Rural Madjaz, Elbab, Tunisia
Abstract: Moisture isotherms and activation energies of limestone rocks were determined. The isotherms followed the classical Brunauer-Emeet-Teller (B. E. T. ) sorption theory with v//m equals 0. 233 mg of water per g of rocks. Arrhenius temperature dependence was observed for the temperature dependent coefficient used in the B. E. T. model. The value of c//o in the Arrhenius equation was found to be 8. 114 multiplied by 10** minus **8 for adsorption with DELTA H equal to 44. 418 kJ/mole. Hysteresis was observed with c//o for desorption being 12. 231 multiplied by 10** minus **8.

Title: ELECTRODYNAMIC MODEL FOR THE GET-AWAY TETHER EXPERIMENT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Southeastern Symposium on System Theory
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Greene, M., Auburn Univ, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, AL, USA; Wheelock, D., Auburn Univ, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, AL, USA
Abstract: The planned Get-Away Tether Experiment (GATE) will demonstrate the potential of a low-cost plasma-probe to implement the Alfven engine and Alfven generator characteristics in an anisotropic magnetoplasma. An electrodynamic model of the interaction of the GATE and the ionosphere is developed and analyzed. This model is represented by an equivalent circuit containing collection, emission, and resistive charge flow. The ionosphere completes the circuit by supplying a conductive medium. The circuit model is incorporated into a complete dynamic orbital simulation to predict mission performance. Simulation results show the feasibility to transfer energy between electrical storage and orbital momentum.

Title: THERMAL-HYDRAULIC ANALYSIS OF SPENT FUEL STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rector, D.R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Wheeler, C.L., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Lombardo, N.J., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the COBRA-SFS (Spent Fuel Storage) computer code, which is designed to accurately predict flow and temperature distributions in spent nuclear fuel storage and transportation systems. The decay heat generated by spent fuel in a dry storage cask is removed through a combination of conduction, natural convection, and thermal radiation. One major advantage of COBRA-SFS is that fluid recirculation within the cask is computed directly by solving the mass and momentum conservation equations. In addition, thermal radiation heat transfer is modeled using detailed radiation exchange factors based on quarter-rod segments. The equations governing mass, momentum, and energy conservation for incompressible flows are presented, and the semi-implicit solution method is described. COBRA-SFS predictions are compared to temperature data from a spent fuel storage cask test, and the effect of different fill media on the cladding temperature distribution is discussed. The effect of spent fuel consolidation on cask thermal performance is also investigated.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER AIDED ANALYSIS; HEAT TRANSFER; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; COBRA-SFS COMPUTER CODE; SPENT FUEL STORAGE (SFS); THERMAL-HYDRAULIC ANALYSIS; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Abstract: This report is the result of work carried out by the Systems Group to prepare material needed to assist the Swedish Council for Building Research in drawing up its Programme Plan for Energy Technology for the three-year period 1987-1990. The main objective of the work has been to enable the Swedish Council for Building Research to obtain an overall view of, and to evaluate, other material prepared as raw input data needed in drawing up the programme plan, and produced by various working parties established for the purpose within the energy technology sector. Within the energy technology sector, the Swedish Council for Building Research (BFR) has set up five working parties: solar collectors, heat pumps, heat storage, heat distribution, and systems. These groups reflect a formalisation of the research and development activities for which the Council is responsible.

Title: EXPERIMENTAL INVESTIGATION AND SIMULATION OF BUILDING ENERGY HEATING REQUIREMENTS AND TEMPERATURES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Emery, A.F., Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA; Rodenhizer, D.W., Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA; Kippenhan, C.J., Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA; Heerwagen, D.R., Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this study has been to examine the use of thermal mass in a direct gain, passive solar system in the mostly cloudy climate of the Pacific Northwest. In the study, the measured temperature response has been reported and compared to predictions based upon a thermal network simulation code. The predicted responses are in such good agreement with the measured values that simulation can be used to determine the effect of changes in thermal mass volume, area and properties, and glazing area. The results of the simulation indicate that the use of the optimal storage area to glazing area ratio of 9:1 produces an effective passive solar design. Not only are the daily temperature swings reduced, but the supplementary heating needed to maintain occupant comfort can be reduced by as much as 40%.

Authors: Mcardle J., Wilson T.G., Wong R.C.S.
Title: Effects of Power-Train Parasitic Capacitance on the Dynamic Performance of DC-to-DC Converters Operating in the Discontinuous MMF Mode
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Room 1B326, 260 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, NJ 07054, United States; Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mcardle, J., Bell Laboratories, Room 1B326, 260 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, NJ 07054, United States; Wilson, T.G., Bell Laboratories, Room 1B326, 260 Cherry Hill Road, Parsippany, NJ 07054, United States; Wong, R.C.S., Duke University, Durham, NC, United States
Abstract: A widely observed phenomenon is investigated where a dc- to-dc converter operating in the discontinuous MMF mode with a constant-frequency control law can exhibit wide variations in dynamic performance over a narrow range of input voltage or output load. This behavior is related to the sinusoidal energy exchange between the parasitic capacitances of the power stage and the energy-storage reactor during the discontinuous MMF mode of operation. The resulting ringing can cause dramatic variations in the apparent gain of the power train, thereby affecting the dynamic performance of the power supply. The objective is to provide the power-supply designer with insight into this phenomenon. In this endeavor, a new large-signal computer simulation technique is employed to compare theoretical results with actual measurements. Abstract: Probabilistic production costing methods utilizing the conventional load-duration-oriented probability technique for power systems composed of units having energy limits or time-dependent technologies may fail to capture the energy-limiting factor in the operation of these plant. The segmentation probabilistic technique is used here to model the operation of energy-limited units. Title: Honeycomb roof cover system for passive solar space heating
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, new Delhi, 110016, India; D. J. Post-graduate College, Baraut, Meerut, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushika, N.D., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, new Delhi, 110016, India; Sharma, M.S., D. J. Post-graduate College, Baraut, Meerut, India; Kaul, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, new Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the passive space heating characteristics of an air-filled honeycomb placed on the concrete roof-top of a building. In particular, the solar transmittance and heat losses through the honeycomb cover system have been investigated to estimate the solar collection efficiency and heat retention duration of the system. Numerical calculations are carried out for a typical winter day in New Delhi (28°N). and a relatively colder day in Boulder (40°N). It is found that the honeycomb cover system considerably increases the heat collection efficiency of the roof. It also reduces the nocturnal heat losses to enable longer heat retention. The system is more effective in colder climates. © 1987.
Author Keywords: Honeycomb; Passive solar space heating; Solar collector-cum-storage system; Solar energy; Solar thermal utilization
Index Keywords: PASSIVE SOLAR SPACE HEATING; SOLAR COLLECTOR-CUM-STORAGE SYSTEM; SOLAR THERMAL UTILIZATION; HEATING

Authors: Forsström J.P., Lund P.D., Routti J.T.
Title: Economic analysis of heat storage in energy systems
Affiliations: Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, Espoo, SF-02150, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Forsström, J.P., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, Espoo, SF-02150, Finland; Lund, P.D., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, Espoo, SF-02150, Finland; Routti, J.T., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, Espoo, SF-02150, Finland
Abstract: Thermal energy storage (TES) enables more efficient use of conventional energy conversion plants and enhances the exploitation of renewable energy sources. Storage primarily promotes the replacement of heating oil with less expensive fuels, for instance biomass, coal or industrial waste heat. In this paper, some applications of heat storage for large‐scale and centralized residential heating systems are presented. Analysis methods to estimate the economy of storage in these energy‐systems are also derived. It was estimated that the maximum market potential for short‐ and long‐term heat storage in the present Finnish heat production system would correspond to about 1–1.3 TWh of supplied heat per annum. Copyright © 1987 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Economics of heat storage; Heat storage; Large scale heat storage
Index Keywords: HEATING - District; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; HEAT STORAGE; LARGE SCALE HEAT STORAGE; STORAGE COSTS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES); ENERGY STORAGE

Title: LEAD ACID BATTERY FOR SMALL PHOTOVOLTAIC EQUIPMENT.
Affiliations: VARTA Batterie AG, Hanover, West Ger, VARTA Batterie AG, Hanover, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Leiblein, K.-H., VARTA Batterie AG, Hanover, West Ger, VARTA Batterie AG, Hanover, West Ger
Abstract: Small solar power units have been revealed as an alternative for the electric power supply of vacation homes, especially in remote areas. The solar unit is a noiseless, low-maintenance source of energy and sometimes the only one possible. In most photovoltaic applications, lead-acid batteries, especially those with pasted plates, have proved to be an economical and reliable energy storage device. The new VARTA Solar Battery 82000 is the recommended battery for small solar units. This battery is rated for solar units with a generator power of about 20 to 1,000 Wp and a capacity of approximately 100 to 500 Ah.
Index Keywords: ACIDS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Applications; ELECTRODES - Lead; LEAD ACID BATTERY; VARTA SOLAR BATTERY 82000; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Bell Kenneth R., Johnson Charlie R.
Title: CONTAINMENT OF LOW-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL.
Affiliations: Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD,, USA, Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bell, Kenneth R., Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD,, USA, Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD, USA; Johnson, Charlie R., Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD,, USA, Bechtel Civil Inc, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy has completed a short term storage site for the containment of low-level radioactive residues and contaminated soil near Lewiston, New York. The site, known as the Niagara Falls Storage Site, has been used as a depository for the contaminated material for over four decades. In order to provide positive control against the contamination of groundwater and release of radon gas from the contaminated material, an engineered containment earth structure was designed and has been constructed at the site over the past five years. The containment structure consists of three major elements. The base of the containment is comprised of a naturally occurring heavy gray clay layer. The four sides consist of a compacted clay cutoff wall keyed into the underlying clay. The cutoff wall extends from the gray clay to a minimum of 1. 5 meters above the surrounding grade. After all contaminated soil material and residues were placed inside the 860-metre-long cutoff wall, the 4 hectare containment area was covered with a multi-layered cap which includes a 0. 9 metre compacted clay layer.
Index Keywords: CLAY - Applications; GEOLOGY - New York; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Environmental Impact; SOILS - Permeability; WATER POLLUTION - Underground; CONTAMINATED SOIL STORAGE; GEOTECHNICAL PRACTICE; LOW-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE RESIDUE; NIAGARA FALLS STORAGE SITE; SHORT-TERM STORAGE SITE; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: Comparison of experimental and calculated performance of integral collector-storage solar water heaters
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Center for Building Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fanney, A.H., National Bureau of Standards, Center for Building Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: Experimental measurements of the monthly performance of an integral collector-storage solar water heater for a one-year period are compared with performance predictions using the method of Zollner. The prediction method requires two parameters which were obtained from indoor experiments with a solar simulator. The experimental measurements are also compared with predictions in which the two parameters were obtained from short-term outdoor tests. © 1987.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; INTEGRAL COLLECTOR STORAGE (ICS); SOLAR DOMESTIC HOT WATER (SDHW) SYSTEMS; SOLAR SIMULATOR; TRNSYS SIMULATION PROGRAM; ZOLLNER METHOD; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Bansal N.K., Kumar A., Batra A.K.
Title: Performance equations for a closed-loop water-heating system using a solar air-heating collector
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Bansal, N.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Kumar, A., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Batra, A.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: Performance equations of the HWB type have been derived for a closed-loop water-heating system using a solar air collector. Explicit expressions are given for the collector efficiency and overall heat-loss coefficient. The utility of the performance equations has been established with the help of an experiment in which water is recirculated from a storage tank through the air/water heat exchanger in a closed-loop cycle. © 1987.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; SOLAR ENERGY - Mathematical Models; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; CLOSED-LOOP WATER HEATING SYSTEM; PERFORMANCE EQUATIONS; SOLAR AIR-HEATING COLLECTOR; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Ho-Ming Y., Shau-Wei T., Wang-Tang H.
Title: Time-temperature variations in the storage zone of salt-gradient solar ponds
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Ho-Ming, Y., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Shau-Wei, T., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan; Wang-Tang, H., Department of Chemical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: Simplified equations are derived for the time-temperature variations in the storage zone of salt-gradient solar ponds. The temperature distribution in the nonconvective zone was assumed to be approximately linear with water depth. The theoretical results are easy to use. Time-temperature variations in the storage zone of a salt-gradient solar pond in Tainan have been estimated for 4 yr of operation. Comparisons are described with measurements. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Mathematical Models; HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; SOLAR ENERGY - Taiwan; NONCONVECTIVE SOLAR PONDS; SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: A Second Law analysis of the optimum design and operation of thermal energy storage systems
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krane, R.J., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996-2210, United States
Abstract: Second Law analysis techniques based on the minimization of entropy generation are applied to the optimal design and operation of a sensible heat thermal energy storage system in which the storage element is both heated and cooled by flowing streams of gases. The results of this study show that (1) an entire operational cycle, which consists of a storage process and a removal process, must be considered (as opposed to the storage process alone) in order to optimize the design and performance of such a system; and (2) a typical optimum system destroys approximately 70-90% of the entering availability and, therefore, has an extremely low thermodynamic efficiency. © 1987.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Equipment; SECOND LAW ANALYSIS; STORAGE ELEMENT; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; THERMODYNAMICS

Authors: Webster T.L., Coutier J.P., Place J.W., Tavana M.
Title: Experimental evaluation of solar thermosyphons with heat exchangers
Affiliations: Building Systems Analysis Group, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Webster, T.L., Building Systems Analysis Group, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Coutier, J.P., Building Systems Analysis Group, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Place, J.W., Building Systems Analysis Group, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Tavana, M., Building Systems Analysis Group, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: The advantages of solar thermosyphons in terms of simplicity, reliability and cost have long been recognized. Recent studies have also shown their thermal performance to be comparable with that of equivalent active systems. When pump power is considered, the energy savings of domestic hot water thermosyphons can be significantly superior to active systems. In spite of these advantages, use of solar thermosyphons in the United States is almost negligible compared to their widespread use in other countries. A major limitation to the use of thermosyphons in the United States is lack of effective, reliable freeze protection. One technique for reliable, passive freeze protection is to use a heat exchanger in the storage tank and a nonfreezing fluid in the collector. Previous analytical work indicates that the performance penalty for these systems with practical-sized heat exchangers may be small enough to make these systems economically feasible. A full-scale, residential-size test facility has been constructed for testing this concept and validating the theoretical models. This paper describes results of testing comparing the performance of a horizontal tank with and without heat exchanger to a baseline case of a vertical tank without heat exchanger. An analytical expression for a "heat exchanger penalty factor" for these systems is derived and compared with the experimental results. © 1987.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; FREEZE PROTECTION; PERFORMANCE PENALTY; SOLAR THERMOSYPHONS; TEST FACILITY; WATER HEATERS

Title: Heat Transfer of Latent Thermal Energy Storage Capsules Arranged in Alignment with Fluid Flow. (1st Report Experiments on Heat Transfer Characteristics)
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, T.; Ueda, H.
Abstract: Experiments were performed to obtain data for the heat transfer characteristics of latent thermal energy storage capsules. The arrangement of the capsules was in alignment with the flow direction. During the melting of the phase change material (n-Octadecane), there is less difference in the phase change rate of each capsule than for the solidification case because of the effect of natural convection in the liquid phase on heat transfer. It was also shown that the non-dimensional time required to complete the solidification of each capsule can be arranged without distinction of the rows in the flow direction. © 1987, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aligned Capsules; Convective Heat Transfer; Latent Heat; Phase Change; Thermal Energy Storage
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ALIGNED CAPSULES; ENERGY STORAGE CAPSULES; LATENT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE; FLOW OF FLUIDS

Authors: Hirata T., Ueda H., Fujiwara M.
Title: Heat Transfer of Latent Thermal Energy Storage Capsules Arranged in Alignment with Fluid Flow. (2nd Report Analysis for Solidification Process)
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, T.; Ueda, H.; Fujiwara, M.
Abstract: Analytical considerations were presented for the solidification process of latent thermal energy storage capsules. The arrangement of the capsules was in alignment with the flow direction. It was shown that good agreement between the predicted and the experimental results can be obtained by application of the quasisteady assumption on the solidification process. Numerical calculations for fifty rows of capsules showed that there is a certain location in the rows where the heat transfer rate between the capsules and the flow shows a maximum value, and the location moves to the down-stream rows as time proceeds. © 1987, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aligned Capsules; Analysis; Convective Heat Transfer; Phase Change; Solidification; Thermal Energy Storage
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ALIGNED CAPSULES; SOLIDIFICATION PROCESS; FLOW OF FLUIDS

Title: Chemical reactions on clays
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Liége, Liége, Belgium; Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Laszlo, P., Department of Chemistry, University of Liége, Liége, Belgium, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: Layer aluminosilicates catalyze reactions in numerous ways. They stabilize high-energy intermediates. They can store energy in their lattice structures and can release it in the form of chemical energy. They can catalyze redox reactions and can serve as photocatalytic devices. They often exhibit high surface acidity. Organic reactions that are catalyzed by the agency of days are reviewed. The role of clays in prebiotic chemistry is also examined.
Index Keywords: CATALYSIS; CATALYSTS - Clay; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Catalysis; SURFACE PHENOMENA; ENERGY STORAGE; LAYER ALUMINOSILICATES; ORGANIC REACTIONS; PHOTOCATALYTIC DEVICES; PREBIOTIC CHEMISTRY; CLAY

Title: HEAT TRANSFER MEASUREMENTS FROM A LOAD-SIDE HEAT EXCHANGER IMMERSED IN A STRATIFIED STORAGE TANK.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Farrington, R.B., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the performance of a 'load-side' heat exchanger immersed in a stratified tank designed for use in a solar energy space heating and hot water system. A load-side heat exchanger is one that removes energy from the storage tank by passing cool water through the heat exchanger. The measured heat transfer rate versus time is presented as is the calculated effectiveness as a function of the difference in temperature between the storage tank and the heat exchanger inlet. The effect of changing the storage tank temperature definition on the calculated effectiveness is discussed and a method of using time constants to predict the heat transfer rate of immersed heat exchangers in a stratified tank is presented.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Testing; HEAT TRANSFER - Measurements; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; HEAT FLUX; HEAT TRANSFER AREA; HEAT TRANSFER RATES; LOAD-SIDED HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEATING

Title: DIMENSIONLESS DESIGN FUNCTION FOR THE OPTIMAL DESIGN AND SIZING OF SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Arafa, A.A., Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The largest obstacle for the efficient utilization of solar energy for space heating is the lack of simple optimization techniques. The intricate interrelationship between a multitude of parameters of a solar heating system makes its optimization an uneasy task. The purpose of this study is to provide a reliable but very simple optimization technique which can be utilized without requiring any special skill or equipment. This was done by finding the value of a dimensionless design function (DDF) which shows the maximum values of the system performance as function of the important components and system parameters. The results have shown that the optimal values of the DDF lie on either a straight line or second order equation for different values of V/A (the ratio of storage volume to collector area). These equations will help to calculate optimal values for intermediate and extrapolated values of V/A in addition to the values considered.
Index Keywords: HEATING; DIMENSIONLESS DESIGN FUNCTION; SOLAR ENGINEERING; SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS; HEATING

Title: EXPERIMENTAL AND ANALYTICAL INVESTIGATION OF SOLAR RADIANT FLUX DISTRIBUTION ON INTERIOR SURFACES OF A SUNSPACE.
Affiliations: NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA, NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S.T., NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA, NBS, Gaithersburg, MD, USA
Abstract: The short wave solar radiant flux distribution inside a sun-space model with a large south opening was studied experimentally under clear sky conditions. Miniature photovoltaic pyranometer sensors responsive to short wave radiation were mounted at various locations on the interior surfaces of the enclosure. An NBS developed solar flux distribution program was tested against the experimental results and was found to give good agreement. The computer program can be used as a design tool for the evaluation of thermal storage location and solar physical properties of floor and walls in a passive solar structure.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Radiation; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Mathematical Models; HEAT FLUX; INTERIOR SURFACES; SOLAR RADIANT FLUX; SUNSPACE; BUILDINGS

Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE ELECTROLYZER/FUEL CELL POWER CYCLE: PRELIMINARY DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS.
Affiliations: Univ of South Carolina, Columbia,, SC, USA, Univ of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Morehouse, J.H., Univ of South Carolina, Columbia,, SC, USA, Univ of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, USA
Abstract: A model of a high temperature electrolyzer/fuel cell, hydrogen/oxygen, thermally regenerative power cycle is developed and used to simulate system performance for varying system parameters. Initial estimates of system efficiency, weight, and volume are provided for a one kWe module assuming specific electrolyzer and fuel cell characteristics, both current and future. Specific interest is placed on examining the system responses to changes in device voltage versus current density operating curves, and the associated optimum operating ranges. The performance of a solar-powered, space-based system in low earth orbit is examined in terms of the light-dark periods requiring storage. The storage design tradeoffs between thermal energy, electrical energy, and hydrogen/oxygen mass storage are examined.
Index Keywords: SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; HIGH TEMPERATURE ELECTROLYZER FUEL CELL; SOLAR POWERED SPACE BASED SYSTEMS; THERMALLY REGENERATIVE CYCLE; FUEL CELLS

Title: THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF SOLAR PONDS UNDER HOT CLIMATIC CONDITIONS - ARABIAN GULF.
Affiliations: Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar, Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar
Authors with affiliations: Hassab, M.A., Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar, Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar; Tag, I.A., Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar, Univ of Qatar, Doha, Qatar
Abstract: Collection and storage of solar energy in salt gradient solar ponds under the conditions of high ambient and ground temperatures and all year-round sunny weather are investigated theoretically. A transient model based on measured local environmental conditions (solar insolation, ambient temperature and ground temperature) is developed to predict solar transmission, temperature and salt distributions inside the pond for any day of the year. Erosion of the insulating layer caused by wind generated turbulence in the upper convective zone is considered. Effects of heat dissipation into ground, bottom reflection, pond dimensions, load extraction and variations of the pond's physical properties with temperature and concentration are investigated.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR ENERGY; ARABIAN GULF; HOT CLIMATIC CONDITIONS; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: LABORATORY TESTS OF CLEANING TECHNIQUES FOR IMMISCIBLE SOLAR PONDS.
Affiliations: Univ of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA, Univ of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bathen, K.H., Univ of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA, Univ of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI, USA
Abstract: A series of four solar pond tests, conducted from September 1982 to August 1983, were completed during a previous project to observe the ability of several immiscible fluids to absorb and store solar energy. The change in heat storage performance and fluid characteristics, i. e. spectral transmittance, vertical stability, biocide impact and clarity, were examined following prolonged exposure to sunlight, wind and the addition of ambient dust and debris. These tests were continued from September 1983 to May 1984 examining techniques of cleaning and maintaining pond clarity without disturbing pond stratification or causing a significant loss of heat.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL PROPERTIES; SOLAR ENERGY; CLEANING TECHNIQUES; HEAT STORAGE PERFORMANCE; SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE; SPECTRAL TRANSMITTANCE; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Nikaido M., Takeno Sadamasa, Kurioka Hitoshi
Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY ON A SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR POND.
Affiliations: Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Nikaido, M., Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Takeno, Sadamasa, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn; Kurioka, Hitoshi, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: An experimental salt-gradient solar pond with a new type of exchanger was built on an island at lat. 25 degree N, and operated to examine heat collection, heat storage and heat extraction. The purpose was to clarify the correspondence between the analytical results and actual measured values and to collect basic data for design. From the experimental study, how to construct the initial density gradient of the solar pond, how to keep the pond clear, and the performance of the salt-gradient solar pond were investigated. Analytical results of the temperature inside the pond from a simulation were found to be similar to the test results.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; SOLAR ENERGY; CONVECTIVE AND NON-CONVECTIVE; EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR POND; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: IDENTIFICATION OF SALT-ALLOY COMBINATIONS FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE APPLICATIONS IN ADVANCED SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Whittenberger, J.D., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA; Misra, A.K., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Thermodynamic calculations based on the available data for fluoride salt systems reveal that a number of congruently melting compositions and eutectics exist which have the potential to meet the lightweight, high energy storage requirements imposed for advanced solar dynamic systems operating between approximately 1000 and 1400 K. Compatibility studies to determine suitable containment alloys to be used with NaF-22CaF//2-13MgF//2, NaF-32CaF//2 and NaF-23MgF//2 have been conducted at the eutectic temperature plus 25 K for each system. For these three NaF-based eutectics, none of the common, commercially available high temperature alloys appear to offer adequate corrosion resistance for a long life time; however mild steel, pure nickel, and Nb-1Zr could prove useful. These latter materials suggest the possibility that a strong, corrosion resistant, nonrefractory, elevated temperature alloy based on the Ni-Ni//3Nb system could be developed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; ADVANCED SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEMS; FLUORIDE SALT SYSTEMS; SPACE POWER SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF THE EFFECT OF WATER EXTRACTION ON THERMAL STRATIFICATION IN STORAGE.
Affiliations: Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wu, L., Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA; Bannerot, R.B., Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: Thermal stratification in a horizontal water tank simulating the thermal storage for a solar thermosyphon water heating system was investigated experimentally in two load flow plumbing configurations and for eight continuous load flow rates (30 to 450 ml/s left bracket 0. 5 to 7 gpm right bracket ). The flow entered and exited through standard three-quarter inch pipe nipples welded to the exterior of the tank. Stratification was characterized by a newly defined stratification coefficient and by an extraction efficiency. Stratification was preserved in the tank for load flow rates of less than about 60 ml/s left bracket approximately equals 1 gpm right bracket . While initially fairly stable, stratification was significantly degradated after one to two total tank volume exchanges in the flow rate range of 60 to 200 ml/s left bracket 1 to 3 gpm right bracket . Stratification was quickly eroded for higher flow rates. The stratification coefficient was correlated with a Reynolds number and a Grashof number and regimes of stratification were identified.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Testing; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR THERMOSYPHON WATER HEATING SYSTEM; STRATIFICATION; THERMAL STORAGE; HEATING

Authors: Smith D.C., Saloff S.A., Staed T.P.
Title: DESIGN AND TESTING OF AN ADVANCED MOLTEN SALT CENTRAL RECEIVER.
Affiliations: Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH,, USA, Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.C., Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH,, USA, Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH, USA; Saloff, S.A., Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH,, USA, Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH, USA; Staed, T.P., Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH,, USA, Babcock & Wilcox, Barberton, OH, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the design and planned testing of a solar central receiver using molten nitrate salt as a heat exchange fluid. Design studies for large commercial plants (30-100 MWe) have shown molten salt to be an excellent fluid for solar thermal plants as it allows for efficient thermal storage. The paper describes: the configuration of the receiver, the design and sizing of the heat absorption surface, the structure and supporting systems, and the methods for control. Test plans for the receiver are described including the objectives and operational tests to be performed.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; ADVANCED MOLTEN SALT CENTRAL RECEIVER; MOLTEN NITRATE SALT; WORKING FLUIDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: PROTOTYPE SOLAR HEATING SYSTEM FOR POWERING AN ABSORPTION COOLING MACHINE.
Affiliations: Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Arafa, A.A., Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this work is to investigate the reliability of utilizing a concentrating solar collector for powering an absorption cooling machine, in Stuttgart, West Germany. Two fiber glass cylindrical troughs with 3-M aluminum foil as the reflector were used as concentrating collectors. The tilt of the collectors can be adjusted manually by a gear rack while the whole frame of the collectors tracks the sun automatically around a vertical axis. A 200 liter tank was used as storage. These collectors can be connected either in parallel or in series. The system was tested and monitored showing that the temperature in the storage tank did not exceed 180 degree C and the efficiency of the collectors did not drop below 50%. The system efficiency however, did not exceed 20% due to the high heat losses from the pipes, armatures and storage tank.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Federal Republic of Germany; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ABSORPTION COOLING MACHINE; SOLAR COOLING; SOLAR HEATING SYSTEM; HEATING

Authors: Sedgwick L., Nordwall H., Kaufmann K., Werner D., Cohen S.
Title: SOLAR DYNAMIC RECEIVER DESIGNS FOR SPACE APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sedgwick, L., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Nordwall, H., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Kaufmann, K., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Werner, D., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA; Cohen, S., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Electric power generation equipment for future space missions will require large capacity, long operating life, low cost, and high reliability with a minimum of on-orbit maintenance. Solar dynamic electrical power generation will meet these requirements if properly developed. This paper describes the development of solar dynamic heat receiver and thermal energy storage configurations designed to supply 25 kilowatts of electrical power. Separate receiver designs are developed for a single-phase closed Brayton and a two-phase organic Rankine thermodynamic power cycle. Results of trade study analyses provide data necessary to rank and compare the preliminary designs.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Space Applications; SPACE RESEARCH; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; SOLAR DYNAMIC RECEIVER; SOLAR POWER; SPACE POWER SYSTEMS; SPACE PLATFORMS

Title: ADVANCED SOLAR-POWERED CLOSED BRAYTON CYCLE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ,, USA, Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pietsch, A., Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ,, USA, Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ, USA; Heath, B., Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ,, USA, Garrett Fluid Systems Co, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: The highest-temperature component in solar dynamic power systems is the thermal receiver which limits the maximum operating temperature of these systems. The design of a solar receiver may be complicated by the incorporation of thermal energy storage (TES) to provide continuous engine operation during occultation, or the shadow period, of an orbit. Thus current designs of closed Brayton cycle (CBC) systems for the NASA Space Station are limited to those designs with turbine inlet temperatures in the range of 977K (1300F) to 1033K (1400F). This paper addresses the potential for achieving these advanced goals by operation at higher temperatures utilizing advanced materials currently under development as well as those which hold promise for application to solar dynamic systems. These include new metal alloys and ceramic and composite materials. Advanced thermal-storage materials will also be addressed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SPACE RESEARCH; ADVANCED MATERIALS; CLOSED BRAYTON CYCLE SYSTEM; SOLAR RECEIVERS; SPACE POWER SYSTEMS; TOTAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Cui-Rong-Qiang, Yang Jin-Huan, Ye Ying-Qing, Wu Shui-Cheng, Fang Kai-Nian, Kang Wen-Hua, Du Chun-Hua, Wei Shu-Jun
Title: NEW AUTOMATIC TRACKING PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China
Authors with affiliations: Cui-Rong-Qiang, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Yang Jin-Huan, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Ye Ying-Qing, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Wu Shui-Cheng, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Fang Kai-Nian, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Kang Wen-Hua, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Du Chun-Hua, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China; Wei Shu-Jun, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China, Xi'an Jiaotong Univ, Xi'an, China
Abstract: In this paper, a new automatic photovoltaic system is described. It consists of one time-controlled electromagnet-driving single-axis rotating two-axis tracking system, one 100 watts solar cell array, 30V 300AH silicongel lead storage battery, and load of several 8W fluorescent lamps, one television set and one recorder. We describe the detail structure of the system, analyse the tracking accuracy, and introduce the actual performance of the system installed at Ye'an, Shaanshi, China.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; AUTOMATIC TRACKING; PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: DESIGNING PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Photovoltaic system design understanding has matured rapidly in the last decade. Initially the design process emphasized detailed modeling, load match, and on-site energy storage. This entire approach ended once the systems were allowed to operate interactively with the utility. Current design thinking emphasizes system energy cost in relation to utility avoided cost. This leads to a new logic that allows for much simplified design procedures. This paper reviews these procedures for the two types of grid-connected photovoltaic systems and presents a brief discussion of balance-of-system options.
Index Keywords: SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; GRID CONNECTED; LOAD MATCH; PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Title: NEW VOLTAGE REGULATION AND LOAD MANAGEMENT ALGORITHM FOR STAND-ALONE PV (SAPV) POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Groumpos, P.P., Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH,, USA, Cleveland State Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The various subsystems of a Stand-Alone PV (SAPV) Power System are briefly described. Its most important control functions are defined. The Voltage Regulation control function is described extensively and a new algorithm is developed. The efficient and reliable operation of a SAPV depends on Load Management strategies. A new Load Management Algorithm is developed, based on the number of load priorities and the State-of-Charge (SOC) of the energy storage system. Illustrative flow diagrams suitable for computer program development are provided. A number of challenging research topics are briefly discussed.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; LOAD MANAGEMENT; STAND ALONE PV POWER SYSTEMS; VOLTAGE REGULATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: This paper provides a general, but by no means exhaustive, overview of the near-term goals and objectives of the DOE's Solar Buildings Technology Program. It begins with some background information on progress to date and then reviews the general directions the Program is pursuing to improve solar energy's contribution to heating, cooling and lighting the nation's buildings.

Title: PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT OF AN INTEGRATED SOLAR ENERGY COMPLEX.
Affiliations: Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Al-Kandari, A., Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait; Al-Marafi, A.A., Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait; Suri, R.K., Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait; Maheshwari, G.P., Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Safat, Kuwait
Abstract: An integrated solar thermal complex was installed jointly by the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, Kuwait, and the Messerschmitt-Bolkow Blohm GmbH (MBB) of West Germany in a desert area (Sulaibiya) in phases from 1978 to 1985. It forms the basis of a food/water/power establishment in the desert area. The system can generate 100 kW of electrical power during the sunshine period and can dissipate nearly 500 kW of thermal power at a temperature of about 100 degree C, which is suitable for absorption cooling or as thermal energy input for a multistage flash (MSF) water desalination system.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COLLECTOR FIELD; INTEGRATED SOLAR ENERGY COMPLEX; SOLAR THERMAL COMPLEX; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: WHITE CLIFFS SOLAR THERMAL ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Australian Natl Univ, Canberra, Aust, Australian Natl Univ, Canberra, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Kaneff, S., Australian Natl Univ, Canberra, Aust, Australian Natl Univ, Canberra, Aust
Abstract: White Cliffs I is a 14 paraboloidal dish solar thermal electric system employing a high performance uniflow steam engine, driving an alternator and operating with battery storage as a stand alone system (with diesel back up) supplying the township of White Cliffs - running automatically and unattended, with maintenance provided by local inhabitants. The station was completed in December 1981, run for nearly 2 years on 'dummy' load, then connected to the township in November 1983; since that time operation has been continuous and reliable. This paper analyses performance and operation since November 1983 and evaluates the system economically and technologically.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; STEAM ENGINES; PARABOLOIDAL DISH COLLECTORS; SOLAR THERMAL POWER SYSTEMS; WHITE CLIFFS PROJECT; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Lof G.O.G., Cler G., Brisbane T.
Title: PERFORMANCE OF A SOLAR DESICCANT COOLING SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lof, G.O.G., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Cler, G., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Brisbane, T., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Abstract: A solar desiccant cooling system was operated at the Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, throughout the 1986 summer. The system comprises an American Solar King fresh air heating/desiccant evaporative cooling unit, a Sunmaster evacuated tube solar collector, hot water solar storage tank, auxiliary electric boiler, controls and accessories. The cooling unit is operated in the ventilation mode, fresh air being dried in a rotating desiccant matrix, and cooled by heat exchange and evaporative cooling. Return air is used as a cooling medium in a rotating heat exchange matrix, heated by solar energy in a heat exchange coil, and discharged through the rotating desiccant bed.
Index Keywords: DRYING; HEATING - Solar; MOISTURE CONTROL; SOLAR ENERGY; EVAPORATIVE COOLING; ROTATING DESICCANT MATRIX; SOLAR DESICCANT COOLING SYSTEM; ATMOSPHERIC HUMIDITY

Title: SOLAR DEHUMIDIFICATION SYSTEM APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Gershon Meckler Associates, New, York, NY, USA, Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, G., Gershon Meckler Associates, New, York, NY, USA, Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: The first commercial/institutional applications of desiccant dehumidification with solar regeneration are described, a nursing home/clinic facility and a courthouse with attached new county office building. Both systems, designed by the author, integrate solar energy, cogenerated heat, and off-peak utility energy in a selective-energy system that provides heat for desiccant regeneration. The systems described separate dehumidification from sensible cooling, dehumidify with a moisture-absorbing desiccant, and use heat from the solar system directly or via thermal storage tanks to dry the desiccant for re-use. Backup energy for regeneration on cloudy days is provided by cogeneration and off-peak electric utility energy (night electric resistance heating at off-peak rates).
Index Keywords: DRYING; EVAPORATION; MOISTURE CONTROL; SOLAR ENERGY; DESICCANTS; SOLAR COOLING; SOLAR DEHUMIDIFICATION; ATMOSPHERIC HUMIDITY

Title: LOW-COST SOLAR WATER HEATING FOR COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS USING UNGLAZED COLLECTORS.
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spain, T.K., Univ of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL, USA; Guinn, G.R., Univ of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: The Alabama Solar Energy Center has studied the use of unglazed EPDM collector absorbers for application to commercial service and industrial process water heating. A system design concept has been proposed which eliminates the need for a collector-to-storage heat exchanger and allows use of unpressurized storage tanks. Performance and life cycle cost analyses for a range of climates show that the system provides attractive rates-of-return when compared to conventional glazed selective-surface flat plate absorbers. Three test systems utilizing the unglazed collectors have been installed by the Center; annual performance data for one system is presented.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Climate Control; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; LOW COST SOLAR WATER HEATING; UNGLAZED COLLECTORS; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Bleem J., Burns P., Winn C.B.
Title: NIGHT VENTILATION STRATEGIES IN DRY CLIMATES.
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bleem, J., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Burns, P., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA; Winn, C.B., Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins,, CO, USA, Colorado State Univ, Fort Collins, CO, USA
Abstract: Night Ventilation, the use of outside air to cool the mass of a building at night, has been shown to reduce both auxiliary cooling energy usage and maximum cooling loads for buildings with significant 'available mass'. 'Available mass' is defined as building mass which can be cooled at night, primarily by the effects of night ventilation, and which then absorbs heat from the conditioned space during the day. Energy and demand savings are realized due to the cooling storage effects of the mass. The present work involves determination of cost savings based on results from an analytical modelling process.
Index Keywords: METEOROLOGY; SOLAR ENERGY; AVAILABLE MASS; DRY CLIMATES; NIGHT VENTILATION; BUILDINGS

Authors: Huang H.H., Shyu R.J., Fang L.J.
Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF SOLAR THERMOSYPHON HOT WATER SYSTEMS WITH HORIZONTAL STORAGE TANK.
Affiliations: Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, H.H., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Shyu, R.J., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Fang, L.J., Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan, Industrial Technology Research Inst, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: The thermal characteristics in the horizontal tanks with and without internal baffles of thermosyphon solar water heaters were studied experimentally. In this study, tests were conducted on two thermosyphon systems with similar collector but different storage tanks subjected to actual weather conditions in Hsinchu, Taiwan. The experimental results showed that the temperature distribution inside the storage tank without baffle is quite different from that of the tank with baffles. It is also found that the storage tank with baffles is superior to the tank without baffle in discharging hot water.

Title: Thermal energy store for a heat-pumped, domestic, central-heating system
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 OAL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Buick, T.R., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 OAL, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Bedford, MK43 OAL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A computer model describing the effect of the presence of thermal energy storage upon the performance of a conventional heat-pumped domestic central-heating system was developed. To validate this model and to discover what problems would exist in a real system, an experimental test rig was built: it incorporated a phase-change material heat store in the heat-load circuit of a heat-pumped heating system. The performance of each component of the system was determined, and the overall performance of the system compared with that predicted by the computer model. The improvements in the performance of the heating system as a result of this investigation included: higher heat output potential; less frequent on/off cycling; and reduced running costs. © 1987.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEAT-PUMPED DOMESTIC CENTRAL HEATING; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Abstract: A survey of stratified thermal storage tank models available in the literature has been conducted. Several one-dimensional models were tested and compared against the experimental data obtained at our laboratories. Although various factors affecting the performance of a stratified tank can be accounted for by the higher order models, i. e. two- and three-dimensional models, the introduction of empirically based mixing parameters into the one-dimensional models renders them widely applicable and practical in the simulation of energy systems incorporating thermal storage tanks.

Authors: Brant-Zawadzki M., Weinstein P., Bartkowski H., Moseley M.
Title: MR imaging and spectroscopy in clinical and experimental cerebral ischemia: A review
Affiliations: Department of Radiology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94143, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brant-Zawadzki, M., Department of Radiology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94143, United States; Weinstein, P., Department of Radiology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94143, United States; Bartkowski, H., Department of Radiology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94143, United States; Moseley, M., Department of Radiology, University of California, San Francisco, CA 94143, United States
Abstract: The superior sensitivity of MR imaging to changes in brain water caused by various insults is well established. Because detectable alteration of brainwater content may start within the first hours after an ischemic insult, MR imaging promises to be a unique tool in the experimental and clinical approach to cerebral infarction. MR spectroscopy offers a noninvasive method for observing the fundamental metabolic processes of cell function. Phosphorus-31 (P-31) MR spectroscopy can elucidate the accumulation and depletion of molecules that act as the energy storage substrates of the cell and their breakdown products. The pH within the tissue of interest can be calculated. Hydrogen MR spectroscopy can detect lactate accumulation when ischemia forces a shift from aerobic to anaerobic glycolysis. More sophisticated metabolic pathways are also accessible to MR spectroscopy. Because MR imaging and MR spectroscopy can be done with the same instrument in a single experimental model or in a human patient, MR offers a unique methodology for investigating acute (potentially reversible) ischemia, its evolution, and the effect of various therapeutic interventions on its prognosis. The purpose of this review is to summarize the initial experience with MR imaging in the clinical setting of cerebral ischemia and to introduce the reader to the potential future application of combined MR imaging/spectroscopy in this disease process by discussing clinically relevant experimental models. A brief overview of the basic principles of MR spectroscopy is included. A broad understanding of the pathophysiology of ischemia is vital to the task at hand and is a good starting point for subsequent discussion.
Index Keywords: angiography; brain ischemia; cardiovascular system; central nervous system; computer analysis; computer assisted tomography; diagnosis; dog; etiology; human; nuclear magnetic resonance; priority journal; proton nuclear magnetic resonance; spectrometry; survey

Title: Automated gunshot residue particle search and characterization
Affiliations: Georgia Bureau of Investigation, Division of Forensic Sciences, Decatur, GA 30034, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tillman, W.L., Georgia Bureau of Investigation, Division of Forensic Sciences, Decatur, GA 30034, United States
Abstract: The main disadvantage to gunshot residue (GSR) particle analysis utilizing scanning electron microscope/energy dispersive X-ray (SEM/EDX) instrumentation has been the excessive operator time required for search and identification. This study uses an automated particle search and characterization program for unattended GSR search and identification. This system allows for automatic matrix search, particle sizing, chemical typing, and spectral aquisition with subsequent storage of data to disk for later operator review and verification. This work describes various aspects of the program, determines appropriate parameters adequate for both unique and characteristic GSR particle identification, and evaluates the reliability of data obtained. Samples are collected via the tape lift method from test-firings of .38, .32, .25, and .22 caliber handguns at time after firing intervals of 0 to 6 h. Unique GSR particles are consistently and correctly identified by this method on tape lift samples taken up to 4 h after firing. False positive results of unique GSR particles are not encountered on control handblank samples. This technique appears to provide the forensic science community with an operator-free method of reliable GSR particle search and an improved analyst-time-per-case ratio.
Index Keywords: gunpowder; electron microscopy; gunshot injury; identification; methodology; nonhuman; preliminary communication; priority journal; scanning electron microscopy

Title: Glycogen, a cytoplasmic reserve polysaccharide of Cellulomonas sp. (DSM20108): its identification, carbon source-dependent accumulation, and degradation during starvation
Affiliations: Institut für Biotechnologie 1, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich GmbII., Jülich, F.R.G.
Authors with affiliations: Schimz, K.-L., Institut für Biotechnologie 1, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich GmbII., Jülich, F.R.G.; Overhoff, B., Institut für Biotechnologie 1, Kernforschungsanlage Jülich GmbII., Jülich, F.R.G.
Abstract: During batch cultivation on complete medium or mineral salts medium with different carbon sources, Cellulomonas accumulates glycogen. The intracellular concentration of glycogen increases with increasing C/N ratio and reaches a maximum value of about 0.22 mg per mg dry weight. Under conditions of carbon starvation this polymer is degraded. Furthermore, Cellulomonas grows well on glycogen if administered as sole source of carbon and energy. The results show that glycogen is an additional energy and carbon storage compound in Cellulomonas sp. which also accumulates trehalose. © 1987.
Author Keywords: (Accumulation; Cellulomonas sp.; Degradation); Glycogen

Title: ON THE CONTROL AND STABILITY OF GRID CONNECTED PHOTOVOLTAIC SOURCES.
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece, Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Kalaitzakis, K.C., Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece, Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece; Vachtsevanos, G.J., Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece, Technical Univ of Crete, Chania, Greece
Abstract: A methodology is proposed for the effective integration of photovoltaic (PV) devices into the electric utility distribution network operations. The dispersed PV generator is viewed as an active device used to improve system stability by appropriately modulating the power conditioning unit's output power. Disturbances on the utility system can be damped out by injecting this power into the grid in such a way so that the net effect is a cancellation of undesirable oscillations. The approach is implemented by monitoring the oscillating power and generating control signals which shape accordingly the interface unit's output power. Successful implementation of the scheme relies heavily on the speed and flexibility with which the electronic inverter moves power from the primary source/storage facility to the utility lines. Simulation studies, using the proposed control approach, indicate that application of these policies may result in reduced load following requirements for conventional power generating units, increase the value and acceptability of new energy technologies, and improve power quality and stability of the interconnected system.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Control; DISPERSED PV GENERATOR; DISTRIBUTION NETWORK; ELECTRONIC INVERTER; GRID CONNECTED PHOTOVOLTAIC SOURCES; POWER CONDITIONING; UNDESIRABLE OSCILLATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Authors: Weaver H.T., Axness C.L., Fu J.S., Binkley J.S., Mansfield J.
Title: RAM Cell Recovery Mechanisms Following High-Energy Ion Strikes
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Division 2147, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Division 8233, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, H.T., Sandia National Laboratories, Division 2147, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Axness, C.L., Sandia National Laboratories, Division 2147, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Fu, J.S., Sandia National Laboratories, Division 2147, Albuquerque, NM 87185, United States; Binkley, J.S., Sandia National Laboratories, Division 8233, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Mansfield, J., Sandia National Laboratories, Division 8233, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: Recovery times for a RAM cell following a high-energy ion strike are calculated using simulation techniques in which transport and circuit behavior are modeled simultaneously. The recovery time, typically several nanoseconds for a 140-MeV Kr strike, is intermediate to analytical results for funneling and diffusion. For such large strikes, the primary factor determining recovery is modulation of the photocollection by loading at the struck node, not intrinsic funneling characteristics, as is expected for smaller alpha particle strikes. The recovery is fundamentally linked to the cell configuration and cannot be accurately modeled using calculations representative of the individual cell elements. Title: CWT'S test fields.
Authors with affiliations: Watson, G.R.
Abstract: Discusses the technical designs possible in a hybrid wind/Diesel system, noting the role of storage. The three basic systems are; interruptable load with store; continuous load with store; continuous load, no store, and a fourth system is an interruptible load with no electrical store (e.g. electrical submersible pump). Title: HEAT TRANSFER RESEARCH FOR HIGH TEMPERATURE SOLAR THERMAL ENERGY SYSTEMS.

Authors with affiliations: Wang, K.Y., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Kreith, F., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: The possibility of using high-temperature solar energy for industrial processes has prompted research in this area. In this paper, we present some recent developments in high-temperature solar thermal energy systems that have received particular attention: a liquid film, direct-absorption central receiver, high-temperature sensible heat storage, and direct-contact heating of small particles or droplets. Technical problems that warrant further research work are also identified.

Title: Refrigeration throughout the world
Affiliations: Institutt for Kuldeteknikk, Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Lorentzen, G., Institutt for Kuldeteknikk, Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: The economic impact of refrigeration technology throughout the world is already very impressive, and more significant than is generally believed. While the yearly investment in machinery and equipment may approach US$100 billion, the value of products treated by refrigeration is perhaps ten times this amount. The importance of refrigeration is bound to increase since it will be an essential factor in solving two major problems of the future: the supply of enough food and the development of new energy sources. The use of low temperatures constitutes a major means of conservation of perishable foods during storage and distribution and it is widely applied in the developed countries. In the Third World, however, the use of low temperatures is mainly limited to food for export and the needs of the 'well-to-do' sector of the population. Refrigerated or frozen foods, in their present form, are generally priced too high for the undernourished poor. There is a pressing need for simple and inexpensive cooling methods to enable efficient low cost mass production and distribution under more primitive conditions. The future of man, and his food supply in particular, depends on the availability of sufficient energy. At present, fossil fuels carry the main load, but in the course of the next century new energy sources, such as nuclear fusion, will have to be commissioned. Refrigeration technology will play an important part in this development. © 1987.
Author Keywords: economics; refrigeration; review
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT; FOOD PRODUCTS - Refrigeration; ENERGY NEEDS; ENERGY SUPPLY; FOOD NEEDS; POPULATION EXPLOSION; REFRIGERATION

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF THE ZINC CHLORIDE BATTERY FOR UTILITY APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The zinc chloride battery is the first advanced storage battery system to be evaluated using full-scale modules. Tests of 10-kw modules in a 100-kw system and of a 125-kw module in a 2-mw system resulted in substantial improvements in system integration, control, operation, and maintenance. Using results from the BEST Facility test of the 100-kw battery, the investigators developed a new simplified design for a 2-mw, 6-mwh commercial battery system, called FLEXPOWER, composed of sixteen 125-kw modules coupled to a single chlorine hydrate store. In the final year of the project, EDA fabricated and tested one of the 125-kw modules.
